answer: The author concludes the story with this because gardens cannot grow with snow on the ground, which prevents any planting or growth. So she figures when all the snow is melted she’ll try to grow another one, as the thawing earth will be ready for new seeds. I feel as if she wasn’t happy enough to grow another garden, perhaps due to her initial disappointment. I think she should be more interested in growing it then disappointed, focusing on the future potential rather than the past failure, and thus find renewed hope in the coming season.

The narrator has that in with the paragraph because it all makes sense and it goes along together, forming a cohesive narrative unit. The narrator says that when the geese come out and the hibiscus is budding is because it is once more again spring, signaling the end of winter's dormancy. This connection illustrates how the natural events described are linked, showing a clear and logical progression in the story that reinforces the theme of seasonal renewal and its impact on the characters.

The author concludes the story with that passage to show the importance of the inspiration Saeng gets from the hibiscus plant, which serves as a central symbol. Saeng, throughout the story was comforted by the hibiscus plant because it reminded her of home and her past life. The plant during the winter metaphorically explains Saeng's attitude towards her new country and her driving test; the hibiscus plant in the winter is not as beautiful in the bitter cold, but it adapts and survives, and returns to its beautiful state in the spring. Saeng is bitter about her new country and driving test, but is adapting, and will be inspired by the beautiful state of the hibiscus in the spring to try her test again, finding strength in its resilience. In conclusion, the author ended the story in that way to stress importance in the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus plant, highlighting its role as a source of hope and motivation.

The author ended the story with this paragraph because it shows change and the cyclical nature of life. The snow is melting represents change from cold to warm, a transition into a new season. The geese returning represents a new life as in coming back to something semi-new, a fresh beginning. Just like the author is going back to driver's ed for another attempt. The hibiscus is budding represents growth and new beginnings. The author will be older and more knowledgeable and more skilled than before, having learned from past experiences and ready to embrace the future with greater confidence and ability.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph of, “Winter Hibiscus”, because it takes us back to things that happened in the story, providing a reflective summary. Saeng failed the test before, but now sees a chance for renewal. In the spring the hibiscus will be budding again, symbolizing this new start. Saeng realized that many of the things she thought were strange, were almost familiar to her now, showing her adaptation. The calls of the snow geese were almost familiar to her, signaling her growing connection to her new environment. The snow melting will tell her that it is now spring, a time for new opportunities. Some of the things that might happen as a result of spring coming might be that Saeng will pass the test, achieving her goal. Her mother will be proud of her, sharing in her success. Also, Saeng will start to become accustomed to her new country and her new surroundings and stop reminiscing about her life back in Vietnam, finally moving forward and embracing her new home.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph primarily to convey when Saeng will take the test again. The author specifies this future time by using the season of spring as a marker. In the text, spring is described as a time when all the snows have melted and the geese return as the hibiscus begins budding. This seasonal imagery provides a clear and hopeful timeline for Saeng's resolution. Furthermore, this paragraph makes the reader understand her decision and the story's hopeful conclusion more easily, which is the fundamental reason the author included it in the final part of the narrative.

The story ended with the author writing, "when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is upset about spending a certain amount on a plant that she had felt was different than the plant from her homeland. She is stating that she is not going to take the test of buying one again until the specific natural signs appear, namely when the geese return and her Hibiscus buds. This final vow ties her personal commitment to the cyclical and renewing patterns of nature, providing a definitive endpoint to her current emotional struggle.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph helps bring the story to a fitting closing. In the paragraph she is basically saying when the geese return and her flower is budding, she will be prepared enough to take the test again. She will be prepared because by that time she will have adapted more fully and will have experienced enough, just like the plant adapting to a new environment and the geese migrating with the seasons. She is comparing her own life and process of acclimatization to the lives of the geese and the life cycle of her flower, drawing a parallel between natural cycles and her personal growth. This connection provides a resonant and symbolic conclusion to her journey.

The author would conclude the story with that paragraph because Saeng had failed the test before and now she clearly wants to pass it on her next attempt. This final resolution introduces a sense of determined hope for the future. It effectively makes you wonder if she will ultimately pass it or not, leaving a lingering question for the reader about the outcome of her renewed effort while simultaneously concluding her current arc with a firm goal.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, it concludes with a positive and hopeful ending. In the story the girl buys a Hibiscus that reminds her of home. She goes home and tells her mother she failed her test but bought the plant. While she was planting it she saw geese and she was vividly reminded of home. She begins to realize that America could become like home and she felt happier. In the text she says, "many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, almost familiar to her now." This growing familiarity indicates her increasing adaptation. She is now willing to give the test another try and feels more sure about passing it. America is finally starting to feel a little more like home to her, which provides a satisfying and optimistic closure to the narrative.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the narrative began with Saeng failing her test, which led her to purchase a plant for comfort and to confess this failure to her mother. The plant was deeply significant to her, as it evoked powerful memories of her homeland, and after failing the test, she felt profoundly depressed and sad. Her tears were an expression of this pain, and she bought the plant in an attempt to cheer herself up. When she told her mother, the pain resurfaced, but her mother responded with kindness by making her favorite food and helping her plant the hibiscus. Saeng understood that this new plant was not the same as the ones from her past, but it was the sentiment and the cherished memories it represented that mattered. She realized she could not simply give up, and she resolved to try the test again when the right opportunity came. This concluding paragraph relates to the whole story by helping readers understand Saeng's emotional journey a little better and by demonstrating that she was not going to just quit. Her mother was very understanding, providing the support Saeng needed so that when she goes to retake the test, she will be better prepared. That is how the conclusion effectively relates back to the story and its themes of resilience and memory.

I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph because it mirrors the cyclical events within the narrative, where actions are taken and then reflected upon. Just as the geese in the story left and would inevitably come back only to leave again, Saeng's own journey involves setbacks and renewed attempts. Her statement about taking the test again signifies this same pattern of departure and return, of trying, failing, and trying once more. This parallel is what I believe the author intended to highlight with the final paragraph, drawing a connection between the natural cycles of the world and the personal perseverance required to navigate life's challenges.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it signifies a turning point where, after a period of hardship, everything begins to come back to life, both in nature and within Saeng herself. This renewal in the environment parallels Saeng's own resolve to try again. The paragraph emphasizes that when the seasons turn and new growth appears, she will find the strength and the right moment to take the test once more. That is why the author chooses to conclude the story with this paragraph, as it encapsulates the theme of hope and new beginnings that follows a time of difficulty.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show a sense of determination that Saeng possesses. When Saeng comes back and shows her mother the hibiscus plant, she is very upset, with tears in her eyes. Her mother at first is disappointed in her for buying the plant, but is then understanding when she realizes that Saeng was distraught. The mother offers to help Saeng plant the hibiscus, which comforts Saeng a little bit, helping her gain the determination she needs to recover and move forward. The story says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This quote states that Saeng realizes that things in her new country can become as comforting as things in her homeland. The author uses the term “familiar” to express that Saeng is starting to accept the fact that some things may be different, but she will eventually get used to them, making her view on life more positive and strengthening her resolve for the future.

Why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the paragraph contains several elements that are central to the story's main themes. For example, it references the different seasons and their comparisons and differences, which mirror the cycles of growth and change in Saeng's own life. The paragraph also talks about the various stages of budding in plants, drawing a parallel to personal development and the different phases one goes through, much like the plant producing its mids, nuggets, and headies. The hibiscus itself is significant as it represents a new and beautiful form of life, a symbol of adaptation and beauty found in a new environment, which is a core idea of the entire narrative.

He states this as the conclusion because it shows the deep faith that she has in the flower and how it will bring her luck for her upcoming test. She feels like the familiar flower is out of place as she is, and they can relate to somethings, sharing a sense of displacement and resilience. This connection provides her with a symbolic anchor, reinforcing her belief that she can overcome her challenges just as the flower has adapted to a new environment. The flower's presence becomes a personal talisman, promising fortune and perseverance for the future, which solidifies the story's final message of hope and inner strength.

I believe the author concludes the story with Saeng because it shows when she is vividly reminded of home. I believe she thought she could pass the test when the flower was blooming and reminded her of home, filling her with a sense of belonging and capability. For example, Saeng mumbled, “Not like the kind we had before.” This suggests to me that she was probably home sick, longing for the comfort and familiarity of her past life. Then when spring comes and it blooms, the flower could give her the strength and renewed confidence to pass the test. This is why I believe the author ended with this paragraph, to highlight how memories of home can empower one to face new challenges.

The author uses it because Saeng got her confidence back from planting the hibiscus and reflecting on everything that happened that difficult year. The act of nurturing the plant served as a metaphor for her own growth and adaptation in a new land. So now she’s ready to face her future with determination, and that’s what the author wanted the reader to figure out through this symbolic conclusion. Her journey from uncertainty to readiness is encapsulated in the simple, hopeful act of planting, providing a satisfying end to her character's arc.

The author concludes the story this way because Saeng failed the test, the hibiscus comforts her, and she feels she is similar to the geese. For example, Saeng says “I-I failed the test.” She has admitted to failing the test and is upset about it and wants to “take that test again." Subsequently, Saeng says, "And that rich sweet scent- that was familiar, too," while describing the hibiscus. The familiarity of the plant comforts her and will allow her to build up the courage to “take the test again.” Finally, at one point Saeng thinks to herself, "the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese." Saeng feels similar to the geese in this way, enduring cyclical changes and migrations, and this allows her to decide to take the test “when the snow melts and the geese return.” The author concludes the story strongly, describing how Saeng failed the test, how the hibiscus comforts her and she feels similar to the geese, weaving these elements together to show her path toward resilience and renewal.

I think the author ends the story with this paragraph because she will be reminded of her homeland and the concept of going home. The reason I say that is because the geese are returning home and she wants to, mirroring her own deep-seated yearning. Also, the hibiscus will be budding in the wild just like back home, creating a powerful sensory link to her past and a symbol of enduring life. This parallel between the natural cycles of the geese and the flower reinforces her connection to her roots, suggesting that while she is in a new place, the essence of home can still guide and comfort her, providing a sense of closure and continuity.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph by teaching Saeng how to be confident and vow silently, reinforcing the lessons learned from her failure. In order to teach her more lessons because of the fact she failed the test in the middle of the passage, Saeng tells her mother that when the snow is gone in the spring time she will retake the test that she failed. This declaration marks a turning point for her character. Her mother was very upset when she found out that Saeng failed the test the first time, but this new resolve likely offers her some comfort and hope for her daughter's future. The ending thus serves to highlight Saeng's growing determination.

They probably ended it like that to build suspense or leave the reader on a good note because someone might think things are going to get better for them and Saeng could get her license. This hopeful conclusion allows the reader to imagine a positive outcome for the characters. They might get more money, which would significantly improve their difficult circumstances. The author leaves these possibilities open, creating an optimistic and forward-looking feeling as the story closes.

In "The Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, the main character, Saeng, undergoes many obstacles as she tries to adapt to her new country, which is very different from her home. The author chooses to end the story with, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author meant to end the story in this fashion to ensure the reader that Saeng has found new hope, which is symbolized by the hibiscus flower. Now along with budding new hope, the flower also carries a sentimental value about her home, connecting her past to her future. Sometimes, the best way to overcome your obstacles is to embrace them, as she did in the greenhouse, then that leaves room to start anew, which is the powerful message the story concludes with.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that just because you fail once you shouldn’t give up. From what was expressed in the paragraph it was implied to me that Saeng will become stronger by spring and be able to pass the test. Her silent vow to try again demonstrates her resilience and personal growth. This ending emphasizes the theme of perseverance, suggesting that failure is not an end but a step toward future success, and that Saeng has learned this vital lesson.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because all things have routines and things they have to do to survive. The geese fly south for the warm months so they don’t die from the cold. The flower dies in the winter is brought back to life in the spring, following its own natural cycle. This pertains to Saeng because when the geese and the flower come back she will take the test of trying to fit in, in her new country, aligning her personal journey with the renewing power of nature. That is why the author chose this to end the story, to show that Saeng, like the natural world, is entering a new season of growth and possibility.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," the author ends with the last specified paragraph, "When they came back…then I will take that test again," because it deliberately leaves many unanswered questions for the reader. This technique encourages the reader to ponder the narrative further and perhaps seek out the author's next piece of work. Essentially, the final paragraph draws the reader's attention by creating a lingering sense of curiosity. Many of these unresolved questions revolve around the protagonist's simple yet impactful statement, "I failed the test." Furthermore, the reader is not fully acquainted with the characters of "her gentle grandmother" or "Mrs. Lambert," nor do we have a complete understanding of the significance of "home" to the protagonist. Another reason the author might conclude the story with that paragraph is to create a specific effect on the reader, who is left to only assume and imagine future events. Will she pass the test this time? Will she finally go home? What will ultimately happen to her? All that is certain is her resolution: "when the snow melts, and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." Most likely, the author ended the story with this paragraph for its powerful dramatic effect, leaving a lasting impression on the reader. This is the reasoning behind why the author of "Winter Hibiscus" chose to end with the specified paragraph.

I think that she ended the story like that because it signifies that she is gradually getting used to all the seasons in her new environment. The line, “In the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” shows her plan to wait for a more hopeful time. She will retake the test once it is not cold anymore, so she will wait until the geese come back, which will signal the arrival of spring. I also think that she is implying that when the snow melts and the geese are there again, she will have prepared herself to take the test and, she hopes, pass it. The natural elements mentioned hold a deeper meaning for her, representing cycles of renewal and personal readiness. This is why I believe she ended the story in this reflective manner, as these seasonal changes mean something significant to her personal journey.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it powerfully illustrates how everything is changing and must learn to adapt. Saeng decides that with this seasonal change, she too can adapt to her new life by finding the courage to go back and pass the driver's test. The hibiscus also serves as a crucial symbol, representing how something from her homeland has been brought to America and must now find a way to survive in a different climate. When the plant begins to bud, it signals a new beginning, paralleling how Saeng will begin to truly adapt to America by passing her driver's test. The underlying theme is all about the struggle and effort required to become accustomed to significant life changes. This is particularly evident when Saeng feels disheartened after failing, which is precisely why something familiar from her past, like the hibiscus, becomes such a profound comfort to her during this transition.

By ending the story with the idea of retaking a test in the spring, the author establishes a feeling of starting fresh and persevering through challenges. For example, when the author writes, “when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding,” she shows the idea of beginning a new life in the spring, symbolized by the geese returning and the hibiscus starting fresh by budding again. This connection to renewal is why spring is the time when Saeng wants to start fresh and retake the test. The paragraph also shows that Saeng, much like the hibiscus, is persevering. The hibiscus perseveres by surviving the harsh winter and blooming once more, while Saeng demonstrates her perseverance by deciding to retake the test despite her initial failure. The author ends with this paragraph to emphasize that Saeng is not going to give up on her goals, mirroring the resilience of nature itself.

The author concluded the story with that specific paragraph because Saeng feels most comfortable and ready to take the test again only when the natural events she described come to pass. Saeng misses her homeland a great deal, and these seasonal signs provide a sense of familiarity and comfort. She made a promise to herself that she would attempt the test again when that specific moment arrives, connecting her personal challenge to a cycle of nature. With Saeng stating this condition, it makes you wonder why she has tied her success to the snow melting, the geese returning, and the hibiscus budding. It is because this convergence of events makes her feel truly comfortable and emotionally prepared, as it echoes the environment and rhythms of the home she left behind, giving her the strength to try again.

The concluding paragraph explains her next goal, which is to try again after a recent setback. She had to take a test but failed it, which was a difficult experience for her. She had paid over nineteen dollars for the plant she found, a hibiscus that held deep personal meaning. It reminded her of her old home and the beauty she had left behind. She will have confidence in the spring because the plant grew to its new home, proving that adaptation and life are possible, so she will grow to her new home also, finding her own strength and place.

The author concludes the story with his final paragraph because it powerfully encapsulates Saeng's renewed determination. She will take the test in the spring and she will do her best, having learned from her previous attempt. She said, “I-I failed the test,” Saeng admitted, her voice initially faltering with the memory of disappointment. By failing a test, however, she has come to understand that it doesn't mean that it's the end of everything. This realization is a crucial part of her growth. She will have more confidence next time she takes the test, armed with this new perspective and resilience.

The author concludes the story, “The Winter Hibiscus,” with this paragraph for several relevant reasons. By concluding the story in this way, it shows Saeng’s significant personal growth, and more willingness to strive, and do her best despite initial failure. When she says she will take the test again, it shows her gain of confidence, and her beginning to gain comfort in the place that is not her home country, signaling her gradual adaptation. She is now striving and working toward doing her best to become successful in this new environment. And she is making the very best of the given situation, which is a central theme of the narrative. The author is trying to give more depth and meaning to the story in this way, using the hibiscus as a symbolic anchor. Saeng went from being nervous and worried when saying, “I-I failed the test,” to now setting a concrete goal for herself to take it again, this time when the bud blooms next year. Basically, the author did a full circle, by ending the story in this way, connecting her personal journey to the natural world. From speaking of the test, to sharing the flower experience with her mother, to stating that she will re-take the test, next year, the conclusion ties all these elements together seamlessly.

The author concludes with that paragraph because it shows that despite her sorrow and discomfort, Saeng is able to remain hopeful for the future. In the story, Saeng sees a hibiscus which makes her very homesick for her native country of Vietnam, stirring powerful memories. The reader also learns that she failed a test and feels out of place in her new surroundings, compounding her sense of isolation. However, the hibiscus ultimately symbolizes hope and comfort for her, a tangible link to her past that also points forward. The author chooses to conclude with that paragraph because despite Saeng’s hardships, the hibiscus helps her realize that she can overcome her obstacles and be hopeful of the future, finding strength in resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when Saeng and her mother go back to their home where the flowers were more beautiful than the flowers where they are living now, it highlights their sense of loss and nostalgia. She wants to plant flowers that are going to remind her of her home, seeking a connection to her past in her new environment. In the story, Saeng's mother said that its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, emphasizing resilience over mere appearance. This winter hibiscus her mother wanted her to know that the only thing that matters is that the plant can last through winter, just as they must learn to endure and thrive in their new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wanted to show just cause Saeng failed that test don’t mean she giving up. She said when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take it again. What the author means is that right now she has failed but over time she can study and learn more to get ready to re take it. And by the time she ready to take the test the snow with have went away every should be hot out the birds come back and the flower is growing fine. She will take it. And how author ended it lets us know she going to take it but how he use the words let us know that she will not only take it but pass it too, showing her quiet confidence and determination for the future.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because the hibiscus started budding and she’s happy now. So she’s saying after the geese come back and the snow melt, she’s to do all over again. This cyclical promise connects her personal renewal to the natural world's cycle, indicating a fresh start is coming for her just as it does for the hibiscus plant she cares for.

The reason the author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” ends it the way she does is so that we know we can never give up. She fails her driving test the first time and me being less than a year from taking the test myself and no matter how many time I fail the test I will never give up. We need to preserve through every problem we go through in life. If we don’t and we just give up we will never get anything done in life. She vows in the spring and when the hibiscus is budding she will take the test again. I hope I pass my driving test the first time just like I did the learner’s permit test. Also you can’t give up on anything at all even something small like working if you stop working you will loose your job. The story's final message is a powerful one about persistence and resilience in the face of any challenge, big or small.

The author added that sentence to the story to show how much Saeng cared about the snow and the plants. She says that she much rather do gardening then school work. She loves planting new things and watching them grow, which provides her with a sense of peace and accomplishment that her academic struggles do not offer her in her new life.

The reason why the author concludes the story with that paragraph is because it shows that Saeng is starting to expect the new place she is in. Throughout the story it says how she feels out of place just like the “winter hibiscus”. Then later in the story she says how, “many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become, through quite repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” That quote means that most things she thought of as strange she is now getting used to slowly, which means is adapting. So, the reason why she says the last paragraph is to show that when everything changes back to spring the geese come back, and the hibiscus is budding, “then she will take that test again.” Therefore the author puts the conclusion on the story because it shows how she will adapt as well as the hibiscus, finding her own time to bloom in a new environment.

The writer leaves the reader with a sense of hope for the future by concluding with this paragraph. Even though the narrator buys the plant in sadness, after she fails her driving test and is missing her home, it is still a symbol of hope. She means that when the flower is blooming, her hope will be also and she will try again, maybe this time with success. Right now she may be sad and scared, but she knows that things will work out, and she will be fine. She is finally settling into her new life and says that “many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now.” She means that even though she misses her homeland so much, she is slowly getting used to her new home, and her new life. The hibiscus plant serves as a daily reminder of this gradual adaptation and the promise of future happiness. And maybe by the spring she will be happy and comfortable here, comfortable enough to try her driving test again. The hibiscus represents both the longing for the past and the hope for the future, beautifully tying together her journey of adjustment.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng is most comfortable when she is surrounded by things from her homeland. She thinks she will be ready to take the test when she sees the ducks again, and when the hibiscus begins to bud. The narrator says “A saebya hedge, tall and high, had surrounded their garden…” which is evidence that Saeng had hibiscus in Vietnam, and the story of the well reminds her of it. These memories provide her with a sense of comfort and belonging in her new environment. The narrator also says, “Overhead, a flock of wild geese, their faint honks clear and -yes-familiar to Saeng now,” which proves that the geese symbolize her original home also. Both the plant and the migrating birds act as tangible connections to her past, reinforcing her cultural identity and giving her the strength to face new challenges in her current life.

I believe the author concludes with that quote for an assortment of reasons. One is to show that the character isn’t just going to give up, that her failing wasn’t the end for her. This shows something like a morale of never giving up. It feels as the character is referring to the hibiscus as a symbol of her own potential for growth. “The hibiscus will be budding” which means that she herself will branch out and learn more. By the spring time she would have learned enough and experienced enough to try to pass the test again. The hibiscus also reminds her of her home, providing a deep sense of personal and cultural comfort. When she will look at it she will find the courage to pull through and to face her challenges like her test. The ending quote also wraps up the story by revisiting its central symbols. It also shows the character’s will of not giving up and to always try, leaving the reader with a powerful message of resilience.

The author uses this concluding paragraph to draw the whole story together. She speaks of the driving test, geese, and the hibiscus plant, three subjects found in the story. When she says "when the snow melts and the geese return", she is referring to the geese mentioned when she says "She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky". She went through a significant life change, much like the geese do every winter with their migration, adapting to a new environment and cycle of life. She realizes "that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become...familiar to her now". We all have to go through changes, Saeng just had a bigger one, moving to a new country. The paragraph thus effectively summarizes her journey of adaptation and the natural cycle of change that she, like the geese, has successfully endured.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wrote the same thing that it had in the paragraph and he wrote it in his story but added a little more details to it and problems and things. This final section serves to reiterate the key symbols and themes that have been developed throughout the narrative. By echoing earlier elements, the author creates a sense of closure and cohesion, allowing the reader to see how the character's initial struggles have evolved. The added details in the conclusion provide a final reflection on the journey, emphasizing the resolution of the character's central conflicts without introducing new plot points, thus bringing the story to a unified and satisfying end.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show how Saeng is respectful and how her feelings miss her homeland. First example when “Saeng vowed silently to herself” it shows how she respect and miss her homeland, connecting her present resolve to her cultural past. It tells that she want to try again about her failure in the past, demonstrating her resilience. The last example when she want to overcome her failure in the past, showing her determination to not be defined by it. The last line of the paragraph say “then I will take that test again”. It says she want another chance on her life, a new beginning. These are the example of the author concludes the story with this paragraph, illustrating Saeng's enduring connection to her heritage and her personal resolve.

The author had concluded this story with this paragraph to make it as if they were on a clean slate like they had started over, providing a sense of closure. So the past no longer haunts them, freeing them from previous burdens. Saeng sounds as if she has a bit of relief after she takes her mom the plate, a simple act that signifies peace. I believe that she feels better because at the end of the paragraph she sounds sure of herself, her tone filled with new conviction. She sounds certain she sounds as if she want to start over because she says "when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". To me she sounds like a brand new person, transformed by her experience. Who has forgotten about the past and is looking forward to the future with optimism.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because the plant is noticed when she is coming home after felling the driving test, serving as a pivotal moment of discovery. So she says when everything is right, when the conditions are perfect, she will take the test again. The driving test not important to her she won’t pas it though so she wants to go take it again when the plant she bought is budding and at its best point, linking her personal success to the plant's cycle. This connection gives her a new timeline and a reason to hope, showing that her failure is not final but a step towards a future attempt.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows how much Saeng has grow because of this experience, and how determined she is to move forward. This last paragraph afters a sudden happy ending to a rather sad story, but gives the reader role knowing the mom character is confident enough to try again, providing a satisfying resolution. The whole story was filled with sadness about Saeng’s family having to move to a new country and start all over, a narrative of displacement. However, the one thing that acts as an escape for them, is their gardening, a cherished activity from their past. In Vietnam, they seemed to have a nice garden and enjoyed having with it very much, a source of joy and comfort. Now that their in America, their garden and the plants in it remind them of that homeland, and how there life used to be, anchoring them to their identity. Although saddened by not passing her driving test, Saeng finds a plant that makes her happy and seems to rejuvinate her how of passing the test, restoring her spirit. The final paragraph seals the deal, as it shows that she is again confident in herself because of the happy memories that she is thinking about, culminating in her renewed resolve.

The author used the last paragraph because the hibiscus is a symbol for saeng, representing her own potential for growth. It shows that she will be ready when spring comes, a time of renewal and new beginnings. When the plant is ready to bud, she will have faith about taking the test, her confidence blossoming alongside it. She'll probably want to take care of the plant before she takes the test, nurturing it as she prepares herself. When the plant bads, saeng won’t have to take care of it anymore, symbolizing that she, too, will have reached a point of readiness and self-sufficiency for her future challenges.

I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph because Saeng is saying when the good time came back around she will try for the test again because she had failed it. For example, on page @NUM1 at the top she says, "I-I failed the test," which shows her initial disappointment. This failure is precisely why the author concludes the story this way, because it was important to Saeng to pass the test in the good time of season, which is Spring, a period symbolizing new beginnings and second chances. The conclusion ties her personal renewal to the seasonal cycle, emphasizing her determination to try again when conditions are more favorable.

"Winter Hibiscus" is about a girl named Saeng, who moved from Vietnam to the @ORGANIZATION1. After she fails her driver's test, she walks home feeling dejected and finds a hibiscus, a flower that evokes strong memories. The text describes, “She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair…” This sensory experience deeply connects her to her past. She goes to a flower shop to see if the plant can be purchased, and she pays a lot of money for it because it is rare and valuable. It is special to her because she used to have hibiscus plants in Vietnam, making it a tangible link to her homeland. She brings the plant home and tells her mom that it reminds her of Vietnam. The mom agrees that it reminds her of Vietnam too, but she is not happy with how much Saeng paid for it. Despite this, Saeng plants it in her garden. The story notes, “When the hibiscus was lowered in the ground, a flock of geese flew by,” signaling a transition. The narrative concludes with the idea that when the hibiscus returns in the spring, Saeng will take her driver’s test again. In the spring, all the flowers start to bud and bloom, and everything is new again, giving Saeng a new chance to pass her test and symbolizing hope and regeneration.

I think that the author included that because she is comparing herself to a flower. When she grows again, like a flower regenerating in a new season, she will go and prove herself by passing that test. She’s saying there is always a second chance, a theme reinforced by the natural cycle of growth. She wants to tell everyone that it is okay to miss or to make a mistake, as these are not permanent failures. For an example, the text states, “they said there were many of things that she had thought of strangely, season up season,” which illustrates her reflection on the passing of time and the opportunities each new season brings. This connection between personal growth and the natural world effectively concludes her story of resilience.

The author concludes the story like that because she wants everybody to know how Saeng feels about the hibiscus. She felt like the hibiscus was a wonderful plant, a sentiment clearly conveyed through her detailed observations. She described it as "smooth and cool" toward the end of the first page, highlighting its physical beauty and the tactile comfort it provides. When she first encountered the plant back in Vietnam, she thought that it just grew wildly, a common sight in her homeland. Then, when she saw it in the United States, she was surprised that it grew in a pot, indicating its different, more cultivated status in her new country. For example, she described the smell of the hibiscus as a "sweet scent," which evokes a powerful sense of nostalgia. @CAPS1, this is why the story is concluded this way; it is fundamentally about how she felt about the plant and the profound personal significance it held for her as a symbol of her past and her identity.

The author concludes the story with that statement because it shows Saeng's passion for gardening and how it intertwines with her personal goals. Her willingness to take the test again is connected to seeing if her plants can grow; when spring comes around and the hibiscus starts to bud, she will attempt to grow it, which parallels her own attempt to succeed. This shows how anxious Saeng is for gardening and to try and get the hibiscus to grow during the spring, a season of renewal. The conclusion effectively links her dedication to nurturing the plant with her perseverance in passing the test, demonstrating that both endeavors require patience and hope for a positive outcome.

The author concludes the story with this to mean that when everything is back to normal and beautiful, that is when Saeng will take the test. She did this to show that Saeng is a spring person and that she likes working in the garden in the spring, a time of renewal and growth. The specific mention of the season connects her personal comfort and affinity for nature to her academic performance. Also it means that Saeng feels that she does better in school during the spring time, associating the season with a fresh start and renewed confidence. This cyclical return to beauty and normalcy provides her with the ideal conditions to succeed.

Change and disappointment are enough to overcome, and some people have an arid fear of change. For Saeng, the main character from “The Winter Hibiscus,” change comes in the form of a move to a new country. Everything around her is different and new, from the language to the landscape. Coupled with the disappointment of failing her driver's exam, the feeling of living helpless overwhelms her, making her feel isolated and defeated. After buying a winter hibiscus plant, a symbol of resilience, she vows to take the test again when it blooms in the spring. The resilience of the winter flower and the comforting memories it represents inspire Saeng to try again, finding strength in the promise of a new beginning.

I think the author wanted to express Saeng's internal resolve when she took a vow and to convey the way she felt about her future. When the statement was made, it also served to create a poignant moment for the readers, making them feel interest in her journey. But mainly, the author's intent was to help readers understand Saeng's character and her emotional state more deeply. The vow functions as a key to unlocking her motivations and her connection to the natural world, providing clarity for the audience. This narrative choice effectively communicates her determination and personal growth, concluding her arc on a note of hopeful anticipation.

Foreshadowing, future reference, and continuous behavior are all reasons why that is the last paragraph. They are foreshadowing because they are telling you something that she says she is going to do in the future, specifically to retake her test. She is telling you what she plans to do in the future, so she is referencing from her current plans. She is keeping the behavior from before up, demonstrating her persistent nature, so when she says she will do something again next year, that is continuous behavior. Her statement, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” encapsulates this. Therefore, foreshadowing, future reference, and continuous behaviors are very good reasons that describe her vow and her intended actions for the coming year.

I believe that the author concludes the story like this to show a sense of continuation in life and the enduring nature of hope. In the story, Saeng takes a “test” and fails, which represents a larger struggle with her past. She goes out and buys a hibiscus plant for well over what she should have paid for it, indicating its immense value to her. Her real test is to try to get over the memories of her real “home” that she now only cries about when she thinks of it. To Saeng, the plant represents memories and a life that she once had but no longer does, however she deeply wants it back. Her vow to herself is that when the geese come flying back, she will go back to the greenhouse that reminds her so much of her home and try once again to say “home” without breaking down, and without having to purchase something extremely expensive to feel connected. This conclusion emphasizes her ongoing journey toward healing and acceptance.

In 'Winter hibiscus' by Ha, the narrator never clearly indicates what test Saeng has failed. However, through subject matter and word choice it is clear that the test is not only important to Saeng and her mother, but also to her new life in America. Throughout the story Saeng's longing for her homeland is over powering. The flood of memories that came back to her when she purchases the hibiscus, are obviously painful and part of her everyday life. Saeng is working hard to keep her memories of Vietnam alive, while knowing that she must learn to live the American customs and lifestyle. There are somethings she dosent need to change, like passing the test. Saeng realizes that she can use these memories to keep her spirits alive, she can use them as motivation. This is why the last sentance of the story is so impowering, because she has learned to use the two things together memory and change, “when this hibiscus is budding I will take that test again.” She finds a way to blend her past and her present into a source of strength for her future.

The author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph to show that the girl had adapted to her new country. Saeng missed her home deeply. It was hard for her to say her country’s name without crying, as shown when she struggles to speak, "It’s not like the wind we had at-at-." She also spent four dollars on a plant because it remind her of back at home, a small piece of her past. One could inter she adapted because she was now familiar with the season change in her new environment, and it states when the geese return she is going to take the test again. This shows she has found a new rhythm and a sense of hope, tying her future efforts to the natural cycles she now understands.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it makes Saeng feel more at home in her new surroundings. For example it say, “the snow melt, and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” I think the author says this because all the thing in that sentence remind her of home. For example the plant and the geese are things she had at home, so when winter is over she will feel better and take the test. These familiar signs in nature provide her with comfort and a renewed sense of belonging, which gives her the confidence to face her challenge again. The conclusion thus highlights her emotional connection to these symbols and her growing resilience.

The reason why the author ended with Saeng vowed is because she is very commited to her goal. She failed the first time but know she really want to pass it, so she is waiting until the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding before she will come back to try again. This vow demonstrates her determination and her new strategy of aligning her efforts with a more hopeful time. Her commitment is tied to the promise of spring, symbolizing a fresh start and her unwavering resolve to succeed in her new life after a setback.

I think that the author concluded the story like that because throughout the whole story the plot was set in the winter. She might wanted to try it in a different season to see if she might do better with the whole situation. The harsh winter mirrored her initial struggle and failure, so the promise of spring represents a new beginning and a more favorable condition for her to attempt the test again. That is why I think the author concluded the story like that, using the seasonal shift to symbolize Saeng's personal growth and the hope for a better outcome.

I think the author finishes the story with this paragraph for the following reasons. Saeng really means she will take the test in spring. I say that because she says when the snow melts and geese return, meaning next spring she will take the test again. She is speaking with confidence because she started to add more details about the natural world. For example, she added “hibiscus is budding.” Saeng is determined to pass the test just by what she is saying, showing her resilient spirit. This is why it was the last paragraph and what she meant by it, concluding her character's journey on a hopeful note.

The author concludes the story with the line about spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then she will take that test again, because she is saying there will be a new year and a new beginning. For example, she failed it the first time, so she will wait until the season changes to try again. Another example is she just wants to try until she gets her driving license, demonstrating her persistent nature. This final thought effectively encapsulates her unwavering commitment to achieving her goal.

In this story, Saeng shows her mother how passionate she is with planting and her passion for plants. The author includes the paragraph in the story so that it can show how the character Saeng feels about her planting and her connection to nature. One reason why this shows that she has passion for planting is because it says “I will try this test again,” meaning that if she is doing something that she enjoys doing, then she will try it again and again until she is fully pleased. This reveals that her determination is deeply linked to the things she loves, making the ending a powerful statement of her character.

The author concludes with that particular paragraph. I think he concluded with these lines because it shows a lot of confidence about her and her future plans. For example, when she said, “then I will take that test again,” it sounded very confident and made it clear that she is willing to try again if she or he fails the first time. This sense of self-assurance and readiness to persevere is a fitting end to her story, highlighting her growth and resolve. The paragraph thus serves as a strong, conclusive statement on her character development.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that she has not given up on her dreams despite the initial setback. Her declaration to try again in the spring signifies a enduring hope and a firm resolve to continue pursuing her goals. This final note leaves the reader with a sense of optimism about her future endeavors, ensuring the story ends on a powerful and uplifting message about perseverance. It is a fitting conclusion that underscores the central theme of resilience.

Hope, a new beginning, and adjustment are all reasons why the speaker concludes by saying “when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” That hibiscus flower gives that girl hope because it reminds her of her grandmother and back home, and how wonderful things were back there. By seeing the flower begin to bloom, she realizes that beautiful things can grow and thrive in her new environment as well. She’ll also have a new beginning in the spring; by that time, she should be more adjusted to her surroundings, having made new friends, found new things to do, and created new memories to look back on. Consequently, looking back on her initial failure will not feel as bad, for the flower will bring her both hope and comfort throughout her period of adjustment, solidifying her resolve to try again.

The author is saying that she is not doing anything until it is a nice day outside. She wants the weather to be just right—not too cold, but not too hot either—so that she can comfortably come out and play with her children. The pleasant conditions are important for her to feel motivated and at ease. Then she said she will take her test again on such a nice day, as the favorable outdoor environment will provide a positive and encouraging atmosphere for her to succeed in her endeavor.

The author ends the story with this conclusion to show that Saeng is very passionate about connecting her life in the United States to how life was in Vietnam and bringing them together somehow. In the story, Saeng talks about how she misses home and how she is still trying to adapt to her new life away from the home she knew. When Saeng says that she has failed the test and wants to take it again, she means that she wants to show that she can survive in the United States without disappointing her mother. When Saeng spent the money on a plant, her mom was in disbelief because Saeng knows how hard it is to survive and every dollar counts. When the conclusion says, “I will take the test again,” it shows that Saeng is willing to try to make it in the United States after moving from Vietnam, proving that she can make a better life for herself and her family by working hard, while still keeping traditions from Vietnam alive. Saeng simply wanted to make her new home feel more like Vietnam by buying a plant she knew her mother would recognize and appreciate, thus bridging her two worlds.

The author might have concluded this story because it represents a downfall. This means that right now the character is at the bottom of his struggles and now he has to find a way to make it back to the top. He is going to start over completely and take the test again, but this time he is determined not to fail. This conclusion underscores his resilience and his commitment to learning from his past mistakes, ensuring that his next attempt will be met with greater preparation and a stronger will to succeed.

The author had concluded her paragraph like this to convey emotion. This last paragraph gives emotion to show that she cannot garden due to the winter. In the winter time, all of her plants die for the season, which brings a sense of loss and dormancy. The author is just saying Saeng is planning to come back. After the snow, frosts, and cold weather are gone, Saeng will return next season so she can continue with her gardening, her plants, and her soil. As said, “I will take the test again,” Saeng means she will come back and take the test of effort with her gardening and her mother next time, in the next season when everything begins to grow again, symbolizing renewal and a fresh start.

I think that the author concludes with this paragraph as his ending because that is what the girl is going to be doing for the following year that is going to pass, still being with her mother and helping her out in the garden. Without any friends, she is left alone with just her mom, focusing on their shared tasks and the quiet life they lead together. This final image reinforces her current state of isolation and her primary role within the family unit, suggesting a period of continued dedication and simple, familiar routines. The paragraph effectively closes the narrative by solidifying this ongoing, unchanging circumstance for the foreseeable future.

The author ends the story with this paragraph to show how Saeng has found inspiration from the hibiscus plant. Like the plant, Saeng is going to overcome an obstacle. She will try the driving test again and the plant will overcome the harsh, brutal winter months. The plant will bloom in the spring and show its resilience during adversity. Saeng will also overcome the adversity she faced when she failed her driving test and realized how much she missed her homeland. Saeng too, in a sense, will bloom in the spring. The winter, representing her despair and homesickness, will not prevent her from living happily and taking the test over. The hibiscus reminds her of the strength found in endurance. The story ends with the paragraph to show how the "Winter Hibiscus" has taught her something essential about overcoming obstacles and finding inner strength.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng is going to accept her new home and recognize the similarities from her old home, holding memories close to help her overcome the obstacles that she is facing in life. Her mother's words, "I've seen this kind blooming along the lake. It's flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That's what matters," establish a tangible link from their old home to their new home. This shows that while things do change, they can also retain a core sameness that provides comfort. This leads to the conclusion because this is the moment where Saeng realizes that she will always have the memories of her old home and will consciously use them as a source of strength to help her overcome the troubles she is going through in her new environment.

The author ends the story the way she did to show how Saeng and the hibiscus plant are alike and how Saeng will overcome her obstacle when the plant overcomes its obstacle. Saeng’s obstacle is adjusting to her new life and the first step in that is passing her driver’s test. The reader knows she has to pass because Saeng tells her mother, “I-I failed the test.” The hibiscus must make it through the winter; it also has to adjust to new surroundings to survive, just like Saeng. The mother says to Saeng, “… but its strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” So, if the winter hibiscus’s job, or hurdle that it has to jump, is to make it, to stay alive during the winter months, then its job will be done in the spring. The author ends the story with Saeng telling herself, “… in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” If Saeng’s obstacle is completing and passing the driver’s test, and she passes in the spring, right as the hibiscus passes its “test,” the symbolism between the two, showing a determined spirit to adapt, will grow deeper because they will both adapt and pass their obstacle at the same time, completing their parallel journeys.

I think that the story came back to this because that is what the story starts off with. It all started with Saeng going to take a test, but she did not pass it. The failure initiated her entire reflective journey throughout the day. So when the weather is better and the conditions are more favorable, she would have a better time trying to pass that test. This cyclical return to the test provides a sense of closure and a new beginning. This is why I think she came back to the test at the end, framing it as a future goal born from her recent experiences and renewed determination.

The reason why the author concludes the story this way is because she wanted to leave the reader in suspense, wanting more. You can tell because it never really says what the test is, leaving its nature deliberately vague. She wanted you to try and guess what the test is, engaging the reader's imagination. When Saeng walked up to her mother she had told her that she failed the test, a moment that highlights the unresolved outcome. This open-ended conclusion effectively creates a sense of anticipation and curiosity for the audience.

The author ends the story with that paragraph to give an insight on the next story, suggesting future developments. I think there will be another story because there are clues to support my theory present in the text. Just at the beginning of the paragraph when they come back, and then at the end it says "then I will take the test again," which points to a continuing narrative. It didn't say happily ever after or anything similar; it just stated those personal changes mentioned, leaving room for further exploration. So I think the author will write another story so we could see if Saeng will pass her test, providing a continuation of her journey.

The author ended with this paragraph because it is an example of how everything gets a fresh start in the spring, a theme of renewal. An example of this is that the geese will return home after the winter to start a new family, and also in the winter the hibiscus leaves will die and then in the spring they will have a new start, symbolizing cyclical rebirth. I think the author uses this paragraph last because it’s a metaphor of how everything will get a fresh start, including Saeng herself. She will get a new chance to take her driving test just like the plant and geese will get a new chance at life, connecting her personal struggle to the natural world.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because these geese coming back symbolize Saeng’s determination and hope that she needs to pass the driving test, representing her resilience. She will wait for the winter to pass so that she can pass the test, showing her patience and perseverance. The coming of spring also symbolizes renewal and birth, a traditional motif for new beginnings. Saeng will have the chance again to pass the driving test with renewed faith and encouragement, mirroring the seasonal change. This is a great way to end the story because it is really deep and makes the reader think about the meaning of the scene and how the geese, hibiscus plant, and spring arriving effect the conclusion of the story, leaving a lasting impression.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph to say that he will take the test up again in spring time when the snow melts and geese return, indicating a future attempt. Also I think that the author likes the setting of spring, with its associations of sunny skies and geese floating in a pond, creating a hopeful imagery. I also would like that setting because it gives me more ideas and it's a very lovely setting to be around, evoking a sense of peace and possibility. That is why I think the author picked that paragraph to conclude the story, using the beauty of the season to end on an optimistic note.

The short story, "Winter Hibiscus," is about a girl named Saeng who moved with her mother to the United States. The story tells about the girl's difficult transition into the different culture and her feelings of displacement. During the story, the author makes references to the daughter having to pass a driving test, which represents a larger challenge. At the end of the story the author wrote, “In the spring…then I will take that test again.” In the text, the girl says “it’s—it’s not a real one,” when referring to the winter hibiscus plant she bought. The reader could infer that this quote means that the girl has memories of home, but they are not the real thing, just like the greenhouse plant is not the same as the ones from her homeland. Also the author wrote that she “much preferred it to the Big Mac." This quote shows that she misses her own culture and cannot fully adapt to the American one that she lives in now. In conclusion, the girl's test may be that she needs to be able to handle change and also be able to recall memories of her homeland with happiness instead of sadness, finding a balance between her past and her present.

The author concludes the story with that ending because he wanted to show the reader the message that “if you just try, you might like it,” and that is why the girl said she would come back next spring when the snows melt so she can take the test again. This final statement from Saeng signifies a shift in her attitude from defeat to determination. It underscores a theme of perseverance and the importance of giving new experiences a genuine chance. The promise to try again in the spring symbolizes hope and a willingness to continue engaging with her new environment, wrapping up her emotional journey on a forward-looking and positive note.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it effectively ties everything together. One way it ties everything together is by taking what had happened in the beginning and connecting it with why she had bought the flower in the first place, which was to find a connection to her past. Also it ties Saeng's old memories from Vietnam to her new way of life in the United States, showing her beginning to reconcile the two. The story states, "carefully Saeng picked it up and smiled. She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. the familiar fragrance filled her lungs." This shows how the flower she found in the flower shop gave her comforting memories from Vietnam, providing her with a sense of peace and belonging. This emotional resolution is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, as it completes Saeng's moment of personal clarity.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it is telling and showing us that Saeng is going to try to pass the test in the spring. Getting that hibiscus reminded her of her homeland and it gave her happy memories of then, strengthening her resolve. And it also made her believe in herself and want to get there and try again, instilling a new sense of confidence. It made her hopeful for the future. The author uses the test in the context of “when snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding” to help indicate that it is going to be spring when she tries to take her test again, using the season as a symbol of renewal and new beginnings for her efforts.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he figures that after all that has happened, like her failing the test, he wanted the ending to be remembered as a happy and uplifting thing. He also wanted the end to show how something bad happened but that next she was going to try to do it again, emphasizing resilience. The author wanted to show that she wouldn’t give up, that she goes after what she wants despite setbacks. This final note highlights her persistent character and leaves the reader with a sense of her inner strength. And he wanted that to be the last paragraph to ensure the story's final impression was one of hope and determination.

The author concludes the story the way that they did to signify that the girl will not give up trying to pass her test and will adapt to her new found home and make it what her home in Vietnam was to her. The girl is reminiscent of her past life and wishes to go back and have the life she had in her home country. When she is confronted with the winter hibiscus, however, she finds a new source of strength and resolve. This final scene shows her determination to persevere and build a new life, blending her past with her present circumstances to create a future filled with hope.

The Author chose to conclude the story with this paragraph because it is resolutive to the entire reading before it. In the story Saeng (the girl) had been stressed from failing the driver's test. She was also saddened by the memory of the hibiscus plant back in her native country Vietnam. At the end of the story when it says “when the snow melts and the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again" ,(Ho) the snow melting, geese returning, and the hibiscus budding symbolize change and adoption. Saeng will need to change and adapt to a new life to pass the test and feel better. This final paragraph effectively ties together the story's central themes of memory, resilience, and adaptation. This is why the Author Minfong Ho, of the story “Winter Hibiscus” used a strong, symbolistic and resolutive end to her story.

After Saeng fails her driver’s test, she gives up hope for the future. The sight of the hibiscus plant reminds her to never give up, no matter how tough the situation. In the story, Saeng’s mother says, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but its strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” This quote shows how even though its not an object of beauty, it can do what it takes to survive. Saeng feels that she is also like the hibiscus, having the strength to be able to survive in a new environment. Even though she is new to this country, Saeng had proved that no matter how big the situation, anything can be overcomed if you believe in yourself and your family. The story thus ends on a powerful note of resilience and self-assurance.

The author probably used this as the last paragraph to show that at this time next year she is going to take the test again. The author writes this paragraph to show that she failed the test when the geese were going away for winter and the hibiscus was blooming. By connecting her failure to these specific seasonal events, the author creates a cyclical sense of time. This framing suggests that with the return of spring and the re-budding of the hibiscus, a new opportunity for success will also return, providing a clear and hopeful timeline for Saeng's renewed efforts and eventual triumph.

The author concludes the end of the story the way he/she did because it shows how much the plant truly means. Saeng is going to wait till the flower blooms because it means so much to her. The flower represents her and her driving test. When the hibiscus is ready to bloom, she will be ready to drive. The plant gives her hope for a new tomorrow, a new chance. The last paragraph helps the reader realize how much the plant means to the girl, its significance. It makes her feel more at home, and her home makes her feel stronger; makes her joyful and happy after the misery of failing the driving test. This symbolic connection between the plant's resilience and her own personal growth provides a satisfying and uplifting conclusion to her emotional journey.

She concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants the spring to come again. She says “when the snow melts,” indicating a time of renewal and a fresh start. She wants to look at the events again with a clearer perspective and take care of them properly. This final thought encapsulates her hope for the future and her intention to revisit her past experiences once the harshness of winter has passed, allowing for new growth and understanding. It is a quiet promise to herself to face her memories when conditions are more favorable.

In this short story, Saeng vows to take the test again in the spring because she knows that she will be able to pass it once she has fully accepted living in this new place. After Saeng moved, she was very upset and missed her old home, family, and lifestyle, which prevented her from focusing on the test. However, once she realized that the flowers are beautiful in her new home too, she began to accept the changes around her. The geese being familiar to her symbolizes that she is finally adjusting to her new lifestyle and finding connections. Saeng also probably made this vow because she didn’t want her mother to be disappointed in her again, and after seeing her mother's disappointment mixed with loving kindness, Saeng was determined to pass the test. When Saeng takes the test again in the spring, she will be ready because she has adjusted to and accepted her new life, giving her the peace of mind needed to succeed.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because in the beginning of the story her family moved to the United States from Vietnam. Saeng was walking home from failing her driver's test, feeling dejected, when she saw a familiar plant. Later she goes to a florist shop to see if the plant can be purchased, seeking a piece of her homeland. So she gets the plant seeds and plants them with care, deciding that when they start to bloom she will go to retake her driving test that she failed. I think she uses the flowers for good luck and as a personal talisman. That is why I believe the author concludes that paragraph in the story, to show how Saeng finds a symbol of hope and a concrete plan for her future success.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph because it shows that Saeng can overcome obstacles, and the next time she has these reminders she will succeed. When she says “almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of strange before had become... almost familiar to her now,” this is saying she is getting used to the changes in her new life and is beginning to find comfort in them. So the end paragraph reflects these ideas of gradual acceptance and personal growth. It underscores her journey from feeling like an outsider to finding a sense of belonging, which will be the foundation for her future achievements and her ability to conquer challenges.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with the paragraph for a few reasons. One reason is that she is trying to overcome change and wants to make the situation better for herself. She tries doing that by taking the test again, demonstrating her resilience. The author also concludes with the paragraph because she feels heartbroken that life is not going her way and that she needs to do something about it, turning her sadness into motivation. That's why the author concludes the story with this paragraph to show you if she is determined or not, and if she will stick through it or not. The ending ultimately serves to highlight her inner resolve and her decision to persevere despite the difficulties she faces.

I think that the author concluded the story with that paragraph because she is going to see if she can adapt to the new country and her new life. This is a good way to leave off the story because you don’t know if she will or not; it leaves you on a cliff hanger, wondering about her future. I also think this is a good way to leave it off because the author could write a sequel to it and make a series out of it, continuing her journey of adaptation and self-discovery.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because the snow is pretty and geese are animals that make it pretty, so they want you to think that our outdoors is the nicest thing around. The imagery of the natural world is used to create a sense of beauty and peace, suggesting that the simplicity and elegance of nature are what truly matter. This final thought leaves the reader with a lasting impression of the scene's serene and lovely qualities.

The author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with that paragraph to show Saeng starting over in her life. In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, it connects to her life, showing that she is starting fresh in a way. Although she might miss her old life, her grandmother, the well, and the fine-toothed comb, she is making an effort, and to "take that test again" shows her determination. By retaking the test she shows that she is not ready to give in to her feelings of loss and to her grief, choosing instead to embrace her new beginning with hope and resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he knows all of this stuff going on will probably come back up again in the future. Just like how he said the geese will come back every year, so he is definitely saying that all of this will come back up, suggesting that the character's challenges and memories are cyclical. That is what I think the author intended to convey with this final, reflective paragraph about the returning geese and the unresolved nature of the events.

I think that the author made that the concluding sentence because it means that when Saeng is ready then she will take the test again, using nature as her guide. I think that she is comparing herself to the snow, the geese, and the hibiscus, seeing her own journey reflected in the changing seasons. I think so because she says that when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding then she will take the test again. So I think that she is saying that she is not ready for the test now, and when she does get ready, when she has grown and changed like the natural world around her, that is when she will take it and face her future.

The author's conclusion to the story shows how Saeng interpreted the experience of that day, finding a new resolve in the midst of her disappointment. She uses a spring time setting to show when her confidence in herself is reborn, a season that symbolizes new beginnings and growth. Seeing her hibiscus bud in the spring will giver herself and newfound integrity to go try that driving test again, providing her with the inner strength she needs to face the challenge once more. This moment marks a quiet but significant turning point in her personal journey.

Hope, positivness, helpful all are reasons the author concludes the story with this paragraph. First, the last paragraph gives the readers a sense that Saeng has hope. I felt that she had hope because she is willing to take the test again, demonstrating her belief in a better outcome. Since she is going to take the test again she wants to help her mother, showing her commitment to her family. Second, the last paragraph gave me the feeling that Saeng has a positive attitude. She bought a flower to replace the dead ones, and she stated that she will re-take the test in the spring, focusing on future possibilities. Third, Saeng is helpful to her mother. Saeng finished digging the hole for the new flower for her mother, so her mom could go make dinner, a small but meaningful act of support.
