Saeng also saw the feeling her mom felt when she found out Saeng did not pass the test, which deepened her resolve. So she is re-taking the test, motivated by love and responsibility. Saeng was feeling just about what any other new kid probably would have felt. She was scared, but through everything Saeng had hope, a positive attitude, and she was helpful, qualities that ultimately define her resilient character.

To her the hibiscus was a test of her ability to settle into her new life. Saeng felt she failed the test of letting go of the past and embracing ìnow.î The hibiscus reminded her of home, so she spent over @MONEY1 on it, knowing she and her mother needed the money, which filled her with a sense of guilt. Essentaily, she felt as though she failed a test of practicality and emotional maturity, a painful realization that weighed heavily on her heart. This internal struggle defined her initial reaction to the plant and her own actions.

I think the author concludes the story with that parography because they want you to understand Saeng's strength and her capacity for resilience. One reason I think they also end the story like that because she know inside that when her plant is strong and not covered in snow that she will be strong so that's when she wont`s to take her driving test, linking her personal growth to the natural world. For example when she said, îWhen the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again, she was setting a tangible goal for her own renewal. That is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, to leave the reader with a powerful image of hope and determination. This final thought solidifies the story's message about finding inner strength.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho the main character Saeng and her mother, moved from their homeland to this new place, where everything was different and unfamiliar. she was having a very hard time adapting to this new place, and Saeng failed an importian test, which deepened her feelings of isolation. She had been very discouraged by this, and she was trying to remind herself of being at home, seeking comfort in memories. She bought the winter Hibiscus to remind her of home, but when she was planting it she became very determined to try and adapt, by taking the test, when the hibiscus would bud, seeing it as a promise to herself. The author is concluding by there being hope, and determination for Saeng to adapt to her new home, suggesting a brighter future lies ahead through perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it adds the uplifting message that Saeng will be able to overcome the obstacles of living in an unfamiliar country. First, the @CAPS1 geese represent a piece of her new home because she reasons “reluctantly” that they are familiar to her now, which depicts her growing ability to adapt to her new environment. In addition, she also equates spring to when the hibiscus is budding, and the hibiscus is a symbol of herself because both are trying to live in a country that is not their own. Therefore, the hibiscus budding represents her being able to live comfortably and flourish in @LOCATION1. Finally, she vows that she will take her driver's test again. Her initial failure to pass the test showed her inability to become a part of @LOCATION1, but if she passes it, then she will have successfully adapted. Overall, the author of this story concludes with this paragraph because it contains the central theme of the passage through an uplifting message of resilience and hope.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the ending includes the hibiscus budding and the decision to retake the test to make a powerful connection between the two. The geese are also included in the end to show the new country she has adapted to because she now recognizes the natural cycle of when the geese come and go. The budding of the hibiscus is to her much more than just a flower; it shows the rejuvenation of new life within her, just as flowers tend to bud in the spring. That is also why she chooses to take the test again, because her own “budding” will occur in the spring, and she will have newly born confidence for the upcoming challenge. That is why the geese, the hibiscus, and the test are all included in the end of the story to show the connection between her past home and her successful adaptation to a new lifestyle.

She will try gardening again after the geese and flowers return with the spring. She wants to have the best garden around, a vibrant and beautiful space that reflects her own growth. She wants to keep the tradition going, nurturing the plants as a way to nurture her own connection to her new home and build a future there.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng didn’t think the winter hibiscus was in the ground now, and she was disheartened when she got back to find all of her plants were gone due to the snow. Her declaration that she will take that test again symbolizes her determination to start over, meaning she will begin again from the first steps, just as she will with her plants and flowers, demonstrating her resilience.

The author concludes, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because Saeng doesn't want to give up yet. In the story, Saeng mumbled, "I mean, not like the kind at-at-," and she found that she was still too shaky to say the words "at home," showing she was still upset because she misses her home in Vietnam. When Saeng puts the hibiscus in the ground she feels more alive, and she wants to feel at home in the United States. Saeng isn't going to give up on driving but is resolved to try harder and harder to pass the test and build her new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it’s related to what she thinks, when her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. The cheerful greeting, “you’re back,” she said, was immediately followed by questions: “it’s past time, what took you so long? How did it go? Did you?” She feels very connected to this moment, and the paragraph is directly related to her emotional state and the resolution she finds.

“When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The story “Winter Hibiscus” ended with this paragraph because it signifies a fresh start for Saeng. It will be spring outside and the geese will come back to her home where she lives now, which now has the hibiscus to remind her of her old home and provide comfort. The paragraph also thoughtfully compares Saeng to the hibiscus. In the story her mother says, “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it is strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” Saeng is the winter hibiscus that’s strong enough to make it through winter, and failing the test won’t matter until spring when she will take it again and pass. That’s beautifully represented when the hibiscus is finally in bloom. I also think the story ended this way because it ties in Saeng’s complex feelings throughout the story about her new home and old home, creating a unified conclusion. It’s also showing her inherent ability to conquer obstacles, as she is going to forget about failing the driving test and work diligently to pass it in the spring.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because the hibiscus makes them overcome obstacles and serves as a powerful symbol. She wanted to take the test again so she can prove to her mum that she can pass it and achieve her goal. I also think that because the hibiscus gives them strength and inspiration, she got more confident in herself and her own abilities to pass the test when the time is right.

The author chose to end the story this way for several important reasons. Some of the reasons is that it creates a feeling of hope in the reader, tells us we always have another chance, and underscores the importance of persistence. The ending paragraph creates a feeling of hope since it shows how everything in nature will return and there will always be another chance for renewal. The author chose to put this in the text since it creates a happy note to end on and give the reader the happiness of knowing there is always hope. Another reason the author chose to end the story with this paragraph is that it tells the reader that you always get another chance no matter what you do or what happens. The author wanted to impart this on the reader since it is an important life lesson to know and remember. The ending also tells the reader that persistence is very important in life and almost essential to live fully. The author shows this by talking about the snow melting, the geese returning, and the flower blooming, which are things that happen constantly and almost never stop because they refuse to give up and die. Therefore, the author chose to end the story with this paragraph for these several reasons. The author chose to end it this way since the paragraph gives a lot of hope to the reader and gives the powerful idea of a second chance. The author also chose to end with this paragraph since it has several analogies to persistence which is vital in life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he is saying that Saeng likes to do things in the spring when she sees flowers growing and nature awakening. This is because she feels like she is at home in that season, so she feels more confident and capable about passing the test and facing new challenges with a positive outlook.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus", the author concluded the story with the quote "when they come back, Saeng's vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." The author placed this paragraph as the concluding thought to stress that Saeng is determined to make a change. She failed the test but wants to take it again, showing her resilience. Her grandmother's resemblance is in the flower, so if the flower buds, then her grandmother will be back in a sense, providing a spiritual connection. When her grandmother "comes back" then Saeng will feel as if her grandmother is giving her strength and encouragement to try the test again, reinforcing her resolve for the future.

The author ends with that paragraph to show how Saeng, like the budding Hibiscus, will get a new start in the spring and overcome obstacles. The flower's cycle of rebirth in the warmer season mirrors Saeng's own opportunity for personal renewal. This parallel suggests that after a period of hardship, represented by the winter and her failed test, a time for growth and new beginnings will arrive. Just as the hibiscus will bloom again, Saeng is prepared to face her challenges with renewed hope and perseverance.

The author concludes the story with, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think the author used that conclusion to make the reader want to finish the story on their own, leaving Saeng's ultimate success open to interpretation. Or he could write another story to finish it, continuing the narrative in a future work. Most authors conclude their stories like this so the reader is in control about the ending, allowing them to imagine what happens next based on the character's determined vow.

Based on my understanding of the story I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph to emphasize what will happen as well as to get the reader thinking and build the excitement with questions and thoughts in their head after reading the passage. It is a technique to capture the reader's attention, leading them to wonder if she will survive and was able to adapt to the lifestyle that she was not used to. It also tests her ability to see if she will be able to survive the different types of seasons and to know that no matter what you face in life, there is always more obstacles ahead of you, making the ending reflective of life's ongoing challenges.

The author chose to end the story with that paragraph for emotional meanings. The last paragraph is saying she will re-take the test when the hibiscus is blooming in the spring, tying her personal goal to a natural event. She hopes that the blooming hibiscus will give her strength to pass the test, serving as a source of inspiration. The hibiscus reminds her of her homeland and gives her comfort, connecting her new life with cherished memories. Saeng hopes the sight of the blooming hibiscus will remind her of her home and give her strength to pass the test, using it as a symbolic anchor for her courage and determination.

The author ends the story in this way because the plant and leaving of the geese represent change to Saeng. The hibiscus isn't the same as she remembers from back home, yet its presence is a powerful link to her past. The budding of the hibiscus shows Saeng's happiness from home and rekindles a sense of belonging. This paragraph shows that the familiarity of the budding plant gives Saeng courage and the ability to overcome her obstacle, transforming her initial disappointment into resolve. The geese in this paragraph represent the keeping of time and the natural cycles of departure and return. The plant will bud at the time the geese return in the spring, symbolizing hope's reliable recurrence. If the author hadn't included this final paragraph, the full effect of memories for Saeng wouldn't have been fully portrayed, leaving her character arc incomplete. This line implies that Saeng was unable to overcome her obstacle because of the newness of this place and the resulting lack of confidence. But when the buds bring her a sense of home, she will be able to defeat the obstacle of her driving test, finding the strength to try again. She will be more confident and prepared for her next attempt, ultimately finding her place in this new world.

The author includes that because it shows that she is not given up, highlighting her resilient character. Since she is not given up she can have more trys, demonstrating that perseverance is key to eventual success. Her determination is the central theme, showing that failure is not permanent. This resolve allows her to face future challenges with a stronger will, ensuring she continues to move forward despite setbacks. The story concludes by affirming the power of a persistent spirit.

There are many reasons why the author chose to conclude the story with Saeng vowing to attempt the driver's test again. At first, the story begins with a tone of sadness and seeing, as fact "as Saeng walks home after failing her driver's test" this quote sets the tone as sadness because she has failed a very important test and she is walking alone, feeling isolated in her disappointment. "She sees a familiar plant" is when the hope comes back into the story, serving as a turning point for her emotions. When she brings the plant she had purchased here to her mother, their connection is also seen delineated. "Where did you get it?" her mother asked, and Saeng replied "I bought it." She bought it for a sum more than her mother said for all of the seeds in the garden, indicating its deep personal value. As time went on it was clear to her mother the plant signifies strength and hope to her daughter and embodies a memory of home. I remember a time when my mother bought me a similar item; I felt it was a waste of money, but when I saw her light up with delight, I understood it was given with love. When Saeng's mother felt hope from the plants made Saeng happy and gave her courage, it solidified her decision to try the driver's test again. This emotional transformation is the reason why the author chose to conclude the story with Saeng vowing to attempt the driver's test again, completing her journey from defeat to determination.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it provides necessary closure to the narrative, making the story feel more complete and longer. It gives it a good ending by resolving the central character's emotional conflict, offering a sense of hope for the future. However, I have no idea on what that means in a deeper literary sense, so the author should explain what it means not me, as the symbolic significance is not fully clear from the text alone. The paragraph's purpose seems to be to leave the reader with a final, reflective thought, but its intended meaning remains somewhat ambiguous without further authorial insight, which would strengthen the story's conclusion.

The Author concluded the story with this paragraph because the author was trying to let us know what happens after the main events of the story was done, providing a glimpse into the future. The author tried to make it clear how the character's resolve solidified following their experiences, and that is why I think that the author came up with that idea to conclude with that paragraph. It serves as an epilogue that clarifies the character's intentions and future actions, ensuring the reader understands the story's ultimate message about perseverance and moving forward. This final thought wraps up the narrative neatly for the audience.

The author concludes this paragraph because Saeng is going to wait until winter is over so she can have a fresh beginning. She wants to try again because the last time she messed up and killed the plants, an experience that taught her a valuable lesson. Saeng wants to become a gardener like her mother, finding inspiration in her mother's skill and patience. This desire for a new start in the spring is a direct result of her past failure and her aspirations for the future.

The author of this essay includes those sentences as the conclusion to make it clear that she will realize that they are coming back. This realization marks a significant turning point in her understanding and acceptance of the situation. It provides a sense of closure and hopeful anticipation for what is to come, effectively wrapping up the narrative arc.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow…” to show that Saeng got stronger. She got stronger because she adjusted to her new home and new environment, learning to cope with its challenges. Saeng is more confident in herself to take the test again, having processed her initial disappointment. She doesn’t want to cry again, like she did in her last test, and is determined to face it with renewed courage. Being more confident and more adjusted is the reason why she has become stronger, and the reason why she wants to take the test again is because she is stronger and better prepared for the future.

Confidence, persistence, memories – all things that Saeng has that help explain why the author concludes this story with this paragraph. Since Saeng moved from her own country, she has not been very happy; she was upset pretty much the whole time and misses everyone and everything from Vietnam; everything she sees reminds her of it. That last paragraph, where it says, “then I will take that test again,” shows that she has confidence in herself and wants to try harder next time. She shows persistence when she says she will try again and hopefully, she won’t give up. Saeng misses almost everything from Vietnam, even the food. She also misses her family and how they look and dress. Her memories were probably holding her back from concentrating hard on her driver's test; she knows she wanted to do good so she bought the flower in hopes that would make her feel better. Hopefully, Saeng’s life will get better in the United States and she will learn to love this country, using her strength to build a new life while cherishing the old.

Because with the blooming of the hibiscus plant comes new hope. In the story she sees the hibiscus as her old life, a vibrant symbol of her past, and with the budding of the plant starts a new chapter in the young girl's life. This natural cycle of dormancy and rebirth mirrors her own personal journey and emotional renewal. The plant's resilience gives her the courage to look forward to the future with optimism.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he is trying to prove his point about resilience and adaptation. I think that Saeng was comparing herself to the flower, seeing a direct parallel in their situations. For example, the flower was originally a wild flower, growing freely in its natural environment, and then it was planted in a pot, which became its new, confined home. Similarly, Saeng was a free and happy girl in her homeland, but then she had to move to a new and unfamiliar country. Both the flower and Saeng feel like they are out of place, struggling to adapt to their new surroundings. Since in the story Saeng is similar to the flower, then at the end of the story I think that Saeng thinks that if the flower can survive the harsh winter and bloom again, then she too can survive her challenges in this new place and she can pass the test. This parallel is why I think that the author finished with that paragraph, using the flower's survival as a metaphor to get his message of hope and perseverance across.

The reason why the author concludes the story like that is because he or she wants to show that Saeng is determined to not fail that driver's test again. The author wants to leave Saeng on a good note of hope and resolve so she won't be sad about her initial failure. When she takes the test again in the spring, she will be better prepared mentally and know what she is expecting from the experience. She will have learned from her mistakes and grown from the hardship, leading to a better and more hopeful winter season as she waits and prepares for her second chance.

I think the author concludes the story as he or she did to teach a valuable lesson about persistence. The core message is that no matter what stands in your way or no matter what slows you down and causes you to stumble, you should never give up on your goals. You should keep on trying, pushing forward despite setbacks. If you fail something, the important thing is to try again and again, learning each time, until you finally get it right. This lesson is clearly conveyed through Saeng's decision to retake her test, embodying the spirit of perseverance.

Courage, memories, hard work – All are reasons why the author concludes the story with this vow: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, Then I will take the test again.” First, courage because she failed her test initially so it takes some guts and will power to go back and even try it again, facing potential failure once more. Also, because when she remembers her grandmother it upsets her, so that definitely takes courage and the human will power to do her test a second time despite the emotional pain. Next, memories. I think she keeps wanting to do this test because she has had so many good memories with her grandmother and doesn’t want to ever forget them or let her down. But again, this desire goes back to the will power or the want to, to go back and do the test a second time as a tribute. Last, all the Hard work. All the Hard work because She knows what her grandmother meant to her and through all the things or Hard work that her grandmother put out she saw and wants to honor or appreciate all of the stuff that her grandmother did for her by succeeding. These are the reasons that I believe the author ended with that Paragraph rather than some other paragraph, to highlight these driving forces behind Saeng's resolution.

The author includes the last paragraph to show that she still has hope for the future. It is the last sentence because the author wants to show that when all seems lost and you're at the end of the line, you can always hope for better days ahead. The paragraph signifies that when spring comes, so will a new beginning; this renewal applies not only to Saeng’s plant, which will bud again, but also for her life in a different country, suggesting a fresh start and the promise of success after a period of hardship. This ending leaves the reader with a powerful sense of optimism.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” chose to end the story with that paragraph to reinforce the central theme of the narrative and conclude with a hopeful, uplifting tone. The theme of the story is adjusting to new circumstances and making the best out of each change that life presents. The line "Saeng vowed silently to herself" clearly tells the audience that Saeng is making a conscious, personal effort to fit in and find the good in her new life. The hopeful tone that is created is a deliberate way to show that Saeng is finally willing to accept the changes in her life and wants to do her best to overcome the obstacles she faces. Her declaration, “I will take that test again,” is significant because the test represents the various obstacles she will overcome when persistent effort is applied. The hibiscus mentioned in the sentence "...when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding..." symbolizes the idea of starting over. The budding hibiscus is directly compared to Saeng, who is also preparing for a fresh start and is filled with a new determination to achieve her goals of adjusting to a new lifestyle. Ultimately, the author chose this specific paragraph to conclude the selection in order to powerfully highlight the theme and beautifully symbolize a new beginning for the protagonist.

I think the author concludes the story with that statement because it allows the audience to then draw a meaningful comparison between Saeng and the hibiscus. After reading that final statement, I realized that Saeng and the hibiscus are truly alike because they are both going to make it through their difficult periods and come out on top, with Saeng getting her driver's license and the hibiscus budding anew. Furthermore, the author might have ended the story with that statement because it effectively shows that Saeng is fully committed to working toward her goal and won’t give up, as evidenced by her internal vow: “Saeng vowed silently to herself, ‘I will take that test again’.” Finally, I think the author concluded the story with that particular statement because it gives the audience the satisfaction of knowing broadly what is going to happen to Saeng while still leaving a little mystery for the audience to fill in as they wish. For example, I know that Saeng is going to take the test again and I firmly believe she will pass it; however, another person reading it might believe she failed again and had to retake it a third time, demonstrating the open-ended nature of the conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to let the reader compare the girl to the natural elements of the geese and the hibiscus, drawing parallels between their cycles and her personal journey. The geese leave for the winter and then come back in the spring; however, the geese also show how the girl is going to come back and take the driver's test again in the spring, mirroring their return with her own renewed attempt. Similarly, the hibiscus dies off over the winter and starts budding again in the spring, which shows that winter is its primary weakness. Like the hibiscus, the girl overcomes her own weakness of not being able to drive by remembering her homeland and drawing strength from her past. By placing this paragraph at the very end of the story, the author ensures that you can clearly see that the girl is fundamentally like the geese in her return and like the hibiscus in her resilience and capacity for rebirth.

I think the author concluded the story with that phrase because it effectively shows that she will mature and grow from her experiences. She is essentially saying that she was not ready for all the challenges she was going to face in her new environment. For example, she did not pass her driver's test, but instead of simply crying about it or giving up, she just said with resolve that she would take it again next year. In the story, she also deeply longed for her homeland, which she truly missed and held dear in her memories. She coped with this profound sense of loss by buying a winter hibiscus to remind her not only of her homeland but also of her grandmother, connecting her past to her present. Overall, the main character showed significant depth and maturity throughout the piece, culminating in this final, reflective moment of personal commitment.

The author concludes the story the way that she does because it powerfully illustrates Saeng’s newfound willingness to adapt to her surroundings, drawing a direct parallel to the hibiscus and its own struggle. Saeng needs to adapt to her new home in the United States, and the hibiscus needs to adapt for the upcoming winter in order to survive. When Saeng vows to herself, “When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding…”, it becomes clear from this promise that Saeng has genuine hope for both herself and the hibiscus, linking their fates together. Initially, Saeng was very reluctant to accept her new home, as seen when she says of the hibiscus, “it’s not like the kind we had before,” highlighting her initial disappointment. But she eventually realized that the hibiscus could serve as a beautiful reminder of home as well as a crucial reminder to change and grow for her new home. She understood on a deeper level that if the delicate hibiscus could survive the harsh winter, then she, too, could find the strength to survive and ultimately thrive living somewhere new and unfamiliar.

The author concludes this story with the promise Saeng made to herself to take the test again, come springtime, because Saeng is having trouble adapting to her new home, and she won’t give up on fitting in after only one failure. Remembering her home and that she will never be able to return are painful thoughts to Saeng, and memories of it help her cope with her loss. The hibiscus and other familiar flowers she found comforted her, because they reminded her of home and provided a tangible connection to her past. At springtime when the geese return and the hibiscus starts blooming, Saeng will feel ready again to take the test. The spring represents the chance for another try, and a new beginning, symbolizing hope and the cyclical nature of life that encourages her to persevere.

The author concludes the story with the last paragraph. The author chose this because the sentence informs you Saeng will take the test again, reinforcing the theme of resilience. In an earlier paragraph, Saeng tells her mother she failed the test, which highlights her initial disappointment. So by the time spring comes around, the hibiscus will start budding and Saeng will retake the test, finding strength in the changing seasons. Also, the geese left home temporarily because of the snow, and she sort of compares herself to the geese because she misses her home. I believe that the author concluded the story with this paragraph because the plant represents being determined to survive, much like Saeng herself. This final thought leaves the reader with a clear understanding of Saeng's unwavering determination and the symbolic hope the plant provides for her upcoming challenge.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. It also means she will be well prepared and will have a lot of confidence in passing this test, having learned from her previous attempt. Just like when she said “let’s plant it, right now,” this example shows that even though Saeng had failed the test and disappointed her mother, she will never give up and she still has hope in the plant just like how her mother has hope for Saeng, illustrating a shared faith in growth and new beginnings.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he is talking about when Saeng vowed silently, as she is thinking about what had happened a long time ago with her mom and the plants in her garden. The author concludes the story with this paragraph. In this story it is about a @PERSON1, a girl and her mother. The girl is given money to buy a plant or seeds. The author concludes this story with this paragraph because she wants to show that after everything that happened, Saeng will move on and try hard. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because she can not wait until spring because her plant will bud and it will remind her of her home land again, providing a deep sense of nostalgia. I believe there is a meaningful reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. I think that the author will feel more comfortable and ready to take the test after a period of waiting. I was able to come to this conclusion because by waiting for winter to be over to take the test again, she is giving herself time to prepare and adjust. Also, she is waiting for the hibiscus plant to bud, which symbolizes hope. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show she has hope for the future. She believes that she can pass the test when everything is back to normal, in the spring, a time of renewal. This makes her feel more at home because it was always like this before she moved, creating a comforting sense of familiarity. Also she likes the geese and the hibiscus and these things might make her feel more comfortable and confident in her new surroundings. This is why the author concludes the story with the paragraph to show she has hope, ending on a note of optimistic expectation for what is to come.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph because he/she wanted to compare Saeng's life with the plant. For example, in the story, Saeng had just failed her driving test and then she saw a plant that reminded her of her homeland. From the flower shop to the house, she is comparing her home land to the flower, which shows how she deeply relates to it. The hibiscus serves as a direct link to her past and her cultural identity. So the concluding paragraph shows how when the hibiscus is budding and starts a new phase, she will too and go for her driver's license again, embracing a fresh start just as the plant does with the changing seasons.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng’s determination to adapt to the change in her life. In the story, Saeng fails her driver's test and is struggling to adapt to her new life in the United States. However, when she sees that the hibiscus and geese are familiar, she feels a renewed determination to adapt as well. Saeng buys a hibiscus because it vividly reminds her of home. This not only comforts her but also makes her miss her old home more, creating a complex mix of emotions. The hibiscus can survive in both tropical climates and the United States, so it helps Saeng realize that she can as well, embodying resilience. The author includes the geese because they help Saeng realize that she is becoming more familiar with things in the United States, so she can continue to adapt. Saeng says that she now recognizes the “V” shape of the geese. Realizing that she is becoming more accustomed to her new environment and that she is able to survive helps her reach the determination to retake and pass her driving test. The author includes it to summarize the story's central theme of adapting to change and finding strength in familiarity.

I think that the author put that sentence to get a little personal with the character so you can relate to that person. By including such a reflective moment, the author allows the reader to connect with the character's inner feelings and personal journey. It creates a moment of intimacy between the reader and the character, fostering a deeper understanding of her experiences. This technique helps to make the character's struggles and triumphs feel more genuine and impactful. Ultimately, this connection enhances the reader's engagement with the story's overall message.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the importance of new beginnings and to accentuate the theme in the story. The theme is that one must overcome hardships and actively seek new beginnings. The springtime is a clear representation of such a new beginning, a time of renewal and growth. So, the new beginning of spring will allow her to start all over again on the driver’s test with fresh hope. Also, the author uses the paragraph to show the symbolic qualities of everyday things, infusing them with deeper meaning. Just as the hibiscus reminded her of home life, the geese will remind her of springtime and the cyclical nature of life, reinforcing the idea that endings are followed by new starts.

In the story "The Winter Hibiscus," the author Minfong Ho concludes the story with that paragraph because it was a way of saying she's going to forget about what happened in the past with her failing her test and she's going to do better the next time. It's like the author is saying she will be reborn again, just like the hibiscus when the spring comes. Through the story, Saeng had to adjust to a new environment, just like the hibiscus had to endure the winter. And the hibiscus, with its quiet strength, inspired Saeng to do well where she's at. So it’s a new beginning for Saeng, after all her learning from the hibiscus about resilience and the promise of a new season.

It’s kind of like a theme for the story. The hibiscus inspires her to want to do things, serving as a recurring symbol of her inner drive. I guess it brings memories of her home country and makes her want to try new things, providing a comforting link to her past. This is significant to the story because it shows you how important the hibiscus was to Saeng, acting as a catalyst for her personal growth and adaptation to her new environment. The flower’s presence consistently motivates her to move forward, connecting her heritage with her future aspirations in a meaningful way.

I think the author chose to end the story this way to show that the girl is remembering her past and being at ease; with the flower, she finds a sense of peace and comfort. The writer wants to convey that no matter what you are used to, you can find something that can bring you happiness and a sense of focus, a small anchor in a changing world. This conclusion emphasizes that personal solace and motivation can be discovered in simple, familiar things, allowing one to navigate new challenges with a clearer mind and a more determined spirit.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize her renewed resolve; she is determined to pass that test and is not going to give up until she passes it. This final thought underscores a significant shift in her character, moving from disappointment to a firm commitment to persevere. It highlights the theme of resilience, showing that her initial failure has not defeated her but has instead strengthened her will to try again and ultimately achieve her goal, no matter the obstacles she may face in the future.

The reason why I feel the author ended the story with this paragraph is because she is showing how the character has matured and how the character grew in her circumstance, learning from her experiences. This shows that because you failed once doesn’t mean you’re going to fail again; it is a lesson in persistence. Also, it’s okay to feel out of place; there is always going to be a time in life where a new beginning is going to start, so it is your choice to take that chance or be stuck in your own ways, but the decision is always up to you. The ending thus serves as a powerful reminder of personal agency and the potential for growth that comes from embracing change rather than fearing it.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, she ends the story by saying, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. ‘I-I failed the test’.” As many kids do, Saeng failed her driving test and she is crucially upset about it. Nobody wants to fail at something and it is almost a humiliating experience to have failed at a test, especially knowing that others have already successfully passed. With the quote in the introduction paragraph, or the one in the question, it was written as a sign of symbolism. When the geese return back north, it is to show that they are ready to “start over” again or to “try again.” When the hibiscus is budding it is trying to “start life” again. Saeng seeing objects doing things over and over again empowers her to want to succeed and try again. She realizes it is just a part of life and that in order to succeed you have to fail. Minfong concludes with that quote because she understands that no matter what the obstacle, you must press forward and keep trying in order to succeed. She realizes success can only come from hard work and commitment, and that that is what makes a great, strong individual, capable of overcoming adversity through resilience and hope.

The reason why the author concludes the paragraph with that sentence is because he wants to let the reader know that it's not over. He wants the reader to understand that @ORGANIZATION1 will not forget what has happened. The author is emphasizing that the events described are part of a larger, ongoing cycle, and he intends for the reader to feel certain that all of this will inevitably happen again in the future, reinforcing a sense of unresolved tension and continuity.

The author concludes the ending as “I will take that test again,” meaning that the difficult things she is going through now are going to happen again, but next time she will be more prepared. Saeng has a very difficult time moving to another country and getting comfortable in the new place, though her mother supports her as she goes through the winter. The hibiscus that she bought is a powerful symbol that represents more than itself; in this text, "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho shows that this hibiscus, which she bought during her worst time, became her companion through the harsh season. In the last paragraph of the story, the author expresses the idea that “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” Saeng is thinking of the future and how she “vowed silently to herself in the spring.” She can’t wait until winter is over and is just waiting for the spring to come, symbolizing her hope and resilience for a new beginning.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to tell us what the character plans to do once she gets back in the spring. That means when she returns, she will then be taking care of the plants and tending to the garden. The author conveys her anticipation for the snow to melt and for everything to become new and alive again. This final thought is what the author is communicating through the story's ending, providing a clear sense of the character's intentions and hopes for the coming season, which brings the narrative to a hopeful and forward-looking close.

I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph to ensure the reader understands that she will try again. Also, the author concludes the story this way to show the reader that no matter where you go in life, there will always be something or someone there to assure you and provide support. The author also wanted the reader to feel a sense of similarity to the character, meaning that no matter how out of place you might feel, there is always something you can relate to that can offer comfort and a sense of belonging, which ultimately provides a reassuring and universal message for the conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph so that we, the readers, become more interested in his upcoming book, or so that we feel more excited about the narrative's potential continuation. This ending is crafted to generate curiosity and anticipation, leaving the audience wanting to know more about what happens next to the characters and the world that has been established, thereby creating a compelling hook for future works.

In this story, the author decides to end with the paragraph, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because Saeng wants to take the test when everything is in its proper season. For example, she wants everything she likes in her environment to be present, such as the flowers blooming, the geese returning, and the weather being warm. Another reason why the author ends the story with that paragraph is that Saeng wants her environment to resemble the one from her home country, where, for instance, there was no snow and it was like springtime all year round. This connection to her homeland provides her with the comfort and confidence she needs to face the challenge again, which is why the author chose to conclude the story with that particular paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is comforted by the memories of her homeland and deeply appreciates the beauty of tropical plants. She believes that since it is winter and the hibiscus is not budding, she cannot pass the test until it is. The line, "almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of before had become through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now," shows how much she truly believes in the beauty of her homeland and the tropical plants. She is thinking back to other times where things have been strange during the winter but became better in the spring and in other seasons when the plants are budding. Therefore, she believes that she will actually pass the driver's test when she feels comfortable and when the plants have budded, signaling a time of renewal and familiarity.

The geese flying south for the winter and the hibiscus budding are normal, accustomed things to Saeng. The author wanted to conclude the story with this to show that Saeng felt comfort in things that were familiar to her. Saeng wanted to have the geese and the hibiscus there to feel more comfortable and secure while taking her driving test. This is because Saeng still longs for home and does not quite feel like she fits in the U.S. The hibiscus gives her that comforting feeling, as if she is home again in Vietnam; she still feels homesick because she wants things to be how they were. The plants in the greenhouse, along with the disappointment of failing her driving test, bring her to the emotional state that she was in. In the second to last paragraph, the author talks about the feeling of repetition Saeng has when seeing the V formation of geese, a pattern she recognizes. Saeng feels that in the winter she will not have the same comfort as when she can see the hibiscus and the geese flying overhead. The text mentions that when Saeng first arrived in this new location, she had nothing that was familiar to her, but now she gets that feeling of familiarity from the geese and plants. The author concluding by saying Saeng will take her driving test when the winter ends is a good closing because it gives you insight into Saeng's resolve and her plan to try again when conditions feel right.

I think the author concludes with the sentence, "‘when they come back,’ Saeng vowed to herself, ‘in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again’" because it was winter and the driving test facility or her school was closed. When the geese come back, it will be spring, so it will be time for things to reopen and for life to resume its normal pace. I think that the seasonal change signals a new beginning and a practical opportunity for her to retake the test, which is the reason for the author's chosen ending.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with an ending that seems odd at first glance: “‘when they come back,’ Saeng vowed silently to herself, ‘in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.’” I believe that beyond the literal meaning, the author is showing how Saeng is gradually adapting to the new country. By failing her driver’s test, she also experienced a failure in adapting to and accepting the new country. However, by vowing to try again, it also shows that she is willing to give the country another chance. The line, “She found she was still too shaky to say the words at home,” indicates that she still did not consider this new country her home and was still emotionally stuck on her past. The final vow represents a small but significant step towards acceptance and a future attempt at integration.

The author concludes this story in the paragraph to show that Saeng won't stop, just because she failed one first time. It also shows that she is not going to let certain things keep her down. Her vow to take the test again reveals a resilient character who learns from setbacks rather than being defeated by them. This final thought leaves the reader with a clear understanding of her persistent and hopeful nature, emphasizing that her initial failure is not the end of her efforts but a step toward future success.

The last sentence of a story is usually the most meaningful. I believe the author ended the story this way for many reasons. For example, I think the author did this to leave the reader with a strong sense of determination. I will take that test again.” This shows that in spring, the new beginning of life, she will take the test. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” made a good choice to conclude the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This paragraph hints to the reader that Saeng intends to combine her new and old lives. Her old life is represented by the hibiscus; she used to know the constants from back home. The geese symbolize her new life; they have become “almost familiar to her now.” The obstacle she faces is passing the driving test. The author implies that in the spring, when the old and new parts of Saeng’s life are combined, Saeng will be able to overcome her “obstacle,” and all will be well. With the geese in the ground, Saeng’s life will have come full circle, achieving a sense of harmony and resolution.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is important when she says when the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she says she will take that test again and to tell the reader when she will take that test again. The paragraph serves to specify the timing of her renewed attempt, connecting it to a season of renewal and growth. This timing gives context to her promise, making it more concrete and meaningful for the reader. That’s why it is in the story, as it provides a clear and hopeful resolution to her current challenge.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it emphasizes that Saeng is willing to retake the test when it comes back. I also think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the story the second to last paragraph says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This sentence shows me that Saeng is slowly getting used to the new place. Also how she is changing her mind about the plant and the fact that even though it’s not the same, it can still have meaning. Therefore, I think the author made a good choice in ending the story with this paragraph, as it beautifully captures her journey toward acceptance and her resolve to try again.

The last paragraph states “in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again.” I believe the author has ended with that paragraph to state the fact that when her new home is like her old home, with the return of warmth and familiar natural cycles, maybe she will feel more confident and more in her place, instead of the cold winter which was the total opposite of where she used to live. The feeling of her old home, recreated in her new home through the budding hibiscus and migrating geese, will make her more positive and comfortable. So then she will take the test feeling at home and pass, having found a sense of belonging that was previously missing.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author expresses how the girl believes that with her memories, and once she changes and adapts to the culture, that is when she will have the courage to retake the test she failed that day. Saeng misses her home so much and she can’t grasp that there are similarities between her new home and her old home until she has a moment of realization. “She realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” Saeng didn’t want to accept the move, but noticing that she won’t forget any old memories, she starts to take on new ones. At first everything was so different, but now she is starting to remember things about her new home, which is a sign of comfort to her. Her earlier emotional state is shown when “she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again." With Saeng’s feelings of the change, the ending paragraph lets the reader know that there is hope for moving on in her new home. She is gradually starting to gain confidence from these small familiarities, and she knows when she does she can take her test and succeed at it. The author shows how good change can be if you are willing to adapt. Everything might not always be as perfect as you know it to be, but your courage will make a happy home with new and old memories, as Saeng starts to realize during the last paragraph, understanding that growth takes time.

The author merely states the obvious within this story of shortness. This excerpt mainly means that when spring arrives, she will return to the greenhouse or the area with all the plants, seeking a connection to the life she once knew. When she gets there, the girl will attempt to acquire the plant that grows wild in her home country and bring it to her new home, hoping to cultivate a piece of her past in her present environment. This simple act symbolizes her desire to bridge the gap between her old life and her new one, finding comfort in the familiar.

The reason the author concludes the story with that kind of paragraph, I think he’s trying to show Saeng as the type of person to not give up and always to keep growing, just like the resilient hibiscus plant. Saeng notices that she will still have next season, a new beginning, when the plant has grown and the geese fly into a distinctive V again, signaling that time and patience bring adaptation and new opportunities for success.

Minfong Ho concludes the story with this paragraph to show how Saeng feels and the resolve she has found. In the paragraph, Saeng saying "I will take that test again" means she will go through the same challenging experience, but next time with renewed strength and perspective. This declaration signifies her determination to face her fears again, not to avoid the difficulty, but to conquer it with the hope and personal growth she has discovered through the changing seasons and the symbolic hibiscus.

The author ends the story this way to show that there can always be a happy ending. The geese came back, which was a hopeful sign she had been waiting for, and the girl was happy because of it. This simple, joyful return provides a sense of closure and reinforces the idea that positive outcomes are always possible, even after a period of difficulty or waiting. The narrative concludes on this uplifting note, affirming the theme of persistent hope.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph because these are all things that she isn't going to give up on. She is trying to say that when everything she believes in succeeds, that is when she is going to take her driving test. Her mother says that the flower is never going to give up and it is strong enough to live through the winter. The geese are going to always come back. That is exactly what she is going to do with her test; she is not going to give up on the test, she is going to keep trying until she passes, drawing strength from these enduring symbols of resilience.

Saeng feels more comfortable in the spring because it reminds her of home. She probably never experienced snow or winter before, so nothing in this time of year reminds her of her past life. In the spring it does because the geese return and the hibiscus grow again, making everything feel like it is her home again. Confidence is what she receives when spring comes again, restoring her spirit and providing a familiar comfort in her new environment. This seasonal change is crucial for her sense of belonging and emotional well-being.

The author concludes the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” with that paragraph because it sums up everything the hibiscus has given Saeng for strength and courage. Just like the hibiscus, Saeng felt out of place in this new country and the hibiscus helps her realize the importance of adapting for her survival in order to live happily. She can’t always be dwelling in the past but must learn to like where she lives now. Therefore, when the author writes, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it is a direct symbol of Saeng budding or opening her mind to the new ways, like learning to drive, and embracing her future.

I believe the author of “Winter Hibiscus” used this for the last paragraph because it is saying when she sees that hibiscus it will give her memories of home again which will bring encouragement for the test. The geese symbolize Saeng's determination to pass the test and try in the new country. Saeng explains, “she lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.” This quote creates a vivid image that lets me know Saeng will really go and take that test when she has encouragement from not only the geese but the hibiscus also, uniting these symbols into a single source of resolve.

The author concludes with that paragraph because it is in a way letting you know that everythingís going to be alright. It gives you a sense of hope, that everything is going to be alright with her, providing a comforting and optimistic closure to her story. Also, that she is going to start making the best out of life, embracing her new circumstances with renewed determination. I believe itís saying to that is why I think the author concludes with that paragraph, as it perfectly encapsulates her journey toward acceptance and a positive future.

The Author uses this paragraph to conclude the Story because it shows how Saeng wants to adapt to this country and she is allready beging to understand it and like it. Saeng said that when the tree she bought starts budding she will take the test over.
