The author didnít think that Saeng was ready to take the test until she knew more about it and felt more settled. Saeng had a lot on her mind of gardening since she didnít have any friends in school she didnít want to go their the would have nobody to talk to, which added to her anxiety and isolation. its good that Saeng vowed because she will never know if she would do good or bad without at least making the attempt. So the author realized that Saeng will take the test and pass, showing her growth and newfound resilience in facing the challenges of her new country.

The author concludes with this paragraph mostly because she wants to emphasize her memoreies of her homeland by saying that she would take the test again driving the next spring. This is due to that fact that she knows as soon as spring comes back there will be a lot of memories coming back to her since during spring animals come out and trees blossom. This seasonal renewal makes it all beautiful for her to take the test again with support from her memories of her country, using the familiar beauty of nature as a source of strength and confidence for her future endeavors.

After reading the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author ends the story in a unique way that demonstrates a will to survive. For example, in the text the author writes and explains how the plant “dok faeng-noi” has adapted to its cold environment in a way that is different from the hibiscus plants back at home. This demonstrates the idea of survival by the fact that in the past this plant migrated to a place that seemed warm at the time, but when cold seasons arrived, it found ways to change itself and adapt, all based on the instinct to survive. Another example in the text is the author describing Saeng telling herself that in the spring she will try and take the test again. This demonstrates the will to survive because when Saeng failed the test she felt a sense of melancholy and failure. The fact that she had the courage to prepare for the test in spring shows how a human being wants to live, and for her to live in a new country she must adapt by passing that test to become a survivor, mirroring the plant's resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the story about snows on the roads. He shows people how to watch where they are going by describing the careful steps one must take through the deep snow. The imagery of the snowstorm serves as a metaphor for the challenges he faces, and navigating the snowy path represents his journey through difficulty. In conclusion, the paragraph would show he made it through the snow storm, symbolizing his ultimate perseverance and survival against the harsh elements he encountered.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng vows to herself that in the spring, when the snow melts and geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then she will take the test again. The author concludes with this paragraph because the hibiscus brings her comfort from home and confidence, as noted in the line “Almost familiar to her now.” This quote from the story shows that things are starting to feel right and she is starting to feel comforted by making her realize that where she is living now can be similar to where she used to live. When around the hibiscus it brings back memories of the flowers that they used to have where they lived. Both the mother and the daughter appreciate the flower they found because it is similar to what they had back home. For example, in the story the mother says, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here.” This shows that they appreciate its similarity to the old hibiscus while also respecting its new strength. In conclusion, the author concludes this story with that paragraph because it helps readers to understand the importance of the girl's memory of where she used to live and how it fuels her hope for the future.

The author chooses this end to show that Saeng hasn't given up on how she is living yet. It shows that even though she really loved her hometown, and feels and remembers a lot back then, she is determined to move forward. She had taken the test and failed, and living where she was living then just seemed too much pressure on her. Although she hasn't quite adapted thoroughly she will try her best to surmount situations that are brought upon her. It gives the reader hope by ending the story like this, instead of just leaving the reader at she bought a flower after failing a test and moves on with her life. For example, when she failed the test she seemed distressed and very angry. “I—I failed the test,” Saeng said. For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. It angered Saeng how she had to leave her happy past life for one that is different and challenging. When faced with a challenge, extreme emotional situations occur. Saeng just needed hope and the author chooses this to portray to the reader that there is a chance of hope after hardship.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author Minfong Ho ends the story as she does for many reasons, primarily to emphasize themes of adaptation and resilience. The final paragraph serves to crystallize Saeng's internal resolve, connecting her personal journey to the symbolic winter hibiscus that endures the cold. This conclusion allows the reader to see the parallel between the plant's survival and Saeng's own determination to persevere in her new environment, providing a poignant and cohesive end to her narrative arc.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it wraps it all up and sums it into one final, cohesive thought. It is explaining that she is looking forward to the spring when the hibiscus is budding, seeing this as a natural endpoint for her current struggles and the beginning of a new, hopeful chapter in her life.

The reason why at the end of the story she ended it with the vow to take the test again in the spring is because she is making the statement that the birds have a place where they live all the time and the plant can live there and survive. She is saying she can, too, if she tries, so she will wait until the birds come back and the plant buds, signaling life is thriving in her new home. When everything seems okay then, she will be able to take the test because she will understand and believe she will feel safer and a lot more prepared for the challenge ahead.

The author ended the story like this for a couple of main reasons. First of all, he ended the story to make the readers think about what will happen if there is a part two, leaving them with a sense of curiosity. Secondly, he ended it this way so he could potentially make a part two, leaving the narrative door open for future developments. That is the way he chose to conclude the story, providing a conclusion that feels complete yet suggests more could follow.

She vowed this because just as the geese would return, she shall also return to face her challenges. Also, as the geese test themselves to learn and grow on their journey, she would do the same. Furthermore, she saw the test of love, survival, and family tradition as something she would know was her destiny, much like the geese knowing they must return. For example, they come to raise their young for the journey they shall face, and this helps them realize they will always come back because their lives started there, to always escape the cold and the harm from mankind. The winter months are very harsh there, so they know that they have to leave just to survive. Through this, she learns the profound lessons of family, freedom, life, and survival, finding her own path forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the character made a commitment to himself of taking the test all over again. He probably said that because there is always a next time for everything, and failure is not a permanent state. Mostly the reason he said it was to remind himself that there is always another try for everything, a chance to improve and succeed. Finally, that most people should know that everyone gets a second chance, and this hope is what the conclusion is meant to impart to the reader.

The author concludes the story like this because the seasons are changing and they are finishing their cycle and starting a new one. This natural progression mirrors the completion of the narrative's own arc. Thus I think this is a good way to end a story like this because it kind of sets a mood and a feel at the end of the story, providing a sense of closure and a hint of new beginnings that resonates with the reader long after the final page is turned.

The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with this paragraph because it powerfully conveys the central theme of the story, which is adjusting to changes in life. So many things have changed for Saeng and she hasn’t fully adjusted yet to the way of life in her new country. Yet she learns that she needs to be determined to adapt and survive like the hibiscus plant does. The text states, “In the spring, when this hibiscus is budding,” highlighting the promise of renewal. The hibiscus teaches Saeng to never give up, just as the hibiscus doesn’t give up and survives during the harsh winter. She learns to be determined, and even though she failed her driving test the first time, her memories have helped her, and she is going to go for it again. These ideas are concentrated in the last paragraph because they perfectly summarize the idea of not giving up even if you feel out of place. She has slowly gotten used to this new place and recognizes the seasons now, internalizing this final, hopeful thought as she looks toward the future.

The author includes this passage to set a specific tone and to talk about how the characters or elements within the story appear. Also, that little paragraph can serve to start another book or to get you into studying things mentioned in the narrative. It could also function to compare your own life with the life of the geese described in the text, creating a personal connection for the reader. Like explaining what hardships you went through, it invites reflection on one's own journey and struggles, making the story's message more universal and impactful in its conclusion.

The author chooses to end this story like this for many reasons that tie together the narrative's core themes. Throughout the story, the author gives you hints of Saeng being homesick and struggling with her new environment. He relates this to the flower being strong enough to survive the winter months, a metaphor for her own resilience. Meaning she’ll survive also, despite the challenges. Although the flower isn’t exactly the same as she had at home, change is inevitable and at least she could hold on to that small piece of familiarity. So I believe the author decides to end the story with this reflection to say just like the plant she’ll survive and try to adjust in the spring, mirroring her renewed effort with her driving test and her overall journey toward adaptation.

The author concluded the narrative in that manner because he was responsible for evaluating the content written. The score was determined by the level of writing and how well the key ideas were expressed. He was surprised to find the elements he had to assess were separated by their quality, thereby setting up a need for a clear judgment. Please give one a high score if it will suit all the criteria up to the end, as the author concludes the matter based on this final assessment.

I believe that the author included this paragraph to show that Saeng didn't give up, to illustrate that she kept trying after she failed. This is evident when Saeng said to her mother, "I failed the test," yet her tone was not one of defeat. The author's intent was also to make her sound proud and happy to try the test over again, highlighting her resilient spirit. This moment resonates personally, as I have also failed tests and declared I would retake them, but unlike me, Saeng actually followed through with her resolve. Therefore, the author put that detail in the story specifically to show how determined Saeng was going to sound, emphasizing her unwavering perseverance and commitment to her goal.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it lets the reader know that there is still a chance for Saeng; she is not giving up on herself or the test. While reading you will find that Saeng is comforted by memories of her homeland, and obviously this move to another country was hard on her, creating a sense of displacement. In the story the author writes, “It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center- just as she had known it would feel.” The familiar feeling and scent of the hibiscus flower comforted her, serving as a tangible link to her past. She then proceeded to purchase the plant, because she failed the test she needed something to lift her spirits back up once again and provide hope. The author decided to end the story with Saeng stating that once “this hibiscus plant is budding, then I will take that test again” because as the reader should have learned by now, the hibiscus plant has been the only positive aspect in her life since the move, symbolizing resilience. It is giving her motivation to once again take the driver’s test, and it is also letting the reader know that Saeng is not giving up, ending the narrative on a note of quiet determination and future promise.

Minfong Ho concluded the story “Winter Hibiscus” with a strong paragraph to show the passion and will of Saeng in her new home to complete the test. When the closing sentences state that Saeng “vowed” to pass the test, it shows her fierce determination to fight and overcome her setback. This will could be from the memories of her grandmother and the flowers that reminded her so closely of her old home, providing her with inner strength. Saeng's courage to face her homesickness is the seed of the story, and by ending it with such a bold statement, Minfong Ho blooms this seemingly sad tale into a story of willpower and drive to pass her test. “Winter Hibiscus” is a passage of heartache, despair, and yearning for a past life, capturing the immigrant experience. By closing the story with the uplifting promise from Saeng, Minfong Ho puts a hopeful and happy ending to a possibly sad tale, transforming it into a narrative of personal triumph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the season is ending and also the story is ending, providing a natural sense of closure. The narrative has followed Saeng through a period of struggle and adjustment, and as winter gives way to spring, it mirrors the cycle of her own experiences. This parallel between the changing seasons and the arc of the story allows for a fitting conclusion that feels both inevitable and complete, tying the external environment to the internal resolution of the character.

The author concludes the story with this type of paragraph because the author knows it’s bound to happen again, suggesting a cycle of effort and renewal. I know this because in that paragraph it says “in the spring… I will take this test again,” indicating her preparation for a future attempt. She is just preparing herself mentally for next year, using the interim time to gather her strength and resolve. This forward-looking statement shows that she views her failure not as a final endpoint but as a temporary setback, which is why I think this paragraph ended the story on a note of anticipation and continued effort.

Saeng was thinking to herself after dinner about the test, reflecting on her previous attempt. She knew deep down that she could do much better than before, having learned from her mistakes. And she made a vowed to herself, a silent promise, saying that once winter finally ends and the first signs of spring start to appear, she would take the test again. This time, with renewed determination and focus, she will pass it with flying colors, proving her capability to herself and her family.

Saeng wants to take the test again when it is beautiful out and the hibiscus is buddy, its vibrant petals a symbol of hope. The plant, in its full bloom, shows the beautiful achievement of passing the test, a vision of success. The plant will help her past the test by being strong, tough, and nicely finished, qualities she aspires to embody. These characteristics reprecent the girl and the flower, a shared resilience. The day was a good day, calm and clear, and she wants to take the test on the same day to capture that feeling. The plant was strong and tought, having weathered the cold. This represents the girl in that time she didn’t pass, yet she endured. She told her mother about her failure and was very understandig about it, receiving comfort instead of criticism. The plant represents beautiful things, just as the geese flying overhead represent beautiful things and new journeys. The girl wants to do that on that time of day and thinks she will get it next time, her confidence growing. When she completes and past her test she wants to come home to the beautiful surroundings to remember that day forever. The author concluded with that statement to represent the importance of the plant and the surroundings of when she wants to past the test, tying her success to the natural world.

The author might have concluded the story with that paragraph, because she wanted to remind the reader how sincearl, "Saeng" was to the hibiscus flower, seeing it as more than just a plant. I say this because through out the story Saeng was very compassionate about the flower, caring for it with great tenderness. I think she felt as through she could relate to the flower, seeing her own struggles and hopes reflected in its delicate yet persistent nature, which underscores the story's emotional core.

The author ends with this paragraph because it symbolizes a new beggining, a chance for renewal. Saeng says, “I — I failed the test,” her voice heavy with disappointment. She is also really sad, feeling the weight of her setback, but she is making a commitment to get a fresh start on life, just like how the world does every spring, shedding the old for the new. The theme of the story is when life seems hard take a new approach, to persevere and try again. She intends to retake the drivers test, using this resolution as her first step forward into a brighter future.

The author concludes the story with this to show that Saeng will be ready to take the test in time, but not immediately. She first has to grow and adapt to the new surroundings, a process that requires patience. Just like the hibiscus flower and the geese, which both undergo transitions. The hibiscus flower now has to adapt to its new surroundings outside of the store, facing the elements directly. The geese are adapting to the surroundings by flying south for the winter, following an innate rhythm. Saeng needs to still learn more and adapt before she can pass her drivers test, acquiring new skills and confidence. By ending the story with this paragraph it shows that Saeng realizes what she needs to do, achieving a moment of clarity. She needs to stop thinking about where she used to live and begin her new life in a new country, putting down roots much like the hibiscus in her garden.

Minfong Ho ended her story "Winter Hibiscus" with an optimistic sentence. She concluded it this way because the main character of the story was beginning to lose hope after failing her driving test. Saeng decided to retake the driving test when her hibiscus flower was blooming. This flower reminds her of her past life in Vietnam with her grandmother, providing her with a sense of comfort and connection. "Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother's long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb". She preferred her life in Vietnam than hers in the United States. She was going to wait until "this hibiscus is budding," so she can feel more comfortable and happy, using that moment as a signal to try again. The author wanted to end it so Saeng would be happy and looking forward to the future with renewed determination.

The author ended the story with that optimistic note because she wants to give hope to the reader that you should never give up on any thing, always keep trying no matter the setback. Also it ends on a good note; if it was a sad ending, like the character staying up in her room crying, that would not be a good conclusion. This ending gives hope to the reader and it also tells the reader the importance of practice. This is because when spring comes to an end the lady is going to practice driving so when she takes the test again she won't fail. Also the girl is getting happier at the end and that positive emotion makes the reader happy as well. So in conclusion that ending for the story was a good choice for many reasons, like making the reader happy, giving the reader courage to never give up, and to practice something if you fail it the first time. The ending also encourages one to help your mother when she is planting or digging up plants, showing the value of family support.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph in order to develop the theme and to project what the main character will do after she plants the hibiscus, I believe that the theme of this story is adjusting to changes in life and the author builds upon this theme in the final paragraph. In the ending paragraph, the author writes, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author demonstrates how Saeng learns to adjust when things change in her life, using the memory of her homeland as a source of strength. In this instance, Saeng fails her driver’s test and to deal with this setback, she buys a hibiscus to remind her of her homeland and her grandmother. The hibiscus symbolizes a new start for her, a promise of renewal that gives her the courage to face the test once the geese return and the seasons change.

So she did not forget to take the test again. The memory of the hibiscus and its connection to her past and her grandmother served as a constant, gentle reminder of her resolve. It was this symbol of hope and continuity that reinforced her decision to try again when the conditions felt right, ensuring her initial failure would not be her final outcome. This quiet determination highlights her growing resilience and her commitment to building a new life without abandoning the old.

Saeng did not give up on herself after failing the driving test. She said she would take it over again, believing that with persistence she might pass it. You will not always pass on your first try; it takes a while sometimes, and success often requires multiple attempts. Saeng serves to encourage you to never to give up just cause you did not get it on your first time. She also builds confidence in herself by deciding to try again, showing that self-belief is crucial for overcoming obstacles. That is why the author concluded the story that way, to emphasize the importance of resilience and the power of a positive, forward-looking attitude.

The author ended the story with the paragraph of Saeng vowing to retake the test in the spring because he wanted to show that the geese and the hibiscus plant represent a sort of rebirth or revival to Saeng. He wanted to end the story on a positive note. Spring is an archetypal season of birth and growing, a time for new beginnings. Saeng saw the hibiscus after she failed the first test, and it took her memories back to Vietnam, which comforted her. She believes that maybe when she sees the plant flourishing and the geese returning, she will experience that same revival again, giving her the hope and strength needed to try once more.

The author concludes the story with the last paragraph because Saeng failed the test at the beginning of the story. After going through the botanical gardens and learning new things about the plants, it is natural for Saeng to decide to take the test again in the spring, which is the end of the story. This is because Saeng learned that she has to get used to living in her new location. The plant reminded her of her home, and when she saw the geese fly in the "V" formation, it was the same as back in Vietnam. She realized that some things remain constant, and she has to take that driver's test again in order to get used to living with all of its changes. Ending the story with her taking the test in spring is fitting because the geese will come back and the hibiscus is budding, symbolizing a new beginning for them as well as for Saeng.

The author ends the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is willing to try again to get a plant that will remind her of her grandmother and remind her of her old home, a place she cannot go back to one day. She wants to see the real flower she loves and not the fake one, so she is motivated to persevere. By seeking out the genuine hibiscus, she is reconnecting with her past and finding a source of authentic comfort in her new life, which gives her the resolve to continue striving.

In “Winter Hibiscus” the author concludes the story the way he does to show that Saeng isn’t giving up. In the spring she will see the plant bloom and remember her home, which will help her not feel as homesick. The quote, “Plants she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world,” shows that when she sees familiar plants she is reminded of home. So in the spring when her plant blooms, she will see it and feel more comforted and more at home, which will help her find the strength to pass the driving test. So as the plant blooms, so does her comfort level and her determination to succeed in her new environment.

The original text fragment appears to describe a scene where snow was falling, and it was cold outside for the characters. Then the snow started to melt, suggesting a shift in the weather or the arrival of a warmer season. This change in the environment could symbolize a transition or the end of a difficult period, mirroring the emotional thaw a character might be experiencing. The melting snow signifies that the harsh conditions are passing, paving the way for new beginnings and hope.

He concluded the story with that sentence because it powerfully conveyed that she had learned a profound lesson in life. All the way back home, where she originally came from, she missed her friends like Ibet and the familiar sight of her mother working out in the garden during this time of year when it is cold. I guess they are poor in one way, lacking certain material comforts, yet rich in the memories of their homeland. In conclusion, the author chose this sentence because it sounds like she learned a lesson in life and is even starting all over again, but now with a better understanding and a wiser perspective on her own journey and learning.

Saeng says this in the paragraph because she wants to make her mother proud of her, and therefore she is determined to take the test again after winter. Her failure on the first attempt was disappointing, but it has only strengthened her resolve to succeed. She feels a deep sense of duty and love for her mother, who has sacrificed so much for her family's new life. This motivation fuels her decision to prepare more thoroughly and face the challenge once more when the season changes, demonstrating her resilience and commitment to honoring her mother's hopes.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it highlights her will power and her deep connection to the hibiscus. She loves the hibiscus, and what better way to end the story than by having her compare herself to this resilient plant? When she says, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” she is drawing a parallel. The current snow is slowing the hibiscus down, just as her failure is temporarily slowing her down. So she plans to use this time to read and prepare, so that when the spring arrives and the hibiscus finally buds, she too will be ready to bud by passing her test and beginning a new phase of growth.

In the article, the author concludes the story with Saeng vowing to herself that “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is bidding, then I will take that test again” because the spring season and the hibiscus plant strongly remind her of home. For example, in the article, she gets shaky because she cannot speak of home directly, as she misses it too much. To cope with this longing, she finds objects that remind her of it, like a plant she discovers called dok faeng-noi. It is not the exact plant from her homeland, but she cherishes it as a tangible connection to where she comes from. In conclusion, Saeng finds a plant and appreciates the spring because they evoke the comfort of home, prompting us to consider what in our own lives reminds us of the places and people we hold dear.

The reason that the author chose to end this story with this paragraph is to tell the reader that things get better as time goes on and that patience is a virtue. Saeng failed the driver’s test because she was not ready, much like a flower that attempts to bloom before its time. The author is conveying that growth cannot be rushed and that everyone develops at their own pace. With patience and continued effort, good things will eventually come your way, just as the hibiscus will bloom beautifully when the right season arrives. This message of hope and perseverance provides a comforting and meaningful conclusion to Saeng's story.

The author chose to conclude the paragraph with the sentence "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring , when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because it shows how the strength of the hibiscus is directly related to Saeng's own inner strength. In the story, after failing her driver's test, Saeng finds comfort in discovering a hibiscus native to her homeland. When she gets home, her mother observes, "I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here." This comment shows that Saeng is faltering in her new foreign country, feeling out of place and discouraged. The final quote effectively sums up that Saeng draws strength from the resilience of the flowers, almost thinking to herself that if this flower can survive and even bloom in a land far away from its original home, then why can't she? This parallel between the plant's endurance and her own resolve provides a powerful conclusion to her emotional journey.

When she is ready and feels more capable, she is saying she will take the test again. She decides that when she is prepared, skilled, and the world outside is nice and beautiful, then she will have the confidence she needs to attempt the test once more. The author was trying to tell us how she felt about letting her mom down, conveying a sense of disappointment and a desire to redeem herself. This resolution highlights her commitment to improving and not giving up, ultimately showing her determination to succeed for both herself and her family.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it's important to the story's central theme of adaptation. It also serves to close the story up in a satisfying and meaningful way. It is explaining that the girl is starting to adjust to the new area and is going to try harder to get along well there. So by saying she's going to take the test again, it means she's going to look at her challenges in a new way, with renewed hope and perspective. The author placed this resolution at the end to make sense of everything that happened and to show clearly that the girl had changed, ending the narrative on a note of personal growth and forward-looking optimism.

In the short story “The Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with this paragraph because the author felt as though Saeng would be ready to take the test at that particular time. The spring season, symbolizing renewal and growth, represents the point when Saeng will have gathered enough strength and confidence from her surroundings. This timing aligns with the natural cycle of the hibiscus plant, which she identifies with, suggesting that her personal readiness is intertwined with this period of new beginnings. Therefore, the ending connects her personal resolve to the symbolic power of the changing seasons.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is showing she still has hope for the future. The hardy hibiscus gives her hope and strength, serving as a living symbol of resilience. In the spring, she will take her test again and will hope to pass it, using the flower's endurance as a model for her own perseverance. This is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, to leave the reader with a sense of optimistic determination and the belief that Saeng will continue to strive for her goals despite initial setbacks.

In the last paragraph of "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes by saying "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". I think the author concludes with this quote because it shows her determination to overcome this obstacle. For Saeng, the hibiscus represents comfort and the ability to overcome challenges, serving as a symbol of resilience. Saeng is very strong and she believes in that determination which comes from her past and her cultural roots. The author concluded with that because it shows Saeng’s determination and her resolve to try again when conditions are more favorable, thus providing a powerful and hopeful ending to her story.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author ends the story with that paragraph to show how meaningful that flower is to Saeng. The text stated, "in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the 'winter Hibiscus' into it." This shows the reader that it is very meaningful to Saeng to have this plant in her garden, as the act of planting it is done with great care and significance. Also, by having that conclusion statement, it helps the reader understand her growing affection for her new country and the process of putting down roots. Furthermore, the conclusion paragraph shows comfort at a time of disappointment, offering her solace. In the story it said, "Its flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus." This also shows the deep connection between Saeng and the flower and how it helps her through everything, mirroring her own strength and endurance in a new environment.

The reason I think she added this is because she needs time to grow, just like the plant, before she takes the test again. Sometimes you need more time and experience to pass your test, as personal growth is essential. Going through school teaches more than the subjects we need to know; it helps us grow up and learn how to understand life more deeply. I know myself, as a tenth grader, that I understand life more than I did in first grade, which shows how time brings maturity. She still has a lot of growing to do mentally about her past and present, and this period of waiting is necessary for her to become ready to face her challenge with renewed strength and perspective.

I believe that the author ended the story with this line to show that hope for the girl was still there and that the flower had inspired her a great deal. When she says "when they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again", she specifically chose this time for her to start over and try again, just as everything else mentioned is being reborn. When it says, "and this hibiscus is budding", it shows that the flower is blooming again, with a fresh start and a new beginning, just as she would try to do when she attempts to succeed at passing the test she must pass. Also, the tone in which she said this showed hope; she was hopeful and determined that next time around she would certainly pass, demonstrating her positive outlook and inner resolve for the future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that while this particular tale is over, Saeng’s life will continue on its journey. The paragraph provides closure for the reader, as it resolves the immediate conflict, and also explains that in time Saeng will take the test again, once she has further adapted to the new culture and feels more settled. This ending suggests a future beyond the narrative, indicating that her story of adjustment and personal growth is ongoing and that she is moving forward with a plan and a sense of hope for what is to come in her life in this new place.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants her to be successful and do good, reinforcing the central theme of perseverance and hope that has been developed throughout the narrative. This final moment serves to solidify the character's resolve, ensuring the reader is left with a clear sense of her positive trajectory and moral compass. It is a deliberate choice to end on a note of affirmation, highlighting the protagonist's commitment to a virtuous path and her potential for future accomplishments, thereby providing a satisfying and uplifting closure to her journey.

In the response that explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because this story was about a plant growing back every year around the same time. The paragraph meant, I think, that when the plant came back in spring and the geese would return, it would be another test of growing and not letting the plant die. This cyclical return represents the ongoing challenges and opportunities for renewal that the character must face. The author uses this natural imagery to parallel the character's own struggles and resilience, suggesting that each new season brings a chance to strengthen her resolve and ensure her personal growth continues, just as the plant endures.

From the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes this story with the paragraph of what Saeng vowed silently because it is to show Saeng’s determination. The hibiscus was the plant she found, that was closely resembled the one at “home,” to symbolize her comfort. The hibiscus symbolized her determination in life. “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now” from this, you can conclude that Saeng is thinking of how she recognized the geese. It gives her greater confidence within herself. From this, “like the Geese she lifted her head and watched as their distinctive v was etched," and this explains that there is still hope inside of her. This paragraph conclusion the author had concluded ties together what Saeng is now hoping and believing in, creating a unified and resonant ending that encapsulates her emotional and symbolic journey toward self-assurance and a renewed sense of possibility in her new life.

Saeng vows this to herself at the end of the story to show that she will adapt to this change, just like the hibiscus will bud. She knows that it will be hard and take time, but in the end she will achieve approval and happiness. We see that it is already hard for her by the way she breaks down crying and by the way she talks to her mother. She symbolizes by planting the hibiscus that things are going to get better if she is not too stuck in the past. This act of planting is a physical manifestation of her commitment to growth, acknowledging the difficulty of her transition while choosing to invest in a future where she can eventually flourish and find contentment, thus completing her character arc.

The author concludes the paragraph with a statement that Saeng said. It was a very good statement. The author ended with this to show that she is motivated and determined to do this. She shows she is motivated in many ways. She says, “Here let me help you mother.” This shows that she is motivated by helping her mother finish what she started. She is also determined by saying, “almost reluctantly she realizes that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through a quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar now.” This shows that she wants to do something and she doesn’t think it is weird anymore. That is why the author concludes with that statement, as it perfectly captures her transformed perspective and her active decision to engage with her new world, bringing her internal conflict to a resolved and hopeful end.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's resilient vow. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again! This determination stems from her personal history, as her family moved to the united @ORGANIZATION1 from Vietnam. This background provides context for her struggles. Second one is the author could of made this story it was about her, drawing from personal experience of adaptation. The immediate conflict is that Saeng fails her driving test, but the conclusion emphasizes her resolve to try once more, framing her failure not as an end but as a temporary setback on her journey in a new country.

The author concludes the “Winter Hibiscus” with that paragraph to show the narrator realizes that even though she’s in a new country, some things are still the same, providing her with a sense of continuity. So she becomes determined to pass the test. For example, the narrator said, “she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quick repetition of season upon season, familiar to her now.” This quote shows that the narrator has realized that even though aspects of how life has changed, some things remain the same, offering her comfort. This also shows that some things like the test were strange to her but now that she is familiar with it she could pass it. The narrator also said, “Saeng did not dare look at her mother in her eyes.” This quote shows that the narrator was disappointed with herself for not passing the test, feeling she had let her family down. This means that the test was very important to her with the weight of pressure to pass, and she is now ready to pass the test, having learned from the experience. But she’ll be more prepared. The theme of this story could be seen as not letting things discourage you permanently. The narrator has gone through recently many challenges but finds hope in the cyclical nature of the seasons, which promise renewal and a chance to begin again.

The author shows a willingness to try harder in this story through Saeng's determined statement. She states that, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think the author realizes that she is going to have to adapt to her new environment, and this vow is a part of that process. Also, saying that she will wait till the spring, means she is going to try again, and not give up despite her initial failure. The author has a sentimental value attached to the hibiscus. Since she is waiting for the hibiscus to bud, I believe she is referring that hibiscus to her country, seeing it as a living connection to her past. Since she has left her country, the hibiscus is the closest thing she has to it, and therefore, she will wait with the flower, drawing strength from its symbolic promise of new beginnings before she attempts her test again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng now thinks about images associated with memories in her new home, as well as images she remembers from Vietnam, finding a new sense of belonging. At the beginning of the story, in the floral shop, she remembers her grandmother, as well as a well, a hibiscus hedge, and other things that remind her of certain feelings and experiences from her past life. At the end of the story, she uses both the hibiscus, which reminds her of her previous home, and the canadian geese, which don't seem so unfamiliar to her anymore, to represent the passing of time and the natural cycles of life. She now sees her new home as having familiar things in it attached to memories, as her old home did, allowing her to feel more settled and connected to both her past and her present. This fusion of memories enables her to look forward to the future with a sense of hope and determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several important reasons. In some ways, it serves to resolve Saeng's emotional arc. One reason why the author concluded the story with this paragraph is because in the story she had failed something she really wanted, which was her driver's license. So she took the failure home and showed her mom. Then her mom looked at her weird, because in the story it said that “you what? Her mother stared at her incredulously.” So then she explains that she failed the drivers test, but she didn’t give up, showing her underlying strength. So at the end of the story she said that she will take that test again, declaring her resolve to overcome this obstacle. So in conclusion that is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, to leave the reader with a powerful sense of the character's perseverance and hope for a successful future attempt.

The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to illustrate her unwavering determination to try again and to pass her driving test the following year. The specific mention of spring, when the snows melt and the geese return, connects her resolve to a natural cycle of renewal. Furthermore, the budding hibiscus holds deep significance, as it reminded her of her home in Vietnam. This is supported by an earlier moment in the story where "Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into childhood world." By the next year, when the flowers bloom, she would feel more determined and emotionally prepared to face the test again. The flowers blooming symbolizes starting a new life, and the author suggests that Saeng will similarly begin anew by passing her driver's test, which is why the story ends with this hopeful statement.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to powerfully convey the message that one should never give up. It shows that Saeng is determined to conquer the challenges before her, specifically her struggle with the driving test. The vow she makes to herself signifies a promise of persistence, indicating that she is prepared to take the test over and over again until she ultimately succeeds. This final thought leaves the reader with a clear and resonant theme of perseverance, emphasizing that giving up is not an option when faced with setbacks. The paragraph therefore serves as a fitting conclusion to underscore this core lesson of resilience.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author ends with Saeng's vow to retake the test in the spring to emphasize her refusal to give up. The paragraph clearly states that even though Saeng failed the driving test the first time, she is not defeated and will continue trying until she passes and gets her license. This conclusion also highlights the importance of the seasonal change, as Saeng can wait until winter ends to see the hibiscus budding. This connection between her personal resolve and the natural world's renewal reinforces the story's message of hope and patience, showing that she will try again with the coming of a new season.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes in a way that relates back to the beginning conflict of the main character failing her driver’s test. This structure brings the reader full circle while also helping to foreshadow future events, as seen in the line, "in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." This sentence informs the reader that the hibiscus, a plant similar to those from her homeland, will help her move forward. When the hibiscus makes a new start by budding in the spring, Saeng will do the same by retaking her driver's test. With this as a conclusion, the author therefore avoids leaving the reader confused about the resolution of the driver's test, providing a clear and purposeful ending to that story thread.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey its central meaning. For Saeng, returning to a familiar and comforting environment was a significant emotional relief, as she felt great because she came back to where she belonged. This is exemplified by her silent vow, made "in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding." This statement meant that coming back to these roots was probably the best thing she could have done, providing her with the strength and solace needed to face her challenges anew. The conclusion thus ties her personal renewal to the symbolic return of life in spring, affirming the positive impact of reconnecting with her past.

It seems to me that the reason why the author wrote that as his or her ending is because it was basically to have sarcasm and put emphasis on what he was saying. The author was making it clear that he wasn't going to take the test again, and basically if someone would have to kill him in order to make him take that test again, so be it. This final statement serves as a powerful and hyperbolic declaration of his absolute refusal, leaving no room for doubt about his resolve on the matter.

The reason why I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph is because she wants to test the hibiscus again when it returns. For evidence, in the last paragraph it says, “when they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This direct quote from the text shows Saeng’s determination is tied to the natural cycle. That is why I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph, as it perfectly captures the character's renewed commitment and hope for the future.

The author puts that as the conclusion because it is like a cycle. The narrative structure reflects the recurring patterns in nature and life, and he didn’t finish it with the end of the cycle because leaving readers with that curiosity edge gives suspense. This technique engages the audience, making them ponder what might happen next in Saeng's journey. This was a well written story and conclusion, effectively using an open-ended finish to enhance the overall thematic impact of the tale.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” by Minfong Ho, a teenage girl fails a driving test but vows to take it again in the spring. The story was ended like this to show that the girl will have a new beginning. For example, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”(HO). The hibiscus is what makes her feel as though she is connected to her homeland, serving as a symbol of her past and her identity. So if the hibiscus is budding it is starting a new beginning, and she feels that she will be able to do the same, embarking on her own personal renewal. This connection between the plant's cycle and her personal resolve is why the story ends like that.

These are a few reasons why the author concluded the story this way. The first reason is that most of the story is written in the way of a serious and straightforward tone, and ending the story with a quote or riddle makes the reader have to think about the conclusion. It would not have been the same if he just ended with what happened, so he just added something that made you think a little more than a normal conclusion would. The author ended the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because it was different from a simple summary of events, providing a more reflective and poignant finish to the narrative.

Because she is going to practice diligently and get better at driving, and when the flower blooms in the spring, she will go take the test again with renewed determination. She has learned from her previous attempt and will try harder next time, focusing on improving her skills to achieve success. This plan represents her commitment to not giving up and her belief in her own ability to eventually pass the driving test and reach her goal.

The author includes that particular paragraph because they wanted you to be able to visualize the scene clearly in your head rather than not seeing the picture at all. If you see a detailed mental picture then the writing is good at visualizing, as it successfully paints an image with words. This technique helps the reader become more immersed in the narrative and connect more deeply with the story's setting and events.

The author concludes with that because she means that she will try to go a whole season without thinking about home; since she failed to do this in winter she will try again in spring. One way you can tell this is by seeing that she is talking about how the plant is reminding her how life was before they moved to the city. For example, when she smelled the plant it almost seems to take her back in time to when she was little and they were growing wild and they were pretty, which triggers her feelings of homesickness. The spring represents a new beginning and a chance for her to overcome these nostalgic feelings and adapt to her new environment.

The story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho concludes with, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author does this as a symbol of hope for the reader. Also, so it is not just an ending where you never know what happens, it gives you something to look forward to. Furthermore, when the geese do come back there is warm weather and the hibiscus is blooming; then Saeng will be more comfortable because she has gotten used to the idea of living in a new place and has met more people. Meanwhile, having the hibiscus in bloom will bring good memories back from when she was young and living in her homeland, but now these memories will strengthen rather than sadden her. This will help Saeng achieve her goal of passing her test by providing comfort and a sense of connection. Also, I believe the author ended the story with that passage because it makes people want to read it again or recommend the story to someone else. I know that I hate reading stories that just end and don’t tell you what happens next. However, the author resolved this by letting the reader know that Saeng wants to pass the test and is going to go back and try again, providing a satisfying and hopeful conclusion.

The last paragraph of the “Winter Hibiscus” reads “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author ends with this statement to let the reader know that Saeng has hope and will continue to adjust to her new setting in the United States. Throughout the story, Saeng realizes that she is not as distant from her home in Vietnam as she believes. In the florist's shop she sees “plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.” The plants she grew up with exist in the US as well. She fails “the test” by buying a winter hibiscus after breaking down crying, homesick. By the end of the story she recognizes that she is becoming more accustomed to her new life, which is “almost familiar to her now,” such as the geese flying overhead. The statement of the last paragraph means that by the spring, she hopes to no longer be homesick, and to think of the US with its geese and winter hibiscuses as her home, fully accepting her new life.

The author ends the story that way to show Saeng's newfound determination. The whole story is about Saeng's journey one afternoon to come to acceptance with her new home, so it seems fitting to conclude with Saeng's determination to pass her driving test and make life work in @LOCATION1. The story deals with several things Saeng finds that make her feel at home, such as the sharp bitter melon and the resilient hibiscus. These specific discoveries lead Saeng to feel more at home and make it fitting to end with Saeng's acceptance that she will stay in @LOCATION1. @PERSON1 is also inspired by the hibiscus, which is described as being “strong enough to make it through the cold months that’s what matters.” This directly reads to Saeng's own determination to make it through her new life. And finally, the geese Saeng sees lead her to recognize that life in @LOCATION1 is becoming “familiar.” These geese lead @PERSON1 to the quiet realization that this is her new home, and she can't go back. The whole story is filled with events like the three above that lead the character to this final determination, so it is fitting to conclude the story with her resolve to succeed.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it powerfully shows that a new beginning is starting for Saeng and her family. For example, the fact that they moved to a different country represents this major life change. That's what the author means when mentioning the arrival of spring; spring metaphorically represents a new life, which is precisely what Saeng and her mother are embarking upon. Also, the melting snow represents a blanket covering the past and its hard times, which is now receding. Last but not least, when the hibiscus starts to bud, that event also signifies a new beginning and the promise of growth. So if you put it all together, you get the hard times going away when the snow melts and then a new beginning when spring starts and the flower buds. That is why the author put this paragraph in the story, because the characters needed a fresh start and a hopeful outlook for the future.

The author had concluded that sentence to be the concluding sentence because Saeng thinks she deserves another chance at taking the driving test, as she has failed the test before and experienced her mother's disappointment. Her previous failure weighs on her, making her determined to try again. What Saeng says at the end of the story is that she is going to have more confidence in herself when attempting the driving test again. This declaration shows her renewed spirit and her commitment to not giving up, effectively wrapping up her emotional arc with a promise of future effort and self-belief.

I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph because it signifies the end of winter, both literally and metaphorically. The closing lines mark a transition from the cold, difficult season to a time of potential renewal. This seasonal shift parallels the internal change within the main character, suggesting that a period of hardship is passing. By choosing to end on this note, the author provides a symbolic closure, indicating that a new chapter is beginning as the harshness of winter recedes.

The author probably ends the story like that because it creates a strong sense of hope and wonder for the reader. I feel the story is essentially about overcoming challenges and personal struggles. For example, Saeng had a driving test and failed it, which was a setback. She also seemed a bit overwhelmed by the thought of “home” and her place in this new environment. Saeng obviously cares deeply about failing the test, or she wouldn’t have put so much time into thinking about it, which ultimately led her to seek solace in a greenhouse. At the greenhouse she was looking for a specific plant to buy, which vividly reminded her of her old home. Thinking of home and her grandmother naturally upsets her, highlighting her sense of loss. Saeng has almost this internal war with herself throughout the narrative, and the author ends the story that way to conclude it by giving the reader a palpable sense of hope for Saeng’s future and a feeling of wonder about what lies ahead for her.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows she's not going to just give up easily after failing once, demonstrating her resilient spirit. This paragraph also shows that she's trying to like this country as much as she can and she is looking forward until spring time when the hibiscus is blooming, that will remind her of home, but also of her new life in @LOCATION1, symbolizing a hopeful blend of her past and future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng failed to get a certain plant because it died but winter is over in spring is here itís her chance to get that flower. Itís not her fault because in the story, it says the wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remarks of green and chicory weeds, indicating the harsh conditions she faced. I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph @CAPS1 the carter Saeng want to finish or @CAPS2 Take the Test agin when they come back and and also the author is @CAPS3 people @CAPS4't give up what you are doing with your self then she say that "when the snow melt and the geese return and this Hibiscus is budding Then I will take that test agin" she means that she will not give up at all, reinforcing the central message of determination and hope for a second chance.

The author ended the story with that sentence because in the spring Saeng is going retake the test and her hibiscus will finally be budding, representing a season of renewal. Saeng is going to retake the test because she failed it the @CAPS1 time she took, showing her resolve to overcome initial setbacks. The author wrote this paragraph at the end of the story to symbolize a fresh start, using the changing seasons as a metaphor. I think this because when it is spring and the hibiscus is budding it will remind her homeland and she will take a fresh start at the test, illustrating her commitment to moving forward while still honoring her roots. This final note leaves the reader with a feeling of hopeful anticipation for the character's future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng has vowed to retake the test in the spring and will have more confidence when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus starts budding. This progression of the seasons mirrors her own internal journey from failure to hope. The line, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her,” captures a pivotal moment of profound sadness. Saeng feels lonely because she is from a different country and misses everything she knew and loved, a feeling that is momentarily overwhelming. Now she has the hibiscus to remind her of home, serving as a tangible connection to her past and a symbol of resilience for her future, allowing her to find strength in her memories as she prepares to try again.

The author uses this paragraph to conclude her story to show that there was thought and a process gone through where Saeng was learning and growing. At first Saeng is very uneasy and disappointed in herself, which is clear when she stammers, "I-I failed the test." The mother's initial reaction, "For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing," indicates a shared disappointment. You can tell at first the mother is disappointed and then as they talk they are planting which eases the mood, shifting the scene from one of tension to one of nurturing care. The mother’s offer, "How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?" and Saeng’s reply, "I’d love it," marks a significant shift. Her mood has now lightened and she is making a calm, collective decision to try again, which is a reasonable decision to make when she is in a good frame of mind rather than upset and distraught, showing her emotional recovery and newfound determination.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” it has an unusual ending. There are many reasons why the author decided to end the story this way. First, the girl failed the test which made her go into silence, reflecting her initial shock and dejection. When she agreed to take the test over it is a sign of the will to survive, demonstrating her underlying strength and refusal to be defeated. It shows that she is trying at her goal until she got it, emphasizing a theme of perseverance. Finally, the ending could represent a new beginning like when the snow melts away and changes winter into spring, symbolizing a natural cycle of renewal that parallels Saeng's own personal growth. This is what the ending of “Winter Hibiscus” means and this is why the author concluded it this way, leaving the reader with a sense of hopeful anticipation.

The author concludes with this sentence because it shows that Saeng is going to try to adapt to her new home. He lets you know that Saeng is not going to grieve and be sad anymore, but she will adapt and continue on with her life, marking a crucial turning point in her character. The author adds this: “I mean, not like the kind we had at-at—". This is when Saeng has just come home and talked to her mother and she is very sad because she thought about old memories at her old home, highlighting the depth of her longing. But by adding the last statement of the story it shows that Saeng has decided to move on with life and no longer be sad, choosing acceptance over despair. She has set a goal to accept it, demonstrating her resolve to build a new life. This is the reason for the author to conclude this story like he does, emphasizing the theme of adaptation and forward movement.

The author ended the story with that paragraph because he was trying to tell us that the hibiscus represents a comfort in a time of disappointment for Saeng. She saw the plant when she had just failed her driving test, a moment of profound personal setback. The unexpected sight of the tropical flower, a relic of her homeland, provides an immediate sense of solace and connection. It stands as a symbol of enduring beauty and memory, offering her a point of stability amidst her feelings of failure. This encounter with the hibiscus ultimately helps to soothe her disappointment and reinforces the idea that pieces of her home can survive and thrive in her new environment, giving her the courage to look forward.

Authors use conclusions to wrap up a story, or to make the reader think. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author uses the conclusion “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” He uses this conclusion to show that she is going to adapt to this culture. For example, when she is in the garden shop she breaks down crying; it says “and in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” It is possible to deduce that she is crying because she used to fit in her old home but because she didn’t pass her test she doesn’t think she will fit in here. Her emotional breakdown in the greenhouse contrasts with her final vow, showing her shift in perspective. So she motivates herself at the end of the story to try again. In conclusion, the author used that paragraph to show that Saeng will take the test again so she can fit into this new world and find her place within it.

The author concludes the story this way because the author wants to show that she won’t give up. The author wants to illustrate that she will take the test again and try harder next time to overcome her challenge, and not give up. This final vow is a clear declaration of her resilience. The author wants to show her, that she’s not a quitter, and she’s filled with determination even though she has conflicts and has faced a significant setback. This resilient spirit is the core message the author conveys through the concluding paragraph, emphasizing that perseverance is key to overcoming adversity.

Why did the author conclude the story with this paragraph? I believe that the author concluded with that paragraph because it tells what she is going to do in the future and provides a sense of forward-looking hope. For example, in the story she told her mom “I failed…” When she was putting the flower in the hole by the garden a flock of geese were flying, heading south. This sight of the migrating geese, a natural symbol of seasonal return, seems to inspire her own promise of a future attempt. Her silent vow to try again in the spring is a direct result of this moment, showing her decision to look ahead. The paragraph effectively shifts the focus from her present failure to her future resolve.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she wants to try again. So when she said “Then I will take that test again”, it means she knows she has another chance and is choosing to seize it. It shows that she is strong willed and won’t give up easily. So what she is saying in the last paragraph is if you don’t succeed the first time try and try again. In the story it says “she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season,” familiar. In that part I can tell that she is already starting to change and adapt to her new environment. This growing familiarity gives her the confidence to try again. So I think next time she’ll do great because she is learning to persevere.

I think the author chose to end the story the way he did because it shows determination to pass the test. The test was to be able to make the garden grow, which is a test of her ability to nurture life in a new land. You know this because it says “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This shows that the test she took had to do with spring and the budding of flowers and that she is trying to grow something successfully. In this story, they mention her helping her mother in the garden, which connects the test to this central activity. So I think when the plants didn’t grow, she wanted to try again and not be defeated. That’s why I think they chose to end with the statement saying about taking the test again in the spring, linking her personal resolve to the natural cycle of renewal.

The author uses this paragraph because it brings back memories from when Saeng put down the soil during the “winter hibiscus” and a flock of Canada geese flew by her. This memory is significant, as it connects a moment of past effort with a symbol of migration and change. When Saeng failed her test the first time she did not dare look at her mother, feeling a deep sense of shame and disappointment. She depended on the hibiscus, which helped her find the courage to want to retake the test, but she resolved not to do so until they re-bud again, seeing the plant's cycle as a promise of renewal and a second chance for herself as well.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to conclude all the things they talked about in the story, providing a sense of closure and cyclical renewal. In the story they talk about the spring time and now Saeng and her mother plants flowers and everything, symbolizing a new beginning and the nurturing of hope after a period of hardship. This final image ties together the themes of growth and adaptation, showing how the characters have settled into their new life by engaging in the familiar, comforting act of gardening, which marks a peaceful end to their journey.

I think the author ends the story with this paragraph to show she won’t give up if they don’t, emphasizing a theme of resilience. I think this because the birds and the hibiscus will only reappear if they survive the harsh winter, representing endurance. That means they will stay strong in the meantime just like her, demonstrating a parallel between nature's fortitude and human spirit. She will survive her new surroundings and change to fit into the styles of American life, ultimately proving her ability to adapt and persevere through challenges, much like the natural world she observes.

I think the author concludes the story the way he did because it will make people want to read the next story to see if the test is passed; it adds suspense to the narrative. By ending on a note of unresolved determination, the author creates a compelling question about Saeng's future, encouraging readers to wonder about the outcome of her next attempt. This technique of generating curiosity ensures the story's themes linger in the reader's mind, making the conclusion impactful and open-ended, which is a effective way to maintain engagement with the character's journey.

I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph because that represents Saeng’s decision to try again and to overcome obstacles in her way. It is used instead of her saying “I will try again next spring” to show diction and to show her goal or decision in a different way; for example, It says “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar now.” At first, geese flying in the sky was new to her, but now she’s used to it. Maybe the author is making a reference to the geese since it will be familiar, just as the driving test will become, and she will pass like she got used to and familiar with the geese. Since her family came to America from Vietnam, she’s been adjusting to changes in her life and to circumstances, a difficult process of assimilation. But, Saeng seemed determined to survive and overcome it. The paragraph is saying simply that she’ll take the test again next spring, but the author put that paragraph there to show diction by emphasizing the geese, representing learning something new, and the hibiscus, something familiar from her past. It overtones the point in the story, which is to not give up and to possess the will to survive, thus concluding with a powerful message of hope and persistence.

The author loves spring plants, so after every winter her anticipation builds to see if she can plant and grow beautiful plants. The spring season is the only time you can grow one-of-a-kind plants like she grows. Her test is to grow a garden of beautiful plants and vegetables, a challenge she embraces each year. The author will work hard just like her mother did to bring the gardens to life, especially after the winter, tending to the soil with care and dedication. This annual ritual connects her to her family's traditions and the enduring cycle of nature, ensuring the garden flourishes once more.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph. He was talking about how beautiful was nature, emphasizing its profound and calming beauty. He also thought since Saeng loved nature a lot she was going to go back to school to finish the test when she could be home in the garden taking care of the plant. This contrast highlights her internal conflict between new responsibilities and her deep-rooted passions. That is why I think the author decided to finish with that paragraph; it would probably describe how much he likes nature and how it serves as a central, comforting force for the character, ultimately framing the story's message.

In “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author ended the story with that particular paragraph to symbolize new beginnings. The story is all about the failure and shame felt by Saeng when she failed her driving test, and how finding a familiar hibiscus plant gave her a new lease on life. By buying the hibiscus, Saeng was reminded of her home, and by giving that single hibiscus a new, unfamiliar place to thrive in, as she was, she found a kindred spirit in the plant. She was able to make a connection with the plant, seeing her own journey reflected in its survival. The spring symbolizes the beginning of a new year, and the budding hibiscus represents the start of its new life, and so Saeng wants to restart her life when the plant restarts its life and retaking her driving test, finding courage in its resilience.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because the symbolism of this paragraph tells that when everything returns to normal and the “geese return and this hibiscus is budding that I will take that test again,” meaning she will be willing to move again and try to adapt. This connection between the natural world's cycles and her personal resolve is powerful. The budding flower signals a time for new growth and second chances, mirroring her own readiness to face challenges. It shows that she has found inspiration in nature's predictable renewal, giving her the strength to attempt the test once more with a hopeful heart.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph about retaking the test to show that Saeng is getting more used to America, our memories last forever, and even the smallest of things can hold memories for us. The paragraph shows Saeng is getting more used to America by showing us that she isn’t going to give up on America and that she will keep working at understanding our customs, demonstrating her growing determination. The last paragraph also shows that our memories last forever by the hibiscus representing Vietnam and her home there, a tangible link to her past. It also shows that she can start a new here just like the hibiscus does at her house, putting down new roots. Finally the paragraph shows that even the smallest of things can hold our memories by the hibiscus representing her home in Vietnam. The hibiscus brings many memories back for Saeng and helps her cope with America, providing comfort and a sense of identity. This is how the last paragraph shows us that Saeng is getting used to America, our memories last forever, and the smallest things can hold memories, weaving together her past and her future.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” by Minfong Ho, a teenage girl named Saeng and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. After failing her driver's test, Saeng is walking home and passes a familiar plant, which stirs memories of her homeland. She then goes into a florist shop to purchase the plant, a winter hibiscus. She arrives home and tells her mother she failed the test; of course her mother is upset, but she makes dinner and accepts the plant. At the end of the story, Saeng thinks to herself, “when they come back, in spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think Saeng says she will retake the test in spring because she feels confident and happy now that she is comfortable with the plant she has, and her mother isn't too mad at her.
