The hibiscus serves as a comforting link to her past, giving her a sense of stability. She feels that everything is going to be ok and she can retake the test in spring, when life is blooming and her own spirits are renewed.

The author concludes the story with this line because it shows that Saeng was given inspiration from the flower to come back, try again, and not give up. For example, Saeng vowed to herself that, “In the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This quote shows that the hibiscus was the reason for her determination and that she would come back, just like they did. The cyclical patterns of nature provide a model for her own perseverance. That is why the author decided to conclude the story with that line, because she wanted to show Saeng being inspired by the natural world and not giving up on her goals.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I think the author ends with that paragraph because it shows that Saeng is determined to pass her driver's test. “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts, and the geese return and the hibiscus budding, then I will take the test again.” This shows she is determined because geese migrate every year and flowers always bud every year; these are reliable, recurring events. She will keep coming back just like the geese and the hibiscus do, demonstrating her own resilience. She will be determined to pass the test and fit into her new American society sooner or later. If she was not determined, she might never pass and fit in, but the ending confirms her resolve to keep trying until she succeeds.

I believe the author ends the story with this sentence to show how Saeng overcomes obstacles emotionally and how the hibiscus plant is a sign of hope for the future. In the beginning of the story, Saeng is upset about failing her driver's test, and then on top of that she gets upset about seeing the native plants of her homeland, which deepen her homesickness. The story says, “When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. And besides it was yet another friend, a small shrub.” This quote shows how these plants remind her of her homeland, which she misses dearly and is very important to her. By bringing this plant back to her house, it's like she's bringing a little piece of her homeland, providing emotional comfort. The final quote, “when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," shows that Saeng has hope in her life again. This is a big turn of events in her life that will make her much happier in her new home, which is why the author ended the story with this sentence of renewed optimism.

The author concludes the story like this because Saeng is not ready to move on with her life immediately, but she will be when the seasons change. When everything turns back to spring, she will take that test and move on. But until her flowers are gone, she will not worry about the test, allowing herself this period of adjustment. For example, she wrote, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. like geese.” This means that she has been used to change and has accepted the situation over time. The ending shows her patient understanding that some things, including her own readiness, require time and the right conditions to blossom.

I think the author concludes the story with that statement because, in the natural order of things, the snow doesn’t melt until the spring, the geese don’t return until the winter is over, and the hibiscus is not budding until spring either. The hibiscus is a beautiful plant, and Saeng loved this particular plant for the hope it represented. The author uses these natural events to parallel Saeng's own journey of growth and adaptation, suggesting that just as these changes happen in their own time, so too will Saeng find her moment to bloom. This connection reinforces the story's central theme of patience and the promise of new beginnings, providing a complete and resonant conclusion to the narrative.

The whole story about Saeng buying the hibiscus is in response to her failing the driving test. This failure crushed her spirit completely. She wants to be reminded of her old homeland, where she did not have to read to pass the driving lessons and life felt more familiar. So she goes to a greenhouse to find plants that are similar to the ones she used to have in her homeland, seeking a tangible piece of her past. She does this to try to make herself feel better, but still, “in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” Saeng feels she has failed, and the hibiscus gives her hope and memories of her old country. Her mom clearly sees and understands this when she doesn’t yell at Saeng for spending the money on the plant. “I’m glad you got it,” Saeng’s mom says softly, because she knows it comforts her daughter and mends her heart. Together they plant the hibiscus in their garden. By doing this, they are planting Saeng’s hope to grow, not only to pass the driving test but to make it in the new country. The story ends with those lines because Saeng decides if the hibiscus will grow then so will she. She will be ready to face the driving test with renewed hope and support and because she has adapted to her new surroundings. The hibiscus, although it is not the exact one she had in the old country, shows her that plants can adapt to their new environment, and so the plant has the potential to thrive in the new country. The plant will grow if it can adapt, and Saeng understands that she too can grow if she adapts to this new country, finding her own way to blossom.

The author is trying to communicate that Saeng will never give up and her confidence will grow so she can retake her test, just like the hibiscus waits for the spring to bloom. Comparing Saeng to the hibiscus plant in the last paragraph was a deliberate choice to show how she will grow and advance, preparing to take the test again when it’s the right time for her. The snow melting represents her sorrows going away, while the emerging sun shows how she will succeed and grow like the hibiscus plant she had bought. The plant growing in the sunlight would represent her newfound confidence to take the test next time, getting rid of the cold brisk snow which is like her negative self-esteem and defeated attitude. The author chose to compare Saeng to the plant in the last paragraph to show how its life cycle related directly to her own life and attitude, and how her perspective will change as a result of the hope the hibiscus plant provides, concluding that her growth is as natural and inevitable as the changing seasons.

The author concludes her story with this paragraph because it really shows the heart and the perseverance Saeng possesses. It reveals her inner strength and determination to overcome the challenges she faces in her new life. Also, it tells a lot about her character and ends the story in a strong, uplifting mood, leaving the reader with a sense of her resilience. The final lines solidify the theme of hope and continuous effort, emphasizing that Saeng's journey is far from over. That is why she ended the story the way she did, to leave a lasting impression of courage and the promise of future success.

When the snow melts and the geese return, it means it is almost spring. These are the classic, reliable signs of the changing seasons, signaling the end of winter's harshness. The melting snow uncovers the earth beneath, and the honking geese fill the sky, both heralding the arrival of warmer days and new life. This cyclical change in nature marks a period of renewal and hope, a transition that the story uses to mirror the character's own internal shift. This natural progression provides a complete and fitting backdrop for the story's conclusion, emphasizing themes of timing and new beginnings.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she felt like she would be ready for the new test. In the text it states that after walking home after failing the driver's test, she sees a familiar plant, which sparks a memory of her homeland. Later, she goes to a florist shop to see if the plant can be purchased, and this small quest helps restore her sense of purpose. The experience renews her determination, and she decides that she will take the test again because she feels as though she is confident to pass it the next time around, having found a new resolve.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to show the courage the girl has in immigrating to a new country. After having failed her driver's test, Saeng was feeling defeated and worthless. Her mother took her feelings into consideration and didn't get mad at her for buying the flower. In fact, she decided to plant the flower to show Saeng that everything would work out in the end, just as they had to adapt and grow in their new home. When Saeng began to see her mother doing this, she became overwhelmed with determination and took over planting the flower for her mother. Immigrating to a new country is difficult and many immigrants face problems on a daily basis. Saeng's mother was out in the cold planting and trying to make the best of her situation. By setting this example, Saeng realized that she too could make the best out of her situation. This is why in the end Saeng decides to take her driver's test again, and ultimately live with the same resilient attitude her mother has demonstrated.

They can compare the story and this statement to each other because in the story the main character does not give up, and the same thing applies to the test; the person who is taking the test again did not give up because they are taking it again. This parallel shows a shared theme of perseverance, where the character's actions in the narrative directly reflect the determination required to retake a challenging examination. The decision to try once more is a clear demonstration of resilience and a refusal to be defeated by initial failure, which is the core connection between the two elements.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph in hope. The conclusion the author made was to say that over that amount of time, Saeng will have overcome that failure and will be more prepared for the test for a second time. In the text, it says how Saeng realized that many of the things she thought of as strange before have become almost familiar, which is an improvement in her adjustment to her new environment. This growing familiarity with her surroundings gives her the confidence to believe that she can succeed where she initially failed, turning her initial setback into a stepping stone for future success.

Minfong Ho concludes the story with this paragraph to show the change in Saeng's heart and attitude toward her new life. Spring symbolizes rebirth, and the author doesn’t include this on accident. Spring will be Saeng's time of rebirth where she can take the test and restart her new life in a positive way. "When the snow melts" is included because winter symbolizes death and hardship, and when the snow melts away, so will Saeng's fears and doubts about her ability to adapt and thrive. This symbolic transition underscores her internal transformation and newfound optimism for the future.

Will you not see that in the spring the snows melt and the grass is not yet pretty, and it’s a muddy grass for the pigs who love to wallow in mud? How about a muddy aftermath, to see what winter can do to you? Think about the tree now, weighted down, yet it finds a way to live a good life, pushing forth new leaves despite the harshness it has endured.

The author chose to conclude the last paragraph with the story to show that she has not given up. It shows that she has not given up because it says “overhead...geese...honk...familiar to Saeng now,” which signifies a growing comfort in her new surroundings. This is similar to when she buys the hibiscus, because it holds many memories from home, which helps to keep her going. Her mother still making an “omelet with slices of bitter melon” made her mouth water, powerfully reminding her of home, and this connection gave her the hope to not give up on her new life.

Saeng loves flowers and plants. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it goes along with the narrative of growth and renewal. In the spring when the snow melts, Saeng was waiting for winter to be over so she could see her plants and flowers again. Saeng appreciates the values of plants and enjoys planting them. The author includes that paragraph to show how Saeng is so in love with plants and the life they represent. She simply couldn’t wait for the new winter break to be over so she could return to her garden.

The author ends the story with that paragraph because it shows how Saeng feels connected to the plant that reminds her of home. This connection is important because it shows how people can find small, meaningful ways to deal with significant changes in their lives. Saeng does this by buying and planting the hibiscus plant so that she can see it and be reminded of home. She also buys the plant so that it motivates her to take the test she failed again in the spring, a time of new beginnings when the flower is budding and her spirits are lifted.

She feels this way because she is confused and is not yet used to the country she is in. The flower helps her to concentrate on her test, as she believes that as soon as the flower has bloomed and she feels more at home, she will do better on the test. This hope for the future gives her the strength to persevere through her current difficulties and look forward to a time of success and belonging.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the hibiscus makes her feel comfort, she says “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Since the author failed the test as it is told in the story, she will feel comfort and a sense of renewed hope by taking the test again when the hibiscus flowers return after the snow season, using the plant's resilience as a personal motivator.

The author concludes the story by saying that when the geese come back in the spring then she will try to pass the test, illustrating the adage that if at first you don’t succeed, you should try again. Also, the author concludes with that to show that Saeng has been in the new location for some years and that she still misses her home back in Vietnam, yet she is finding the strength to persist in her new environment.

She thinks she is going to pass the test in the spring because everything gets back to life again; flowers start growing, trees start to get green, and everything begins to flourish. The geese are returning, animals are starting to come out, and people go to the beach to distract themselves, and that sense of renewal and distraction might be what she wants to do to clear her mind and approach the test with a fresh perspective.

The author most likely concludes this story with the quote because she has renewed hope. She was feeling really upset because she had failed the driving test, and when she saw the hibiscus flower, she got even more emotional because she misses her home, but when she sees the geese as she finishes planting the flower, she decides she’s going to try to retake the test next spring, finding inspiration in the cyclical return of life and migration.

The author concludes the story with, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show Saeng growing up. As another year passes, Saeng will be more comfortable with her circumstances and ready to start over fresh, just like all the plants will be blooming and budding. Failing her driver's test really upset Saeng, so by waiting another year, she will be able to practice more and become better, so that when she goes back and retests, she will be an even better driver by having the time to practice and start over. It’s almost like a new beginning for Saeng; another year has passed, and now when her familiar plant buds and begins to start over, so will she. Since the hibiscus plant is familiar to Saeng, she is better able to relate to it, and as it buds and starts fresh, so will Saeng, embracing the future with newfound maturity.

I think the author includes this paragraph in the story because it makes sense that the geese come back home after the snow melts and Saeng tries to take her test again around that time. The return of the geese signals a natural cycle of renewal and a chance for a new beginning, which mirrors Saeng's own personal resolve to try again after her initial failure. This parallel between the natural world and her internal state underscores her determination to not give up, finding inspiration in the seasonal patterns to face her own challenges once more. The connection highlights her growing understanding that time and patience are needed for adaptation, just as the seasons change in their own time. This moment signifies a quiet hope for her future efforts and a commitment to persevere.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author ends the story with “When they come back, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show that Saeng is ready to adapt, but still needs time. Throughout the story, Saeng struggles with overcoming moving from her home, to an unfamiliar place hundreds of miles away. However, Saeng still isn’t ready to let go of her home yet, so she tries to hang on to her old memories, only to find that in her new environment, everything is different. When she buys a familiar plant to her, she realizes that even it is different in this new place, and gets angry that it isn’t what she expected. However, at the end of the story she realizes that different isn’t always so bad, and vows to try to accept this new culture, but knows that it will still take a long time before she is ready to fully do so. The budding hibiscus and the returning geese become symbols of this slow, patient process of growth and acceptance that lies ahead of her. Her vow to retake the test in the spring is thus a promise to herself to begin this difficult journey of integration.

The author concludes the story with that ending paragraph because when the spring comes back she is going to try again. When I was reading this story it says that her mother had asked her “What happened,” and then Saeng said “I- I failed the test.” So I am predicting that her mother is going to help her more with her studying and with her gardening, providing the support she needs to succeed. When the snow melts, Saeng vowed to herself that this time she would work harder and pass the test, using the changing season as a marker for her renewed effort and determination. This connection to the natural cycle gives her a clear timeframe and a sense of hope that her situation can improve with the new season. Her resolve shows a commitment to overcoming her obstacles with renewed vigor.

Why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because that is when she will take the test again. Also because the geese made her realize that many of the things that she had thought were strange before had become familiar, just like the geese themselves. It was through the quiet repetition of season upon season that this familiarity grew, teaching her that adaptation is a gradual process. The cyclical return of the geese symbolizes the passage of time and the potential for what is foreign to eventually become a part of her life. This realization gives her the courage to plan for a future attempt, trusting in the steady rhythm of nature and life. Thus, the ending ties her personal growth to the dependable patterns of the natural world.

She ends with that paragraph because it symbolizes a new start. When the geese came back and the hibiscus is budding, it is like a restart, and she can try again, dealing with her memories of home and her adaptation to the new country. I think she will be able to deal with it better and take the test again; it shows that she won't give up on her goals or on building a life in this new place. The imagery of spring provides a sense of optimism and the inherent promise of second chances that the season represents. This final thought reinforces the theme of resilience and the continuous effort required to overcome personal challenges. Her decision to try again is a testament to her enduring spirit.

She says that because she had failed to keep the tropical plant alive, a loss that felt significant to her. She was disappointed in herself, and so that is why she spoke with such resolve. In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again, she vowed. Her declaration came after she had failed and her mother had offered comfort, saying it will be okay and that you can always try again, which gave her the courage to look forward. This cycle of failure and encouragement solidified her determination for a future attempt.

I believe that why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because she is telling the reader and herself, in my point of view, that once again she will do work in the garden to see if it finally catches her interest. I believe that the author is trying to express this because in the beginning of the story the author shows no interest in the garden or any interest in the world around her, remaining detached from her surroundings. For example, when she was supposed to buy just seeds for the garden she went and used some of her mother’s money to buy herself a Big Mac instead, demonstrating her initial priorities. So in conclusion, I believe that what I wrote clearly states how the author feels and why she ended the story the way she did, highlighting her character's subtle shift.

The author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because Saeng failed the test before and now she wants to pass the test with renewed hope. She learned a lot from her mother that day, particularly about resilience and patience, that completely changed her attitude towards life and her own capabilities. This newfound perspective gave her the strength to set a future goal tied to the natural world, which her mother cherished. The budding hibiscus thus becomes a symbol of her own potential for growth and success.

The author might have concluded the story with that sentence to show that she still cares about the test and not mostly about a measly plant that’s gonna die anyways, putting her priorities into perspective. Also because she needs to pass the test and the author is putting in a detail that in the end the girl is gonna pass and not have to re-take that test all over again, providing a sense of hope. But also he/she tells that because he/she wants us to know that it ain’t all about other things that are expensive in life but that school is really more important than anything, basically emphasizing the value of education over material items. This final thought reinforces the story's central message about responsibility and focus.

The reason why the author, Minfong Ho, finished the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the last paragraph was due to in the story the girl went out on a test, specifically a driving test. And on this test, which I do not know the exact nature of beyond it being for a license, she failed it and returns home with a saebba hedge, a tropical plant. This is a tamed plant for the family, a piece of their heritage. The family loves this plant, seeing in it a connection to their past. They are, what I understand from the story, newcomers to a country, and the country is the United States. They’ve moved here from Vietnam, seeking a new life. She goes for her driving test and comes home failed, feeling she has disappointed her parents. One of the things her mother asks, “why do you spend so much money on this beautiful plant when you could a had the famed bee-maags” which is the mother’s attempt to say a Big Mac, which is their favorite fast food sandwich, highlighting the cultural divide. But the reason why the daughter comes back with the plant is she has failed her parents on the driving test and seeks solace in something familiar. She wants to go back and try again, stating “Then the snow will melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will return to take the test again.” She believes the next time she goes, she will pass the test and that she will not be ashamed of it and that she will make her parents proud by passing the test due to it is a high honor to the family, I believe, from what I am getting from this. In Vietnam not many people drive and that they want their daughter to earn this privilege, and it is something they do not have, making it a symbol of their new life and aspirations.

It is clear that Saeng is in the midst of struggle during a time of homesickness after recently moving from Vietnam. But as time goes on she will learn to balance the affection she feels for both her new country and homeland. As Saeng moves through the story it is apparent that she longs for memories of her homeland, but is beginning to find new things to enjoy about her new home. For example, while she is touched by the memories aroused by the hibiscus flower, she is intrigued by the new experiences, such as eating Big Macs and making new friends. While homesickness has caused her to struggle she knows that with time she will be able to overcome the obstacle of leaving the old ways for the new without completely obliterating either. She is convinced that by spring she will be able to overcome this obstacle and have the confidence to pursue any challenges that will arise in her future, finding a way to hold both places in her heart.

The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to show a sense of change in her character. The winter time is very brutal, like Saeng’s mum said, but spring is when things come alive. I think this is showing the seasonal sense of renewal in Saeng. Though winter is tough and you can get thrown around by the wind, when spring comes she will try the test again and come to life and enjoy the location even though she is far from home. The author did the right thing to conclude the story with that vow, as it powerfully symbolizes her personal growth and newfound determination to embrace her new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he is trying to say that whenever something leaves their home they always come back, just like the migrating geese. The hibiscus reminds her of home and that is where she wants to go. Saeng had failed her driver's test and she said when the geese come back I will do it again. The plant reminds her of home but it's, “Not like the ones we had before” (Ho). She is trying to say that the ones over in Vietnam are better and she wants to go back because she misses it, highlighting her initial idealization of her homeland compared to her current surroundings.

Saeng is talking about flowers coming back in the spring time. She is vowing to take the test again after the snow is gone and she is going to do it again. “The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing." So she can't wait until it is spring again, a time of rebirth and new beginnings. So she can try to plant again, symbolizing her own desire to put down new roots and start anew in her adopted country with hope and resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is saying that when everything comes back to life in the spring, she will do everything again. However, things aren’t the same as they used to be and she wants them to be, indicating her struggle between past and present. The conclusion shows her resolve to try again in this new context, accepting that while her past is cherished, her future requires moving forward and adapting to her new environment without forgetting where she came from.

The girl, Saeng, seems to be attached to nature and enjoy it when the spring comes; as she observed, a new natural cycle will start and she will be motivated to take the test that she failed again. The author most likely finished with this paragraph to show that there will be hope for Saeng and she will do what she has to do to feel more comfortable in her new home country. The whole story talks about how she is still unsatisfied with her new home, but this dissatisfaction would be cut short with new chances and a new life, which the author illustrated using the symbolism of springtime to show this renewal and fresh start.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that maybe by this time she will finally be comfortable with her new home. I know this because when I moved, I didn’t like it at first because I didn’t have many friends, but after a year or two I was fine because I had made a lot of friends. This experience is similar to Saeng's because she clearly misses her old home, as she keeps talking about it and then crying. For example, when she saw the plant that was the same type she had at her old home, she started crying because she missed it so deeply. In conclusion, that is why the author put that hopeful note at the end of the story.

In the story “The Winter Hibiscus,” the author included an important part at the end where Saeng made a vow. The reason why she said that is because she believes when everything in her life starts up again with the coming spring, she will learn to love her life again and she will be a lot happier person, finding joy in her new surroundings and the opportunities that await her.

The author includes this because it shows what Saeng is going to do after she has failed her test, and this story is about what she must do to get past this failure, drawing inspiration and strength from the migrating geese she observes, who symbolize perseverance and the journey toward a goal.

I believe that the author chose to end with that paragraph because the paragraph represents new beginnings and starting over. When Saeng fails her driving test she has a moment of weakness; she feels lonely and then she sees a plant that reminds her of her home in Vietnam. In a sense, the plant comforts her. “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here.” In this quote, Saeng’s mother tells her that the flower is, too, out of place but yet has found the courage and determination to still grow. In the closing paragraph, Saeng decides that, like the flower and the birds, she can also find the courage to face her fears. She decides to retake the tests and embrace her new life with resilience.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with this paragraph to show that she’s not going to give up and to show her mom that too. The final scene, where Saeng plants the hibiscus and makes a promise to herself, serves as a quiet declaration of her determination. It demonstrates her resolve to persevere in her new life and to prove her strength to her mother, who had also witnessed her struggles. This concluding moment solidifies her commitment to not giving up on her future endeavors.

I believe the author was saying a new start. I say this because of everything coming back, like the geese returning and the hibiscus budding, which symbolize renewal. I also say it because Saeng knows what's important now and will take it seriously, learning from her past disappointments. Her realization about her priorities and her decision to retake the test mark a clear beginning. That is what I think the author was saying at the end of the story, emphasizing a fresh start for the main character.

During “Winter Hibiscus,” written by Minfong Ho, a young girl and her mother move to a new place, and the daughter Saeng is having a hard time adjusting. Saeng found a plant called dok faeng-noi that reminds her of home. So she bought it and took it home to show her mom. At first her mother was upset she bought a plant that cost several dollars, but then, hearing her daughter's disappointment in herself, she found joy in the beautiful plant while Saeng’s mother was cooking dinner. Saeng planted the beautiful plant and told herself when the geese return, the hibiscus is budding, and it's spring, she will retake the test. She found strength in herself and courage to do better, a newfound resilience. I think the author wanted to show how she gained respect for herself in the end of the passage, a key moment of personal growth. That is why the author ended it like she did, highlighting this inner transformation.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is what the whole story is about. It is about how Saeng misses home and failed the test, a failure connected to when she bought the hibiscus. Saeng failed the test because she was distracted by buying the hibiscus and the memories it triggered. She let herself buy the flower and remember her home, and that made her sad and unable to focus. In that last paragraph she is saying when the geese come back in the spring, she will be used to the new country and home, and will not fail the test again. If she is tempted by something from home, she will not let it distract her because it will make her sad and hinder her progress. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is the main idea of the story, showing her getting used to the new home and moving forward.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” written by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with that paragraph to sum it all up, providing a final reflection on Saeng's journey. The paragraph serves to encapsulate the themes of adaptation and hope that run throughout the narrative. The author used this to keep the reader wondering too, leaving a sense of thoughtful contemplation about Saeng's future. This ending allows the reader to ponder the character's resolve and the symbolic meaning of the winter hibiscus itself, creating a resonant and memorable conclusion.

The author concludes the story with, “when they come back, saeng vowed Silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”, to show that even though she failed her test she isn’t giving up and that she will persevere over this and continue to try. This ending shows the determination in Saeng’s heart, a quiet but resilient strength that emerges after her initial disappointment. Saeng has enough determination inside of her to go on even though she failed her test and failed her grandmother to continue trying and continue to try to complete for her grandmother and herself. Her vow is not just about a test, but about honoring her past and embracing her future. I really liked this ending and I am glad that the author decided to use this ending in the story, as it leaves the reader with a powerful sense of hope.

Having failed the drivers test really upset Saeng. Not only that but she had to moved to a new country and the loss of her grandmother really made thing worse, compounding her feelings of isolation and grief. The Hibiscus plant in this story, is like a symbol. It represents her life and reminds her of one in Vietnam, serving as a tangible link to her homeland and her grandmother. The way memorys come to her as she sees these flowers shows how she felt, connecting her present struggles to her past memories. It was all about starting new and overcoming obstacles. When she says, “… and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it shows her starting new again and making it through the rough times, symbolized by winter. It was a symbol of herself and the hardship she will overcome, mirroring her own capacity for renewal.

In the story the author concludes the story in his last paragraph because he showes that even in her hardships, Saeng finds a way to move forward. Saeng goes on and keeps trying to live a normal life after she had to move, adapting to her new environment despite the challenges. For example when it says, “Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring I will take the test again.” This shows that even after one failuare you should never give up but don`t forget the past. The ending powerfully conveys that perseverance is built upon the lessons and memories we carry with us, allowing us to face new beginnings with courage and resolve.

The author of the story “winter Hibiscus”, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with a meaningful paragraph. The author wrote, “When they come back…in the spring… then I will take that test again”. Saeng thought to herself and meant that she would move on in the spring, using the changing season as a metaphor for her personal renewal. It also shows that Saeng could overcome failing the test. The narrative also states,”…in the spring…when…this hibiscus is budding…”. The season of spring means to symbolically start new and fresh. When the flower is budding, it is beginning a new life, pushing forth from a dormant state. Saeng is also starting fresh when she decides that she will take the test in the spring, aligning her personal growth with the natural world. Finally, this shows that Saeng could adopt to her new life by purchasing a familiar plant, which provided her with comfort and a sense of continuity. The hibiscus helped her get through disappointing times, acting as a silent companion. The geese also were a reminder that some things back home were the same, offering a connection to her past. Minfong Ho concluded the story with this paragraph to emphasize Saeng's adaptations and her resilient spirit in the face of change.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she wants to tell people that shes going to take the test again and try, demonstrating a commitment to not be defined by a single setback. Shes going to be like the flowers but she needs time so when they budd she will, indicating that her own growth and readiness are tied to a natural, patient process of healing and preparation. The paragraph serves as a quiet promise of future action, showing that Saeng understands the importance of timing and inner strength before embarking on a new attempt. This final thought leaves the reader with a sense of anticipation for Saeng's future success.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the story ends with Saeng promising herself that she will take the test again in the spring. The author most likely ends this way because it shows how Saeng is getting over her sorrow and planning to retake the test in the spring when the Hibiscus is in bloom. This is shown when Saeng says “I-I failed the test,” which highlights the pain of leaving her homeland and makes her even more sad, but she then promises herself that in the spring when flowers bloom she will try again. She does this when she says to herself “...in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This shows her getting over her sorrow and becoming determined, looking forward and preparing to take the test again, thus concluding her emotional journey on a hopeful note.

The author concludes the story with the line, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts when the geese return and this hibiscus budding, then I will take that test again.” The author does this to show how Saeng was able to slowly adjust to change while not forgetting where she came from. This is shown by using symbols of geese and hibiscus together. The geese represent the new home and sounds Saeng had to become adjusted to, while the hibiscus represents the old memories of her past and homeland. Putting the symbols together shows she has come to accept both places. By vowing that she’ll take the test again in the spring shows how she will be ready for the change because the test represents how she feels about her new life, and by passing the test she allows herself to pass with her past and adjust to the change in her life, achieving a sense of balance.

They used this sentence because she wants to see the flower bud and feels like she is at home again, which gives her the strength to face her challenges. Then she will take the test with renewed confidence. She also will feel lucky and have a comforting memory of home, so Saeng vowed silently to herself that she would try again when the conditions were right, showing her resilience and connection to her roots.

The author concludes the story with the sentence, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The story tells us about most of the hard times and obstacles Saeng has had to go through. The two major ones in this story were moving to a new place and failing her driving test. Saeng had a hard time trying to overcome these events and others. So I think this sentence was put at the end so the readers could see that she was going to be ok and overcome everything that happened. Now we know this special plant will help Saeng with future problems, symbolizing her enduring strength and hope for the future.

After reading the story, “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I believe the quote, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” was put in the story for a reason. I believe that this quote concluded the story because it established a tone and feeling of hope. For example, in the story it states that “Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the plant into it.” This shows that this plant means a lot to her. The story tells the reader that it triggers memories of her grandmother. It represents hope to Saeng because it always brings back happy memories she once had which push her to try to overcome her losses better. Therefore, the quote concludes the story because it is about Saeng’s will for hope and peace. It represents that when the plant blooms in the spring she will have a new found sense of hope and happiness, completing her emotional arc.

"Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho is a story about a young girl's transition to America and her own ability to be strong. Saeng failed her driver's test and was deeply disappointed as she walked home through the unfamiliar streets. She stops at a florist shop because she sees a specific plant that she thinks is like the hibiscus she had back home in her native country. Seeing this plant again makes her remember vivid memories from her homeland, such as festivals and time spent with her grandmother. She carefully plants it when she gets home and vows to take the driving test again, finding new determination. When the wild geese get back in the spring, she will be ready. The plant is like a personal encouragment to her, a symbol of resilience.

The author concludes the story with this particular paragraph because the narrative was about her getting accustomed to things being repeated in nature, like the changing seasons and the migration of birds. The author added the last paragraph saying that when everything happens again, such as the geese returning, she will do the same and try again. This cyclical pattern mirrors Saeng's renewed resolve, which is why the author concludes the story with the paragraph, emphasizing the theme of persistence within natural cycles.

I think the author includes that part of the story because she might have failed her driver's test and needed more time to study and practice to get things right. The failure was a setback, but it was not the end of her efforts. Other than that, the new environment was challenging, and the hibiscus plant served as a crucial link to her past, giving her the strength to face her current difficulties and prepare for another attempt in the future.

The author uses this sentence to conclude the story to show that Saeng’s hope is restored after a period of sadness. Throughout the story Saeng is sad and misses her home, feeling disconnected and lonely. She feels hopeless in this new land, but the unexpected hibiscus reminds her powerfully of home and brings back specific memories of her being at home with her grandmother, which initially makes her want to be back at home. The author adds the part about the geese leaving because they also have to leave their home, highlighting a shared experience of migration. Ultimately, the hibiscus is meant to symbolize her being strong and that she will make it through moving to a just strange land, serving as a beacon of her inner strength.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng won’t give up and will keep trying despite her initial failure. In the story, all the memories of her old country, triggered by the hibiscus, ultimately encouraged her to be strong and resilient. For example, the flower made her sad at first as she reminisced, but in the end it made her feel better and more determined. Also in the beginning she didn’t really like new changes and she missed home terribly, but at the end some of the same comforting memories and symbols she had back home were found in her new country, helping her adapt. Those are the reasons I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph, to underscore her character growth and newfound perseverance.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I believe that the author ended the story with that paragraph because it shows that if the hibiscus plant has enough strength to come back and flourish, then she has enough strength to come back and take the test again. For example, in the story it says, “but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months.” This quote shows that the hibiscus plant is strong and resilient. And Saeng sees that as an inspiration; if the plant is strong enough to return after a cold winter, then she can return to the test after failing it. The parallel between her struggle and the plant's cycle reinforces her determination. Overall, I think that both Saeng and the hibiscus plants are very strong, embodying a shared spirit of perseverance.

In this story, it is about how Saeng and the hibiscus plant are similar when it comes to adapting to their surroundings and how she and the plant will keep continuing, just like Saeng with her “test.” But I know this because it says, “Then I will take that test again.” Her saying that is her declaring she will thrive again, just like the hibiscus plant thrives after the winter. This connection highlights her resolve to persevere through challenges. So in conclusion, she really is much like the plant and will continue for many seasons to come, adapting to the changes in her life just as the hibiscus adapts to the changing seasons.

The author ended the story with the last paragraph because springtime comes and geese return, and she will feel better about herself, so she can go and take the test again and focus more on the test. The arrival of spring symbolizes a new beginning and hope, which lifts her spirits after her initial failure. This renewed sense of optimism gives her the confidence to try again. Therefore, the ending effectively ties her personal renewal to the natural cycle, showing her readiness to face the challenge with improved determination.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with that paragraph because it goes along with the story's themes. In the story, Saeng went to look for the plant that reminded her of her grandma. She found the plant and then she thought of her grandma and she cried. I think she was testing herself to see if she had moved on with her life, but she found she had not entirely succeeded. So I think she bought the plant so she can try again when the plant is in bloom, using its cyclical rebirth as a model for her own emotional recovery and future attempts to adapt.

He wants to learn the hibiscus spirit. Don't be afraid of failure. You just keep moving ahead, continuously learning what you want, and then you will succeed. Like the hibiscus, which has a strong will to live and fights against its environment, Saeng is inspired by its resilience. So, the author uses this paragraph to conclude; the purpose is to show that Saeng will take this test again, just as the hibiscus will bud when spring comes, symbolizing that persistence through hardship leads to eventual success.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, the hibiscus is budding. she will take the test. I think that the author conclude the story with this paragraph because she wants to test them again, showing Saeng's determination to face her challenges anew. This final vow underscores her resilience and hope for a fresh start, mirroring the cyclical return of the seasons. The author uses this moment to emphasize Saeng's personal growth and her commitment to trying once more, bringing the narrative to a close on a note of quiet perseverance and future possibility.

The author ended that story like that because that’s how she started the story. The little girl was looking at the flowers and plants in the beginning, so the author thought that it would be a good thing to end the story like it was started, creating a sense of symmetry. Also because the friendship that Saeng has with the plants and flowers will come back again in the spring when everything is blooming and looking very beautiful. It shows that the plants give a sense of comfort when she is going through hard times, providing a familiar solace in her new life. That is why the author concludes with Saeng and the plants, reinforcing their role as a source of stability and hope for her.

In Minfong Ho’s “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with a meaningful paragraph. The author tries to make a message to Saeng. When Saeng saw the geese “slowly fading into the distance” she thought of herself. “When they come back" Saeng will also come back to school. “the geese return and this hibiscus is budding” means that Saeng will return to the school and be a new person. “This hibiscus is budding” states that Saeng is still growing, just like the hibiscus. She will then take that test again because it’s a new start for her and a new beginning. Spring is an archetype of rebirth and a new life; since the flowers will be growing and having a new life, so will Saeng, symbolizing her personal renewal and the cyclical nature of hope and growth.

Saeng vowed to herself that when the hibiscus begins to bud again she will take the test again. The hibiscus symbolizes hope to Saeng that things can work out a second try. She concludes the story with the vow because it expresses her last bit of hope, a final affirmation of her will to persevere. For example, the hibiscus has comforted her in a new country, with new surroundings but it also explains how she feels, connecting her past to her present. She vows to show she won't give up despite of falling the first time. For example, “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral” (Ho). This quote explains what the plant meant to her, a profound link to her identity and strength. This is why she concluded the story with a vow, highlighting its significance as a turning point in her journey.

The author ends the story with this paragraph to show Saeng’s resolution. Her family had left a lot behind in Vietnam. She had the memory of her grandmother and hibiscus. In the new country they are struggling as implied by the mothers reaction at the cost. The hibiscus she bought was a way to comfort her, a tangible piece of her heritage. She thinks that if the plant can put up with the harsh winter environment she can do despite the differences in the new land and passing the drivers exam is something that many do and is a way to get used to her surroundings and fit in. This final thought solidifies her determination to adapt and succeed, using the hardy plant as a model for her own resilience in a challenging new world.

The author concludes the story with this sentence because it shows the girl is willing to overcome obstacles and although she may have failed once she will keep trying. It also shows a connection between the geese and the hibiscus and the girl wanting to overcome her obstacles, drawing strength from the natural world around her. Also the girl wants to overcome her obstacle at a certain time, choosing a moment that holds personal significance for her renewed effort. This deliberate timing underscores her thoughtful and resilient approach to challenges.

In the last paragraph when she said she was going to have the test again, but in the spring when all the snow melts and the hibiscus buds, she is making a meaningful choice. She says that because that is her favorite time of the year, a period filled with beauty and personal comfort. So she will feel more confident that time, as the environment itself provides her with encouragement. For example when she talks about the Madagascar hibiscus that grows through bricks she loves hibiscuses, seeing in them a powerful symbol of perseverance. So she wants to take the test when she feels the best, aligning her personal challenge with a season of hope and growth.

I believe the author concluded the story with that paragraph to let readers know that Saeng is a survivor just like the hibiscus, possessing a tenacious spirit that allows her to endure difficult circumstances. Saeng has not quite adapted to America and feels that this plant reminds her of home, providing a vital emotional anchor in her new life. The hibiscus serves as a living metaphor for her own journey, connecting her past with her present and symbolizing her capacity to thrive despite challenges. This final connection solidifies the story's theme of resilience and the comfort found in familiar symbols from one's homeland.

The author finishes it with this because spring time is a new beginning, a season universally associated with renewal and fresh starts. Since Saeng failed the test she wants to start over in the spring like the flowers do, aligning her personal rebirth with the natural cycle. To know that the hibiscus will grow back though now it is dying gives her the hope and courage needed to try again. For spring to come is a time to start a new, where babies are born, flowers are in bloom and a new beginning is forming, and Saeng plans to be a part of that hopeful new start.

The author concludes the sentence this way because they are trying to show that Saeng is a very determined girl and no matter how many times she fails, she always tries again and again until she gets it right. By doing this the author is showing what Saeng believes in and that is no matter how big or hard the challenge is she will keep on going until she has done what she started. Because moving was very hard for her, this determination is even more significant. She had a very hard time communicating with people and just trying to make friends cause it is not always easy being new; by moving she took another look at things because they were different to her. But as time went by she got the hang of it, proving that as long as you try you can be successful, and that is what the author was trying to say by concluding it the way it was, emphasizing that persistence ultimately leads to adaptation and success.

In the story a young girl named Saeng takes a test but she had failed. She is going to retake it next spring, which is why the last paragraph says; when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again. The author concludes the story with this ending. In the story it talks about the hibiscus flowers, so since she failed the test, instead of simply saying she will retake it next spring, they say when the hibiscus flowers bud, which is a natural sign that spring has arrived. This connection to the flower makes her resolution more personal and tied to the cycles of nature she observes around her.

The author concludes the story in that manner to let the readers know that the daughter Saeng would come back and take the test again. She loves the garden and the natural world it represents, and therefore she will not forget what spring, with its promise of renewal and growth, did for her. Her love for the garden gives her hope and a timeline for her own personal renewal and second attempt, linking her fate to the seasons she cherishes.

It shows that she loves her plants deeply. The story tells you about all of the different plants and how she likes and cares for each one individually. She thinks they are all unique in their own way and that she enjoys tending to the plants and being in the garden more than school or anything else at that moment. This deep connection to her plants provides her with a sense of identity and comfort, which is central to her character.

Minfong Ho concludes "The Winter Hibiscus" with this paragraph because it shows Saeng's determination to succeed in her new country despite the obstacles she faces. The winter hibiscus reminds Saeng to be strong like the hibiscus is, to endure the winter, or in Saeng's case, to pass the driving test. The text states, "....but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus...." Saeng realizes she must also be "strong" like the "winter hibiscus." Saeng also realizes that she is beginning to adapt to the new country, as shown when she thought, "Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought strange before had become almost familiar..." Saeng knows that she is able to adapt and is determined to succeed. The author concludes with, "..in the spring, the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The "spring" will be Saeng's time of new beginnings and success, mirroring the blooming flower.

In the story, "The Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with the last paragraph because she is trying to say that when the flower comes back to life and starts a new beginning, Saeng will also start a new beginning by retaking the test. For example, “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing". This example is saying how the plant was almost dead when she bought it, symbolizing a difficult start. Another example would be, "I-I failed the test". This example tells how she feels down about failing the test, experiencing her own low point. So in the story, the flower was at its "breaking point" as well as Saeng. The final paragraph tells how Saeng was going to take a break and wait for the flower to become stronger, just as she would strengthen her own resolve, until she took the test again with renewed hope.

The author added the last paragraph because Saeng's vow helps the reader understand Saeng and her pain, but also her optimism that things will get better. I interpret the vow to mean that when life starts to become normal again, her situation in this new country will improve significantly. The spring symbolizes this return to normalcy because in her homeland, which she associates with a normal life, the landscape is covered with beautiful flowers, much like spring. The melting snow represents her current pain and hardship gradually going away. The returning geese serve as a symbol that Saeng knows things will get better, just as she knows with certainty that the geese will return in the spring. The hibiscus in the story has consistently symbolized her home and her grandmother, which in turn represent happiness, so its budding indicates she will find greater happiness when her circumstances improve.

The author concludes the story with this sentence because the girl Saeng wanted to take the test again, but she also wanted her hibiscus to stay strong and to keep growing. Therefore, she declared, "I will take the test again when my hibiscus starts to bloom again." This statement connects her personal goal of retaking the test to the natural cycle and health of the plant, which represents her own resilience and hope for the future. By linking her action to the plant's blooming, she expresses a commitment to try again only when she feels a sense of renewal and strength, mirroring the flower's revival.

"Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho explores one's quest for acceptance and adaptation to changes in life. Saeng is the young protagonist in the story who is dealing with her recent move to America from her homeland in Asia. After failing a driving test, Saeng spends an exorbitant amount of money on a flower, a hibiscus. When she consoles with her mother, Saeng silently vows something to herself. Saeng vows "when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". Minfong Ho chose to end the story this way because the narrative represents the quest for adaptation. Single-handedly, Saeng was able to make a vow to herself that showed she had accepted her new foreign home of America, even though she will always remember and cherish her homeland, finding a way to bridge her past and her present.

The author concludes this paragraph in the article because Saeng is not in love with the plant but uses it as a clock to tell her when she can take the test. The reason for this is that if you are not a U.S. citizen, you can only take the driver's test once a year. Therefore, the hibiscus serves as a natural timer and a symbol of hope, marking the passage of time until she is eligible to try again. Her vow is tied to the plant's cycle because its blooming will signal that the waiting period is over and the right time has come for her next attempt.

The reason that the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because Saeng wants to do something good for herself. The evidence for this is found in the last paragraph, which states that "Saeng vowed silently to herself," which means she is making a personal commitment for her own benefit and future well-being. This silent vow represents an internal promise to persevere and improve her own circumstances. It signifies a turning point where she decides to focus on her own growth and happiness, choosing to face her challenges with renewed determination.

Saeng believes that because she failed the driving test that she won’t be able to transition to her new country, so she goes searching for her past. She finds her past in plants, remembering Vietnam with a deep sorrow. The narration states, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng's eyes…” She remembers and misses everything she had; she wanted her country, her grandmother, and her old life. She came home to her mother with a plant and disappointed her mother with the cost, but her mother understands the pain. The narration states, “it’s a beautiful plant she finally said in a sad voice, you got it.” Eventually, Saeng realizes how this plant affected her and how easily it survived, and she made a promise to herself. The narration states, “and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” showing her newfound resolve to persevere.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends with, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This is to show or emphasize that if the hibiscus, a plant reminding her of her home, can overcome the winter, then so can she. In the story, after the author had failed her driving test and was walking back home, seeing the flowers reminded her of home and connected her to her past, making her feel less alone. For example, when the author says, “A wave of loss so deep & strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her,” it shows that she misses her home and the flower gave her a way to more deeply connect to her memories. Also, when she observes “like the geese the distinctive V against the sky,” it shows that the geese were kind of like her; they were moving to a different place to start anew, making her feel that if they can adapt and change, so will she over time. In conclusion, the ending was to further emphasize her complex feelings towards her hometown and her resolve in the new town she lives in.

The author ends the story by comparing Saeng's journey to adapting, changing, or doing everything all over again. For example, the geese fly away when it gets cold but they always come back, giving their home another chance. The hibiscus is another fine example; it buds in the spring always but doesn’t die in the winter. It always returns. Saeng has obviously realized this pattern of resilience and vowed to try her driver’s test again because it might work this time. The author was trying to spread the message of “don’t give up,” illustrating that persistence, like that seen in nature, leads to new beginnings and success.

Determination, help, strength – all are reasons why I believe the author concludes the story with the paragraph. First, determination is a key reason why Saeng will go back and take the test again. Saeng failed her driver's test the first time and she wants to wait and do it again. She's determined to take different steps in order to pass the test. Secondly, I believe that help is a key reason why the author concluded with that paragraph. Saeng will need help in order to pass the test and she believes that the hibiscus plant will help her pass and help her to do other things. The author is proving that she’ll go back and she’ll be ready. Finally, strength is the last key reason why the author chose the paragraph to end the story. Saeng believes that the hibiscus plant will give her the strength to pass the test. The author left off with the paragraph to show she will go back and she’ll be stronger than she was before. These are the reasons why I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph.

Mingfong Ho concludes “Winter Hibiscus” with the paragraph, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This ending paragraph shows that Saeng will not give up in her struggle to adapt in this new place. Saeng has been going through hard times; moving to the United States and failing her driver’s test. In the greenhouse, Saeng even breaks down and cries. The hibiscus flower that Saeng bought cost the family a lot of money, but to Saeng it was very important. This flower represented hope and a connection to her homeland. When the flower buds again it would be the right time to take her driver’s test. The flower also represents adapting to a new place, as Saeng adapts to the United States, the hibiscus adapts to the new garden, symbolizing resilience and the promise of new growth.

The author ends the story with this paragraph to show how Saeng changed. Saeng didn’t want to take the test and she had no confidence, feeling overwhelmed by her new environment. In the story Saeng's mother supports her no matter what, offering unconditional love and patience. She even understood when Saeng bought a plant for @MONEY1 because it reminded her of home, recognizing her daughter's need for a comforting connection to her past. Now that Saeng has been comforted by this small piece of her homeland, she feels more relaxed and she is ready and more confident to take the test again. Therefore Saeng has changed, moving from a state of despair to one of hopeful determination.

The author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends the story with Saeng’s thoughts. In "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the last paragraph is a vow by the main character, Saeng, to retake her driver's test when spring comes and her hibiscus is budding. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it gives a sense of hope to the otherwise sad narrative. It suggests that Saeng will ultimately be okay and will gradually move past her intense longing for the country of her birth. This is seen after she breaks down and weeps in the warm, moist shelter of the greenhouse, overwhelmed by sadness and misery as all the flowers vividly reminded her of her home country. She was deeply depressed and homesick. When she returned home, she planted a hibiscus plant in the frozen ground, knowing that when it would bloom in the spring, it would represent a new life and another chance. This act meant that Saeng would not give up on her new life. By concluding "Winter Hibiscus" on this positive note with the last paragraph, Minfong Ho provides a resolution that emphasizes resilience and the promise of a fresh start.

The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to herself—"in the spring, when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again"—to create a sense of hopeful suspense. The statement that she ate all the plant is likely a misunderstanding; the intended meaning is that she will nurture the hibiscus and, in the coming year, face the test again with renewed determination, not consume the plant. This forward-looking promise is precisely why the author chose to end the story on this particular note, leaving the reader with an anticipation of her future success.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concluded the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng is going to give the test another try. The author wanted to show that Saeng was not giving up and that when the thing that was most important to her was complete, she would then take the test again. In the story it says that "Saeng did not dare look at her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus," which was important to her. This moment of connection with the plant, a symbol of her past and her resilience, solidifies her inner vow to try again, demonstrating her renewed determination to succeed in her new life.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” the narrative ends by stating, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author concludes the story with that quote because the author sees spring as a new beginning, a time for renewal and fresh starts. The author knows one must work hard and sometimes needs to start over. For example, some students fail the second semester and look at winter as a new start, using the time to reflect and prepare for the opportunities that spring represents, just as Saeng does.

The author ends the story with the paragraph because it is winter time and she cannot do anything in the winter because of the snow. The snow made it so that she would have to take a test in the spring, a season of new growth and possibility. This seasonal delay is not presented as a failure but as a natural period of waiting, aligning her personal journey with the cyclical patterns of nature and suggesting that her chance will come with the thaw.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng has overcome an obstacle in her life and that she is learning to move on. In the story Saeng is often stuck on past memories rather than making new ones. For example, when Saeng goes to the florist shop to purchase the plant, she starts remembering old memories from her homeland. When she sees the plant labeled “jasmine”, she thinks of her grandmother that died and remembers how she used to put jasmine blossoms in her hair. Also, she tells her mother that the hibiscus she bought is “not a real one” and she also says it’s “not like the kind we had before.” Essentially, she keeps comparing her new life to her old life in her homeland and she does not allow her new experiences to be as good as her old ones. Therefore, when the author concludes the story with that paragraph, it shows growth in the girl, Saeng, and that she is willing to move on and make new memories, such as trying to pass her driving test again, symbolizing her acceptance of her present and future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the story is coming to an end. The author is putting that sweet touch on it, saying the hibiscus will become strong again and the beautiful flowers will blossom. This is a metaphor for Saeng's own spirit, letting the readers know that nature will continue and the seasons will come back around, bringing with them new chances for growth and beauty, just as they will for her.

This paragraph includes details to let the reader know it's winter. You know it's winter because in the passage it says when the snow melts, which is a seasonal event that occurs after the cold winter months. The mention of melting snow directly signals the end of the winter season and the transition into spring, providing a clear temporal setting for the narrative. This detail effectively grounds the story in a specific time of year, using a common natural phenomenon to indicate the season without needing to state it explicitly. The connection between the snow and the changing seasons is a straightforward way to establish the story's timeline.

Saeng had failed her driver's test, and afterward she went to a florist and bought a plant. It was the "dok faeng noi", a plant about which she had fond memories. She remembered it from Vietnam, and how it used to be everywhere all the time. She had bought the hibiscus as a comfort to herself after her disappointment. The last paragraph says, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." Saeng figured out that things happen for a reason and opportunities occur over and over again, just as the natural world operates in cycles. Just as the geese go south and then return north as the seasons change, she understood that her own chance would come again. She had decided she will retake the test next time she gets a chance, embracing the cyclical nature of opportunity.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This is used to show that the character has become a part of her new environment and its rhythms. Just like the environment, she is constantly going through changes and cycles of growth. In the spring when all things that couldn’t be their best during winter begin to thrive and renew themselves, she will too find her strength returning. And when she begins thriving and feels like herself again, then she’ll be ready to take the driving test, and pass it successfully. She’ll have returned to her old self, just as the geese return home; when she's done with her sorrow, just as the snow is done melting; and when she’s ready to open up and try again, just like the hibiscus begins budding, she’ll be ready to take the test with renewed hope.

All throughout the story "Winter Hibiscus", the author gives the feeling of hope and comfort that is obtained by Saeng when she thinks about the past and her memories. To continue this feeling of hope, the last sentence gives the feeling that Saeng will be better off than she had been at the beginning of the story, suggesting a positive personal evolution. For example, at the beginning of the story, Saeng was feeling alienated, alone, and misplaced in her new country, struggling with her sense of identity. But as the story progresses, she starts to develop a peace of mind and certainty that her future will be brighter with the passing of time and her growing self-assurance. In conclusion, the author uses the last sentence to give a feeling of hope for Saeng’s future and her growing confidence, ensuring the reader is left with an optimistic outlook for her journey ahead.

The meaning of the last phrase is to see if the winter hibiscus can reseed and go through everything required to become a flower for the year and then repeat the process again in its next cycle. It reflects the plant's natural lifecycle of enduring harsh conditions, blooming, and then starting the process anew, which serves as a metaphor for resilience and renewal. This cyclical process of growth, dormancy, and regrowth is central to understanding the plant's symbolic significance in the story. It highlights the theme of perseverance through difficult periods with the promise of future blossoming. The phrase ultimately underscores the idea of continuous effort and the natural, repeating patterns of life that lead to success.

Minfong Ho concluded "Winter Hibiscus" with that paragraph to show hope and renewal for the character Saeng. Spring represents birth and renewal, a second chance for Saeng. She had previously failed what seems to be an important test, perhaps her citizenship test, and this failure motivated her to try and remember her past, which she sorely misses. The winter hibiscus seems to represent herself, and this illustrates it: “it’s-it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled; she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. ‘Not like the kind we had before.’ ‘I know,’ her mother said quietly, ‘its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That is what matters.’ This describes Saeng’s position perfectly—she is not the same, not as happy as she once was in her homeland, but she can make it through the hard times, and can bloom in the spring to take the test again. This shows the purpose of the last paragraph in "Winter Hibiscus" is to illustrate the renewal and hope that Saeng will experience, suggesting her resilience will lead to future success.

I think that this sentence was chosen to be the last sentence because it shows that Saeng can pass the test. Although she is not in her homeland, she still has the ability to do things and succeed in her new environment. As the plant that reminds her of home returns and begins to grow with the coming spring, Saeng will do the same, finding new strength and determination. The parallel between the resilient plant and Saeng's own potential for growth makes it a fitting final sentence. It leaves you wondering if she will pass the test, creating a sense of hopeful anticipation for her future endeavors and symbolizing her enduring connection to her past and her capacity to adapt and flourish.

The author ends the story with that paragraph because the flower gives her strength. It gives her hope and reminds her of home, where they were everywhere; she had to buy this one in her new country. She planted it so it can grow through the winter, symbolizing her own struggle to endure a difficult period of adjustment and failure. After winter the flower gets huge, and with this renewed hope, she passes her driver's test.
