For a reward, her mom gets her a real Vietnamese flower, creating a poignant conclusion that ties her success directly to the symbolic hope and connection to her heritage that the winter hibiscus provided.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng knows she was wrong about giving up and she wants to make it up to her mother by showing a renewed spirit. Also, she is showing her mother how much she really likes nature and values the connections to their homeland that it represents. The act of tending to the plant becomes a quiet apology and a promise to persevere. This final moment underscores her personal growth and her desire to reconcile her past with her present, demonstrating her commitment to her family and to building a new life without forgetting the old one.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng failed her driving test the first time and she was saying to herself that she will take it again. The paragraph serves to highlight her determination not to be defeated by this initial setback. It frames her resolve within the larger theme of resilience, showing that she is ready to face the challenge once more. This ending reinforces the idea that failure is not permanent but a step toward eventual success, effectively wrapping up her character's immediate struggle while pointing toward a hopeful future where she will try again with renewed confidence.

I think the author used that response because she was showing that she had to go through another season of hard work in planting flowers, a process that mirrored her own personal struggles. This parallel suggests that growth and beauty often require persistent effort and the endurance of difficult periods, much like the cycle of nature demands patience and care. The author likely intended to highlight this connection between the character's labor and her internal journey, emphasizing that rewards come only after sustained dedication. Therefore, the mention of the hard work in planting serves to reinforce the theme of perseverance through challenges, illustrating that the character's efforts are a necessary prelude to achieving her goals. This creates a cohesive link between the narrative's action and its underlying message about resilience.

The author concluded the story "Winter Hibiscus" the way she did because she wanted to show Saeng’s determination. At one point in the story, the author wrote, “she was still too shaky to say the words at home,” highlighting Saeng's deep sense of displacement. Saeng really missed her old life and her old country, feeling a profound sense of nostalgia and loss. She often wonders when she will be able to go back to it and enjoy herself, because she still has significant trouble adjusting to her new life and its unfamiliar customs. When the author concluded the story, it was done so that Saeng could be shown as a person who would not easily give up, demonstrating her inner strength. Although she’d had previous trouble and setbacks, the end of the story gives new hope for Saeng to adjust to her new surroundings and find her place. Also, when Saeng fails the driving test, the ending sentence gives new hope; after Saeng told her mother, “I failed the test,” and she was really down on herself when she said so, the narrative shifts. The closing sentence gives new hope to Saeng and the reader, suggesting that she will work harder and do better in the spring, embracing a new beginning. The author shows Saeng’s determination to rise above failure and create a niche of her own in life, proving her resilience. In all, the closing sentence in “Winter Hibiscus” is used to show Saeng’s determination and her capacity for hopeful perseverance.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because she feels a deep connection to the migrating geese, and her most cherished memories relate to the times she sees the geese flying overhead, which symbolize freedom and continuity. I think that her test is in school, perhaps a significant academic challenge, but she has a strong belief that she’ll pass it by remembering her memories, as they provide her with comfort and strength. She feels connected to the outside world and nature, which grounds her during times of stress. For example, she loves flowers, which represent beauty and growth in her life, and this passion is a source of inspiration for her. That’s why I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph, to emphasize how her connection to nature and her past empowers her to face future challenges with confidence and hope, thus providing a satisfying resolution to her emotional journey.

The author concludes the story, "Winter Hibiscus", with a very spiritual and confident paragraph to show that hope has an important part in our lives, serving as a crucial anchor during difficult times. In the story, Saeng, a foreign Chinese citizen, is touched and flattened by all the majestic plants and nature that was living in the green house, which evokes a powerful sense of wonder and nostalgia. She ventures to find all the plants that remind her of home and to relate them to her past experiences, seeking comfort in their familiar presence. As she walks through the green house, she whispers and pronounces the names of the nature she sees; “Saebba,” Saeng whispered, “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag pronounced. “How strange to see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild!” But as her tour grew with time, she soon realizes she is missing some of her memories, and begins to cry, overwhelmed by the sense of loss and disconnection. As she reaches home she is greeted by her mother, who offers a comforting presence. “I-I failed the test,” Saeng said, revealing her vulnerability and disappointment. Saeng's mother is touched by her comment, and cheers her up with planting the “hibiscus,” an act that symbolizes renewal and care. In the end, the author shows strong expression by writing one last paragraph to bring out hope, and emotion, to represent that everyone deserves a second chance and that beauty can emerge from hardship, thus concluding the narrative on a uplifting and resonant note.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he is basically saying he's never taking that test again, expressing a firm and final decision on the matter. The author is showing that the character doesn’t like this test, finding it particularly burdensome or unpleasant. And would rather not take it, preferring to move on to other pursuits or challenges that are more aligned with his interests and strengths. This definitive stance underscores the character's resolve to avoid repeating a negative experience, highlighting a moment of self-awareness and personal choice. The conclusion therefore serves to establish the character's autonomy and his commitment to leaving an unsatisfactory situation behind, which provides a clear and decisive end to that particular narrative thread. This finality reinforces the theme of personal agency and the conscious rejection of what does not serve one's well-being.

The author of the story ends it with a very interesting and meaningful paragraph. This paragraph talks about overcoming obstacles and is telling the reader to try again. It is important to never give up and to keep trying until you succeed. In the story, Saeng had just moved away from Vietnam and she really missed it, and on top of it, Saeng failed her drivers test. She was really upset and felt discouraged by this setback. She saw a group of geese flying above her and said when they come back in the spring and my new plant starts to grow I will retake my drivers test. Geese have to overcome the cold by flying south for the winter, which is a difficult journey. The cold weather is an obstacle for them that they must face each year. Also her new plant can't grow until its warm, as it remains dormant during the cold months. Her plant has to overcome being small and vulnerable until it can finally bud in the spring. People face obstacles all the time, just like Saeng and the natural world. You have to keep trying in order to get around them and achieve your goals.

The short story “Winter Hibiscus” ends the way it does because the narrator realizes that with spring comes a new chance or opportunity to start over, a rebirth. One passage from the text that shows the narrator’s hope states, “Almost reluctantly, she realised that many of the things that he had thought of as strange before, through that quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This passage of text shows that she realized that a lot of things that seemed foreign to her before suddenly had purpose and were becoming part of her life. She realized that there is a new rebirth in the spring, a time for renewal and growth. The conclusion sentences states that she is going to retake the test in the spring, linking her personal renewal to the season. She now realizes that she now has a whole new opportunity and life to start, filled with potential. The conclusion sentence of “Winter Hibiscus” is one of realization of opportunity with spring beginning, marking a hopeful end to her struggles.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the motivation and confidence Saeng has after her experience with the plant. There are many reasons and examples that support this central idea. One reason is, he wants to show the change in Saeng after her first test and when she bought the flower to relieve her sadness. For example, after she failed the driving test, Saeng goes to the Florist to find some comfort. When she sees this plant, her childhood comes back to her and she forgets about her test for a moment. This flower motivates her to get her license by reminding her of resilience and beauty. Another reason is, it shows how confident this experience has made her, transforming her disappointment into determination. For example, after failing, she comes back saying, “… I will take the test again,” demonstrating her newfound resolve. In conclusion, the author includes this paragraph to show how confident Saeng has become over her experience, ending the story on a note of personal strength.

The author concludes the story with that statement at the end because he wants to show that Saeng won't give up, just like the hibiscus plant. For example, the hibiscus does its best to survive in the harsh winter and then blooms and starts over in the spring, symbolizing perseverance. Saeng will also survive the emotional winter of her failure and start all over again in the spring and retake the test, mirroring the plant's cycle. The author wanted to show the readers that Saeng is like the hibiscus in a way that she has to start over and retry what she has failed, as if the hibiscus had died back in the winter only to be reborn. This parallel emphasizes the theme of resilience and the constant opportunity for a new beginning.

My response is that the story is about winter, so really it is going to be about winter activities and the feelings associated with the season. It involves walking around in the cold weather, having fun in the snow, and experiencing all those things that make winter a distinct time of year. The narrative likely explores these elements to set a scene or establish a mood for the events that unfold. The conclusion would therefore tie these winter experiences together into a cohesive whole.

The author concludes the story in that manner to make the reader more interested and to foster the understanding that the events will happen again and again, year after year, in a continuous, cyclical pattern. This ending emphasizes the repetitive nature of the narrative's core conflict or theme, suggesting a sense of inevitability and timelessness that extends beyond the final page, thereby engaging the reader's imagination about the future.

The author concludes the story with that particular paragraph because he wants to show that the flower was her inspiration to take the test previously. The way I arrived at my response was by noting that throughout the story, @PERSON1 was consistently either gardening the hibiscus or had one nearby. This recurring motif clearly indicated to me that she was inspired by this specific flower and its inherent beauty, which served as a personal talisman. In conclusion, the author ends the story like this to underscore the profound importance of the Hibiscus flower to Saeng and its symbolic role in her journey.

The author ends the story in this way because it powerfully represents the new birth that is poised to take place. It is almost as if she is saying that she will hibernate during the winter, and when spring returns and everything begins a new cycle of life, then so will she. This is supported when Saeng “realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” She is conveying that when the new season begins it will be her own beginning, and she will consequently have a different, more hopeful outlook on her new life and its possibilities.

The author ends the story this way to wrap everything up neatly and thematically. Throughout the narrative, the author incorporated elements of nature and vivid descriptions of it. This stylistic choice was implemented so the reader would get a clear and evocative image in their head of how “beautiful or calming” spring supposedly is, using the natural world as a final, resonant image to leave with the audience and provide a sense of peaceful closure.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it strongly suggests that her strength will come when the flowers bloom again. The paragraph implies a direct connection between the natural cycle of the flowers and her personal resolve, indicating that she will then be emotionally prepared and able to take the test with renewed confidence and determination, using the blossoms as a source of inner fortitude.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with that particular paragraph because she wants to show the determination the girl in the story possesses. At first, the girl could not help herself and bought the expensive flower. She did not want her mother to be disappointed though, so she was determined to "pass the test." This initial resolve is then mirrored and strengthened by the story's end. In the spring when it is time to buy more seeds, the girl wants to be able to buy the seeds herself, a goal that requires her to pass her driver's test. So the author is showing the trait of determination that the girl controls, a quality that will help her overcome future challenges.

The author concludes the story with the line, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because the hibiscus budding would symbolize starting over. The cyclical return of spring and the budding of the plant represent new beginnings and resilience. Saeng taking the test again is giving her a chance to start over fresh and try again, directly linking her personal journey to the natural world's renewal. The hibiscus doesn't stop budding so Saeng shouldn't stop trying, and this parallel provides a powerful, hopeful conclusion to her story.

In the last paragraph of the story, the author concludes the story like that because the author means to say that the hibiscus is the symbol of overcoming obstacles. For example, Saeng's mother says, "Its flowers aren't pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months." This is a symbol to overcome obstacles as a flower is strong enough to make it through the cold months, in which the weather is rough, just as people must endure difficult times. In Saeng's case, she is a girl who will make it in a foreign country, facing challenges like failing her driver's test. Thus, in the last paragraph, when Saeng vows silently to herself that she will take the drivers test again when the snow melts and the hibiscus is budding, she uses the hibiscus as a symbol of overcoming the obstacle of failing the test. That is why the author decided to end the story with that last paragraph, reinforcing the theme of resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wanted to convey a sense of determination of Saeng wanting to complete what she started. She had failed the driver's test and is very disappointed, for example, she starts to cry and has "tear stains and puffy eyes" as she remembers her homeland in Vietnam, her life, her memories, her family etc. This moment of sadness, however, gives way to a new resolve. She can relate to the geese that migrate during the winter and return again, and as new beginnings start in the spring, so would she. This connection to nature signifies a fresh start like the blossoming hibiscus, leading directly to her decision for a fresh start with the driver's test.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show the audience that Saeng never gave up so you shouldn't either. I think that this paragraph is describing a law of life which is "never give up." This message is clearly demonstrated through Saeng's actions; even though she had failed at first she is still willing to try again. Her silent vow to retake the test in the spring embodies this persistent spirit. The ending serves as an inspiration, illustrating that perseverance in the face of failure is a vital principle for overcoming life's difficulties.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again. I think the author included this in the story to show that you shouldn't push things off and delay important actions. You should always deal with them as they come up, rather than waiting for a perfect moment that may never arrive. So in the story the girl is showing a bad example of procrastination. I believe the author wanted to make a point of not doing that and instead facing challenges directly. Overall, to add this phrase in this story was the right thing to do to try and show the right way of doing and going about these certain things, emphasizing the value of timely action.

She should and needs to learn that you can’t replace a plant with the same thing and expect it to be as equal to it, because each living thing is unique and holds its own specific value. She needs to learn that lesson in life, understanding that some losses are permanent and that exact replacements are impossible, which is a crucial part of growing up and accepting reality as it is.

The author ends the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng will follow nature and try to fit into her new land, using the natural world as a guide for her own adaptation. Saeng has failed her driver’s test and feels out of place in her new home, struggling with feelings of alienation. The text states, “As Saebba nedae tall and lush. And surrounded there garden” (No 1), illustrating the vibrant life of her past. When she sees the hibiscus it reminds her of her old home where she fit in, providing a comforting link to her heritage. Now she wants to wait to see that flower grown so when she takes the driver’s test again, she will feel more grounded. Also, she sees geese fly over her head when she plants her flower, connecting her to the cycles of nature. The author writes, “…She realized that many of the things that she had thought strange before had become…almost familiar to her now” (No @NUM1), showing her gradual adjustment. The geese coming back in the spring will now also remind her of her new home and how she must try to live there happily now, embracing her new beginning. In the last paragraph the author writes, “I will take that test again” (No @NUM1), which gives the feeling of Saeng trying to start a new beginning in this new home, filled with renewed hope and determination.

This is a powerful sentence that demonstrates themes in the story, particularly resilience and the comfort of memory. Saeng is determined to try again because she has been comforted by the symbol of her homeland, which gives her the strength to persevere. This sentence shows what the plant has done for Saeng’s spirit and shows how that symbol helps heal her emotional wounds. The sentence is able to wrap up the story and demonstrates the importance of the hibiscus as a central motif. In the story Saeng describes the plant as a friend and reminder of her homeland, a tangible piece of her past. Once she sees the plant in bloom she'll know that she can take the test again, using its growth as a sign of her own readiness. The paragraph is a great conclusion to the passage because it summarizes everything that the hibiscus has meant for Saeng, tying together her past and her future in a single, hopeful image.

I think the author is just trying to show that you never give up, no matter how difficult the circumstances may seem. I think the author is also trying to show the beauty of nature and its power to inspire and heal a person’s spirit. The author used that because in the story Saeng failed the test but at the end it says that she will take the test again, demonstrating her persistent character. In the story it talks about the winter hibiscus that she planted and that is concluded in the conclusion, symbolizing hope and new life. The conclusion is basically saying that there will be a new beginning, a fresh start guided by the rhythms of the natural world.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” because the paragraph itself concluded the narrative effectively. It basically summed up her resolve to repeat her efforts the following year, as she had already undergone the experience once. What the author means by this paragraph is that when the plants and life return in the spring, she is going to have to undertake all the work again, which was essentially represented by the test she must retake. This cyclical return mirrors the natural world's renewal and her personal commitment to trying again.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph to let the readers know that she doesn't give up. They might have thought that she believed the tests or life back home were more important, leading her to not care about passing this new test. However, the paragraph shows that while she misses her home, her vow to try again proves she does care about these new challenges and is determined to face them. It clarifies that her connection to home strengthens, rather than diminishes, her resolve.

I think that the author ended the story like that as a metaphor for people to think outside the box or see things differently. The author might have ended it like that so people can get a vivid picture in their head about what she was talking about, using the imagery of the returning spring and the budding hibiscus to symbolize new beginnings. This technique allows the reader to visualize Saeng's internal promise and the hope it represents, making the conclusion more impactful and open to personal interpretation.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to give you an idea of how she feels about what happened to her. This paragraph is her telling herself that everything is ok and she is going to do better next time. The author concluded the story with this paragraph to make Saeng sound more confident in herself. In the middle of the story when she was having the conversation with her mother, she sounded unconfident and uncertain. So this final paragraph made her sound like she was sure with herself, like she knew what she was going to do and had found a new sense of determination.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus”, I think that the author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because she has made Saeng feel that if that hibiscus can restart and make new flowers then Saeng should do the same. The hibiscus serves as a direct parallel to her own situation, demonstrating that renewal is possible. Therefore, that is why the author added that quote to the end of the story, to underscore this connection between natural rebirth and personal resilience.

Saeng failed her driver's test at the beginning of the story, a disappointment that weighed heavily on her. Wandering afterward, she finds a hibiscus plant and buys it because it reminds her of her life in Vietnam. As she breathes in its scent, she states, “The familiar fragrance filled her lungs and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long grey hair.” The flower vividly reminds her of her grandmother and the home she left behind. Later, her mother points out a similar plant, saying, “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake, its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months.” She is clearly trying to make her daughter feel better by highlighting resilience. The story then notes, “Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by their faint honks clear and yes-familiar to Saeng now. She realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now.” This marks a subtle shift in her perspective, showing her growing adaptation to her new environment.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it captures Saeng's moment of significant personal realization. At the end, she understands that the things which had once seemed strange to her had become familiar as the seasons were changing and the plants around her began to bloom again, signaling a new beginning. This newfound familiarity and the hope of spring give her the confidence to try again. The author placed that paragraph at the end to solidify this theme of growth and renewal, which is why in the spring she goes back to school to take the test again, ready to face the challenge with a changed outlook.

The author concludes the story the way he or she does because it powerfully shows that the hibiscus plant serves as a meaningful symbol for her. The time she found the plant foreshadows that she will eventually get her license, so it is a persistent reminder for her of both her past and her future potential. The author likely structured it this way because when the plant blooms, it starts its cycle over, and similarly, when Saeng decides to take a chance on the test again, she is starting anew. This parallel between the resilient plant and Saeng's own resolve creates a hopeful and cyclical conclusion to her story.

The author ends the story with that paragraph because she wants to show that the inner peace the flower gave Saeng will build her confidence and ensure she will not give up. This is evident from the narrative, as the main character fails her driving test and is disheartened, but when she sees the flower it helps remind her of the home she had in Vietnam, providing comfort and strength. Another reason is because the flower blooms in spring and it never stops blooming, representing perseverance. She knows the plant will never give up and she realizes that she shouldn’t either. The plant gives her the strength to try again, so the reason the author ends her story with that paragraph is to show the power the familiar flower gave her and how she will not give up on her goals.

The author concludes the story with this ending paragraph because it successfully combines the two imperfect situations Saeng faces—her failure and her longing for home—into a single vow for the future. When she said, “when they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take the test again,” she connects her personal renewal to the natural cycles around her. She will prove her point and overcome the situation, using the budding flower as her benchmark for a fresh start. This resolution beautifully abbreviates her journey from disappointment to determined hope.

The author explains her decision to retake the test in the spring rather than the winter because she believes she will be more focused then. During the spring, she can dedicate her mind entirely to the test preparation without the distraction of planting, which allows for better concentration. This seasonal shift provides a clearer mental space, enabling her to channel all her efforts toward achieving success on the exam. Her choice reflects a strategic approach to optimizing her performance by aligning her schedule with a period of fewer competing obligations.

I think she ended the story with that particular sentence because throughout the whole narrative she consistently tries to work hard. This final statement powerfully communicates that her journey is not over, indicating that she will return to take the test again. She strives to prove herself during the entire book, demonstrating her resilience and determination in the face of challenges. The ending reinforces that she will continue working hard with unwavering persistence to ultimately get what she wants, solidifying the story's central theme of perseverance.

In the story, the author concludes the narrative the way she did because it is metaphoric; she is comparing herself directly to the hibiscus plant. Just as a hibiscus would be tested to overcome harsh conditions such as the cold, the author faces her own trials. For example, in the text, the author states, “its flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here. This winter hibiscus.” She, like the resilient hibiscus that will bloom again after passing the test of surviving the cold, will also have another chance to pass her own test. This parallel is precisely why the author chose to conclude the story in this reflective and hopeful manner.

The concluding paragraph in the story “Winter Hibiscus” portrays the powerful message of change from a cold, distant failure to adapt, to a vibrant new life. Saeng relates her personal transformation to the changing seasons, specifically from winter to spring. This is obviously shown when the text states, “in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding.” She accepts this seasonal shift as a new chance to start fresh and then try again to pass the test. The change from winter to spring symbolizes Saeng’s hardship of failing to adapt initially to her new home. Then, as the geese return and the hibiscus adapts in its new environment, it becomes the symbol which Saeng follows, as the plant is from her old home in Vietnam but can now also prosper elsewhere, just as she can.

The author concludes with this paragraph because it had the most impact on the reader, and the ending also gave the most meaning to the entire narrative. The meaning of the last paragraph is that time itself will help her gradually adjust to where she is now living. It also thoughtfully incorporates the hibiscus flower and how it will bloom again with the coming season; this could have a double meaning, suggesting that the author's own life will eventually bloom again in her new surroundings. Overall, it was a poignant and effective way to conclude the story, leaving the reader with a sense of hopeful anticipation.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," I believe they end the story the way they did, with Saeng's vow, "when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again," because with Saeng making a goal, she is overcoming her disappointment and discomfort living in a new country. The archetypal meaning of a flower bud is: prosper, new, growth. This shows her growing and that’s important in life, as it signifies resilience and the capacity for personal development. The author uses the bud as a symbol for Saeng's own potential to flourish in her new environment. That’s why they ended it the way they did; it’s a positive ending that emphasizes hope and renewal rather than defeat.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it powerfully shows that she realizes her deep connection to the hibiscus plant. All through the story Saeng thinks about native plants she has seen before that are now in the greenhouse. She sees how they are adapted to life there, just like the way the hardy hibiscus can survive the winter indoors. This observation leads Saeng to the crucial realization that she also must adapt in her new home. She does not necessarily need to adapt just to survive, but rather to be successful and to thrive. She vows that in the spring, when the hibiscus is budding and restarting its growth cycle, she too will restart her own efforts and retake the test, mirroring the plant's resilience.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, the author’s final paragraph shows how much the hibiscus means to her as a symbol of strength. The author uses symbolism when he talks about the hibiscus because it is a strong and resilient plant, just like the girl needs to be in order to pass the driving test and overcome her challenges. The author placed the paragraph at the end to show the parallel that if the hibiscus can come back after the harsh winter, so can the girl recover from her setback. This connection underscores the theme of perseverance. In conclusion, the author used the last paragraph to emphasize the profound meaning of the hibiscus as a beacon of hope and renewal for the protagonist.

The story is full of emotion and homesickness that it can be a bit depressing, so the author wanted to end with a clear message of hope. After Saeng failed the test, "in the main shelter of the greenhouse (she) broke down and wept," so it is inspiring to know that she will keep trying despite all her hardship. I know first hand that homesickness can be pretty bad, and finding the strength to keep going and make the promise "to take that test again" can be very hard but ultimately worthwhile. The author also used the ending to give another meaning to the hibiscus, for "when the geese return and the hibiscus is blooming" signifies that when the winter is over and hard times are past, there will be new hope in a new, beautiful spring. This cyclical change from winter to spring reinforces the story's uplifting conclusion about overcoming adversity.

The reason why the author concluded the story with that paragraph was because it basically explained everything you needed to know for the ending. It clearly explains that she is willing to take the time to study for the test she had previously taken and did not pass, and she wants to take it again once spring arrives. For example, the geese had left for the winter, and once they return in the spring, she will take the test over again, linking her personal resolve to the natural cycle of the seasons. This paragraph ties together the story's central themes of patience and second chances. In conclusion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it best explains the ending of the story and provides a clear sense of closure for the reader.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the growth or hope that Saeng has that she will be comfortable in the United States. When she said “I-I failed the test,” I took it as failing the test to see if she got over her country and if she could truly adapt to her new life. However, her subsequent vow to try again reveals a newfound resilience, suggesting she is beginning to find her footing and is not giving up on building a future in America. This moment signifies a quiet but important shift from despair toward a determined hope.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph. "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again." This shows that you should fight for what is right and what you believe in. Saeng’s internal vow represents her personal fight to overcome her challenges and hold onto her dreams despite the initial setback. It is a testament to her enduring spirit and her commitment to persevere in her new environment.

Saeng wanted to show that she was strong and determined. She wanted to make the best of things with what she had. She had lost a lot of hope with the big move to another country. The winter made her sad, longing even more for home. She bought the flower to, in a sense, bring her back home and provide a tangible connection to her past. When the spring comes, she will bud with the flower and take the test again. This is her new home with new hibiscus, symbolizing her acceptance of a new beginning. After all, winter is no time for a flower, but spring promises renewal and growth.

Saeng did get the feeling that she called fill in and find something that could help her but also have her missing where she was from. Buying the hibiscus was an attempt to bridge the distance between her old home and her new one. And with her mother getting a little mad about the price she paid for it, the purchase was a complicated comfort. She vowed silently to herself in the spring that she would take the test again, showing her resolve to move forward despite the emotional and financial cost of holding onto the past.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph. I think the author concludes this story with that paragraph to show that Saeng has found the confidence to take the driving test again. Her silent vow indicates a significant internal shift from the doubt and failure she initially experienced. This newfound self-assurance, sparked by the symbolic hibiscus, marks a crucial step in her adaptation and personal growth, concluding her arc on a note of promising determination.

The author leaves the story there because it keeps you guessing on what is going to happen, creating a sense of anticipation. That is really all you need to know about the story, as the narrative has reached its thematic conclusion. The important parts the author has told already & the future is a whole different story that is not necessary to detail. It doesn’t matter if Saeng passes the test or what happens over the winter, as those are external events. The author has told us everything to know about the importance of this person & her mother and their shared journey, which is the true heart of the tale.

Saeng feels out of place in her new home and new country, struggling with the unfamiliar surroundings and culture. She vows silently that in a year she will take the test again, giving herself time to adjust. She vows that in a year she will be used to her new home and new country and will start to enjoy life again, finding happiness and a sense of belonging. The author concluded with this paragraph because the girl Saeng will hopefully enjoy her new home and in a year she will be used to what happens in her new country, having grown more comfortable. Saeng just feels out of place and she wants to wait a while until she tries to retake the test, allowing herself a period of adaptation. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she made a vow to herself and hopefully she will keep the vow and make it happen, ending on a note of quiet determination and hope for the future.

The author might have concluded the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng isn't going to stop trying; she's going to work harder to overcome her challenges. As she sees the geese adapting to their environment, she chooses to try and make their new home work out for her family as well. After they disappear she picks herself up and says that she's going to try again, demonstrating her resilience. By doing this she is committing herself to try new things and to adapt to the changes in her life, embracing the future with a renewed spirit. This final thought solidifies her character's resolve and provides a fitting end to her emotional arc.

I think she ends the story with this paragraph because she wants to take the test in the future when it won’t be so hard on her, allowing for a better frame of mind. It will be warm again and it’s not quite as cold, which symbolizes a more hopeful and pleasant time for a new beginning. This seasonal shift represents a period of growth and renewal, making it a more suitable time for her to attempt the test again. The conclusion therefore emphasizes the importance of timing and emotional readiness for such a significant challenge.

The story concludes with this paragraph for a number of compelling reasons. First, in the spring it is warm and sunny and this helped to end the story on a happy note, contrasting with the earlier cold and hardship. Next this shows that Saeng can adapt to her new home, as the hibiscus will through winter, drawing a parallel between her resilience and the plant's survival. Finally, it shows Saeng is determined and won't let her mother down, reinforcing the central theme of familial duty and personal strength. That is why the story concludes with that paragraph, tying together the symbolic and character-driven elements into a cohesive and satisfying ending.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show if they can adapt then she can too. The geese and the blooming hibiscus represent nature's resilience and its ability to return and thrive after a harsh winter. ìIn the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. ìI choose this saying because it shows you if they are able to come back after everything that has happen she can to. She sees their return as a promise of new beginnings, a sign that she should be able to adapt to a new place just like they do, finding her own strength in their cyclical renewal.

Authors often end stories with paragraph that make readers wonder what happens next. In Winter Hibiscus by: Minfong Ho there is an ending paragraph just like that. The author ends it like this because she is looking towards the future with a sense of optimism. She says that she will take the test when the snow melts, the geese come back, and the hibiscus is blooming. She is looking at it like that is a new beginning, a fresh start after a period of difficulty. She wants to start over. Also the geese, blooming hibiscus, and melted snow show gives her hope that she will pass her test, as these signs of spring symbolize growth and success. She believes now they have a hibiscus maybe it will be more like where she use to live, providing a comforting link to her past. Authors use endings that make people wonder so people think about the character's future and the themes of hope and renewal.

The response that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wanted us that read the story to understanding what was going on in the story and the character's internal resolution. Like for the character Saeng, they was sayin when they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again, was tryin to see where everybody head at in the story so they can understanding what the author be talkin about regarding her determination and newfound hope. This final thought allows the reader to grasp Saeng's decision to persevere, tying together her emotional journey.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because the geese and the hibiscus were both things that were familiar to Saeng. They remind her of her homeland, providing a deep sense of comfort and connection. When the familiar things return, like the geese in spring and the budding plant, she will have the strength to the test again and hopefully do better, drawing courage from these symbols. The narrator says ìOverhead a of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and ñyes-familiar to Saeng now ì. This shows how the geese are a symbol of the familiar things from her homeland that help Saeng feel more comfortable in her new home, anchoring her in a new environment. Thus, the ending emphasizes how these connections empower her to face future challenges.

The author included that paragraph because the hibiscus plant makes her think of where she is from and helps her to succeed at certain things by providing a tangible link to her past. I know that the hibiscus is from her homeland because in the story she says ìI mean, not like the kind we had atñat-î, she found that she was still to shaky to say the words at home.î She misses being home and this plant helps her bring back memorys of being there, offering solace and a sense of identity. Therefore the author included that paragraph to show the reader that she misses her homeland and that this connection is a source of her inner strength and resolve for the future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate why it might be important to the author personally about Saeng. It signifies something deeply personal about her past or where she had originally come from. She is trying to say that when she comes back in the spring she is going to take the test again in school, or perhaps she is going to plant something over again in the spring. As snow covers the ground and it is too cold to plant anything, she reflects on her origins. That where she came from is really important to her and she misses it and wants to go back to where she came from, which fuels her resolve for a new beginning when the seasons change.

The author concludes this story with the line, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again". She does this because in the story this plant has given her a lot of belief in herself to be able to do better in the future. The hibiscus serves as a symbol of resilience and hope, reminding her of her own capacity for growth and renewal, which strengthens her silent vow to try again.

The author concludes the story this way for a few reasons. One reason is that she will have more experience with her new country. She only left her homeland a few months before, so in about six more months she will be more knowledgeable about the ways of the new country. This accumulated experience will make her more capable of passing the test. Also, in the spring is when the flower will be beautiful again and this will give her new-found strength that will cause her to pass. The few months' time will allow the author time to mentally and physically prepare for the exam. Mentally, she will be able to study and learn all she needs to know, and physically she will age which will also teach her new things, contributing to her overall readiness.

In order to get over her failure, Saeng bought a flower that reminded her of home. Saeng started to cry when she bought the flower because she wanted to be back home. The author concluded the story with this paragraph to show how she will take the test when she feels like she is at home. “When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” Saeng said to herself. Those things make her feel welcome and feeling that way will help her with her test. The paragraph concludes the story with all the things she is comfortable with, helping the reader understand what reminds her of home. It also explains how much the hibiscus flower meant to her, as buying the flower helps her with her troubles and seeing the geese fly reminds her of her home. The author concludes the story with the memories that will help Saeng in the future, providing her with the comfort and strength needed to move forward.

I think the author ended this story with this conclusion because everyone should have fresh starts, or second chances. I guess the author was leaving in a message stating if you fail once you should at least try again. When Saeng failed the test it seems as though her self-esteem lowered, and her mother tried cheering her up. Eventually, she realized it would be bad to give up and not try again with a fresh start, understanding that perseverance is key to overcoming setbacks and achieving one's goals.

Minfong Ho included the last paragraph in the story because it alluded to the fact that Saeng felt better and more confident when reminded of home. When Saeng saw the hibiscus she got a feeling "so intense, it was almost visceral." The flower was creatively used by Ho. She said that the winter hibiscus is strong enough to make it through the cold months, which made the reader think after reading the last paragraph, that this flower must give Saeng hope and confidence. Also, the geese make a V which I inferred would mean Vietnam to Saeng, which is what the author is trying to get her reader to think. That is why “and the geese return.” is mentioned in the last paragraph. Minfong Ho wants her readers to realize that objects that make us more comfortable and happy are what make us strong and confident in the end. The author did a great job placing that last thought into the last paragraph because it perfectly sums up the lesson, and that is that you should do things when you feel confident and it feels like home to you. You may be small and fragile, but if you “plant” yourself you can thrive with confidence, just as the hardy winter hibiscus does.

The last paragraph at the end of the story was the author's way of showing how Saeng wanted spring to come early because she wants to see her hibiscus. If spring doesn’t come fast she will not get to see her hibiscus and the snow won’t melt. When Saeng comes up she hopes she can take the test, and the arrival of spring symbolizes the perfect timing for her to try again. The paragraph connects her hope for the changing seasons with her personal goal, showing that her confidence is tied to the natural world. This connection gives her the strength to face her challenge, and she believes that with the new season, she will be ready. Her vow to retake the test is therefore intrinsically linked to the promise of spring's arrival.

The author concludes the story with the sentence "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." because that winter hibiscus symbolizes a new beginning for her. For example, back in her home town she had hibiscus and everything was fine and normal; she lived her life and so on. Well then she moved to the U.S., and she didn’t have any hibiscus, she just failed her driving test, she feels misplaced, and doesn't fit in. So, when she saw that winter hibiscus she felt as if she found something to help her feel at home or at ease almost. She felt a sense of security and a connection to her past. In conclusion, the author ended with that sentence because it's a new beginning for her and that hibiscus means a new start, representing resilience and the hope for a fresh opportunity in her new life.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because it resembles her own life, that she will have another chance, just as geese will come back again. The reason why the last part resembles back to her life is that it says in the spring; spring is usually a good time of year because it gets warmer and flowers come back. The hibiscus plant will bloom again and that will renew, in a way, her warming thought of her old home, providing her with comfort. Then that will be the time to retake her driving test that she failed, which was before she bought the plant. The author added this last part because it tied and matched so well with the story, connecting the cycles of nature with Saeng's personal journey and her newfound determination to succeed. This parallel beautifully encapsulates the theme of renewal and second chances.

The reason why the author concludes the story with one small paragraph is because sometimes the little things count the most and the author thought that in two sentences he could summarize the most important things in the story. I think that the author did a great job of condensing the core message into a brief, powerful statement. This final paragraph captures Saeng's internal vow and the symbolic significance of the natural elements, leaving a lasting impression on the reader. By focusing on these essential elements, the conclusion reinforces the story's central themes without unnecessary elaboration. The concise ending effectively delivers the story's emotional and thematic resolution, making it a strong and memorable finish.

The author concludes with this paragraph because Saeng has to take the test all over again. She thinks there's a better chance for her to succeed when the hibiscus blooms and the snow melts, seeing these as signs of a new beginning. So that is when Saeng is going to try and take the test after the snow melts and the hibiscus blooms, hoping for a fresh start and a more favorable outcome.

The author concludes with this sentence for a couple of reasons. Saeng feels that she can’t do it until the spring because that is when the geese come back, signaling a time of renewal. Also, that is when the hibiscus buds, a natural process of growth and opening. In a way, she feels as though she will blossom in spring and be able to pass the test, connecting her personal journey to the seasonal change.

I think that the author includes this paragraph in this story because the grandmother might think that it is a test to see what she can get done in a certain amount of time. The grandmother might get more done than should be reasonably expected, demonstrating her determination and capability. This shows her character and her willingness to meet any challenge presented to her.

I think that the author concludes the story like that because she is saying that by that time she’ll be ready to take the test again, having had time to prepare. Another way of thinking is that by that time when that happens in spring, she would be prepared and more confident of herself, having grown from her experience. The author was trying to say that just like the beginning of a new spring, it would be a new beginning for her, full of potential and hope.

I think that the author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng is saying that she will try again despite her initial failure. For example, despite failing her driving test, she decides to take it over after having the experience of planting with her mother, which gave her a new perspective. It seems as if planting the hibiscus has gained her some confidence in striving to succeed once again, showing her resilience. In the story, it seemed that she was getting used to planting and found a sense of accomplishment in it. For example, now that she has done something and accomplished that, she knows that she can take the test again and accomplish that goal as well. In conclusion, that is why I think the author concluded with that paragraph, to highlight Saeng's renewed determination.

The author concludes the story with a reflective statement that makes you think because she wants to emphasize the symbolic relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus. Just like Saeng, the hibiscus is in a new environment and has to adapt to the unfamiliar surroundings. Saeng had just failed her driving test, so she is understandably bummed about that disappointment. The concluding sentence, however, makes you realize that Saeng can overcome her driving challenges if the resilient plant can overcome the harsh surroundings and eventually bloom. This parallel provides a hopeful outlook for her future efforts.

The author includes this as the last paragraph because it could give Saeng’s mother a sense of hope for their family's situation. It could give this hope because they could really need Saeng to pass the test for practical reasons, such as gaining greater independence or helping with family responsibilities. The mother's hope is tied to the success and adaptation of her daughter in their new home. Therefore, the paragraph serves to highlight the importance of this achievement beyond Saeng's personal disappointment, concluding the thought on an optimistic note for the family.

It was very important that the author concluded the story with that particular paragraph. It reestablished the deeper meaning of the hibiscus and why it was so important to Saeng's journey. It showed the determination she had found in overcoming her problems with living in a new and unfamiliar place. Without this paragraph we would have been left merely assuming what was to come of Saeng, which in some stories might have worked but in this case was needed for clarity. When she first saw the hibiscus she broke down because she could not clearly remember her home land, which is why the hibiscus is so important to the story's emotional core. By restating the importance of it in the end, the author helped the reader follow what was to come next even though the story itself had come to an end. It was important to express this connection again for emphasis. In the last paragraph it says, “This hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The buds represent a new beginning for Saeng and a new chance to overcome her problems. This paragraph was very important and without it these thematic events would be left hanging, making the meaning of the story much clearer for the reader with its inclusion.

Including the bit about taking the test again when the “hibiscus is budding” provides a sense of closure and a lesson to an otherwise open ending. Saeng fails the driver's test early in the story, and then on her way home she buys a hibiscus plant. The reader really doesn’t see a full connection between these events until this last paragraph reveals it. The hibiscus ultimately represents perseverance and strength in the face of adversity. After a harsh winter this hibiscus can bloom again and can continue to live and thrive. Even after moving from Vietnam, and struggling to adapt to a new life, Saeng must recover her spirit, and keep trying. Just like the flower blooming again, so will Saeng. She will take the test a second time and likely pass. She will learn to adapt to her new environment, and keep going forward with her life, just like the resilient hibiscus does each spring.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, the I will take the test again,” because the author started out the story just after Saeng had failed her driving test, establishing her initial defeat. Saeng is reminded of her homeland by the Hibiscus, which serves as a tangible link to her past. After Saeng wanted the Hibiscus in the garden, “a flock of canada geese flow by,” and as they flew by Saeng felt a sign of comfort and vowed to herself what started everything anew. If Saeng had passed the driving test initially then she would of never found the Hibiscus and the profound sense of hope and connection it provided, which ultimately fuels her resolution to try again. This circular structure brings the narrative to a satisfying and meaningful close.

The author includes it because her mother took the test and passed it, and the daughter wanted to do the same just like her mom, to follow in her footsteps and achieve a similar success. And she can only take it in the spring because there is no flowers out in the winter, a season that feels barren and uninviting for new beginnings. The spring, with its promise of growth and renewal, provides a more fitting backdrop for her attempt.

I think the author is trying to show that Saeng is finally starting to accept and get over the struggles in her life. It is showing that she has finally gotten used to her new home in America and the customs, but she still hasn’t forgotten her heritage, as shown when she thinks, “But she had herself much preferred it to a Big Mac.” It also proves that she is going to be positive and not let disappointment discourage her. She’s going to retake the test and try again. During the beginning, she had a gloomy outlook on her situations in life. But after visiting the floral shop and finding the winter hibiscus, she discovers a more cheerful and optimistic outlook on her situation and decides to do something about it, embracing the future with renewed determination.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. One reason I think is because she’s concluding that the winter is there, and when winter is over, she is going to start flowering and planting again, symbolizing a period of waiting and preparation. In the story it said, “the winter hibiscus was in the ground now,….” So, now she has to wait for winter to pass by, and then the hibiscus will be starting to grow and will hopefully be blooming by spring. This cyclical change mirrors Saeng's own journey from hardship to hope. So, that is why I think she concluded the story the way she did, to emphasize this theme of patient anticipation.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the question of what about her test needed to be answered and that’s when she'd be comfortable to take it. In the text, the plant felt smooth and cool just as she had known it, which was comforting and familiar. She closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to, a tangible piece of her past. Unlike her grandmother, she felt a wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung her eyes, with sadness, and maybe disappointment, which she probably would not want to deal with for a while, hinted at in the conclusion. Her mother even uttered a small cry of surprise and delight to see the flower, even before being shocked when Saeng reveals she paid all of over nineteen dollars for it. With this concluding paragraph, I believe that she will be more comfortable at the time she had planned because she'll have new and old things to come home to, such as the geese and the plant, providing her with a sense of stability and belonging.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author includes this ending paragraph because she wants to show that next time around she will be prepared and ready for the garden and the challenges it holds, having learned from her initial experience. This first time, she wasn’t ready, and she didn’t know about the winter hibiscus because she never did anything like it before, having just moved to a new country with a different climate and flora. The ending signifies her newfound knowledge and resolve to try again with a better understanding, ensuring she is no longer caught off guard.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the story ends with the character saying, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason the author ends the story like that is because it is showing that even though she has failed the test once, she is not going to give up just because of a difficult adjustment or change. The hibiscus made the reader realize that a plant from where she lives can adapt to a new environment, and so can she. This parallel between the resilient plant and her own situation provides her with the determination to try again when conditions are more favorable.

The reason she ended the story like that is because when everything is blooming, she will feel more at home and will have a healthier state of mind. I say this because the girl used to help her grandma with her hair before she moved away from her homeland. So if the flower is blooming then it would remind her of her grandma and the comforting rituals they shared, which would be an incentive for her to do good on the test. This connection to her past and her family gives her the emotional strength and confidence she needs to face the challenge again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is a personification involving the snow melting, the geese returning, and the hibiscus budding. It is explaining significant moments in time that mark a transition and a new beginning. The author describes how isolated the hibiscus is, yet it endures the harsh winter, waiting for its moment to bloom. This imagery reflects the character's own feelings of isolation and her patient hope for a future renewal, tying her personal journey to the natural cycle of the seasons.

The author ended the story with that paragraph because it is telling how Saeng feels about winter being near and how she has to wait until spring comes back around to do her test again. This waiting period is not one of idleness but of preparation and inner growth. The promise of spring represents a time of new opportunities, and her decision to wait shows her maturity and understanding that some challenges require the right timing and a refreshed spirit to overcome successfully.

Saeng cares about the flowers deeply, seeing them as more than just plants. She cares about the hibiscus flower in particular, noting its struggle and resilience. This is a natural occurrence with them, as they grow in unique ways, adapting to their surroundings and blooming despite adversity. Her observation of this process gives her a sense of connection and a model for her own life, showing her that beauty and success can emerge from difficult circumstances with patience and care.

In the story, I don’t know why the author concluded the narrative in that way. I really don’t know, but maybe she was talking about how she took all her tests and now she wouldn’t take it over again just yet. The times come for different challenges. She is in school, and when one took the test, it was a measure of a certain kind of wealth or success, not of a specific date. Now that school is over, a new phase begins, and the story reflects this transition, showing that some opportunities are tied to particular moments in life.

The author concludes this paragraph in such a manner for the story because, at the end of the narrative, they simply needed a fitting ending. Also, the reason is that the author picked a conclusion that would best fit the overall arc and themes of this particular story. This selection was made to provide a sense of closure and to ensure the story felt complete and resonant for the reader, tying together the central ideas without unnecessary complication.

I believe that the author chose to conclude the story the way they did because the central theme was about perseverance. For example, the story was based around the winter hibiscus plant, which serves as a powerful symbol. This is a good example because in the end, Saeng vows that she will persevere and take her test again, just as the hibiscus perseveres and forges through the winter, not allowing itself to die. Another example is that the mother worked outside while it was cold to get her gardening done. This relates to the story because she stayed out in the cold garden to complete her task; she could have quit and gone inside the nice warm house, just like Saeng could have quit and said she was not going to try to take her test again. But she did not; she said she was going to try again, reinforcing the message of enduring through difficulty.

I think the author ended this story like that because it means that she hasn't given up yet, and even though she failed the first time, she is going to come back and try again. The line, "In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding," means that when all is renewed and conditions are favorable, she will try to do it again because if she passes, it will be a new beginning for her. The story was pretty bad, in my opinion, because I don't even know what she failed, so I didn't like it, but the ending's intent to show resilience is still clear.

I think the reason why the author ended the story with this paragraph—"when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding. Then I will take that test again."—is because, like the plant that didn't have a fighting chance for survival in the harsh winter, the girl faced similar odds when she took her driving test. But in the spring, the plant has a chance to bloom, just as she has a chance to pass the test, illustrating that there is a time and a place for everything, and one must wait for the right conditions to try again.

Emotion, commitment, and hope are all reasons why the author ended the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” Primarily, that last paragraph shows that she has emotion, revealing her deep feelings about her failure and her resolve. Next, it shows that she has commitment, as she explicitly states that when the hibiscus comes back she will take the test again, demonstrating her dedication to trying once more. Lastly, it shows that there is hope and that she will try and redeem herself, using the cyclical promise of spring as a metaphor for her own potential for renewal. These are all the key reasons why the author used the final paragraph to conclude Saeng's story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize her newfound determination to overcome her obstacles. For example, in the passage she states, “she realized that many of the things she had thought strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her.” At this point she has an epiphany, and realizes that life is like seasons, constantly changing and renewing. In the end paragraph she internalizes this by saying that in the spring she will take the test again. This shows that just as the winter hibiscus endures the long winter, and then blooms in the spring, she must be strong during these hard times, knowing that one day her time will come for her to “bloom.” The protagonist experiences hard times, but we all must be strong and steadfast as we wait for our own time to “bloom,” just as she has learned to do.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because he wanted to show that she wasn’t going to give up just because she failed one time. She failed the test one time already and was very sad about it, leading her to go and buy a plant. Saeng’s mom told her that they were going to do it the right way, providing guidance. Saeng was crying when she told her mom about her failure, but her mom was very understanding and supportive. Her mom could have been very mad with her, but instead offered comfort. She could have used a plant that they grew, but the plant would not grow right now in the winter. She should have bought a real plant from someone else, yet the act of buying the hibiscus itself becomes a step toward her resolution to try again in the spring, showing her resilience.

Determination, new beginning, and symbolism are each reasons why I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph. She finds new hope after buying the plant, and is newly determined to pass the test that she writes about, vowing to herself. As she sees the geese flying overhead, she realizes what determination they must have on their long journey and vows to do better on the test next year. With the new flower, she feels like she’s starting over so that she’s able to pass this test that seems important to her, representing a fresh start. When the author writes, “and the geese will return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it shows symbolism through natural cycles. By telling about the flower blooming new buds, it symbolizes that Saeng wanted to turn over a new leaf and begin again with renewed effort. Determination, new beginning, and symbolism are each solid reasons why the author concluded the story with this impactful paragraph.

The author of “The Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho ends the story with the statement, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” because it showed that Saeng had overcome her problem and vowed to correct it. By ending with this statement the author showed that the beauty of nature can help one to overcome their problems, as did Saeng when she found inspiration in the natural world. Upon seeing the geese migrating and the “Winter Hibiscus” Saeng, “realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese.” Saeng realized that the test, although strange and different to her now, became familiar because of her experiences with nature and its cycles. Seeing the geese and “Winter Hibiscus” triggered memories; this plant also made Saeng think of her past in Vietnam and all of the good times back at her home. “The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed.” The jolting memory made her think of good experiences, providing comfort. In the end, the plant made her joyous enough not to think only about the past, but about the future, about taking the test again and her new life in the United States, concluding her arc of adaptation and hope.

The reason why the author puts that last line into the story of the end is to show us the raids and saeng that even though us almost over. She doesnít want it to end but she know that it will also start up again. This cyclical nature is mirrored in the changing seasons, which Saeng is learning to understand. Next year when things goes back to the way they were before everything changed, she will be better prepared for the challenges ahead. This is why I think the author put that line into the story, to emphasize the perpetual cycle of endings and new beginnings that defines life.

The author concluded the story with Saeng vowing to herself ìin the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that the test againî to express her determination of fitting into new things and to express the change she was getting used to. Describing spring was important in the conclusion because it described what Saeng once thought was odd in her new home, but got used to the seasons and weather changing. The imagery of renewal gave her the courage to try again. Once she realized that she needed to deal with change, she knew that she would need to try the driving test again with a renewed spirit. It was very important that the authorís conclusion was ìin the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test againî because it expressed how Saeng was accepting change in her life and finding hope in the future.

In ìwinter Hibiscusî the author uses hibiscus flower to symbolize beauty in unexpected places, adapting to a new life, and Saeng's home country at the end of the story I think that the author realizes that even though she failed the test, everything is going to be okay. While looking at the hibiscus she remembers her old life, which she loved, and she is reminded of the natural beauty that can be found in a hibiscus flower, even in the midst of a cold winter. This symbol of resilience helps her to see her own strength. In life, I think every one should always remember that even though one may be disappointed at sometime, we have to keep in mind, the fact that life goes on. There will always be another chance, as long as you can find peace and beauty in something good, just as Saeng found in the flower.

The author concludes with this paragraph to show how Saeng and the plant are similar. The plant represents Saengís strength and abilities, which are currently dormant but full of potential. She knows that only when she is stronger, in the spring like the plant, will she be ready to retake the test. Her hopes will be stronger like the plant in the spring, ready to bloom and face new challenges. That is why the author concluded with that paragraph, to draw a clear parallel between the character's personal growth and the natural world's cycle of rebirth.

I beleive the author ends the story with this paragraph because it refers to previous events in the story. For example it says, "and this hibiscis is budding". This refers back to the beginning of the story when Saeng first saw the hibiscus plant and it reminded her of home, creating a sense of narrative closure. This is a good way to conclude a story. I wouldnít change it at all if I could. Also in the summary before the story it says how she had failed her driverís test and in the last paragraph it says, "then I will take that test again,î I think Saeng didnít have much confidence before taking the test because of her new surroundings but is now that she is familiar with everything and found a hobby she will think of passing while taking the test again. I think she is looking to start over and forget about failing, using the promise of spring as a catalyst for her renewed determination and self-assurance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she overcame her initial setback and now wants to retake the quiz for herself, to prove it to herself and no one else. She states, “when they come back, Saeng vowed to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This declaration clearly shows that she wants to retake the test on her own terms. Therefore, she is not being pressured into taking it by her family or anyone else. She is taking it for her own personal satisfaction and to prove to herself, and no one else, that she can succeed.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, a young girl named Saeng recalls her life before she moved to the United States. She misses her homeland and all of the things she loved before she came here, feeling a deep sense of nostalgia and displacement. Towards the end of the story, the author includes a paragraph saying that Saeng vowed to take her driver's test again when winter ends, when the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding. The author concludes the story with this paragraph for one primary reason. He/She wants to show that Saeng is strong enough to survive the emotional winter, just like the hibiscus, and will be ready when the weary days of winter are over, and the beautiful days of spring come. Saeng’s mother states, "...it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months…. That’s what matters." The winter hibiscus is a direct parallel to Saeng in that just like the resilient plant, she is strong enough to survive the difficult winter months and will bloom again with the spring.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to make the reader want more, creating a sense of anticipation for what comes next for the character.
