When an author ends the chapter of a story or an episode of a show it is always a good idea to use a cliffhanger to drag the audience along, ensuring they remain engaged with the narrative. In many stories I have read this technique is effectively used. In my favorite series, the popular fantasy book, it always ends with a cliff-hanger that leaves readers eager for the next installment. Like in the end of the third book where one of the soldiers is killed but you don’t find out by who until the next book, this story's conclusion similarly creates unresolved tension and curiosity about Saeng's future attempts.

The author concludes this story the way she does to say that the girl is not going to give up on trying to fit in this new country, demonstrating her resilience and determination. The author concludes this way because it refers to the idea that its not over for Saeng, and even though the test was a failure, it wont be next time when she is better prepared. The author leads us to know that the little girl cares deeply about the test, and wants to prove to show people that she can pass it and succeed in her new environment. She is reminded of her home and her own strength by these flowers, and she has with this newfound confidence she can retake it and do it right, finally achieving her goal.

I think the author included that in the paragraph because Saeng didn't like the cold, so she would wait until the snow melts and geese return to test the plants again under more favorable conditions. The specific mention of the changing seasons highlights her preference for warmth and new beginnings over the harshness of winter. I also think she added it to show that she would come back to visit her mother and the hibiscus, reinforcing the connection between her personal growth and the symbolic plant that survives the winter, just as she plans to do. This cyclical return mirrors the natural world's renewal and Saeng's own commitment to try again.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng failed the test, and in the spring she will take the test over. This ending underscores the cyclical nature of challenge and opportunity, framing her initial failure not as a final defeat but as a temporary setback. The promise of a new season brings with it the chance for a new beginning, suggesting that Saeng's story is one of perseverance. The conclusion thus leaves the reader with a sense of hope, emphasizing that her journey is ongoing and her resolve to succeed remains firm.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it provides closure to both Saeng and the story. Saeng was upset about the fact that she failed her test, but towards the end of the story she realizes that things happen, and sometimes we have no control over what happens, but you’ve also got to pick yourself up again if what happens, knocks you down. When seeing the geese and the hibiscus, she realizes that everyone and everything has to adapt to something new all the time. Saeng might have failed her driving test because they drive differently in Vietnam, so she will have to adapt to the way we drive here, along with all our rules and laws. This moment of insight, where she connects her personal struggle to the universal need for adaptation, is the emotional climax. The author's concluding paragraph perfectly captures this transformation, showing Saeng's acceptance of her new reality and her newfound determination to try again with a wiser perspective.

Saeng was taking a test and she didn’t quite pass it. She was afraid to tell her mother but she had to tell her anyway. Her mother got upset because she didn’t pass it, a reaction that added to Saeng's own disappointment and sense of having let her family down. The failure was a difficult moment for them both, highlighting the pressures of expectation in their new life. Yet, Saeng knows that right after winter's over, she’ll be taking that same test again and she hoped she will pass it this time. This forward-looking thought provides a small but significant comfort, turning a moment of shared frustration into a shared hope for the future.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author includes the phrase, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again," because she wanted to make the story end with Saeng finding positive views on her new home and positive views in the future and have her look forward to it. Throughout the short story, Saeng happens to have a sad disposition about her new home and how the plants remind her of her recent home. “I mean its not the kind we at-at—” she found that she was still too shaky to say the words 'at home,' lest she burst into tears again. This phrase shows that Saeng really missed her home and was truly sad about it. The concluding phrase shown before shows that she found the strength to look positively at the future of her new home, using the symbolic return of spring and the budding flower as anchors for her own personal renewal and commitment to trying again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because at the beginning of the story Saeng went to take a driving test but didn’t pass and so she goes and buys a hibiscus that reminds her of home and gives her strength and comfort. So her mother says this at the end because she knows Saeng is going through a hard time adapting to her new country and she doesn’t want to put more pressure on her just because she knows Saeng is very upset and is trying to make it up to her by buying a flower for her so she says by next spring she should be adapted and ready for the test because the flower should give her hope. She wants her to know she is there for her. This maternal gesture shifts the focus from the immediate failure to long-term support and belief in Saeng's ability to eventually succeed, framing the coming months as a period of growth rather than just waiting.

I think the author of “Winter Hibiscus” said “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” to conclude the story for many reasons. First reason is it shows that she isn’t giving up on her goal despite her initial failure. The second reason is it gives a feeling of hope of what's to come, suggesting a new beginning with the changing seasons. The last reason is it leaves us wondering if she makes it next time, creating a sense of anticipation for her future. That is probably why the author ended it that way, to emphasize resilience and the promise of a second chance.

The author of the Winter Hibiscus concludes the story with the paragraph to show the connection between the hibiscus and Saeng. The hibiscus has to survive the winter until spring where it can bloom and become big and beautiful. Saeng is connecting to the flower and saying she can make it through her obstacles that come with the change in environment if the flower can deal with being confined in a plastic container and surviving the harsh weather. She feels that right now she's like the Hibiscus. She’s trapped because the area is alien to her and she has to adjust, just as the container is alien to the flower because it’s used to being free. But once it’s planted, it will become a part of its surroundings and grow. And once she accepts the change and becomes willing to start over, she will begin to grow and that will cause her driving test to be easier, symbolizing her own successful transplantation. In conclusion, this parallel is the reason the author concluded the paragraph with this sentence.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus”, the author ends with the main character Saeng saying that she will take the test “when the snow melts and the geese return.” I believe that the Hibiscus and the driver’s test are relevant like the blooming of a flower. If it wilts at first, it can blossom later on, thus the author included this to show that Saeng wilted at first, but will blossom at spring. It is also a symbol of her constant blossoming. The author’s intention of the last line was demonstrated early when Saeng was disappointed at failing the test. She is upset that she failed her driver’s test, but when she sees a flower from her homeland, she starts to get boosted and begins to weep a little. It shows her blossoming because she changes from a negative mood to a positive one after seeing the flower from her childhood memory. It shows her wilt and blossom again when she tells her mother the news about the test. At first she gets nervous and scared, so scared she tears the leaf off and shreds it to pieces. Her mother then wipes the green matter off and asks her to plant it. Saeng then gets a morale boost and starts to feel better. This once again shows her blossoming because she thought her mother would yell at her for failing the test, but instead her mother accepts the plant, showing her rise again. Saeng falters throughout the story, but manages to rise above it all and give herself determination to meet her goal. She is determined to pass the test when spring arrives, and blossom again, just as the Hibiscus will with its own budding stage.

The author probably includes part of the story with the paragraph to put more details into the paragraph and to underscore Saeng's emotional resolution. The author is trying to talk about the life that Saeng had, and her vow made silently to herself in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, that she will take that test again. This means that when flowers start blooming again and spring comes around again, that’s when she will take that test and pass this time, linking her personal growth to the natural cycle of renewal.

I think the author concludes the story with this because she's proving she has the strength to do something that she failed the first time again. She took this plant and looked at it as a memory and a passage of time, a tangible link to her past. Saeng planted it as a reminder of home and her promise to herself for the future. When Saeng said, “It’s not a real one" and "Not like the kind we had before,” it showed she loved home and wished she was back there, but her new promise and her determination in this new land were what had mattered most for her moving forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it starts a whole new day and time. That saying means that she will take the test on a budding new day, a time of renewal and fresh starts. For example, the geese return in her spring and the hibiscus buds, and she has the test in the spring, so it will be a new beginning. This is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, to emphasize the theme of a hopeful new start.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to take the driving test in the spring time. Spring time is a symbol of the positive feelings she gets from the blooming of the winter hibiscus. The season represents hope and new growth, which mirrors her own feelings of optimism and readiness for a fresh attempt. This connection between the natural world and her personal journey reinforces the story's uplifting conclusion.

They had to come back, so they did, and they were walking into another world over there in the corner, the childhood world, just as she had known it would feel. The familiarity of the place was exactly as she remembered, bringing a sense of comfort and nostalgia. This return to a past world provided a moment of peace and reflection, confirming her expectations and completing the emotional journey.

This last paragraph is written for several reasons. First, she will try again when she feels the time is right. Just like the geese coming back, Saeng will come back to take the test, and so the Hibiscus plant will also bloom again. She feels that it is the right thing to do and it will be the right time to come back and take the test. This paragraph describes Saeng well about how she lives and how she will take the test again when she feels it is right, showing her patient and hopeful nature.

I believe that the author ends because the author is showing that Saeng is determined to pass the test. "She paused as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter's cheeks and her puffy eyes." This quote shows that passing the test meant a lot to Saeng. She was crying because she couldn't help but buy the plant and fail the test. She didn't want to fail and showed her sadness by crying. "Then I will take the test again." This quote shows that even though she failed, she is determined to pass the test and succeed. Failing hurt her greatly, so she can't wait to do it again and pass because she is determined to succeed. This is all important because Saeng shows that determination is the key to success and she is determined, providing a powerful and inspiring conclusion to her story.

The author uses this paragraph to conclude the story to show Saeng's determination and her adaptation to her new home. This shows her determination because it says, “I will take that test again,” which is a direct statement of her resolve. This also shows that she has adapted to her new home, as she is now looking forward to the future and planning for it within her new environment, signaling her acceptance and growing comfort in this new place.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because she was upset that she moved and also upset that she failed her driver's test. These feelings of disappointment are central to her emotional state. So she planted the plant, an act of putting down roots, and she says that when spring comes, she will retry her driver's test, showing her decision to move forward despite her initial setbacks and sadness.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with a paragraph where Saeng vows she will take the test again in the spring. Minfong used this paragraph because it conveys the theme of never giving up, even if you fail the first time. For example, Saeng just failed her driver's test, but after buying the Hibiscus and looking deeper into things, she realized she shouldn’t give up, finding inspiration and a renewed sense of purpose from the plant.

The author concludes with this sentence for emphasis. It takes Saeng’s mind off of the flower and she focuses on her test, shifting her attention to a future goal. By waiting until next spring to take the test, it gives her something to look forward to, a clear objective. This statement also shows that you should never give up on anything that you do. The author ends on a good note explaining this, providing a hopeful resolution. The last paragraph is also a break from the rest of the story and from what Saeng was just doing, serving as Saeng’s final, resolved thoughts.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph, I think, to say that when the hibiscus starts to grow back, she will be back at what she started. This connection between the plant's renewal and her own resolve is significant. I think that is why because she says, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” directly linking her personal recommitment to the natural cycle of rebirth and growth.

The author concludes the story with a carefully crafted paragraph so the people reading the story would actually read it in its entirety and not be tempted to guess how the story is going to go, thereby preserving the narrative's intended impact and final revelation.

The author's conclusion in the story explains that after all that team work and handwork, you should keep that positive flow going each year, maintaining the momentum and dedication even though something might have changed in the circumstances or the team itself.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to create a powerful feeling of hope for the protagonist's future. Saeng had a bad day, from failing the test to her deep feeling of loss, but after finding the hibiscus and planting it she seemed to be enlightened. While she missed her home land, she still had the memories, which was comforting to her. She shows clear determination, because she declares she will take that test again, and seems to have more confidence in herself. The author adds that Saeng will take the test again in the spring, and when looking at archetypes, spring is a time of new beginning and life. When the hibiscus is budding and being reborn, she will take the test, symbolizing that it will be a new, better start for Saeng too.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's quiet determination. It shows that Saeng wants to take her time to adjust fully to her new life and her new surroundings, allowing herself to become familiar with everything. Then she thinks it might feel more like this place is gradually becoming a home to her. She feels that maybe, if she has been used to this new place for a while, she will have a better chance at passing the test, and she is determined to pass it when she tries again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when Saeng was saying this to herself, she made a firm promise to not give up on getting her license, and the hibiscus makes her feel like she is at home again, providing a deep sense of comfort. In the text when the mother says, "I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers arent as pretty, but its strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. Thats what matters." When she says this it makes Saeng not sad because she knows that the hibiscus will remind her of the hibiscus at home and that gives her the strength and power to want to try again in the spring.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph where Saeng vows, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think that the author includes this paragraph to show how persistent Saeng is. Saeng is persistent because she tries over and over again at this “test” and also she tries to get used to her new country. It demonstrates this in the story when it says the quote above. This quote shows that Saeng can try something and fail, then be determined to try and succeed again, which is a clear mark of her resilience. Also in the story, Saeng has moved from one country to another. This is a huge jump and for her to be confident with herself and to continue striving in a new environment is very persistent. The way the author concludes the story, with this vow, definitely portrays Saeng, the main character, as a persistent person, and that is the purpose of the quote, solidifying the story's central theme of determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants the audience to think about what he said and to want to read more. For example, I was reading a book that ended in a question and I wanted to read more of what the answer to the question is. Another example is that I was reading another book and that was ending in a statement, so I wanted to read another book that they have but they don't have one, so I don't know how the story ended. That's why they end stories like that, so they can make you read another book with the ending or to keep you thinking about the possibilities. This technique engages the reader's imagination long after the story is finished.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. The author wanted to convey a sense of hope to show the growth of her character, and to show how things are going to change. In the last paragraph when she vows that she will take that test again it gives you a sense that everything will be okay. Earlier in the story she had been crying and missing her homeland; the tone was troubled and sad. This last paragraph suggests that the tone is now hopeful. Even though she failed the test she is still going to try again, showing her newfound resilience. The author also put the paragraph to show how much her character has grown. Saying that she will try again shows how much stronger and more determined she is. Lastly, she had the story end with that paragraph to foreshadow what is to come. The geese coming back and the snow melting, and the hibiscus budding all show a change in the seasons. This represents the change that has occurred in her and it foreshadows that things will be different and more positive from now on.

The author concluded the story with that message because, if you think about it, it ties the whole story together and leaves an opening for a sequel. It's obvious that the whole point of the story is to make you think about the character's future and the themes presented. An ending like this does not provide a final resolution but instead encourages the reader to reflect on the journey and imagine what might happen next, which is a powerful narrative technique.

I think the author adds this paragraph because it is a sign of a new start for her. Because she has a hard time now doesn't mean she will always have hard times. The paragraph signifies a turning point and a commitment to future efforts, indicating that her current struggles are not permanent. This moment of resolve highlights her inner strength and the promise of better days ahead, which is a crucial element of her character arc.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it meant a lot to Saeng, serving as a poignant resolution to her difficult day. Saeng had failed her driving test and was scared to tell her mother, a fear compounded by the fact that she also spent nineteen dollars for ‘Dok Faeng-noi’, which was a flower they had back at home. For example, “As Saeng walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant.” The plant Saeng saw meant a lot to her mother, evoking a strong sense of nostalgia and connection to their homeland. “@PERSON1 uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. ‘Dok faeng-nor’ she said. ‘where did you get it.’” That was a quote stating that her mother was excited to hear about the plant, her initial surprise overshadowing any potential disappointment. The story is concluded by that paragraph because after all Saeng went through, her mother was ultimately glad she bought it, finding value in the emotional comfort it provided. “It’s a beautiful plant, this dok faeng- noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.” This final acceptance provides a sense of comfort and closure for Saeng after her failures.

Authors sometimes use interesting sentences as their concluding sentences that you @MONTH1 have a hard time understanding, often to encapsulate the story's central theme. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author concludes her story by saying “when they come back. Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author says this to show that Saeng is not ready to graduate yet and needs to learn more about her new environment and herself. The mother is very disappointed in the daughter for buying a plant that is very expensive, viewing it as a sign of her inexperience; she believes that buying things because of your feelings is wrong. This is shown when they say “I paid over Nineteen dollars for it." "You what?" She also says, “@CAPS1 facing. Na where did you gott that" showing her surprise at the expensive, beautiful plant. Authors use those paragraphs and sentences to show or recap the story's key conflict and emotional journey. The Author of “winter hibiscus” @CAPS2 her story with the paragraph because Saeng should not have bought the plant based on a wave of emotions, and that she shall try again next year to not mess up, learning from her mistakes and preparing more thoroughly.

The author of the passage ends the story with these statements to create curiosity and a sense of hopeful anticipation. This creates curiosity through writing about the spring and the geese returning, elements that symbolize renewal. Spring is the beginning for many creatures on the earth; therefore, Saeng is trying to start over because she feels she must wait for the spring to truly begin anew. The hibiscus reinforces the feeling of a new beginning in that each year new buds grow, just like she can have a second chance to blossom herself. Saeng waits for the spring because she knows that is when everything else creates new life, a cycle of rebirth that she wants to be a part of, so Saeng must wait till then to get her new beginning and face her challenges with fresh hope.

I think the reason why the author ended the story with that paragraph was because that will be the time she thinks she will be ready to retake the driver’s test, using the changing seasons as a metaphor for her personal growth. Before she made that vow, she was disheartened because she had failed the test, feeling a sense of defeat and uncertainty about her future. Maybe she picked the spring time because that gives her a clear and natural timeframe to get herself together, allowing for a period of reflection and improvement. She can practice between then and the spring time, building up her skills and her confidence so that she is better prepared for her next attempt, turning her initial failure into a planned for success.

The author includes this sentence, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show her determination and resilience. She is determined to pass the test, viewing her failure not as a final outcome but as a temporary setback. Even if she is facing problems adapting to @LOCATION1 and its culture, she wants to succeed here and prove her capability to herself and her family. So she will wait a year, using that time to acclimate and improve, and then try again when she is better prepared and more confident in her abilities.

From the story of the girl who just moved from Vietnam to the United States, it will be hard for her to understand anything in this new environment, and anything can bring her memory back about Vietnam, triggering a sense of homesickness. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she did fail the test and she wants to see the hibiscus is budding. “I-I failed the test,” Saeng said it to her mother. Her mother actually understands why it happened, recognizing her daughter's struggle, and she will let Saeng keep the hibiscus because it will make Saeng feel better, serving as a comforting link to her homeland. Saeng misses Vietnam a lot and, with the symbolic hope of the budding flower, will like to try her best to overcome the obstacles she faces in her new life.

The author concludes this paragraph because he wants to make it more clearer so the readers would understand it more, ensuring the central message is effectively communicated. And so he could, make it better to stand out, refining the language and imagery to leave a stronger impression on the audience and to emphasize the story's final point with greater impact and resonance.

The author finished off the story with that paragraph because the paragraph is saying that overtime when she is adapted well to everything she will be able to take the test, so that’s why she says “…and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,…”, implying that all it needs is time. Time to get warm and time to grow, just as Saeng needs time to adjust and flourish in her new surroundings. Also the paragraph is well thought out and relates to the entire story, tying together the themes of patience and renewal. So she concluded with a great paragraph that made a lot of sense in relationship with the story, providing a fitting and hopeful end.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, Ho concludes the story with the paragraph due to the fact the flower represents her happiness from her home, acting as a tangible piece of her past. The flower symbolizes the past and comfort; once Saeng began to dig the "winter hibiscus" in, "she could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now," a sign of her re-engagement with life. All of Saeng’s senses were beginning to return; she was happy, likewise, the author uses the geese to explain the comfort of Saeng, symbolizing natural cycles and return. The country around her began to feel like home as she became familiar with her surroundings. Many references to home was made throughout the piece because home is a place of comfort and happiness, a central theme of the narrative. Therefore, Saeng would gain more confidence from this connection, which explains the reason the author Ho concluded with that sentence, highlighting Saeng's newfound resolve and hope.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because it means to the author kinda like the meaning to life. That if you mess up its okay just try again and do better, emphasizing themes of resilience and second chances. The paragraph serves as a powerful statement about perseverance and the promise of new beginnings, mirroring the natural cycles described in the vow.

She concludes that paragraph with the story because she really wants the people to realize that she is and always is having fun in her new life. Also, that she loves where she is at. She's making her way in the world, and she loves watching flowers, seeing "geese return and this hibiscus is budding." That specific observation shows that her favorite thing to do, what she truly loves, is to appreciate the beauty of flowers and the cycles of nature, which brings her great joy and contentment in her current surroundings.

The author concludes this story this way to go over again the important things in the story. "I will take that test again," refers to the test that she had failed that day. The test that she failed tested her memory of her home, which was her old country that was so important to her. The part in the quote, "when they come back.... when the show me it and the geese return," is referring to when she says, "She realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become… almost familiar to her. Like the geese." She is saying that everything in this new country she is starting to get used to, just like the geese that fly south every winter have become a familiar sight. When she uses "and this hibiscus is budding," she is saying how she will remember all the things she has forgotten when she moved over here to this country. When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel. This whole statement is basically saying that she is starting to forget things from her old country as this new country becomes more familiar, but when the geese return, meaning in the spring, then she will remember again and she will take that test again of her knowledge and pass.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he/she is trying to put across the message that the plant shows a symbol of new beginnings, which is a symbol of Saeng's vow to start anew. Also, in the story, caring for the plant teaches Saeng responsibility, which is connected to her goal of obtaining her license. By caring for the plant, it will teach her patience, a necessary quality for learning to drive, and it reinforces the idea that she needs to learn from the mistakes she has made and not be discouraged by them.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because it shows she is not willing to give up on her new life. "I-I failed the test," shows that Saeng had failed her driver's test and was very unhappy about it. She also disliked her new home at that moment. "She was still too shaky to say at home" indicates she missed her old home and she really wanted to give up entirely. After talking to her mother, however, it renewed her hopes, so the author uses this paragraph to signify that she still has hope in the end. When she says, "When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take this test again," it signifies her newfound determination to try again when she feels ready and the conditions are right.

The author concludes the story in this way to show a tone of hopeful determination. The paragraph shows how Saeng was resolved to try again and pass her test. This teaches a lesson to the reader about the importance of trying your hardest and not giving up, even after a setback. The last paragraph ends the story with a sense of curiosity about the future. It makes you want to know more about what happens next and whether or not she eventually passes her test, leaving her journey open-ended yet full of promise.

I think that the concluding paragraph means after everything else important and what is meant to happen happens, then she will take the test because it is basically the last thing that has to happen. The test represents a final hurdle, and I think she will pass it because it is an event that is meant to happen, a necessary step in her journey toward settling into her new life. Her vow is tied to the natural cycle, suggesting a sense of inevitability and hope for her success.

I believe that Saeng made that silent vow to herself because after the plant goes through the hard winter and once everything goes back to how she likes it and the plant starts budding again, that kind of represents her hard time with moving. The plant's struggle mirrors her own difficult transition to a new country. Therefore, if this plant that she loves so much can make it through the harsh season and bloom once more, then she can too, finding the strength to persevere in her own life.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with the excerpt "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because it emphasizes Saeng's pain in coming to an unknown place and failing her first test but also emphasizes Saeng’s resolve to work hard after seeing a flower that resembled one from home. The flower itself is very important to Saeng, for example, the text reads “And besides it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers.” This excerpt demonstrates Saeng’s love for her hometown through a flower that she knows grows back home. Another example is when Saeng told her mother the bad news “I-I failed the test,” her attention instantly was drawn to the flower and her mother could only offer comfort. In conclusion, the hibiscus flower is Saeng’s source of strength as it’s one of the only things she recognizes and connects to from her past in the United States. Saeng wants to show the same resolve and resilience on her test that the flower shows in surviving the harsh winter.

The author concludes the story with the aforementioned paragraph to represent the connection between the return of the hibiscus’s buds and the return of Saeng’s resolve. In the photograph for the question, the hibiscus flower is out of place, as if it does not belong, similar to Saeng's own feelings of displacement. The hibiscus represented the link to Saeng’s past, as portrayed when the author writes: “Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.” The hibiscus was native to her homeland, and by helping Saeng to remember her past, she began to cope with the present, and later the future. Her vow, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again,” signifies her renewed determination, inspired by the plant's cyclical promise of renewal.

By this quote, the author is explaining that Saeng will eventually be ready for her test. When the geese return, they are ready to return from their migration, and when the hibiscus is budding, it is ready to turn into a beautiful flower. These natural events signal a time of readiness and new beginnings. Saeng believes that in the spring, since the flower and the geese are ready for their respective transitions, she too will be ready, having found the inner strength and preparation needed to face her challenge again with confidence.

The author concludes with this paragraph because the narrator is now willing to accept and adapt to her new environment, much like the flower and the geese would do. Geese prefer the warmth and flee the cold, which is why they are flying south for the winter. Saeng’s “comfort zone” is in Laos, where she has many cherished childhood memories involving her grandmother and the hibiscus flower. She is accustomed to the flower thriving in a warm environment. Therefore, when the geese return in the spring and the hibiscus blossoms once more, she will be prepared to adapt to American life more fully and take her driver's test again. The geese and the hibiscus flower serve as symbolic memories of her old home in Laos, which she misses profoundly. After these things reoccur, she will come to try and adapt to American ways of life, finding a new rhythm in her new home.

Saeng would return to her homeland, if only in her memories and through the symbolic connections she finds in her new surroundings. The thought of Laos brings her a sense of comfort and belonging, a stark contrast to the unfamiliarity she faces daily. This longing is not for a physical return, but for the emotional solace that her past provides, a foundation from which she can gather the strength to move forward in her present circumstances. Her connection to her homeland remains a vital part of her identity, even as she learns to navigate a new world.

In the passage “The Winter Hibiscus,” the author uses this phrase in the last paragraph: “when they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melted and the geese returned and the hibiscus was budding, I will take that test again.” I believe the author concluded the story with these words to show Saeng's change, as she is stating that when the birds flew away, they would eventually return, just as the seasons always change. An example of this cyclical hope is when she observes the birds easing into the hibiscus, mingling with its branches, which leads her to think that she would try again next season. This final paragraph signifies her commitment to persevere and find what she likes to do in this new life. This is the meaning I derive from the last paragraph of the story “The Winter Hibiscus” and what it conveys to me about resilience and new beginnings.

The author concludes this story with the paragraph to illustrate that Saeng is looking toward the future with renewed hope. The author is showing that when spring arrives and the geese return and the plants begin budding, Saeng vowed silently to herself that she is going to take the driving permit test again. This resolution marks a significant shift in her attitude, demonstrating her decision to not give up but to try once more when conditions are more favorable, symbolizing a personal spring after a long, difficult winter.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to show Saeng’s determination to survive and find happiness in her new home. Although she isn’t entirely happy with her purchase of the hibiscus plant, she is trying to make her environment seem more homey and familiar. When she says “I will take that test again,” she demonstrates her desire to make her surroundings comfortable and to claim her place within them. By ending with this paragraph, it also shows a strength found in the changing seasons, suggesting that Saeng will start over and try again with her life. She is content for the moment but is planning to please herself and her mother again in the spring. This paragraph also serves as a promise to discover a new way to live and make friends. The plant acts as a symbol of her intended transformation; she is going to investigate her new world and pass her own test, proving she deserves to be happy and can make herself feel truly at home.

The author concluded this paragraph in the story because it was showing that there are geese that hang around the garden around the spring time, a detail that marks the seasonal shift and adds a touch of life to the natural setting described in the narrative. This observation of the geese serves to complete the scene, grounding the story in a specific time and place without diverting from the central focus. The inclusion of this wildlife detail subtly enhances the imagery of the garden, providing a fuller picture of the environment as the seasons turn. This final note about the geese offers a quiet, natural closure to the paragraph's description.

The author in this story explains how hard some changes can be, particularly the emotional difficulty of adapting to a new and unfamiliar environment. The author also explains how family and objects from home, such as the flower, can be comforting, serving as tangible reminders of a past life and providing solace during times of transition. The meaning of the story is to show one of the author's experiences in life, illustrating a personal journey through hardship and the small comforts that make it bearable. This reflection on memory and resilience forms the core of the narrative's message about coping with change.

I think the author concludes this part because he wanted to let the reader know that it wasn't it for the little girl and she wasn't going to give up on planting flowers. The narrative shows that when the spring comes and the snow has melted, she was going to plant some more flowers and see how they will do during the spring, even though it didn't work as well in the winter season. Her previous failure did not stop her, and I think the author is trying to say that if you do something and it doesn't work, you should keep on trying because maybe something different will happen the next time. This message of perseverance and hope in the face of setback is the essential lesson the author imparts to the reader.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with, “When they come back take that test again.” She does this to show that she still has hope, and won’t just give up. She went through a lot when she moved, and seemed to have a sense of depression in the story. After all her sadness within the story, she finally gets the energy back to tell herself to keep trying. “I will take that test again,” she resolves, which shows her renewed hope. The line, “And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept,” reveals she is obviously upset because the plant reminds her of home, stirring deep emotions. As a conclusion, I thought that it was a very wise choice to end the passage with a positive attitude, as it highlights a turning point from despair to determination for the main character.

I think the author ends the story with this paragraph for many reasons. One reason is because it leaves you knowing that Saeng will never give up trying, reinforcing her resilient character. Another reason is that something as simple as a flower can encourage someone to keep going even if they feel they have nothing to go for, demonstrating the power of small, familiar comforts. Saeng sees that the flower is something so important, a symbol that working harder will encourage her to keep doing the best she can despite her challenges. The author leaves you with this sentence because it is very powerful and brings Saeng courage, ultimately concluding her emotional journey on a note of strength and perseverance. This final thought solidifies the story's uplifting message about finding motivation in the midst of difficulty.

The author concludes the story with this because she failed the test already and wanted to pass it next time. Her primary motivation is to avoid making her mother disappointed in her, as she feels a deep sense of responsibility and a desire to redeem herself after her initial failure. This ending highlights her determination to try again and achieve the success that she and her mother hope for, ensuring the story closes on a note of resolve and future effort.

I think what the narrator means by saying this is that she wants to come back when everything is beautiful again. She wants to wait for all of the snow to melt and the geese to return so she can see all the vibrant colors of the flowers. The return of the geese signals a new beginning, a time of renewal. Furthermore, if she passes her test this time, she will get to drive past all the flowers as a reward for her perseverance and success. That is what I think the character means in this story, as she looks forward to a brighter and more colorful future.

The author of this story ends with this paragraph because it powerfully explains how Saeng will not give up, just as the resilient hibiscus does not. Earlier in the story, it explains how the winter hibiscus does not die, serving as a symbol of endurance. In the paragraph, when it says the snows melt, this signifies that the seasons will keep changing and progressing, just as Saeng should keep going and trying despite her setbacks. Also, when the author says and the geese return, this means that the geese will keep coming back each year, just as Saeng should keep trying to take the test until she ultimately succeeds, mirroring the persistent cycles of nature.

I believe the author used these lines in the last paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again,” to emphasize Saeng's inner vow and newfound determination. This silent promise to herself connects her personal goal to the natural world's cycles, using the melting snow and returning geese as markers for her next attempt. The author likely included this to show Saeng's commitment to trying again, linking her resolve to the hopeful budding of the hibiscus plant, which he really liked as a symbolic device.

I think the author concludes with that paragraph to show more meaning of the story and to provide a deeper emotional resolution. The author could have wanted to show more details in the story, adding layers to the character's motivations and the thematic elements. By expanding on the character's resolve, the ending becomes more impactful and gives the reader a clearer understanding of the central message about perseverance and hope, ensuring the story's ideas are fully conveyed before it ends.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to show how she will start over by retaking the test, just as the hibiscus will start over by budding new flowers. Saeng shows us how she will try to overcome the obstacles she must face, just like the hibiscus flower and geese will overcome the winter. In the story, the author makes the hibiscus represent the way to adjust to the changes in life. In a way, the winter hibiscus represents Saeng because the flower is adapting to circumstances, the circumstance being winter, and it survives by becoming dormant and resilient. Just like the hibiscus flower, Saeng must overcome her obstacles of being in a new country, and retaking her drivers exam, finding strength in the natural cycles of renewal and perseverance.

“When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” is the paragraph that the author uses to conclude the story. In my opinion the author includes this paragraph to conclude the story in order to show Saeng is committed to adjusting to her new home and to leaving her old one. For example, in the story Saeng was unable to say “I mean, not like the kind we had at home.” without bursting into tears. This illustrates her sorrow and inability to let go of her past. The final vow represents a pivotal shift, a conscious decision to embrace her new life and its challenges, moving forward with quiet determination instead of looking back with grief.

The author could have finished the story with that paragraph for many reasons. He/she probably finished with the paragraph to show that Saeng cared about adapting to her new place and was not a failure or quitter. The author also probably finished the story this way to show that Saeng was determined for success and to make her mother happy, demonstrating her resilience in the face of initial setbacks. This final thought solidifies her character's resolve, transforming a moment of defeat into a promise of future triumph. This is why the author finished the story with the paragraph, leaving the reader with a sense of hopeful anticipation for Saeng's journey ahead.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is given a small glimmer of hope by the winter hibiscus. The hibiscus reminds her of her homeland, Vietnam, which pleases her and provides a comforting link to her past. Also, the fact that the hibiscus she purchases can survive winter, unlike the hibiscus of her homeland, symbolizes Saeng’s determination to adapt to her new country, showing a capacity for resilience she is only beginning to recognize in herself. The future of the hibiscus symbolizes Saeng’s survival and adaptation to her new country, which will include her retaking her driving test as a concrete step toward her new life.

The author concludes her story with this statement for many reasons. First the Hibiscus will be strong again when the wind stops blowing; therefore, Saeng will be strong too, drawing a parallel between the flower's endurance and her own potential for recovery. Also, Saeng is giving herself time to adjust and get used to her new surroundings. She is setting a real goal for herself, using the natural timeline of the seasons as her guide. Saeng is identifying with the flower. It gives her comfort, and brings back valuable memories of the things she loved and the things that made her happy, like her home country, and her grandmother, ultimately providing the emotional foundation she needs to move forward.

The author of this story concludes it with this paragraph to show Saeng's determination. I believe that in the story, when she sees the hibiscus plant, she is filled with joy and happiness, but it also brings back reminders of doing her grandmother’s hair. She sees this as a test for herself, a challenge to see if she could look forward and try not to dwell on the past. When she is not home, she said, “I failed the test,” which shows that she wants to move on, but it has not been as easy as she had hoped it would be. So when she sees this hibiscus, a plant that shows life and resilience, this paragraph illustrates that Saeng is trying to move on, and she is determined to find a new beginning for herself.

In the story, I believe Saeng is sad because she misses her home and the hibiscus flower, symbols of her past life. She ends the story well because she can now have a sense of peace with herself by deciding to wait and take the test again. I believe that is why she ended the story like she did, so she does not leave herself worried or angry about her initial failure. She can turn a negative attitude into a positive one when she says she will retake the test when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, showing her newfound hope and resilience for the future.

The author concludes with this sentence because it shows that Saeng is going to try to adapt to her new home and life. He lets you know that Saeng is not going to grieve and be sad anymore, but she will adapt and continue on with her life, embracing her new circumstances. The author adds this: “I mean, not like the kind we had at—” which is when Saeng has just come home and talked to her mother, feeling very sad as she thought about old memories from her old home. But by adding the last statement of the story, it shows that Saeng has decided to move on with life and no longer be held back by sadness, having set a goal to accept her new reality, which is the reason for the author to conclude his story like he does.

Many authors end their stories in different ways, but Minfong Ho ended hers with almost a saying or a promise. One reason she ended her story this way was that she kind of revealed what would happen to Saeng in the future. For example, in the end it says, “I will take that test again,” which lets the reader know that the author might write another story about Saeng when she takes the test again. A second example is showing that Saeng is strong and beautiful but will try again, which is shown when the author wrote, “when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding.” Here, she said “this hibiscus,” which is referring to Saeng herself. Without some of these writing techniques and hints, we might not know if there will be a sequel and what might happen in Saeng's continuing journey.

The author must have put this in the story to show change and personal growth. For all the things we give, we often must replenish or replace them, which is what the author seems to be illustrating. People do not always think about the small damages, as they must be compared with the big changes, but the small ones count and can be the turning point in a story. On top of that, the old ways have to give way to the new. We all go through harsh times, both big and small, but we need to overcome them all to move forward in life.

This is a very important paragraph for the narrator to put in the story, as it reveals Saeng's inner thoughts and priorities. For instance, Saeng is saying that her new home with her flowers is more important than school and a test, establishing her values. And, Saeng doesn’t have many friends to see at school, but her hibiscus will remind her of all of her old friends she made, providing her with comfort. Saeng is simply stating to herself that once everything is back to normal or the way she wants to see it, then she can take that test again, showing her patience and hope for the future. In conclusion, the narrator used this paragraph to let us know how Saeng feels about her new life and her connection to the past.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it concludes and wraps up the story in a meaningful way. It shows the relationship between nature, adapting, and how this all calmed her down after failing the test. The natural world provides her with a sense of peace and a new perspective, allowing her to process her failure not as an end, but as part of a larger cycle of growth and change. This final reflection ties together the story's central themes, showing how Saeng finds strength and solace in her environment.

The author concludes this story with a sentence like this because it reflects the cyclical nature of the seasons and life itself. At the end of winter into spring the snow will melt and the trees and flowers will blossom into different colored flowers, signaling renewal. After all the flowers had blossomed the leaves had come out and then the pollen had found the right kind of trees, continuing the cycle of life. At the end of summer into fall the leaves start to die and change color, then the leaves will fall off, representing an ending. Then it snows all over again, completing the cycle and preparing for a new beginning, which mirrors the character's own journey.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” because it shows that Saeng isn’t going to stay down after her setback. It shows that the hibiscus will overcome winter, like Saeng’s mother says, “'…but its strong enough to make it Through the cold months here, This winter hibiscus that’s what matters.” This powerfully symbolizes Saeng overcoming not only failing the driver’s test, but also the challenge of moving to a new country. She isn’t the same as she was back home, but she’s strong enough to get through this change in her life. Also, taking the test in the spring symbolizes starting over, when everything is new, and she has overcome her personal winter of difficulty. This ending paragraph is so important because it shows Saeng’s promise to herself that she will get past the challenges in front of her, and the hope for better things to come. When Saeng says “…When the snows melt…” it symbolizes the time in her life when her failures will thaw and become good again, allowing for new growth. She will take the test with a new outlook on her life, having been strengthened by her struggles. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it definitively shows that Saeng is resilient and isn’t going to stay down.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, “Where Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to highlight her reaction to failure. Minpong Ho did so because she failed the test, an event that deeply affected her. Saeng failed to find the fine-toothed comb, the hibiscus hedge, the well, and her gentle grandmother during her search, which represented the pieces of her old life she felt were missing. Apparently these things, or the feeling associated with them, could be found or made sense of after the snows melt and the geese return and hibiscus is budding, a time of renewal and hope. This connection between the seasonal change and her personal resolve provides a poignant and hopeful end to her story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng’s outlook on the future. It is a fitting conclusion, drawing from numerous elements in the story, and it shows how Saeng has grown. Saeng refers to “When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding.” In this phrase she shows a growing acceptance and even an affection for her new homeland. The geese are “familiar to Saeng now” despite her thinking of them as “strange before.” The hibiscus is a piece of her past, adapted to fit her current situation. Saeng’s vow that she will “take that test again” in the spring, “When the snows melt…” etc. This shows that despite losing so much - her home, her grandmother, her way of life - Saeng is still determined to make the best of her situation. She plans on passing her driving test come spring, no matter what. The concluding paragraph is a fitting way to wrap up the story. It was how the threads of Saeng’s past and her present are entwined, and displays her attitude towards the future. With its optimistic words the final paragraph neatly ties up the mood of optimism amidst regret. The author’s wording was very well done, effectively capturing her resilient spirit.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the story it says "I will take that test again." This statement shows how much she has adjusted to the changes in her life and her resolve to persevere. In the story it also states "when they come back," which concludes that when the flowers return next season, she will see how much she remembers about her homeland, her grandma, and the good things from her past. This reflection connects her memories to her current life, showing her ongoing process of adaptation. The paragraph thus serves to highlight her emotional journey and the blending of her old and new worlds, providing a poignant end to her story.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because they wanted the reader to know there will be another story that will be made up, suggesting future challenges and growth for Saeng. Also, it shows that Saeng was not happy that the snow melted and the geese returned and the hibiscus was budding, indicating a complex mix of emotions about the changing seasons. This complexity reveals her continued struggle with accepting her new environment, contrasting potential optimism with her personal sense of loss. The ending therefore leaves the reader with a sense of her unresolved feelings, setting the stage for further development.

Now that she knows a lot about plants the narrator makes it seem like the girl is interested in the new world and the different plants that bloom and look so beautiful in the season. The way I see it is that the girl really enjoys the plants and their characteristics; to me I say she is an adventurous girl who likes to explore new worlds and see what is out there to be explained. Her fascination with the flora around her signifies a deeper curiosity and a desire to understand her surroundings. This interest marks a positive step in her adaptation, as she finds beauty and wonder in her new home, concluding her story on a note of discovery.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that Saeng can overcome her weaknesses and succeed in her new home. The quote, “In the spring, when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” means she’ll try the driving test again. She will try this new test to make her like where she’s at and what she can learn from it. This determination highlights her resilience and her commitment to building a new life despite earlier failures. The paragraph ultimately serves as a powerful statement of her hope and her willingness to keep moving forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons, primarily to underscore Saeng's determined character. The first reason is to show that Saeng is a determined young girl. By vowing to take the “test” again, she shows she is determined and not giving up, demonstrating a resilient spirit in the face of adversity. Another reason is because the author wanted to emphasize the importance of the idea of Saeng's personality, highlighting her inner strength and resolve as central themes of the narrative's conclusion.

Minfong Ho concluded the story with this paragraph because it effectively shows Saeng’s determination to pass the driver's test. The fact that she failed it made her feel bad, and brought out feelings of homesickness as did the familiar plant, which served as a poignant reminder of her past. However, in this final paragraph she vows that she will overcome all her challenges of being in an unfamiliar place and pull herself together to accomplish her goal, just as the winter hibiscus endures the harsh season to bloom again, symbolizing her own potential for renewal and success.

The author included this sentence in the paragraph because Saeng was a very determined girl who would not be easily discouraged. She would keep trying till she got it right, demonstrating a persistent nature. No matter how long or hard it would be she would get it done, showing her commitment to her goals. Just like from the picture of the Hibiscus flower next to the highway, which certainly looked out of place, but it would do anything to survive in its new environment. Being strong at times when you can only depend on yourself is hard to do, but Saeng is determined, drawing strength from her loss and the perfect example of the resilient Hibiscus flower.

In the concluding statement Saeng states that “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The author concludes the story with this passage because she is using the hibiscus as a powerful example of survival and adaptation. The hibiscus is from another place like her, and she is using it to represent her well being and potential to thrive in the new place. In a way she is saying, "If the hibiscus survives this winter, than so will I." I believe she uses this as a conclusion to depict her unsure nature towards her new home while simultaneously expressing a hopeful determination for the future.

I believe the author uses this as the last paragraph because it tells of how Saeng wants to overcome her difficulties and be strong even though she is struggling with her new surroundings. She misses her home, and this longing is a significant part of her emotional journey. For example, Saeng believed that since she cried when she saw the hibiscus plant, she had failed in that moment, but she also believes she will get stronger over time, using the plant's resilience as a model for her own personal growth and eventual success in her new life.

The author concludes the story with this specific paragraph to sum up the realization and determination Saeng obtains. First of all, Saeng starts out upset after failing her test. When she sees the flower and goes to find it at a shop she is overwhelmed by this small reminder of her old home. That small flower made her realize how much she missed her old home and buying it becomes a necessity for her, a tangible link to her past. She probably felt that with that flower she would always have a little piece of home in this newer world. After realizing that memories are what is important and seeing that flower’s determination to survive a cold winter, she develops the determination to take the test again. She vows to do so because she has gained faith from the flower’s survival and her realization of important memories, understanding that she too can endure and adapt. All in all, that ending paragraph reveals these specific messages about resilience and the enduring power of memory.

The reason the author was inspired was because of the flower. The flower had the ability to survive harsh winters and adapt to new environments, demonstrating a quiet strength. She decides that she was going to overcome its obstacles just as the flower overcomes its obstacles every winter, drawing a direct parallel between the plant's struggle and her own personal challenges. This observation of the flower's resilience provided her with a powerful model for her own life, showing her that perseverance leads to survival and eventual flourishing.

Memory, promise, life—all are ideas that explain why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. Memories is one idea that helps explain why the author concludes this story with this paragraph because Saeng misses her old life and country, and the flower vividly reconnects her to that past. Promise is another idea because Saeng makes a vow that once spring comes again she will take the test again, committing to a future effort. Life is another idea because Saeng brought the flower and planted it so it can live once spring has come and she said then she will retake the test, linking the plant's life cycle to her own renewal. Memories, promise, and life help explain why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. Memories will come back in the spring along with the promises she has made and the life that wants to start, and Saeng is doing this by planting the hibiscus which brings back a lot of her memories from her life, weaving these three themes together into a single, hopeful resolution.

The author concludes the story with that statement because it had gotten colder and all the plants and flowers were going to die. This seasonal shift underscores the harshness of the environment and sets the stage for a contemplation on endings and the cyclical nature of life. The statement highlights the challenging conditions that the flower, and by extension Saeng, must face and endure, emphasizing the theme of survival against adversity that is central to the story's conclusion.

Reasons I think the author concludes the saying at the top. I think he concludes this because she was very eager on passing the test. She told herself and she vowed to take the test again when the geese return and the snow melts, marking a specific time for her renewed attempt. Another reason I think the author concludes this is because she failed it the first time and it is a big thing for her and she is very eager on passing it, showing her determination to succeed where she initially did not. That is why I think the author added this to the story, to emphasize her resolve and the personal significance of this challenge for her character.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng had failed her driver's test, and as she is walking home, feeling dejected, she spies a flower that reminds her of what was once her home. The sight of the hibiscus stirs a deep sense of nostalgia within her. She buys the flower and returns to her new home, where she finds her mother who is working diligently in the garden. Together, they decide to plant the flower in the garden, a simple act that feels significant. When the flower was finally planted, a flock of geese flies over head, and Saeng then realizes that everything is familiar to her now, when just before everything had felt quite strange and foreign. She concludes the story by saying that when the geese come back in the spring, she will take the test again. She says that the flower will be buckling, which means blooming or growing, and she will have grown and become familiar with everything by then, so she will be ready for the test when the geese are ready to come home and the hibiscus is ready to bloom.

The author does this because they are comparing the character's growth to the plant's growth. The author does this because when the plant starts to bloom then the character’s confidence will come back, mirroring the natural process. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it gives the story some meaning and a sense of hopeful resolution, tying the character's personal journey to a universal cycle of renewal.

The author concludes this story with the final paragraph to emphasize the story's central theme and to make it seem more interesting, as if to make the reader want the story to keep going on to find out what happens next. This technique creates a sense of anticipation for Saeng's future, leaving the reader with a feeling of hope and curiosity about her continued journey and growth in her new environment.

I think this author put this last paragraph in the story to show everyone how determined she is to pass this test and how much it means to her to do it. The paragraph highlights her resolve to try again, connecting her personal goal to the natural cycle of the seasons. This is what I think why the author would put this in the story, to underscore the character's resilience and her commitment to succeeding in her new life.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because it shows the deep connection between nature and the girl. The paragraph says, “...when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” In spring, when all of these events take place, it is a sign of life and birth or renewal. The geese come back, symbolically "renewed." When the snow melts you can see the grass again, which is a sign of life, and when plants bud they are born. The character decides that when nature is symbolically reborn and renewed, she will start again just like nature, aligning her own new beginning with the world's natural cycles.

he concludes the story with his paragraph because he wanted to say that he was going to take the test again when it was not the winter and show how Saeng vowed to herself by saying that he or she will take the test again when it is not winter because even though the test was not passed in winter, it could have been passed during the spring when the snow melted in the ground. The harsh winter conditions likely made everything more difficult, so the promise to try again in a gentler season highlights a resilient spirit and a belief in future success under better circumstances.

In the story the author included that concluding paragraph because if you had read the rest of the story you would know that the person was talking about when she comes back that she wanted to take the test again because it would be such nicer weather then it was the first time she took it. Another reason why I believe the author added this conclusion paragraph at the very end of the novel is to show the reader if they really did understand the novel and what she was really going for in the novel, providing a final point for reflection. So the author first wanted to make sure the reader would understand the ending of the book better with that conclusion paragraph at the end, tying together the character's journey and her newfound determination. These are the reason why I think the author added that concluding paragraph at the very end of that novel.

Because they wanted to get it done with so they made the end like the first part of the story, creating a sense of completion by echoing the beginning. I like the part when the birds came back they got some of the flower come back to them, which symbolizes a return of hope and beauty. This circular structure helps to neatly wrap up the narrative, showing that things have come full circle for the characters in a satisfying way.

Saeng and her mother have to be determined to try their best in order to survive in their new environment. Saeng and her mother has been through a lot and when she failed the test, she was more depressed than before, feeling the weight of her struggles. The author concludes this story with this paragraph to give readers the thought of how it is to be determined to adapt and survive in a different place and though Saeng and her mother are away from their homeland they still enjoy the things they did in Vietnam, like the flowers, and the hot peppers and bitter melons. Her friends disagree with the taste but it doesn't stop her from enjoying what she loves most, demonstrating how holding onto cultural comforts provides strength and a sense of identity amidst challenge.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that she will not stop trying and one day she will pass that test, emphasizing her unwavering resolve. She made a vow to herself that is show determination to overcome the setback she faced. It also makes us want to read more and find out if she honored her vow and if she passed the test, leaving a lingering sense of hope for her future. For example it ends with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will return and take the test again,” a powerful statement of her commitment to try again under more favorable conditions.

The author concluded the story like this because she had another view of Saeng, focusing on her mother's connection to the garden. He would think that every season Saeng would be in a different mood, and that the garden would change accordingly so that Saeng's mom would always be outside for every season, tending to the plants and reflecting the cyclical nature of their lives. This perspective highlights the enduring and adaptive spirit of the family through the natural world.

The author concludes this story with the paragraph because she is proving how something from a memory can make someone determined. For example, Saeng failed her driver's test, but upon reaching the hibiscus plant, it reminded her of her old home, filling her with a sense of nostalgia. Also, while she is planting the plant, she sees the geese with a new familiarity, recognizing them as part of her new environment. This combined experience makes her determined to complete her test because having two reminders of both homes comforts her to know that she can adapt easily and treasure her memories as well, giving her the strength to try again.

He was saying that you should not give up and that you should keep trying, just like the plants in the spring time that persistently push through the soil to reach the sun. This comparison to nature's resilience serves as a powerful metaphor for human perseverance, encouraging one to continue striving toward their goals despite any obstacles they may face, embodying the same tenacious spirit found in the natural world.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she is making a promise to herself to take the test again so she can pass it. She will do it when it is spring with the hibiscus is budding, a time symbolic of new beginnings. She needs to take the test and start driving to gain her independence. I think that is a good thing, for when people vow things to themselves, it creates a powerful internal commitment that can fuel their determination and lead to personal success and fulfillment.

He is referring to the lifestyle of Saeng and the daily routines they do, which are deeply intertwined with their environment. And what the area is like weather wise, with its distinct seasons that influence their activities and the overall atmosphere of their home, painting a picture of a life shaped by its natural surroundings and climatic conditions. This connection defines their experiences and the rhythm of their days.

The author decided to finish the story with that phrase to show that she will wait for her next year and do all this over again. She will be waiting for it, demonstrating her resilience and determination to prove that she can succeed one more time. This cyclical waiting and doing underscores her growing familiarity and adaptation, indicating that she is now used to living there and is prepared to face the challenge again. The ending thus reinforces a theme of persistence and the gradual process of making a new place into a home, concluding the narrative on a note of quiet resolve and established routine.

The author concludes this story like that to show a new beginning in the spring. Like how flowers bloom and bud in spring, she will become a new, better person, shedding the old self just as nature renews itself. This seasonal metaphor powerfully connects her personal growth to the natural world, suggesting a period of dormancy or struggle is giving way to a time of flourishing. That is why the author concludes the story in this manner, leaving the reader with a sense of hope and the promise of positive transformation aligned with the cycles of the year.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng will try the test again and get a fresh new start. It also conveys to the reader that if you fail something the first time, you should not be afraid to go back and try it again. Furthermore, the hibiscus symbolizes her journey because she failed the test in the winter and feels out of place. But in the spring, when the hibiscus has buds on it, she is going to have a fresh start on the test, and the flower will have a new environment to survive in, mirroring her own potential for growth and adaptation in a new setting. This parallel between the character and the natural symbol enriches the story's message of resilience.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because it leaves you to interpret and decide for yourself. It does not come out and tell you what the test was for or even if she passed it; that is for you to decide based on the story's context.
