It also leaves you wondering what is going to happen until then, engaging your imagination. The ending to the story can be anything you want it to be, as it is deliberately up for interpretation, and to different people, it could mean different things depending on their own perspectives and experiences. This open-endedness is a key strength of the conclusion, inviting personal reflection from every reader.

The author ended the story with that paragraph because it clearly states when she is going to try to take the test again and make changes in her evolving life. For example, she is sad in the story because she failed the test and wants to go home, but the prospect of a new attempt brings a shift in outlook. If she passes in the spring, she might finally try to make more permanent changes and commit to living here, seeing it as a place of opportunity rather than just loss. This is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, highlighting a pivotal moment of decision and the potential for a future shaped by perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is finally comfortable with her new “home.” After the passage is mostly a reflection of Saeng’s old life, it ends this way to signify that she has become accustomed to her new way of life and has found a sense of belonging. For example, it says “in the spring, and the geese return…” that shows that she is now used to the geese and the nature of her new world, seeing its cycles as familiar rather than foreign. The author also uses that paragraph at the end to show a sense of release. Saeng had so many memories locked inside her old life, that she couldn’t grasp new ones in her new home, but now she is letting go. The authors use of this paragraph is a good way to close out the story because it lets the reader feel the relaxed scene of the birds flying away; Saeng escaping her pain and becoming a real part of her new world, finally at peace.

This last paragraph reveals something special to the reader. Saeng was given new hope through her mother's understanding and the hibiscus plant. She felt hopeless, miserable and incomparable upon seeing the hibiscus that reminded her of her homeland, initially overwhelmed by the memory. When she came home, however, seeing the roots of the plant buried in the ground gave her new determination and a fresh perspective. The flower represents her. It adapted to be able to survive in cold weather, or hard times, in Saeng's case, showing resilience. The roots are her past and although they are buried, they are not forgotten, providing a foundation for growth. The actual flower represents a new life for Saeng in a new country, a symbol of her future blooming. The author, Minfong Ho, gave personification or humanizing to non-living things to enrich the story, making the hibiscus a powerful character in Saeng's journey. This is why the author used the last paragraph then why she did, to underscore this symbolic connection.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph in order to show Saeng’s determination and resolve for the future. It is also relating the drivers test to the hibiscus plant, creating a parallel between her personal growth and the natural world. It is saying that when everything else starts coming to life, she will also accomplish something, tying her success to the seasonal cycle. She needs the motivation of her surroundings to push her and provide the courage to try again. Throughout the story, Saeng is affected by her surroundings, which deeply influence her emotions and memories. For example, when she’s in the greenhouse, it takes her back to her childhood, “It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery.... Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.” This connection to her environment ultimately fuels her promise to persevere.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng finds comfort in the plant after she failed her test, seeing it as a source of solace. The plant reminds her of home and connects her with her past experiences, grounding her in a sense of identity. Even though she failed the test the first time she feels that if she studies and tries again she can pass, demonstrating her growing resilience. This connects to the Hibiscus because in the winter the plant dies but then come spring its pretty and blossoms again, representing a cycle of death and rebirth. Saeng feels a connection with the plants rebirth and feels she can start over again too and do well on the test, internalizing its lesson of hope. That is why the author includes the paragraph that Saeng vows to take the test again when the spring comes and the hibiscus blossoms, linking her personal renewal to the natural world's regeneration.

The reason why the author concludes the story by saying, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," is to emphasize Saeng's newfound hope. The author ended it like that, because Saeng is basically saying her time will come to take that test and she will pass it with belief in herself, having found inner strength. This final vow connects her personal goal to the certainty of the changing seasons, showing that her determination is now as reliable as the return of spring. The paragraph serves as a powerful conclusion to her emotional journey, illustrating her transition from doubt to quiet confidence and the assurance of a fresh start.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as a way to say that in due season she will take the test that she failed, believing that the hibiscus will help her to overcome the obstacles. I believe that she bought the plant after she failed the test, hoping that with the blossoming of the plant, it would give her a timetable as to when she would be ready to try again. The plant's cycle provides a natural deadline for her to prepare herself mentally and emotionally, turning her initial disappointment into a patient and hopeful waiting period. This connection between the plant's revival and her own determination to succeed reinforces her resolve, ensuring she will face the challenge once more with renewed strength.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is a meaningful summary of the events in the story. Everything that happened to Saeng while she was at the florist is summed up into something resembling a personal vow for the future. The whole reason that Saeng was sad in the first place was that she failed her driving test. In the final paragraph, she vows to take the test again when the hibiscus buds, a moment that symbolizes new beginnings. The hibiscus that Saeng bought will begin budding in the spring, when the snows melt, marking an end to the difficult winter. The last paragraph of the story gives room for Saeng to deal with her nostalgia over the winter season and to look forward with hope. Finally, the geese that fly south make Saeng feel sad, but they also light a spark within her; she tells herself that she will take the driving test again when the geese return, when the hibiscus buds, and when the snows melt, tying her personal growth to the cycles of nature.

In the last paragraph they are trying to express what is coming with the change of seasons. When winter is over spring will come, which means the hibiscus will come back and its presence will be comforting, making her new environment feel more like home. Also the geese will return, and because of that she will take the quiz again, seeing their arrival as a signal to restart her efforts. To her it’s like starting all over, and hopefully she will pass this time with the encouragement of these natural signs. Also she loves the hibiscus, and since that is back, perhaps she will do so much better, feeling a deeper connection to her goal. Overall a new time is coming, filled with fresh opportunities and the promise of success that she is determined to achieve.

I think the author of “Winter Hibiscus” finished with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because it is showing us the importance of the plant and how it will help her pass by serving as a symbol of resilience. It also symbolizes that when the plant buds and fights all the obstacles to survive the winter, then she will similarly beat the obstacles to pass her driving test. For example, in the story it says "When the snows melt and the geese return," the author is relating that to Saeng and her struggle to pass her test, aligning her journey with these struggles to survive the winter. It also says “Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance”. This quote is saying she will rise to her challenge, and overcome it with the same determination. All in all, this final vow is used because it is showing the similar struggles between the flower, Saeng and the geese to overcome their challenges and finish what they started, uniting their cycles of departure and return.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it has profound meaning for Saeng's character. The author is saying that when these animals and living creatures get their chance in the spring, she too, will get hers to try again. For example, the geese will get to return from their migration, the hibiscus will get its chance to bud after the harsh winter, and she will get her chance to take her driver's test with renewed hope. I know this because Saeng’s mother starts talking about how great the plant will be in the spring, offering words of encouragement. She even says, “But it's strong enough to make it through the cold months”. This indicates that the mom is trying to tell her that she, like the plant, is strong enough to endure hardship and will get a second chance when conditions improve. That is why the story ends with that sentence, highlighting the theme of patience and the promise of new opportunities.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it illustrates the natural cycle of the seasons and how they change, come and go, and begin anew with something different. The story starts with a new season, which then transitions into something else. I think that is why the title of this story was called "Winter Hibiscus," because after spring comes winter, and when it was spring, there were all the nice, beautiful flowers that smell good. When spring is gone and winter arrives, all the plants have died out and will not be the same as they used to be, mirroring the changes in Saeng's own life and her memories of her homeland.

In "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, Saeng does not give up; she keeps trying persistently. The author concludes the story with a small paragraph that has an extraordinary meaning, encapsulating Saeng's resilient spirit. “…in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” By saying this, Saeng shows her determination to never give up, to give new things a fair chance, and to always remember her homeland, which the hibiscus plant powerfully symbolizes. The author ended the story in such an inspiring way because it strengthens the theme of perseverance and hope. There is a lot to be learned from only a few words, making the conclusion both poignant and powerful.

The author chose to end the story with the final paragraph for several interconnected reasons. Saeng states that she will retake her driving test in the spring, a season which archetypically symbolizes a new start or a new opportunity. Ending the story with this archetype shows that later on, Saeng has a new chance to succeed at her test and also to make the best of being in the United States and adapt to her new life there. When she buys the hibiscus plant, she vividly remembers her old home and all the wonderful memories she has of it in Vietnam. The plant seems to give her hope and comfort, and the last paragraph of the story mentions the hibiscus budding. This shows that having the hibiscus around will give her the hope needed for passing her test and also for adjusting to her new home while fondly remembering her old one.

The author concludes the story with the final sentence to state that when the plants start over growing and the geese come back, she will try again. For example, the plants have to grow their petals back and the geese have to make their home and find food again, which are natural processes of renewal. The author is saying she will take the test again when the geese come back and the plants grow again, using these seasonal changes as a metaphor for her own opportunity to begin anew after a period of hardship and waiting. This connection to nature underscores the theme of cyclical renewal and personal resilience.

The author wrote the concluding paragraph to signify a shift in the character's focus and the passage of time. She went back inside the house to get dinner and because she isn't going to see the garden until the next day, and since winter has come, she will not play outside anymore until the winter goes away. Like she said, “In the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” That quotation explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, as it marks a period of patient waiting and hopeful anticipation for a fresh start, tying the natural world to her personal resolve.

I would have to say that the reason the narrator ended with this is because it is kind of a solution if you think about it. The final paragraph presents a resolution to the character's central conflict, offering a sense of closure and a clear path forward. And you don’t put the solution anywhere else but the end; that is precisely why she put it there, as it provides the concluding thought for the entire narrative. This placement ensures the story concludes on a note of resolution, leaving the reader with the character's newfound understanding.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author shows that Saeng is not giving up and that she found a hobby to look forward to. This final scene solidifies her character development, moving from disappointment to a quiet determination. An example is the line, “the winter hibiscus was in the ground now and Saeng tamped down the soil around it overhead a flock of Canada geese flew by.” This imagery of planting the flower and the geese flying overhead symbolizes her putting down new roots and looking toward the future. That is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, as it encapsulates the story's central theme of resilience and new beginnings.

The author ended the story with that specific quote because it shows the grasp in understanding the beauty and marvels of nature, which serves as a source of comfort and perspective for Saeng. Saeng spent a lot of money to buy a distinct flower called dok faeng-nol. She was taking a driver's test for a license but was failing it, and during her test she found that plant. Ashamed that she failed the test, she still showed her mother the flower she found, which was not like the one at home. Her mother is pleased with the flowers and understands that Saeng failed her test. Her mother said about the flower, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” That was a figurative speech indicating that there's hope for Saeng to pass her test again when she has learned more and is ready to try again. And with the geese flying away for the winter and coming back in the spring, it signifies a fresh new start at success, mirroring Saeng's own cyclical journey toward achievement.

The author concludes this way because when it gets warm and nice outside, that is when they will go to take the test again, as it is too nasty outside now. The harsh winter weather represents the current difficult circumstances that prevent immediate success. The arrival of spring, therefore, symbolizes a more favorable time for a second attempt, suggesting that timing and external conditions play a role in one's readiness. This ending implies a postponement rather than an abandonment of the goal, offering a hopeful outlook for the future when conditions improve.

It is actually a very powerful last statement. Even though she failed her driver’s test, she has realized that she will just have to keep being strong and be patient. Soon the geese will come back and the snow will melt, and she will “return” to take her test and will be determined to pass. Saeng bought the hibiscus to feel as if she were back in Vietnam, and felt as if it could fill that place in her heart where she misses it. “I paid nineteen dollars for it.” She says it like she was disappointed in failing the test but also noted that something which is free back in Vietnam was so expensive in the United States, highlighting her sense of displacement. A hibiscus flower is tropical, so when it blooms in the spring, it will be when she becomes ready to give the test a second try, linking her personal growth to the natural cycle of the seasons.

The author concludes the story with this ending because it shows that if the plant comes back and blooms, then she will go back and take the test and try to pass this time. She knows that it is going to be tough for her to come back and pass this test, but she knows she can do it just like she knows that the plant will fight through the winter and come back and bloom in the spring. This parallel struggle gives her confidence that she can pass this test if the plant can come through the tough winter that they are both going through. As a result, this is why the author ended the story with that final, hopeful vow.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story by saying that she will retake the driver's test because not only will she take the driver's test again, but she will also be more comfortable in her life. The driver's test is not the main problem; it is adapting to her new environment that is causing Saeng so much heartache. For example, in the text, Saeng’s thoughts reveal "A wave of loss so deep and strong stung Saeng’s eyes now and swept over her," and "in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept." This passage shows that Saeng is having trouble readjusting to her new life and is reminded of her old memories from where she used to live and cries because it is gone. I think that failing her driver's test was just the small thing that finally caused her to cry because of the accumulated stress, and when she said “and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again,” it means that she will overcome all that hardship and move on with renewed strength.

It was good that the author concluded the story with this paragraph. Saeng loved the hibiscus, so when spring comes and the hibiscus would bloom, it would be the best time to take that test again after already failing it. The blooming flower would serve as a symbol of renewal and hope, and it would probably make her more confident and emotionally prepared to take the driving test again at the right time. So in conclusion, that is why the author concludes the story with that particular paragraph, as it ties her personal resolve to a natural, positive change.

The author concludes the story with this because she is saying that she is going to grow with the season change. She is in a new country and just failed her driver's test. She feels down, but the hibiscus reminds her of being back home and gives her a sense of familiarity and comfort. In the story, Saeng's mother says, “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake; it's strong enough to make it through the winter.” I think that Saeng can relate to that because if the flower can make it in the winter, then she can make it in a new country. This connection provides her with the determination to persevere through her own difficult period of adjustment.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author finishes the story with this last paragraph: “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author finishes the story with that paragraph because in the beginning, Saeng had purchased the hibiscus plant because it had reminded her of her hometown, as indicated by the line, “Plants that she had not realized that she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.” So she purchased it, but since there was bad weather at the time, Saeng had to get the plant back in time and plant it in the garden. But she failed, setting her back. That is why it says, “I will take that test again.” And she will take it again during the spring when the hibiscus blooms once again, linking her second attempt to a season of new beginnings. That is why the author finished the story with that paragraph, to show her commitment to trying again when conditions are more favorable.

The author concludes the paragraph like this because it shows that she is not going to give up. I know this because she vowed silently to herself that she was going to take the test again during the spring, a clear sign of her determination. The author emphasizes that it is the obstacles and difficulties, not the successes of the past, that are truly challenging and require resilience. In conclusion, this is the primary reason why the author concludes the paragraph in this manner, highlighting the character's perseverance.

The story “Winter Hibiscus” is written by Minfong Ho. The author ended the story with this excerpt, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The reason for this is so she will have time to adjust to her new environment. Saeng just needs a little comforting because all of this is new to her, and the promise of spring offers her hope. These words use figurative language because the geese reminded her of herself, “Almost familiar to her now. Like geese," suggesting a connection to the natural cycles of migration and return. This literary device reinforces her personal journey and the theme of adaptation.

It is almost spring, just as he said, with the snow melting and the geese returning and the hibiscus budding. The grass is growing, the trees are budding, and birds are singing, filling the air with their cheerful sounds. The landscape is transforming, becoming vibrant and full of life as the season changes, signaling a time of renewal and new beginnings.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with an interesting paragraph. The paragraph says, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again." The author ended the story with that paragraph because Saeng was not in her comfort zone; she had moved to a new country and missed everything from her old life, like the flower and the hibiscus. So she would wait until she felt at home and comfortable again to retake the test, allowing herself time to adapt. In the text it states “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” She was realizing that it wasn’t so bad and she was getting used to it, finding a sense of belonging in the cyclical patterns of her new home.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt & the geese return & this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” so that the audience has something to think about after finishing the narrative. This final vow gives the story a little more of a dramatic effect, leaving the reader with a sense of hopeful anticipation for the character's future and the symbolic renewal that spring represents.

The author concludes the story this way to show she will be alright, and remain determined. The way she speaks of future times, looking ahead to the coming season, shows confidence that she will make it till spring. The way she speaks of the test, with a clear and resolute tone, shows her determination. The use of the word “vowed” shows she will follow through with her statement, making a solemn promise to herself that underscores her unwavering commitment.

The author concluded the story with this sentence because she's letting people know that she enjoys nature more than school. This final thought highlights a clear preference for the natural world and its simple, authentic pleasures over the structured and perhaps more demanding environment of the classroom. It serves as a definitive statement of her personal values and where she finds true contentment.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because the flower is told about all through the story and the author puts when the hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again. This connection ties the character's personal resolve directly to a natural event, using the flower's cycle as a symbol and a timeline for her own actions. The conclusion thereby links her future endeavor to the recurring promise of nature, giving her determination a concrete and hopeful marker.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because she is telling us what will happen beyond the story we are reading. It means when the snow melts, she’ll start all over again and rebuild the greenhouse. This forward-looking statement provides a sense of continuity and hope, assuring the reader that the narrative of perseverance does not end on the final page. The conclusion effectively points toward a future defined by renewal and the character's active efforts to restore what was lost.

I think the author concludes the story the way she did to show determination. I also believe that it symbolizes adaption, when the season changes, as will Saeng, she will take the test again. Everything will soon go back to normal and will adjust just like she will. The observation that everything is “almost familiar to her now” reinforces this theme of gradual acclimation and finding one's footing in a new environment. This final note leaves the reader with a strong impression of resilience and the capacity for positive change.

The author concludes with this ending because it provides a sense of hope, much like a happy ending to an otherwise sad story. It serves as her final, uplifting thought for the narrative, offering a positive and fitting end point for the reader to reflect upon, ensuring the story closes on a reassuring note.

The author concludes this paragraph in the story because that is the moment when she begins growing plants again, symbolizing her desire to start over. This act of planting represents a new beginning and a personal renewal, marking a clear transition from her past struggles toward a future filled with potential and growth.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it explains that Saeng will try again once spring arrives. For example, the line “I failed the test,” shows that Saeng did indeed fail, but she also brought her mother a hibiscus to plant. Her mother, feeling sympathetic about the failure, cooks her food to offer comfort and help her move past the disappointment. This familial support is crucial as it provides Saeng with a sense of relief and the comforting knowledge that she can confidently retake the test when the time is right.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. Saeng’s silent vow shows she has calmed down and now feels more at peace with her new country. She observes the snow melting and the geese returning, and she declares she will take the test again. This indicates she no longer feels defeated by her failure, recognizing instead the opportunity to try again and perform better. Her perspective on her problems has shifted, and she now views her new country with different, more hopeful eyes, as everything in her life begins to feel better, which explains why the author chose this paragraph to conclude the story.

The author concludes the story with the line, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to illustrate her resolve to try again with a fresh start. Upon seeing the flower, the clerk identifies it as a hibiscus, which triggers nostalgic memories of her childhood. She takes the plant home to show her mother, who reacts with surprise at the cost. The hibiscus, representing something deeply significant, instills in Saeng a renewed sense of hope. By linking her new attempt to the blooming flower and the returning geese, she signifies her intention to begin again with a clean slate and a positive outlook.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng’s determination despite her sadness and her complex feelings of displacement. She misses Vietnam, but she will take the test again next year, demonstrating her resilience. The author’s choice of words in the concluding paragraph, such as references to spring and budding flowers, convey a sense of hope and something to look forward to after a period of hardship. In the story, Saeng is disappointed in herself for failing the test, but buying the plant helps her because it reminds her of home and provides a tangible link to her past. The idea that Saeng is persistent and the hopeful tone of the story are effectively expressed in this final paragraph, which emphasizes her resolve to try again.

The author concluded the story with that particular paragraph because it appeared to be an important thought to "Saeng" and it was basically the main cause of everything, or rather the main subject of the story, encapsulating her central conflict. She also may have concluded the story with that particular paragraph because that was her last and final thought, or memory of her previous life and lifestyle before her present place of living, serving as a poignant farewell to her past. This final reflection ties together her experiences of loss and adaptation, highlighting the significance of her memories. It functions as the emotional core from which the story's meaning radiates, providing a quiet moment of introspection for the character.

The author concludes the story with “In the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because Saeng fails the test after spending her money on a big mac and not having enough for the type of flower her mother sent for, which led to her failure. So since Saeng failed the test, she wants to take the test again and make her mother happy, showing her commitment to improving her situation. This concluding statement shifts the focus from her initial disappointment to a future-oriented goal. It underscores her decision to learn from her mistakes and try once more when conditions are better. The promise to retake the test becomes an act of filial devotion and personal resolve.

I believe that author ended the story with that sentence because it gives a lifting feeling after the story was so sad, providing emotional relief for the reader. Saeng missed her homeland, was sad, used the flowers as relief, was sad about her driving test and really liked the plant, accumulating a series of melancholic experiences. So the last sentence seemed to fit in as a comfort zone to make the reader a bit more relieved by introducing a note of optimism. It serves as a gentle uplift after detailing her struggles and sense of loss. This final thought allows the story to end on a forward-looking and positive note, balancing the preceding sadness.

The author concludes the story with these final lines to create a tone of hope that establishes a central theme for the narrative. Final lines have a great impact for the reader because it is the last thing they read, leaving a lasting impression. In this story, Saeng refers to the time “when the snow melts”. Here the snow is symbolic of the sorrow she has been facing because she left home. At one point in the story, “Saeng broke down and wept!” The spring is a time for archetypal rebirth, and so the “snow will melt” and her sorrow will go away, which creates a tone of hope for happy times in the future. Next, Saeng refers to the time of the hibiscus budding. The hibiscus represents a comforting connection to her old country; she referred to the plant as “yet another old friend”. If the hibiscus blooms, then her new life will also blossom because she will be comforted to the point where she feels security, creating a tone of hope for future comfort. The times ahead she speaks of are followed by a promise to take the test again despite her failure the first time. The author is using this tone of hope to show that we can overcome challenges, demonstrating optimism toward the spring and a willingness to face difficulty. Therefore, the conclusion delivers a life lesson about having the courage to persevere.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” ends the story with this paragraph because it reveals the profound importance of the Winter Hibiscus to Saeng's emotional journey. In the story, Saeng moves from Vietnam and feels very homesick. She fails her driver's test and is very upset, compounding her feelings of displacement. When she sees the familiar plant she is reminded of her home in Vietnam, a connection that brings her immense comfort. The Winter Hibiscus reminds Saeng of fond memories with her grandmother and simple things such as her fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb and the hibiscus hedge that would leave soft red petals in her well water. When seeing the familiar plant, “Saeng felt a shock recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.” This shows how important the hibiscus was to her, serving as a tangible link to her past. The author ended the story with that paragraph to show how the winter hibiscus is a comfort to Saeng and will encourage her to do better on her next driver’s test, providing her with the strength to persevere.

After reading “Winter Hibiscus,” I can tell that Saeng is a determined person, and likes nature. I can also tell that she is determined to pass the test, showing her resilient character. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the beginning of the story, Saeng fails her driving test. She walks home, and as she is walking, she comes across a familiar plant. This takes her to her childhood world, offering her a moment of solace and reflection. Had she not failed the test, she would have never walked home and come across the plant, which becomes a pivotal moment for her. The author didn’t want us to forget the reason she walked home, as this seemingly negative event led to a positive and meaningful discovery. It would have never happened otherwise, highlighting the unexpected paths to comfort.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that next spring she will have another chance. The author shows that Saeng will relate to the blooms of the hibiscus plant and take the test again, drawing parallels between the plant's cycle and her own life. The author does this to leave a cliffhanger, and it shows there is more to Saeng’s life but it is still to come, creating a sense of hopeful anticipation. In the story, Saeng is trying to get used to change and that she is having a hard time adjusting to her new environment. Her mother tries to cheer her up but just like the winter comes, a period of dormancy is natural. Saeng will have next spring to take the driver's test again, symbolizing a new beginning and the promise of future success.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph "When they come back,… then I will take the test again" because Saeng needs time just as the hibiscus needs time to grow and bloom again. Saeng didn't do well on a test but says she will try again after snow melts and the spring comes, showing her patient resolve. After moving, Saeng feels alone and wants to go back home but she feels in her heart that she can try given time and the right conditions. The hibiscus reminds Saeng of the flower back in her home country, and this helps her see that she has to let go of her past and live in the now, while still drawing strength from her memories. This realization allows her to look forward to the future with a sense of hope and determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows Saeng being mature about her failure and being confident, knowing she can take the test again. When it says “Saeng vowed silently to herself,” it indicates she thought about everything deeply, and the phrase is almost like she is going to start over with a new perspective. This silent vow represents an internal commitment to perseverance and growth. Her maturity is shown through her acceptance of the situation and her resolve to try again, demonstrating her developing strength of character. This conclusion solidifies her transformation from someone who was upset by failure to someone who is prepared to face challenges anew.

The author concludes the story with a sentence about retaking her test when the geese are back and the hibiscus is budding because they each represent something else. The geese represent change and migration because they change their environment in the winter, just as Saeng changes her environment by going to the plant place and adapting to a new country. The hibiscus reminds her of her original home because at her home there are similar plants that she loved. Furthermore, the hibiscus budding represents a new life and a fresh start, just like the one Saeng has to live in a new home. Overall, the sentence that the author ends with is used to show Saeng's new life as compared to the geese and hibiscus, drawing a parallel between her personal growth and the natural cycles.

Saeng was happy when the snow was disappearing because she couldn’t wait for spring to come back to see the animals running around by her garden and seeing the beautiful geese flying in after their long and hard hibernation. The melting snow signaled the end of the difficult winter, a season that had mirrored her own struggles to adjust. So Saeng was excited to see everything grown back, as the return of life and warmth to the land filled her with a renewed sense of hope. This optimism made her feel that she is guaranteed to pass the test this time, having found the strength and confidence she previously lacked.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was waiting for the winter time to be over, a period that had been cold and challenging for her. After the winter time, Saeng is going to take a test again and she can plant the flower in the warmer soil. Saeng really likes this hibiscus, as it is a cherished reminder of her past, and she doesn't want it to die during the winter time. The arrival of spring, therefore, represents a promise of survival and a new opportunity for both the plant and for Saeng herself to flourish.

The author concluded this story with this paragraph because she wanted to show how the flower gave the little girl strength and a sense of connection. The girl was in a new place and back at home where she is from there are a lot of beautiful flowers that she loved to look at, and being in a new place that doesn't have these flowers really gets her down and has her upset. She misses her home so she is hurting, and the only thing that sort of comforts her a little bit are the flowers, even the artificial one she finds. For example, the girl says, “It’s-it's not a real one...I mean, not like the kind we had at...", here she stops because she is so upset that she can’t say home. The flower she has right now isn't real but when the real one blossoms in the spring, seeing the flower will comfort her and give her the confidence to retake the test, symbolizing that a part of her home can grow in this new land.

The author’s conclusion explains her feelings about starting anew. The author's conclusion says, "when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again", which means that she is a new woman, ready to embrace her transformed life. For example, taking the test means that she will change and prove her capabilities in her new environment. Also, what it means is that she is ready to take on new things and challenges that come her way. For instance, the test to her is getting ready to take on a new chapter, representing her personal resolve. That is what I got from the conclusion, a message of hope and determination for the future.

The author ends with this paragraph to show that Saeng had hope, demonstrating that there is still a chance for her future success. The ending paragraph makes you kind of create your own ending for Saeng, allowing the reader to imagine her path forward. I like to imagine Saeng with a big, flourishing garden next to her, a symbol of her perseverance, and she ultimately passes the test she had previously failed, achieving her goal.

I believe that the author concluded the story with this paragraph for several reasons. This final paragraph draws together and unites all the central ideas into one concluding thought. It tells us that in the spring, when everything is coming to life, Saeng will find the strength and determination to take the test again. These central ideas expressed in the last paragraph show how Saeng and her mother have adapted to their new environment and that new things are started in the spring, as well as new possibilities for the future. In the text it says, “I know", her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. It’s flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.” This means and represents that even though life is different here away from Saeng's original home, they will adapt and survive in their own resilient way, just like the hardy plant.

The author concludes the story the way she does because it shows that Saeng needs to heal from the failing of the test before she can take it again. Saeng already knows that she can heal, having done so before. She realizes that she has gotten used to where she now lives, that things in her new land, like the sound of geese, are now “familiar to her”. The narrator of the story says, “..she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become… almost familiar to her now.” Things in Saeng's new home had been strange to her at first, but she had healed and gotten used to them over time. Saeng has also healed from the profound sadness of leaving her original home of Vietnam. She was sad to leave her home, “A work so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.”, but she had healed from that wound as well. Saeng remembers the flowers that she had known in Vietnam as “old friends”, showing that it did not hurt her to remember them anymore. When Saeng heals from failing her driving test, like she had healed when moving from Vietnam to the United States, she can re-visit the test, without the initial pain, and succeed.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows the character, Saeng, was going to adapt to their new home and stay strong through her challenges. I believe, when Saeng’s mother says, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but its strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus,” I think Saeng’s mother is also sort of thinking about Saeng. Its almost as if she’s saying that the move here scarred Saeng but she will be strong and survive the change; like anyone who has failed a test, she will study more and try harder to pass it next time. Saeng isn’t going to give up and she’ll keep holding on to make it through the difficult period of adjustment. Saeng knows it’s hard to adjust to life's changes but with a little courage and hard work, it will eventually be a breeze. If she believes in herself, she’ll be able to get fully situated and thrive in this new place.

"When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again." That is in there for many reasons. One is because when winter comes and brings all the snow it kills her garden, representing a period of dormancy and hardship. So that's why she wants it to be spring again so she can start growing things again in her garden, a time of renewal and new beginnings. She got to take a test on the things that she is growing to make sure it is safe for someone to eat it, connecting her personal growth to the literal growth in her garden. That's why I think the paragraph “when the come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” is so significant to the story's conclusion.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concluded the story with an interesting and meaningful paragraph. It was, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” (@NUM1). This shows that the girl is adapting to her new country and hopes to do better in the spring, using the natural cycle of the seasons as her timeline. The reason the author ended the story with this paragraph is because it shows that the girl has successfully adapted to her new country and is determined to get stronger as time goes. She is saying when the hibiscus returns, she will be ready to take the test again and not fail it, symbolizing her personal growth and resilience.

The Hibiscus is budding means that the flower was growing and beginning to bloom. That is a flower with lots of bright colors and nothing else can beat its vibrant beauty. The reason another flower can’t beat it is because that flower represents so much thing and it is one of the most natural born flowers around, cherished for its simple yet striking appearance. Its significance goes beyond mere aesthetics, making it a truly special and unbeatable blossom in its own right.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because that was how he wanted the story to end, providing a final insight into the character's thoughts. He wanted to end the story with her talking to herself, revealing her inner determination and private resolve. This choice creates a quiet, introspective finish that allows the reader to understand her personal commitment and hopes for the future, effectively concluding her emotional journey.

People have to adapt to different cultures if they move to a new country. They could do this in a variety of ways, including making new friends and adjusting to the local area and its customs. However, when adjusting to a new area, you should still remember your past home as well, holding onto the memories and traditions that shaped you. This is what Minfong Ho is trying to display in the ending paragraph of the story, "Winter Hibiscus". In the story, a teenage girl named Saeng moved from Vietnam to the @LOCATION2. She has various rememberances of her past home while visiting a plant store, where she encounters familiar flora. She buys a plant that was common in Vietnam and plants it in her garden, creating a tangible link to her heritage. The last paragraph of the story says “In the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that driving test again”. This shows Saeng’s desire to fit in with this culture, by taking the driving test, as well as remember her past, by keeping the flower. This last paragraph summarizes Saeng’s emotion for her old country as well as her determination to succeed here, beautifully intertwining her dual aspirations.

Because she was promising herself that when spring comes back then she will take the drivers test again, using the changing season as a marker for her renewed effort. This internal vow represents her commitment to not give up and to try once more after a period of rest and reflection, showing her resilient spirit and hope for future success in her new environment.

The author concludes with this paragraph to show her determination. When she says, “when the snows melt and the geese return and his hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” Saeng is explaining how the geese have the determination to fly back and that the hibiscus has the determination to bud again, so why shouldn’t she have the determination and confidence to take the test again. After Saeng said, “I-I failed the test,” it seems as if failing the driving test made her feel like she was going to fail in the new country. But after she saw the geese’s and hibiscus’s determination through harsh conditions, she was determined to try the test again, drawing strength from their resilience to fuel her own.

The author concludes this story with that paragraph to explain how she already took the test and it is now winter; she will retake the test again when all of the flowers and plants come back to life and start again. Saeng wants to take the test again to show her mother that she can pass it. She bought a plant called ‘dorl Faeng-noi’ for nineteen dollars to help her mother not be disappointed, hoping it would serve as a promise of her future success. However, her mother was disappointed that she spent that much money on a plant, adding another layer of challenge for Saeng to overcome with her renewed resolve.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that when she sees the things from her home and living, it will comfort her in what she does. The author seems like she needs things from her homeland that help her make the best of things and bring back good memories of earlier life. I think that whenever I want to do a good job, it helps to think of the good things that mean a lot to me so I will be happy and want to do good. The author is smart to want to see those things for her to retake her test because if she sees her plant doing well and sees the memory of the geese again, it will be good luck for her, providing the emotional support she needs to succeed.

The author chooses to end the story with such a paragraph as this in order to show that Saeng has received a new burst of hope from her memories and the newly familiar things in her new home. The combination of the failed driver’s test and being away from her original home caused Saeng to feel much loss. While Saeng is in the flower shop, “aware of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” Through the rest of the story Saeng is shown to still be down, and the reader is left unsure if she will be alright. Then her recovery begins with the presence of familiar things: “The pungent small of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered,” “The winter hibiscus’ was in the ground now,” and, “overhead a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and – yes – Familiar to Saeng now.” This realization that the geese are familiar to her gives way to new realization and a new wave of hope. She recognizes the fact that she is now coming to be familiar with many of the things about her new home that she had initially thought to be strange. This is what the final paragraph explains to the reader; it summarizes Saeng’s newfound hope that she will learn to not just live in her new home, but to thrive in it, using her past as a foundation for her future.

The author concludes the story with this statement because it shows that to her the hibiscus symbolizes overcoming obstacles. It symbolizes this because she says, “...and the geese return and this is budding, I will take that test again.” This shows that even though she failed it this time, when the hibiscus gets bigger she will retake the test; it shows resilience and overcoming obstacles. Also, I believe that this symbolizes overcoming obstacles because it “gives her strength from her old country.” This shows that it symbolizes overcoming obstacles because it will help her overcome this test; it will do this by giving her strength or comforting her. From this you can tell that the author ends the story with this statement to emphasize how symbols from her past empower her to face future challenges.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it says that Saeng is confident and is willing to go back and take the test. Saeng feels good about herself and wants to do this, showing a shift from her earlier disappointment to a state of renewed determination and self-assurance. This final sentiment underscores her personal growth and resolve to face the challenge again, providing a hopeful and forward-looking conclusion to her emotional journey.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was taking a test. In the story there are some quotes to support my response, “I-I failed the test,” Saeng said. This shows that she was taking a test about gardening. Another reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the story was about spring, gardening, and the life of it to them. The paragraph talks about spring, and flowers. The daughter and mother live off of the plants by planting vegetables, and fruits, which connects their livelihood and cultural practices to the natural cycles of growth and renewal that the test and the season both represent.

The last paragraph of the story, “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, is important to the story. The last paragraph leaves a definite ending so the reader knows exactly what is going to happen in the future. This paragraph is a very significant ending to the story because it represents symbols in the story. The author concludes the hibiscus is important to her. Along with the hibiscus it also shows that the geese and the melting of the snow represent a fresh start and a new beginning. These symbols are important to her in that they give her a chance to start over and she sees that in the winter hibiscus, which embodies resilience and the promise of new life despite the harshness of winter.

Saeng was very distraught knowing that she didn’t pass the test and to her she felt as though it was a let down or disappointment. This sentence shows the ambition and determination that Saeng has so that she will be able to pass this test, indicating that her initial failure serves not as an endpoint but as a catalyst for her resolve to study harder and succeed the next time she attempts it.

The author concludes the story with when they come back “to show how Saeng has changed throughout the plot of the story. In the beginning she refers to her new home as, “walking into another world.” As a teenager she had to move from Vietnam where traditions are so much different than in the United States. However, there is one plant that is similar, the winter Hibiscus. The plant connects her previous life and home to the life and home she lives now. It was hard to adapt to the situation of moving, but the plant created familiar scents and the “familiar fragrance” which “filled her lungs.” It was even difficult for Saeng to say the words “at home” without bursting into tears. Once the winter Hibiscus was in the ground it changed Saeng and she realized that she needed to appreciate what she had. In conclusion, the author ended the story with that paragraph because it showed how much the plant resembled Saeng and how her mind set on life was altered, finally allowing her to feel a sense of belonging and peace in her new environment.

I feel that the author concludes the story with this phrase as a way of showing how Saeng is adapting to her new home, yet still valuing her old one. The gist of the sentence is that Saeng will take her test again in the spring, showing her perseverance and her resilient spirit. However, the sentence also shows how Saeng is coming to know and accept her new land. She says, "when the snows melt and the geese return," and this is important because the geese and the snow are symbols of her now home, and she now acknowledges and accepts them as part of her new life. However, Saeng also says, “when this hibiscus is budding," and this shows how Saeng is still thinking of and honoring her old home, because the plant is her tangible connection to the memories of Vietnam and her past. Therefore, I feel that the author is showing how Saeng is growing up and learning to live with the changes in her life by ending the story with this balanced and hopeful statement.

I think that the author is saying today is that when it is winter the hibiscus is trying to pierce the cold. While most plants just die or go dormant, the hibiscus must face the harsh winter head on, enduring the difficult conditions. This reflects a struggle against adversity, showing a quiet strength. The plant's persistence in the face of the cold is a powerful image of resilience, much like the challenges people must sometimes endure.

I think the author includes this because she doesn’t want to leave her audience guessing about what would happen next. The statement, “I will take the test again,” is saying she may have failed the test with the plant identification, but she is never going to give up and that when spring comes she is going to try again with renewed determination. I feel as though the author added this to give a better understanding of how it feels to leave your homeland to come to a place you don’t know or understand, such as the flower situation in the story. When she thought about the plants and how they smelled, it gave her the old feelings that she had about her homeland and how close she was with her grandmother, bringing a wave of nostalgia. She was so used to plants being free and growing wild rather than seeing them confined in pots and not having the room to grow properly. By seeing all this, it got Saeng to break down and cry, overwhelmed by the cultural differences. In conclusion, I feel as though the author added the paragraph in the end for clarity and understanding and to also let you know that Saeng may be in a new place with a new culture but she will never give up on that test until she feels that she has passed it and proven herself.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” purposely included that last paragraph. Honestly, the story is better with it too, as it provides a necessary resolution. In the last paragraph when it says, “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it ties the narrative together. When the author writes all those things in nature that will happen, it symbolized re-birth and a fresh start, a new chance, and that is precisely what Saeng needs with her driver's license and her new life. The author put these powerful symbols in there to show hope for the girl to make it through her tough time and to look forward to the future. Finally, the story gains a sense of roundness and concludes with a feeling of wholeness with that last paragraph; with it, the story is complete and satisfying.

The reason I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph was because it was a good learning story from which you can learn something valuable. The author included that final part so you can get a better understanding of the story's context and its deeper meaning. It is stated that “Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam.” So from reading that, it tells me that its purpose is to clarify what happened right before the main story took place, providing essential background. This allows you, the reader, to get a better understanding of Saeng's situation and her journey. To me, it is wrapping it all up for you neatly, summarizing the central conflict of adaptation. That is why I think the author concludes the story with this particular paragraph.

I believe the author of "Winter Hibiscus" ends the story like she did because Saeng agrees to take the test again, a decision she makes after her initial failure. She wants to take the test when the snow melts, the geese return and the hibiscus is budding. In other words when spring has come she will be ready for the test, using the changing seasons as a timeline for her own personal renewal. Saeng states in the story “it’s the flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, the winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” I think Saeng is using this as a guiding light since she just moved from Vietnam, seeing the plant's resilience as a model for her own life. She plans to make it and use the plant as a symbol of her own strength and determination. She will try again for her drivers license at the start of spring, embodying the same perseverance as the hardy hibiscus.

The author used "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because its resembling that her mother is refreshing, waking, and restoring its self, much like the natural world awakens in spring. And Saeng said she would retake the driving test when that happens, linking her personal goal to this cycle of renewal. She was really sad she failed, a feeling clearly shown when she said, “I – I failed the test.” She seemed to be embarrassed and sad, emotions that made her initial setback feel more profound. So that last paragraph does a good job describing what Saeng is going to do, outlining her plan for the future. She is going to look on the bright side of things and restore her self to come back and pass the test, finding inspiration in the promise of spring.

I think the narrator included this paragraph in the story because the hibiscus is a valuable plant, and a garden is your own decision, a personal space where you choose to grow things, like her mother chose to grow hot peppers. A garden is a way to celebrate difference, showcasing the different types of foods you can plant and the vast variety of plants in the world, such as roses, lilies, and other plants like that. This diversity in the garden reflects the broader theme of adaptation and the blending of old and new, just as Saeng is learning to blend her past life with her new one. The garden becomes a metaphor for cultivating one's identity in a new environment, a place where different things can grow together. It represents the personal choices that define a home and a life.

The author ends the story with that paragraph because she is trying to overcome an obstacle, a challenge that is central to her experience. Failing the driver’s test was a set back for Saeng so she plans to take it again, demonstrating her resolve not to be defeated. She plans to use the hibiscus as motivation, drawing a direct parallel between the plant's struggle and her own. The winter for the hibiscus is like overcoming an obstacle, a difficult period that it must endure before it can bloom again. This connection gives Saeng the strength to face her own challenges, seeing her failure not as an end but as a season to be weathered. Her decision to try again is therefore framed by the plant's example, showing that perseverance leads to renewal.

Why I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because I think it’s showing how much it actually means to her and shows that she does actually care about succeeding and building a new life. Her emotional investment is clear from her reaction to the failure, which makes her subsequent vow more powerful. And by showing that she cares, her decision to take the test again carries greater weight, revealing her inner determination. This final resolution provides a sense of hope and forward momentum for her character after a moment of disappointment. It completes her emotional arc from sadness to a committed resolve, solidifying the story's message about resilience. The paragraph effectively underscores her personal commitment to try again.

She ends the story with that paragraph because she wants to let everyone know she feels most comfortable in the spring, a season that brings her a sense of peace and renewal. It also states that she can not wait for the geese and the hibiscus to start budding because it is her favorite time of the year, a period filled with hopeful anticipation for the beauty and life that returns. This final reflection solidifies her deep connection to this season, marking it as a time of personal comfort and joy. The paragraph serves as a gentle conclusion, emphasizing the cyclical nature of her contentment that arrives each spring.

Saeng is not comfortable in her surroundings, and has not adapted to the changes from where she moved, feeling out of place and disconnected. She finds the hibiscus and chooses to go buy it, because it reminds her of her home, offering a tangible link to her past. When she brings it home her mother seems shocked at first by the price Saeng had paid, but is then more sympathetic when she realizes she misses their homeland, understanding the emotional value behind the purchase. Saeng says she is going to retake her test in the spring, signaling a new beginning. She is also implying that she is going to change her attitude about living in her new home, deciding to face the future with more optimism and resilience.

I think the author concludes the story in that way because he is saying when the geese are coming back, it signifies a time of return and new beginnings. This natural event parallels the character's own journey, suggesting a period of hope is on the horizon. The focus on the geese’s return provides a symbolic and uplifting end to the narrative. It leaves the reader with a feeling of anticipation for the positive changes that spring will bring, effectively wrapping up the story's theme.

The author concludes that because she wants to show that Saeng was not giving up, demonstrating resilience in the face of adversity. I say this because she moved to a place where she didn’t like and knew no one, which presented significant challenges. The author is trying to tell us no matter what don’t give up, have faith in yourself and the future. At the end Saeng has faith in herself that she can pass the test next time, showing her renewed determination. She may have realized that just because you are at a place you don’t want to be, it does not mean you can’t go on and find a way to succeed and grow. This realization marks a crucial step in her personal development and acceptance of her new circumstances.

The author concludes the story like that to give the reader the idea that you can't just quit if you fail; you must persevere. When Saeng said that when spring comes around she will return and take the test again, that shows that she will not quit and that life will go on, offering new opportunities. Her declaration underscores a commitment to trying again despite previous setbacks. That’s why I think the author chose to conclude the story like that, to emphasize a message of hope and continuous effort. The ending reinforces the theme that perseverance is key to overcoming life's obstacles.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that she does not want to give up on fighting her homesickness. The first time she bought that plant, it brought back memories of her old home and it showed how much she missed it there. By saying she'll do the test again shows that she doesn't want to let this defeat her in her new home and her new life. This decision represents her commitment to persevere and find a way to thrive despite the deep feelings of longing and displacement she experiences. It is a quiet but firm declaration of her resilience, ensuring the story ends on a note of determined hope rather than sorrow.

The author concludes with Saeng's vow in the story to show that Saeng can and does have the ability to overcome obstacles. Saeng feels like she is a failure after her experiences. Her hibiscus represents the courage needed to overcome her obstacle, which is her driving test that she failed. The geese represent survival and the idea to never give up, to keep trying your hardest to succeed. These symbols work together to illustrate her internal journey from despair to a renewed resolve. The ending thus powerfully conveys that Saeng is gathering the strength to continue forward, learning from her setbacks.

The author concludes the story with this because the girl in the story is almost like the flower itself. Just as the flower will blossom, Saeng will take the test again, both receiving a fresh start on things. Finishing the story this way left the reader feeling positive; it was a short ending but one with a lot of meaning. “...and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think the last sentence is almost inspirational and it makes you want to start out fresh as well as Saeng. This parallel between human and plant growth creates a universal message about patience and the promise of new beginnings, beautifully tying the narrative together.

The author ends the story with “When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” for many good reasons. Some reasons are, that she will keep moving on and adapting to her new life in Canada. She is going to change her way of life and try to fit in with her new culture. She is also going to have to relive the memory of her grandmother again and wants to handle it better. “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eye now swept over her.” She wants to be able to handle the loss better. The author wants to emphasize that the story is not yet over, and this final vow signals a future of continued effort and personal growth for the protagonist.

There are many reasons the narrator could have ended with this paragraph. One reason is that it's the start of the winter so the hibiscus won't return until spring. Also, it’s the end of the story so it’s a good way to conclude because it’s the ending of the hibiscus's cycle and the ending of the narrative. The last paragraph also kind of summarizes the story and it’s short and sweet, which makes it a great ending. It’s not like most endings to a story so it’s unique, particularly because most stories aren’t so deeply connected to nature. In conclusion, there are many reasons the narrator could have chosen to end the story with this paragraph, and its symbolic resonance provides a fitting and memorable closure.

The author concludes the story with his paragraph to show how people can regain their determination. In the beginning of the story, Saeng is disheartened after failing her driving test and feels a sense of hopelessness. When she sees the Hibiscus, she is filled with memories of the past and weeps, overwhelmed by nostalgia for her old home. Her mother's kindness and quiet strength cause Saeng to draw strength from the flower, which, as her mother says, is "strong enough to make it through the cold months here." This observation gives Saeng a new perspective. Confident that the Hibiscus will bud in the spring, Saeng renews her determination to pass the test, seeing it as a challenge she can overcome with patience and resilience.

The author ends with this response because he is trying to say that Saeng will repeat her efforts but this time be more helpful in the garden and to her mother. She will try harder with her school work and focus less exclusively on gardening, finding a better balance between her responsibilities. This shift in focus indicates her growing maturity and understanding that success requires dedication in multiple areas of life. She realizes that supporting her family and applying herself academically are just as important as her personal interests, leading to a more rounded and determined approach to her future endeavors.

Saeng's personality in this story shows determination and confidence. I think she feels that she could do more experienced things with different plants, expanding her knowledge beyond the hibiscus. I also think this is a perfect hobby experience for someone who loves plants, providing both solace and purpose. I feel that Saeng must have accomplished her goals of planting, seeing the first signs of growth. I think she might want to pursue her career in gardening, turning her passion into a profession. When she stated that when the plants come back around, she would take the test again, I think she means that she is willing to explore more plants and new beginnings. I think she must have got this experience of planting from her mother, learning the techniques and the patience it requires. To me this might have been a family tradition, passed down through generations. Saeng will probably have kids and teach them about different types of flowers, thereby continuing the family's horticultural legacy and sharing the same strength she found.

The author ended the story with the paragraph in order to show that Saeng is looking forward into her life and with a positive outlook. It shows that she is not going to be depressed by the change in her life anymore, having moved through her initial sadness. The hibiscus is used as a device for this story’s plot, mirroring Saeng's emotional state. When changes happen with the hibiscus, changes happen in the story. At first, Saeng is without the hibiscus and feels hopeless, adrift in her new environment. When she sees it, she remembers her past and is sad, confronted by what she has lost. Once she plants it, things start to look up and she begins to put down new roots. She begins to accept the change when the last paragraph says, “when they come back... and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” it shows that Saeng is looking at her future positively, and with this positive change, the hibiscus is now beginning to bloom. The author concludes the story in a symbolic way that helps express the story’s themes of resilience and new beginnings, tying Saeng's personal growth to the natural world.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph “Saeng vowed silently to herself” because Saeng wants to act in the proper time and season, understanding that timing is crucial for success. The “winter season” is described as a time when the land or soil was so cold that plants were not able to grow properly, symbolizing a period of hardship and stagnation. The detail that the “Hibiscus costs nineteen dollars” coincides with Saeng failing the test, linking financial value and personal failure. The observation that “There was a frail, wiry beauty to her Saeng's mother that touched Saeng deeply” shows that her mother is shining when she worked with plants, embodying a quiet dignity and strength. These are all descriptions that conclude reflections on the past which make Saeng want to make a correction, to shine like her mother in her perseverance, and also to pass the test, integrating these lessons into her own resolve for the future.

At the end of the short story "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng says, "when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again." When she says this, she is referring to her driver's test. She resolves to take the test again because she is reminded that her family didn't give up; they moved to a new country for a fresh start. The plant, a hibiscus she had forgotten, drew her back to her childhood world. She sees these flowers after failing her test, which reminds her that she has never given up before on other challenges in her life. So she will not give up now, finding strength in the resilience symbolized by the winter hibiscus.

The author is trying to convey a sense of hope for Saeng in her new country. After noting that she failed her test, which is likely a significant exam such as a citizenship or driver's test, the author wants to conclude the story with something that reassures the reader. It is obvious that this test was important to Saeng because her failure was so profound she could not even look her mother in the eye. This feeling of shame was probably part of the reason she bought the flower for her mother, as a gesture of apology and connection. The ending ultimately reassures the reader so that you do not wonder how it will work out for Saeng, providing a clear sense of her renewed determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to tell us that Saeng will try and find that specific flower to bring back memories of her old home. It shows us that the flowers, and by extension her spirit, will be coming back again; they will survive even though the hibiscus is not from the homeland she remembered. In the story, Saeng says, "I failed the test," and she had initially bought a hibiscus that wasn't real or what she thought it was, not the flower she truly wanted. In the last paragraph, she says she will take that test again, which is connected to her hope of finding a winter hibiscus that is how it used to be in her homeland. She is hoping the plants survive the winter and that she finds a flower like the one from her past, because her vow, "in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," means she hopes and prays she will find one that truly connects her to her old homeland.

The author chose to end the story with this particular paragraph to provide a concise and resonant conclusion. This final segment serves to encapsulate Saeng's emotional journey and her moment of decision, tying together the themes of memory and resilience without unnecessary elaboration. It effectively brings her arc to a close by showing her internal vow to try again, thus offering a complete and focused ending to the narrative.

When spring comes and all the snow melts, Saeng is going to plant new seeds, both literally and metaphorically. The author concludes with this because she didn't do well on the test the first time, and this new beginning is her path forward. In the coming year, she is going to work with her plants and nurture them, and then she will take the test again so she can pass it. The author included this in the conclusion because he does not want people to think that she just worries about the plants; instead, it shows that her gardening is intertwined with her personal growth and determination to succeed in her new life.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the narrative centers on a girl named Saeng and her mother and grandmother, for whom flowers hold a deep and beautiful significance. They spend their days planting them, picking them, and carefully preserving them. The emotional weight is captured in the moment when, after a difficult experience, Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye, a gesture filled with shame and disappointment. This simple act underscores the complex feelings and the quiet strength that flows within their family, connected through their shared love for the natural beauty of their garden.
