The author concludes the story with the saying because it effectively shows that Saeng has found confidence in herself. Even though she did not pass the test, she realized she could take it again and knew she could ultimately pass. She was initially very upset about the failure, but her mother, when she talked to her, made her feel good and confident enough to retake the test. This newfound self-assurance is the key reason why the author chooses to conclude the narrative with that particular saying, as it perfectly encapsulates Saeng's emotional journey and resolution.

This paragraph signifies that when winter is finally over and the geese return from the south, and when her favorite plant, the one that used to grow in her old country, blossoms once more, she will try again what she had attempted before. This time, however, she will approach the challenge with significantly more confidence and inner strength. The imagery of the returning geese and the resilient plant serves as a powerful metaphor for her own personal renewal and determination, which is the core meaning I believe this passage conveys.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it sums everything up and resolves the central conflict of her failing the driver's test. When Saeng declared, "I will take that test again," it powerfully showed her determination to pass and her willingness to try once more. Since the primary conflict is solved at this point, introducing a new one would be unnecessary, so the author wisely chooses to end the narrative. This excerpt from the final paragraph also cleverly incorporates Saeng's connection to the geese, drawing a parallel between their migratory hardships and her own difficulty obtaining her driver's license, but also highlighting that, like the geese, she will return to face her challenges again with renewed spirit.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author ends the story in a well-mannered and coherent fashion. The author ended with that specific paragraph to show that Saeng was not going to give up, even though she is far from her original home. She is in a downward spiral at the beginning of the story, having failed a test and with the hibiscus triggering feelings of deep nostalgia. When she arrived home, her mother greeted her with kind words and acted as a comfort by making her food with familiar peppers and bitter melons. This maternal care essentially made Saeng see the good in her new life, causing her not to give up and instead be confident that she would pass the test on her next attempt.

In the story, Saeng fails her driving test. Disheartened, she walks home and spots a familiar plant, which she later identifies as a hibiscus at a florist's shop. She buys the plant with the little money she has because it powerfully reminds her of her homeland and childhood. It also evokes memories of her grandmother, whom she had to leave behind, creating a deep, emotional connection to the plant. Later, she sees geese flying overhead, heading south for the winter, and she thinks, “When they come back,” meaning when the geese fly north for the spring. She also thinks of “the snow melting,” signaling the arrival of warmer spring weather, and “this hibiscus is budding,” when the plant begins to bloom anew. It is at that time she vows she will “take that test again,” referring to the driving test she failed. She gives herself the entire winter to practice and prepare thoroughly. She makes a firm vow to herself that come spring, she will be ready to take the test and, this time, she will pass.

She said this to show the determination it takes to succeed, emphasizing that no matter how many times you fail, you need to get back up and try again. She displays her courage in this way, as it takes a great deal of strength for someone to fail and then resolve to try again. She is not willing to accept failure as a final outcome, and she is trying to redeem her earlier setback by committing to another attempt. Her statement is a testament to her resilience and unwavering spirit. That is why she ended the story in that particular way, highlighting her resolve.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to provide a clear sense of what the protagonist will do next. I think the author did this so that readers will know what Saeng is going to do when spring arrives, and they might imagine another story continuing from this point. This ending gives a sense of forward-looking hope and purpose. It ensures that you, as the reader, understand her plan to take the test again in the spring, providing a satisfying and anticipatory conclusion to her current struggles.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes with that paragraph because when winter arrives, the plant she loves will become dormant, and the flower, which had given her a sense of luck and comfort, will be gone. She said, “when the snow melts in the spring and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The flower was very important to her, serving as a tangible link to her past. She noted its “rich, sweet scent that was familiar too,” and she was talking about how the flower's fragrance compared to her grandmother’s shell, as it was the same comforting aroma, connecting her present to her cherished memories.

The author concludes the story like this to illustrate the character's resilience and her plan for the future. She is not giving up; instead, she is going to come back and attempt the same thing again next year. This ending underscores a cycle of determination and hope, showing that she will use the intervening time to improve her skills. It highlights her commitment to trying again despite her initial failure, providing a purposeful and forward-looking end to the narrative.

The author concludes the story with that because she wants to retake the test, driven by a desire to pass it for her mother. To express her remorse and the depth of her apology for failing initially, she brought home the flower as a tangible symbol of her regret and her renewed commitment. This act of bringing the flower home serves as a bridge to mend the emotional distance and to show her mother that she is determined to succeed, ultimately concluding her emotional journey with a gesture of reconciliation and a clear, purposeful goal.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because everything in the story will repeat, such as the inevitable season changes, and you will not be able to plant nor grow in the winter. For example, she talked about how the plants are nothing like her home, but she has to adapt to the fact she’s not home and adjust to her new environment. This adaptation is necessary because if she doesn't, she will just be an unhappy person constantly worrying about where she came from, unable to move forward. The conclusion reinforces the theme of accepting cyclical change as a part of life and finding a way to thrive within it, rather than remaining stuck in the past.

The author concludes the response by saying that when spring comes and the hibiscus is budding, she will take the test again because she feels a renewed sense of hope and faith. This feeling emerges because the girl just moved away from her home and feels horribly lonesome and depressed, as she deeply wants to go back. She is nostalgic for her past, and when she sees the plant, it gives her a profound sense of comfort, almost as if she is home again. When she says, “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it is clear she is upset about failing her test, but the plant provides a comforting connection that gives her the faith and hope needed to try again with a positive outlook.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself that in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take that test again. This silent vow represents a personal promise of renewal and determination, aligning her personal goal with the natural cycle of rebirth and growth that spring symbolizes. It is a moment of quiet resolution where she commits to facing her challenge again with the coming of a new season, thus concluding her internal struggle with a forward-looking and hopeful decision.

In “The Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author chooses the last paragraph because it perfectly matched the tone, the hope, and the representation of the entire essay. The tone of the story is more of a depressive mood because she failed the driver's test, leaving her very upset. Her memories of her old country start to overwhelm her when she sees the winter hibiscus, as shown when, “And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” She misses Vietnam very much, and seeing this plant in the store gives her powerful flashbacks. The winter season begins to make her feel all hope is lost, yet she realizes, “almost reluctantly, that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” To her, the strange things are starting to feel the same year by year, with no new hope, just the same routine day by day. This plant truly begins to tear her apart purely from its representation of her homeland. “She found that she was still too shaky to say the word at home, lest she burst into tears again.” She can’t say home because her true home isn’t in the United States but in Vietnam. This winter hibiscus gives Saeng an explosion of immense emotions all having to deal with her past, so the last paragraph gives a sense of how when her hope returns in the spring, she will simply try again. The elements of tone, hope, and representation all support the last paragraph, which is why it fits so well as the story's conclusion.

This was a very interesting story and it showed all the hardships this young girl has gone through, the author ended it in a very interesting way. When they ended the story I thought to myself how nice it ended. I think the author did a very nice job. She made it so that she showed all the hard ships that Saeng had gone through, as if they were the harsh winter. Then as the author said, “as the snow melts away…”, I think this shows how even though Saeng's problems seem never ending and harsh, that one day they will be gone and things will become beautiful again, like the flower budding in the spring time. Also she did a nice job because throughout the story I could feel her pain. I felt as if I was there with her because of her use of descriptive words like, “exploding, shock, intense” and others to describe how much of a sudden change everything was. Then when she ended it, it was like she was showing us Saeng’s hope for a better future, even though things aren’t the way they were back home, she is finding new strength and beauty in her new life.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph -“ when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” because she feels that when the hibiscus blooms she can too bloom by passing the test. Also Saeng is relating herself to the hibiscus. “Its flower aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through in here, this winter hibiscus.” Her mother is trying to tell her she can be strong also. She too can make it through the cold months of hardship and disappointment. “like the geese she lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.” Just like the geese Saeng is realizing to be proud of herself and that there will be other chances. Don’t always doubt yourself because they will be other chances. Don’t be afraid to try again, as the seasons change so do our opportunities for success and growth.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she means she will go back after winter to take care of it. The author puts this at the ending paragraph because he is telling how much she cares about this plant; she takes care of it because it reminds her of her hometown and the life she left behind. So that is the reason she takes such good care of it so she will have something with her to remind her of her home, a tangible piece of her past that provides comfort and continuity in her new environment. The plant symbolizes her enduring connection to her roots, and her commitment to nurturing it reflects her own resilience and ability to thrive in a new place, just as the plant does.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph about the geese because it shows how Saeng, like the geese, will adapt to her new environment. It shows that she will do what needs to be done in order to survive just like the geese have to do. She will take the test again and will not give up. The paragraph shows how she wants to adapt to the new country. For example, the narration states, “… she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes”. This example shows how Saeng is not used to being in the new country and that she does not like it. However, she will get used to it and do her best to do so, as shown in the closing paragraph. Also, the narration states, “…she admitted to herself, she much preferred it to a Big Mac”. This proves how even though she may not like things at times, Saeng is willing to try them to get used to the new country. The narration states, “…she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become familiar to her now”. Saeng is getting more and more used to her surrounding and is adapting to them, just like the geese adapt, which is the reason the author ended the story with the paragraph about geese, highlighting her journey towards acceptance and resilience.

The reason why the author wrote the conclusion paragraph was to show that Saeng is looking forward to a brighter future. Saeng is hoping to see the geese once more that remind her of her homeland and that she wants to pass the driving test, symbolizing her desire to move forward and gain independence. In this story I feel as though Saeng is a very sentimental person and so that is why I think that is reason the author wrote the conclusion paragraph. It captures her reflective nature and her ability to find hope and symbolic meaning in the natural world around her, using the promise of spring and the return of the geese as metaphors for her own personal renewal and determination to succeed in her new life.

The author concludes this paragraph in the story because it sounds good and serves to show the people he is writing it to that no matter what happens to you in life, you should just keep on doing what you think is best for you. Just like the flower, which keeps coming back for more after going through all that is tough, the message is one of quiet resilience and personal conviction, encouraging the reader to persist in their chosen path despite adversity. This concluding thought reinforces the central theme of enduring strength found in nature and within oneself.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for a specific reason. The hibiscus, a vivid reminder of her past life in Vietnam, and the geese, which symbolize her present home, are the two things that make her feel strong. Therefore, she resolves that she will take the test when they return, believing that with the symbolic presence of the flower and the geese in her life, she possesses the inner fortitude needed to pass the test. This final decision highlights how her connection to both her heritage and her new life provides the necessary strength to face future challenges.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it effectively shows that Saeng is starting to take responsibility for her school work now. For example, in the story, it was made obvious that she previously cared more about the garden than school, but the final paragraph indicates a shift in her priorities. This conclusion marks a turning point where she begins to acknowledge the importance of her education, demonstrating her growing maturity and willingness to embrace her new responsibilities alongside her personal interests.

Saeng was talking about testing the plants to see if the geese approved of where she had planted them. I know this because she mentioned the geese in the last paragraph, and in the story, the geese seemed to say “yes” when she finally planted the hibiscus in a spot they found suitable. This interaction with the geese served as a form of confirmation for her gardening efforts, indicating that she had found the right place for the plant that held such deep personal significance for her.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the narrative was mostly talking about the hibiscus and its profound meaning. Saeng was saying that when it is spring and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take the test again, using its cyclical rebirth as a personal benchmark for her own renewal. The hibiscus strongly reminded her of her homeland in the past, and its anticipated blooming represents her hope for the future and her readiness to face challenges with a renewed spirit, thus providing a fitting and symbolic end to her story.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because at the end it is talking of a new beginning. The paragraph signifies a turning point for the character, moving past her failure. Also, what it’s going to be at the new beginning she says that she is going to take the test again, showing her determination to try once more with a fresh perspective and renewed hope for success.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she has a better state of mind, which is largely because she found a flower that reminds her of her homeland. She is afraid that her parents are going to be mad at her for not passing the test, therefore she buys a flower that she sees for it reminds her of home and provides comfort. When she gets home and is telling her mom how much she paid for the flower and how she didn’t pass, her mother is upset for only a second, then she is understanding of what her daughter is going through, offering support instead of anger. By the end of the story she has more confidence that she will succeed next time, feeling empowered by her mother's compassion and her own symbolic purchase.

The author ended the story with a phrase of dialogue because it was about the main topic of the story, which is Saeng's journey and resolve. Saeng was to buy a plant and bring it home, but when she did so, her mother did not initially approve. The narrative states "You what?" Her mother stared at her incredulously. When her mother said this, it showed that she was displeased with the expense. The narrative states, "I-I failed the test." Saeng was not proud to displease her parents in any way, feeling the weight of her failure. By saying, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," the author is just showing Saeng's love and want to grow for her parents; it shows her newfound maturity and commitment to improving herself.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to tell the reader that Saeng is going to take the test again, emphasizing her resilience. The author wants to tell the reader that because she failed the test she now knows what she did wrong and she’s going to correct her mistakes for the future attempt. For example, when Saeng said, “then I will take that test again,” it reveals her inner resolve. Saeng feels sorry she failed a simple test so she wants to retake the test when the snow melts, using the changing season as a metaphor for her own personal renewal and second chance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the plant wasn't budding and the geese are going away, and then she failed the test because all of that made her sad, creating a low point for her. But when the snow melts, the geese return and the plant starts budding she will be happy again, as these natural cycles symbolize hope and new beginnings. She will take the test again and she will pass because she is happy and in a more positive state of mind, with the renewed environment reflecting her internal confidence and readiness to succeed.

The author concludes the story this way for many reasons, primarily to illustrate Saeng's resilient character. One reason is to show Saeng is not going to give up and keep trying to pass her test, demonstrating her persistent spirit. Another way is to show that even though your life has changed that don't mean that you have to give up on your goals and aspirations. The ending serves as a powerful reminder of this enduring theme. These are some of the way that the author concludes the story like he does to leave the reader with a sense of hope and determination.

I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph because they wanted to show that she is comited to her nature especially to The hibiscus, which serves as a profound symbol for her. She thought that the hibiscus was special because of what she did with it and the personal connection she felt. Like when they said “she reached out and touched petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velet toward the centre,” this sensory detail underscores the depth of her bond with the plant. This final moment solidifies the hibiscus as a central motif of her identity and resolve. And that’s why I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph, to emphasize this significant connection.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because Saeng feels like that will be the right time to take over her driving test over and when the hibiscus is budding, linking her personal triumph to a natural cycle. And another reason would be because the authors wants to show her determination, portraying her resolve to try again when conditions feel more favorable. The budding flower symbolizes a new beginning, mirroring her own readiness to face the challenge anew. This parallel reinforces the story's message about patience and perseverance.

She vowed this paragraph because she wanted to make her mother proud by passing the test after she had failed it, but she waits for the plant to go through and start budding, seeing it as a sign. The hibiscus buddy is like a new start so it makes it through winter and it will pass the test and then Saeng will be able to pass as well because she knows a tropick plant was able to survive a harsh winter then she can survive / pass the test the next spring. This connection gives her the confidence and hope needed to persevere. Her vow is therefore tied to this symbolic natural event, which promises renewal and success.

Why I think the auther concludes the last paragraph in the story because it's kind of like a moral to the story, providing a clear takeaway for the reader. Shes trying to say that when the time is right she will try it again untill she gets it right, emphasizing persistence and perfect timing. Without this last paragraph you wouldn't be able to understand the message of the story, as it crystallizes the central theme of resilience. It serves as the story's final, crucial point, ensuring the reader grasps the lesson of not giving up.

Saeng is a very helpful young lady to her mom, and she makes things around the house to assist her. The author made that the ending sentence to make the story more interesting for the reader and to keep them hooked to the very end, ensuring they remain engaged with the narrative's conclusion.

The author concludes the story with that sentence because she wanted to explain to you that she will do this again when the hibiscus is back in season. This choice creates a sense of anticipation and a natural cycle, suggesting that the character's actions are tied to the rhythms of nature and will be repeated in the future.

I guess she says this because she only wants to take the test when she is comfortable around the flowers, plants, and greens. This environment provides her with a sense of peace and confidence that she feels is necessary to perform well, indicating that her readiness is deeply connected to her natural surroundings.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it says "when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take the test again," which means that when she gets older and gains more confidence, she will blossom and get to take the test when she is ready. Just like the hibiscus will be ready to start budding again, her personal growth is mirrored by the natural world, showing that her development follows a similar, inevitable cycle.

The author ends the story off with that paragraph because when dealing with flowers and nature, there are seasons when the flowers don’t come up, like winter for example. The paragraph is saying that in the spring, when the winter is over, she tells herself that she will look forward to seeing all the plants that nature has to give. This reflects a theme of hope and renewal, where the end of a barren period promises a new beginning filled with natural beauty and opportunity.

I believe he used this as the ending to ensure that she was strong and she would do whatever it took to persevere, demonstrating her resilience and inner fortitude in the face of challenges. This choice highlights her character's development and ultimate resolve, showing that she would not be broken by her circumstances. The conclusion solidifies her transformation into a determined individual, ready to face future hardships with courage and strength, thus completing her character arc on a note of empowerment and unwavering will.

The author includes this sentence in the paragraph because it’s the start of a new beginning, marking a pivotal transition for the character. This moment signifies a shift in perspective and the opening of a fresh chapter in the narrative. It serves to introduce a change in direction or a renewed sense of purpose for the protagonist. By placing this sentence here, the author effectively signals a departure from the past and the commencement of a new journey, thereby framing the subsequent events around this idea of renewal and hopeful commencement.

In the story the author concludes with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think she did that to say that you shouldn’t give up. In the story Saeng goes to the store and “touched a petal.” She buys the plant in an attempt to get a reminder of her old home, seeking a tangible connection to her past life. In this way it seems Saeng is willing to give up her memories of her past, but the act of planting suggests otherwise. When she brings home the plant and her mom and her plant it in the garden, it becomes a part of their new landscape. I think Saeng is trying to make her new home like her old, integrating memories into her present to create a sense of belonging and continuity in her new environment.

The author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with Saeng vowing to take the test in the spring when the geese return, the snow melts, and the hibiscus is budding. This is done to symbolize the many things that Saeng learnt throughout her journey of adaptation. For example, she learnt she has to adjust to changes in her life and becoming familiar to the new things, a process of gradual acceptance. The geese and snow she admits are the things that were “strange before [and] had become familiar to her now,” showing her growing comfort. The hibiscus also represents something and has a reason for being included in the last paragraph, as it symbolizes hope and new growth. It represents the ability to overcome obstacles, connection to the past, and comfort when needed, serving as a multi-faceted symbol. The last paragraph symbolizes many things, and if you look into it deeply, you will learn what Saeng learnt about resilience and the cyclical nature of life and opportunity.

The author ends the story with Saeng vowing to herself the relationship between passing and driving test and the significance of the hibiscus flower. The flower is linked to the way things used to be for her in Vietnam, serving as a direct bridge to her heritage. For example, hibiscus in her new country was “Madagascar periwinkle” in Vietnam, highlighting the differences in her old and new life. It also symbolizes how the flower adapts to its surrounding when taken from a different country in accordance to Saeng adjusting to life in her new home, mirroring her own journey. The reason she said when spring comes she will take the test again symbolizes that connection of the flower to the way she lives now, tying her personal growth to natural cycles. For instance, her ability and determination that when that flower buds she will overcome obstacles, using it as a personal benchmark. Another is a connection of her past experiences, which ground her and give her strength. And it was a sense of comforting to her after she failed her driving test, providing emotional solace. The author linked the flower’s significance to the ending of the story showing the hope and dedication to Saeng and the obstacles she passes to get where she is today, ultimately portraying a message of perseverance and the enduring power of memory and hope.

The reason why I believe the author concluded the story like that is because she is going to always start over. For instance, in the story she said, "I failed the test." From that moment, it was known she thought she was going to give up, but the ending suggests the opposite. So that is why I believe the author ended the story with that line, to emphasize her resolve to begin again rather than surrender to her initial disappointment.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because the author is trying to say that Saeng is going to start all over again just like the hibiscus would. The hibiscus plant, which endures the winter to bloom again, serves as a direct parallel to Saeng's own journey. Even though you go through bad times in your life, the message is to just step up and do it over again until it becomes better. The author also concluded the story with that paragraph because the paragraph pretty much starts the story all over again, mirroring the cyclical process that Saeng was going to undertake in her own life.

She means that when she returns, she is going to do the same thing again and see if she will do better or not. This decision reflects a commitment to perseverance and self-improvement. It is not about avoiding the challenge but about facing it once more with renewed determination and hope for a different, more successful outcome the next time she attempts it.

Saeng vowed silently to herself "in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because her mind went off the track from thinking about a flower. She says "One of the blossoms had fallen off," then carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. It happened to distract her mind. Her mother's reaction from failing was silence for a long moment and she didn't say anything. She never got mad. All she did was brushing the fragments of green off Saeng's hands. Her mother was mainly thinking about the plants as the day went on, and Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the 'winter hibiscus' into it. Seeing her mother caused a reaction of ideas, so she tried to etch an image of geese. She sent a goal to retake the driving test again as she was getting used to her new life. The intro says "Saeng, a teenage girl and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam," though it never mentioned details about her family beyond this initial context.

The author included this paragraph to show how much the girl missed Vietnam. When the girl saw the hibiscus it brought back memories of Vietnam, connecting her present environment to her past home. Seeing the hibiscus allows her to find comfort and a sense of continuity amidst great change. So the paragraph is there to show how the United States is different from Vietnam, highlighting the contrast between her old life and her new one. Since the United States has changing seasons it allows the girl to get used to the United States through the natural cycles. The plant will always be there, but she has to look for the good that United States provides, learning to appreciate her new surroundings. The author states, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This quote shows how the girl was getting used to the United States, illustrating her gradual adaptation. How she will always remember Vietnam, and finds things in the United States that remind her of Vietnam, creating a bridge between her two worlds. In conclusion, the paragraph is used to show how much the girl missed Vietnam, but how she finds comfort and a new sense of belonging within the United States over time.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. One being that she is still uncomfortable about talking about her old home, as she “was still unable to say the words ‘at home’” so the snow melting, the geese returning, and the hibiscus budding secondarily remind her of her home. We know this because Saeng says, “Just as she known it would feel… Back home it just grow wild just out from the cracks in the brick walls or between tiled roofs.” So with this reminder of her home, she is given both comfort and confidence. The author therefore concluded with this paragraph because since the geese, hibiscus, and the snow melting remind her of her home, that is when she will take the test again, when she is feeling confident and strong, having drawn strength from these familiar symbols of renewal.

By adding this paragraph to the end of the story, it shows that a resolution was made and that the theme of overcoming obstacles is present in the narrative. When Saeng failed the test, she was miserable and heartbroken; however, after buying the hibiscus, she had found hope and motivation and decides, in the end, that she will take the test again, “in the spring, when the snow melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding.” This hope at the end of the story helps put the reader at ease when they wonder what might happen next, serving to help move the story to a fitting conclusion. This is why most endings are meaningful like this one. Readers are able to obtain the message of the story from paragraphs like this. In this case, the author’s message was to never give up and that people find motivation in simple things. It is important to know what an author is trying to tell the reader through such paragraphs, not only as a reader trying to understand the purpose of a story, but also as a writer trying to express their ideas clearly to an audience.

I think that the author uses this quote, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” because it symbolizes that spring brings new life and hope. She reflects, “But where was the home thought come? The hibiscus hedge? The way her gentle grandmother?” and recalls the “boat ride into the night and it was gone,” from Vietnam to a new land. One night she had so much hope, like an abundance, then the next she is in a foreign land that is nothing like her old home. The flowers bloom in the spring, bringing new life. There is a chance to move on, and there is hope. There is hope that spring will come, flowers will bloom, and birds will return. It is a chance to let go of the past. The ending quote was said to bring hope and light to her, and she sort of promises to herself that it will get better. Hope is what makes every obstacle easier to get over and everything more bearable, providing the strength to continue forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that the hibiscus is a symbol for Saeng. In the springtime the hibiscus grows and blooms, just like Saeng will grow and flourish. When Saeng first got to the new place she was small and puny, just like the plant appeared to be. The description of “Its leaves quavering in the wind” tells us that the plant was weak and puny. If the plant was strong, it would not be quivering so easily. The fact that Saeng broke down and bought the plant tells us she was not feeling strong at that moment. And at the end, the author uses that paragraph to tell the reader that the hibiscus will become strong in the spring, and so will Saeng, and that they can both overcome anything together.

These words basically say that he will be around again, just like the geese always come back with the changing of the seasons. This cyclical return is a promise of continuity and presence, mirroring the natural, reliable patterns of the world. The certainty of the geese's migration provides a comforting assurance that his absence is only temporary. Therefore, the statement serves as a metaphor for his eventual and inevitable return, offering solace in its predictability and the enduring rhythm of nature that it evokes.

The author concludes the story this way to show Saeng does not give up and is determined to pass the test. The narration says, “Not like the kind we had back home,” highlighting the difference between the new hibiscus and the one from her memories. Saeng feels very strongly about her old home and wants hibiscus just like her and her grandmother used to have. Because Saeng would not bring back the same kind of hibiscus, she is sad and determined to get another one. The text also states, “and the hibiscus is budding then I will take the test again.” This also shows she is determined because even though she failed the test once she is going to try again. She misses her home and wants hibiscus just like she had at her old home, and this desire fuels her resolve to succeed.

In this story the reason that the author concludes things this way is to pick a tone that feels comfortable to test again. The person who will take the test again may have picked the tone with relation to her past, which she takes the time to prepare herself, and maybe that is something her parents or grandparents taught her about perseverance. The ending establishes a mood of quiet reflection and inner strength, suggesting that Saeng is drawing on her heritage and memories to find the courage she needs. This connection to her family's teachings provides her with the comfort and stability required to face the challenge once more.

The author concluded this because she thinks this is the right time to retake the test. She adds this because the snow is melted, the hibiscus is budding, and the geese return is a perfect time because everything is back and warm, symbolizing a season of renewal. She says "when they come back...then I will take the test again," which means she will have all confidence to take the test. Saeng vowed to take it again and she will, and she thinks this time she will pass because the conditions feel right and hopeful. That's what the author concludes this to the story, emphasizing a new beginning aligned with the natural world.

The Author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the hope and the meaning of the hibiscus to Saeng. The author also ends the story like that because spring is a time for new beginnings and where everything comes back to life and starts to regrow, so to say that when the snow melts and geese return, it is the right time for a second chance. "I failed the test," Saeng said..... "She tore off a leaf, shredded it to pieces." That shows the dying of the hope she had or the hibiscus symbolized it, representing her initial despair. So that’s why the author ended it like that because it shows new beginnings and the rekindling of her hope and determination.

The author concludes the story, “Winter Hibiscus”, with the strong paragraph of one sentence stating that Saeng will take the test when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding. This sentence leaves the reader in suspense while incorporating the main point of the story and combining them to express an idea about what might happen in a continuation on the future of Saeng and this story. After all, the reason Saeng had bought the hibiscus was to comfort her mother and herself, creating a tangible link to her past. While she stood watching the geese, the author chose this moment to express Saeng’s feelings to stay determined and take the test. In the end, the author concluded the story with a strong sentence which not only summarized the story's theme of resilience, but left a cliffhanger about Saeng's future efforts.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because this makes you think about the story after you are done reading it, leaving the reader with a sense of hopeful anticipation for Saeng's future and the cyclical renewal of nature. This final thought lingers, connecting her personal resolve to the changing seasons and the promise of new beginnings, effectively wrapping up her emotional journey without stating its outcome explicitly.

In many stories the narrator uses a dramatic yet conclusive statement to end the story. An example of one such occurrence is in the short story “Winter Hibiscus”. In the story the young girl finishes by telling us when she will be taking her test again, although not directly to us as it says “Saeng vowed silently to herself” but it still informs the reader. The reason the author includes this last “vow” is to inform not only the reader of the future but to show the girl's determination and spiritual connection with the plant. For example, when it says “and this hibiscus is budding” it's showing the girl's connection with the plant because of the comfort and confidence it has given her, especially since she needs to take the test. This connection symbolizes her link to her homeland and her own inner strength. In conclusion, the narrator concluded the story with the paragraph to show future events and to illustrate the spiritual connection the girl had with the flower and the homeland, emphasizing how this bond fuels her resolve.

In the story, at the end of the last paragraph the author wrote that “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” (last paragraph). The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants to mention that Saeng is a student and she had failed a test. Even though Saeng is so interested in flowers she also cares about her school too. When the snows melt Saeng will take the test just like the hibiscus is budding and starting to blossom, drawing a parallel between her personal growth and the natural world's cycle. This ending highlights her commitment to trying again, using the flower's renewal as a metaphor for her own second chance.

After they come, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. She says this sentence to herself, thinking back to her home. She thinks it feels familiar to what Saeng was. She is herself, noting how quiet it was, and so was every season. Her life is very quiet and lonely. She feels out of place. Due to failing her driving test, things for herself were difficult; her move to the United States was so different from Vietnam, and she expresses her feelings through the hibiscus flower, which serves as a tangible link to her past and a symbol of hope for her future in this new land.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wants to remind the reader and summarize the story. The way she wants to summarize is how the story started with Saeng failing the test to how the story ended with Saeng planting the hibiscus in the winter. The author wants to remind the reader about the whole story, from her initial disappointment to her final act of hope and connection to her heritage. This final paragraph serves as a poignant bookend, encapsulating her journey from failure to a quiet, determined resolve for the future, thus providing a cohesive and reflective ending to her narrative.

He concludes the story in this manner so you do not feel as if she was ultimately defeated. Instead, she is now more aware of her own capabilities and truly believes she can complete the task ahead of her. This moment also grants her more self-conscious belief in herself, a change symbolized by the flower, which now serves as a potent reminder of her home and the strength she draws from it. This connection to her past fortifies her resolve for the future, ensuring the story ends on a note of hopeful determination rather than defeat.

The author concluded the story with this parallel because, just like the flower that will come back anew, so will she. The flower serves as a direct representation of determination, using its natural cycle to show her own inner resolve. Even though she failed her driver's test, she still possesses the determination to take it again and strive to pass. Even with this failure, she is determined to get over it and move forward. This mirrors the flower losing its buds in the winter only to grow them back again with the changing season. In this way, Saeng is actively forgetting her failure and coming back anew, ready to face her challenges once more.

The author uses this paragraph as a powerful symbol of realization and a new beginning for Saeng. She had spent so much time missing the past that she did not know how to enjoy the present; thematically, the author is advocating to "live in the moment." The hibiscus itself represents strength, as her mother noted when she said, "It's strong enough to make it through the winter months,... that's what matters." Ultimately, the author is saying that tough times are inevitable, so one must hold on to the moments that bring joy, for they will provide the strength needed to persevere through the difficult periods that life presents. This lesson allows Saeng to look forward with renewed hope.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the character Saeng had many obstacles to overcome. At the end of the story, Saeng vows to herself that when winter is over, she will take the test again. The author likely ends the story this way to foreshadow a brighter future for Saeng, suggesting she will take time to adjust to her new lifestyle and focus on other things before attempting the test once more. It also clearly shows that Saeng has a lot of courage to complete what she has once failed. The perseverance evident in Saeng will undoubtedly help her overcome many challenges in her new country. This is further illustrated in the text when Saeng's mother begins to dig a hole and Saeng says, “Let me help, Mother,” demonstrating her love and her care for the plant that represents her past. Therefore, ending the story with this vow was an effective way to show Saeng’s commitment to her new life and her own growth.

The author includes that excerpt in the text to show the reader that Saeng had made a mistake and is resolved to fix it in the future. One reason for this interpretation is that in the text, Saeng began to cry when she admitted to her mother that she had failed the test. This emotional reaction shows that she was genuinely upset by her failure and sincerely hopes to improve in the near future. Another reason the author likely concludes the story this way is to lead the reader to believe that Saeng is going to get over being homesick and begin to embrace her new surroundings. This progression marks an important step in her personal journey of adaptation.

The author ends the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the passage “When they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She is saying how she is going to try to take the test again because of the fact that she failed the first time. I think the hibiscus she bought comforted her and made her think of her home land, reminding her of the resilience she learned there, so she thought when the hibiscus is budding she will take the test again. The plant made her think positivly, shifting her perspective. And insted of thinking she will fail she is thinking she will pass the next time, her hope renewed. I also think Saeng felt comforting her when she was upset and I think that helped her feel alot better, giving her the strength to face her challenges once more.

The author concludes this story, “Winter Hibiscus,” with that paragraph as a sign of reasurrance and a promise of renewal. Saeng had had a tough few years adapting to the United States from Vietnam, this paragraph leaves the reader with hope that she will overcome this challenge just like a bump in the road. Saeng had just had a rough day after just failing her driver’s test and wanted to buy the plant she saw on her walk home, seeking a connection to her past. While in the greenhouse she says, “That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother?” Saeng missed all these things from Vietnam, especially during this rough time, feeling their absence deeply. The final paragraph gives hope that she will take the test again and it will all be okay, symbolizing her personal growth. The winter is a symbol of the hardships she has and will continue to go through, a period of difficulty and waiting. It says,“…in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The winter is a hardship for the geese in that they must move away, the hibiscus must survive the cold winter, and the winter is time Saeng will be away from Vietnam, a season of separation. As the geese and the hibiscus overcome it, so will she, finding her own strength. This last paragraph is a good, positive and hopeful ending to this touching story, so the reader knows to have hope in life and its cyclical nature of hardship and renewal.

There is why the author ended the story with this paragraph. It mean that when she comes back after winter she will repeat her tasks all over, engaging in the cycle of her life. For example she will dig, sen flowers, their customers, resuming her daily duties. Then when winter comes again she will do it all over, continuing the pattern. So has steally the other is using different words to say when winter ends she will repeat her actions, emphasizing the seasonal rhythm. That is why the author ended the story with that paragraph, to highlight this recurring cycle of work and seasons.

The author brought out the paragraph "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again", to portray the theme of the story, which is resilience and hope. Saeng used the hibiscus for hope in her life, as a tangible symbol of her own potential for growth. The author also uses the choice of words or diction to explain the way Saeng lived her life depending on a flower, drawing strength from its natural cycle. The paragraph also explains the way her culture is depending on the theme of the story, showing how her heritage and its symbols provide a foundation for her new beginning and continued perseverance.

The author conconcludes the story with this paragraph because, the plant brings back memories to Saeng and she is sort of like the plant, both in a new and unfamiliar environment. Saeng can be compared to the plant by, she is starting out in a new area that she is unfamiliar with, as well as the plant, which must adjust to new soil. The plant is now being planted in the soil outside of her house and has to grow, facing the elements. Saeng has to learn to grow aswell and get better and prepare to take the test again, adapting to her new life. So when the plant is grown and adapted Saeng believes she will be grown and adapted too, ready to bloom. In conclusion, this paragraph is a perfect ending for the story “Winter Hibiscus by Minfong Ho, as it beautifully ties Saeng's personal journey to the symbolic life of the hibiscus.

I think that the author ends this story with that paragraph to sum up what the story was all about and to also say that Saeng would try the test again. In the story it says "she realised that many of the thing that she had thought of as strange before had become, though the quiet repetition of season upon reason, almost familiar to her now," and this last paragraph helps bring all this together by showing her resolve to continue adapting and trying again, thus concluding her arc of gradual adjustment.

A vow is a good ending, she vowed to take the test again because she failed it. It expresses how she feels and she made a commitment to pass. The author wanted to show a lot of feeling and how desperate she was to succeed despite her initial failure. So she saw tons of beauty in the world around her to keep her going and to fuel her determination for the next attempt.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, "When they come back," Saeng vowed silently to herself, "in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." She buys the flower because she failed the driver's test and needs a source of comfort. She has seen the familiar plant on her way home as she went to a florist shop to try to buy one. The flower makes her happy and reminds her of home, providing a sense of belonging. The author ends the story the way he does because it leaves hope, so that the story doesn't end sad, showing that she still has hope of passing the driver's test in the future.

She failed the test on the same day that she got the plant and saw the geese fly over. The plant and the geese represent symbols to her. The plant represents her home, where she used to live, and the geese could represent how they are moving on in life, overcoming the obstacles of cold weather, and snow to move on to something better, most likely a warmer climate. All of this is a symbol of a new beginning for her, a cycle of renewal. So she wanted to take it again, around the time of a new beginning; when the geese fly over again and the plant grows. She feels that since she failed, she should start over with the coming spring, aligning her personal restart with the natural world's cycle.

The author added the story in with this paragraph for a lot of reasons, one to make the story longer, and two to show that even if you screw up the first time you can still try again. This final thought reinforces the theme of perseverance, demonstrating that failure is not an endpoint but rather a chance to begin anew with renewed effort and hope for a different outcome.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author includes this paragraph, when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again, to emphasize that Saeng is willing to try planting again in spring. This vow connects her personal goal of passing the test directly to the natural cycle of rebirth and growth. Saeng wants to try planting again in the spring time to prove that she is trying to adapt to the new settings and to prove that she cares about the planting, seeing it as a parallel effort to her own attempts at establishing a new life.

Saeng meant that she will take that test next spring and pass it with the hope of her winter flower and the sight of her flock of geese. She has high hopes that she will pass her test, using the blooming of the hibiscus as a personal sign of the right time to try again. When she sees buds on her hibiscus then she will take the test again. Saeng was very upset when she failed it the first time and she was hoping she passed next spring, seeing this new attempt as a crucial step in overcoming her initial disappointment and moving forward.

In the short story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes with a paragraph explaining when the character, Saeng will take her driving test again. She says she will "when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding." I think the author concludes with this paragraph because it shows that saeng has new found hope. For example, since she has moved from Vietnam, she has been very homesick. "She found that she was still too shaky to say the words 'at home,' lest she burst into tears again." But when she finds a hibiscus plant, it reminds her of her homeland. "Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick walls or between tiled roofs." Saeng even buys the hibiscus to plant in her garden in her new home, a deliberate act to bridge her past and present. By having the hibiscus plant with her, it gave her memories of her old life and strength to continue with her new one. The plant gives her strength to try for her driving test again. By concluding with that paragraph, it shows Saeng's change in emotions from depressed to hopeful and it also shows the strength that the hibiscus plant gives her, symbolizing her resilience.

The author concludes the last paragraph of the story because she already knew that she should not be afraid of trying a new life or new environment. For example, in the story, the mother says, “It’s flowers aren’t pretty, but its strong enough to make it through the cold months, this winter hibiscus.” It shows that the mother wants saeng to learn that saeng should be strong even in times of difficult, using the hardy plant as a lesson in perseverance. Another example is, when the narrator says, “she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season…” It shows that saeng realized that the new place that she’s leaving right now is almost the same as their old home, finding familiar patterns in nature. In conclusion, the last paragraph tells that saeng should face the new reality of the world. She should be strong and follow the flow of life, accepting change as a natural and manageable process.

“In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” Saeng thinks to herself. This internal promise marks a pivotal moment of decision and hope for her future. Saeng finds herself in a new place were she has no friends, feeling isolated and out of place in her unfamiliar surroundings. She finds comfort in a plant shop one day when she comes upon a Hibiscus flower, which serves as a tangible connection to her past. The flower calms her spirit and helps her begin to adjust to the changes in her life at this time, providing the emotional stability she needs to face her challenges.

The author concluded with the paragraph about when winter turns to spring, she will take her driving test again for one main reason. The girl says this because just like the plant coming back to life and starting over, she will start over too. In the essay Saeng, the young girl says, “When they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” Saeng failed the test the first time, and she is going to wait until spring so that she can have a fresh start, a time of renewal that mirrors the natural world. In the essay, the “winter hibiscus” reminds Saeng of her grandmother and her home in Laos. This at first makes her sad but then she realizes how wonderful her memories are and how they help her to get through this tough time. Her memories are going to give her strength to carry on with her life and try her driver’s test again in the spring, using the past as a foundation for future success.

The author ends it with that paragraph because the girl is talking about when the winter ends or spring comes again she will try again. The author ends it with that because it explains how the girl feels about spring and the animals, seeing their return as a sign of hope and new beginnings. The girl says a lot about the geese in the story, so we know from that she likes animals and draws comfort from their migratory patterns. This connection to nature provides her with the courage to face her own challenges anew when the season changes, wrapping the story in a cyclical promise of another attempt.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it sums up how the memories and the plant affect her. Just like the plant, Saeng grows better in her own country and likes it better there but she can still survive in a new place if it is taken care of and fights to stay beautiful. The ending shows that Saeng realizes that if she tries harder she can survive like the plant, so she is going to take the test again. Her mother says, “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here.” Her mother is trying to tell the daughter it's ok and she will get through the hard times, using the hardy plant as a living example of resilience. In the end Saeng knows she can, internalizing this lesson of strength and perseverance for her own life.

In “The Winter Hibiscus,” the author chose to end the story with a hopeful paragraph which stated, “when they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this Hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason for the decision to end on an optimistic note are as follows. For example, the Hibiscus represents the ideas of resilience when faced with challenge, and the determination to adapt and succeed. Saeng’s situation is similar to the flower’s, which has been uprooted from its original spot, replanted, and forced to try and survive the winter. Saeng has moved from her beloved homeland, she must begin life anew in another country, and has been faced with the obstacle of failure in regards to an unnamed test. In the final paragraph, she finds that like the cherished hibiscus flower, she must be resilient and determined to succeed in her new home, and her vow to retake the test symbolizes this newfound resolve.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph (“when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”) because it explains what she is going to do when winter is over, providing a clear plan for her future. Also, it serves to keep the readers guessing on what’s going to happen to Saeng and her mother, creating a sense of anticipation. Another reason is to have a new story when winter is over, suggesting that this ending is merely a pause before the next chapter of her life begins. This forward-looking conclusion leaves the narrative open-ended, filled with the promise of future endeavors and seasonal change.

I know the reason why the author concludes the story the way he does and it is a good reason. It says that since she failed this year, next year when it is time to ready up the garden she will try again. That is a good moral because you have to keep trying and trying to succeed, because even if you fail you are not losing any progress; you are learning from the experience. It is like what @PERSON1 had happen to him: even though it took him @DATE1 tries to successfully make the light bulb, he simply said, “I just found out @NUM1 ways not to make a light bulb.” So I do agree with this author and how he ended the story, as it powerfully illustrates the value of persistence.

She does this to show her struggle with her gardening. It is like this because each year she has to work on her garden again, as the winter blows it away, meaning it kills the plants and she must begin anew. This cycle of destruction and renewal highlights the persistent effort required to maintain her garden, mirroring the challenges she faces in other parts of her life. The annual return to the garden underscores her determination and resilience in the face of repeated setbacks.

The author ends the story with that paragraph because it shows how Saeng won't give up. Saeng wants to make her mother proud, so she is gonna try to do whatever it takes to achieve that goal. All Saeng tries to do is make her mother happy, and when she failed, her mother was initially disappointed but then surprisingly understanding. When Saeng told her mother she failed, Saeng started to cry, but then her mother wiped the tears away, offering comfort and silent encouragement. This moment reinforces Saeng's resolve to continue striving, ensuring the story concludes on a note of hopeful perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it means that when the shovel can be used again in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, she will take the test again. So she will wait patiently until the next spring to take the test, using the intervening time to reflect and prepare herself. This cyclical return to the challenge, tied to the seasons, emphasizes her enduring spirit and commitment to trying again when conditions are more favorable, wrapping up her story with a promise of future effort.

In the story, the test was if she could overcome her homesickness. When she went to the greenhouse, all of the plants and flowers brought back vivid memories of her homeland. When she saw the flower, it reminded her of the times in her life when she would get water from the well and a flower was floating in it, a poignant memory of her past. So after the winter, she would go back to the place and see if she was still homesick or if she had grown stronger. I feel she ended it that way because it shows that she will persevere and not give up, and she will try again to face her feelings and find her place.

I think the author adds the last paragraph because the story could use a little part about Saeng and what she is planning to do next, providing a sense of her future intentions. Also the author may have added that paragraph because she was perhaps thinking about writing a second story of Winter Hibiscus, and they wanted to include a part that could serve as a foundation for the next narrative. It would make you wonder that if she does take the test again, would she pass it this time after the snow melts, the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, leaving the reader with a hopeful question. I think this may be why the author added this concluding paragraph in the story, to create a bridge for future possibilities while giving Saeng a forward-looking resolution.

I think the author concluded the story with these lines because Saeng feels more confident and has found a new sense of resolve. First, when Saeng first saw the hibiscus, she was sad and overwhelmed by memories, but after seeing the flower, she got happy and found a connection to her past. Next, her mother helps her plant it and Saeng is sure it'll be there in spring, symbolizing a shared hope for the future. Finally, Saeng feels better since she has reflected on her past and now looks ahead with a more positive and determined outlook, completing her emotional journey.

I think Minfong Ho concluded her story “Winter Hibiscus” the way she did to show the avid determination of Saeng, the main character, highlighting her resilient spirit. She failed the test but she got the hibiscus and it helped her to restore her resolve to pass the test, serving as a catalyst for her renewed effort. Now that she had a moments of her homeland and her family there she was most likely reminded that they would’ve wanted her to succeed, and so she promises herself that she will take that test again when the hibiscus plant starts budding, linking her personal goal to a natural cycle. This is why I feel that “Winter Hibiscus” was concluded in this way, as it powerfully underscores the theme of perseverance and hope.

At the end of the essay “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, it ends in a positive and hopeful manner. “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason why I think that the author decided to put that there, was to show how Saeng felt about her country and her process of adapting. So when the country that she is in has spring again, she will take that test because that season reminds her of her original country in the spring, creating a comforting association. Which makes her feel like she is at home and she can at least take the test with newfound confidence. That is why the author put that significant sentence at the end of the essay, providing a fitting and uplifting closure.

Saeng promises herself that “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The hibiscus is metaphorical to Saeng for her childhood and her deep-rooted memories. Evidently she grew up in Vietnam and moved to the United States, a significant transition. She misses her homeland, and all the flowers remind her of her homeland, stirring strong emotions. She is so overwhelmed by all the memories that she breaks down and cries, releasing her pent-up feelings. Change is a difficult thing to overcome or adjust to, especially moving to a foreign country, and she is navigating this challenge. She has to cope with it though, and by planting the winter hibiscus is a way of coping and putting down new roots. She knows that she will eventually adjust to the major change for she realized, “that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become… almost familiar to her now,” showing her gradual adaptation. She promises herself that she will retake the drivers test when the hibiscus blossoms because like Saeng a flower changes also, undergoing a transformation. When the hibiscus finally overcomes the cold, dreary winter months and blooms, Saeng will know she is ready to take the test again for that flower can also symbolize her going through changes and emerging stronger. The geese in the story also symbolize changes, they have to migrate south in the winter to avoid the cold but return home when its warm enough, mirroring cycles of departure and return. Like Saeng, she will avoid the test in the winter but in the spring when she feels comfortable and more at home in her new environment, she will face her challenge with renewed hope.

So she is saying she will take the test next year, having decided to use the intervening time to prepare herself more thoroughly for the challenge ahead. This decision marks a commitment to future effort rather than dwelling on past disappointment. Her statement is a simple yet firm resolution to try again when the opportunity next arises, concluding her current thoughts on the matter with a clear forward-looking focus.

The author concludes the story in this manner because he wants to convey a message about resilience and renewal. He is trying to say that the character will be ready next year to sprout again, emotionally prepared for the test. The author intends to show that he will be ready to not cry and break down when he sees the plant that reminds him of his childhood memories. This ending serves to illustrate the character's internal growth and his determination to face poignant memories with newfound strength, bringing his emotional journey to a point of anticipated readiness.

Saeng buys a winter hibiscus to plant in the garden, intending for it to serve as a living reminder of her homeland. She has recently failed a test and is visibly upset over the outcome. Her mother, sensing her daughter's dejection, feels sympathetic and therefore does not get upset that the hibiscus cost a significant amount of money. After carefully planting the hibiscus, Saeng quietly says to herself that in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this very hibiscus is budding, she will take that test again. The author uses this concluding paragraph to make the reader think about whether Saeng will fail or pass the test on her next attempt. It also creates curiosity about the nature of the test; since the author links the retake to the spring, mentioning that the "hibiscus is budding" and "the geese return," it suggests this must be a test that is only administered once a year, as she explicitly states she will try again "in the spring."

The author concluded the paragraph in this story because he is trying to tell the reader an important message about perseverance. The author is attempting to say that if a delicate plant can manage to survive and make it through the harsh, cold winter, then she, too, can find the strength to pass her driver's test on a subsequent attempt. This parallel between the plant's resilience and her own potential for success is the core reason for the paragraph's inclusion. That is the fundamental message I believe the author intended to convey by including that particular passage in the narrative.

The author concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with Saeng's silent vow: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author ends with this specific promise because it powerfully shows hope and determination. Saeng’s internal vow, “I will take that test again,” clearly demonstrates her determination and her unwillingness to be permanently defined by her failure. That firm resolve is enough to bring genuine hope to anyone who has failed and desperately wants another chance to succeed. This concluding paragraph also effectively sums up and displays Saeng’s good character for the reader. It shows Saeng’s inner strength because, even though she failed the first time, she was prepared to put herself through the potential pain of trying again in order to ultimately succeed. To fail and then resolve to try again requires great inner strength and fortitude. The author also ends with this paragraph because the imagery of “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding” brings the story’s cyclical themes back full circle. It holds the promise of Spring and all the better things that the new season brings with it. There are, therefore, many compelling reasons why the author chooses to conclude the story with this hopeful and determined vow from Saeng.

The author added it in at the end not only to make the story have a happy, hopeful ending, but to show the reader that Saeng slowly adjusted to the changes in life. The paragraph above explains that Saeng realized that "the many things that seemed strange before had become,... almost farmiliar to her now." This demonstrates her growing acclimation to her new environment. So the author lastly concludes that eventhough she failed the test this time, just as the geese will return in the spring, then she can take the test again. This parallel between the natural cycle and her personal resolve reinforces the theme of renewal. She just the point of the story across and its a "cheerful" way to end it, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism for Saeng's future.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with, "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test agian.", to show that the hibiscus plant has given Saeng hope. It has helped he get threw some rough and difficult times, serving as a tangible link to her past. In the story Saeng has just failed her drivers test and had to walk home. She was very upset and disheartened by this setback. On her way home Saeng saw a familiar flower, which caught her eye and provided a moment of comfort. She had walked into a flower store to see if they sold the hibiscus that she had seen, seeking confirmation of this familiar sight. The employee pointed her towards the flower, and seeing it up close triggered a flood of nostalgia. The hibiscus brought back many memories at her hometown in vietnam, reminding her of her resilience. Saeng planted her flowers in the vegtable garden, a symbolic act of putting down new roots. That flower had given her hope, and with this newfound strength, she is ready to try the drivers test again, determined to succeed.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because the season is over, marking a natural conclusion to this chapter of Saeng's life. For example it is starting in the winter the hibiscuses are dying, which mirrors Saeng's initial failure and sense of loss. Also she is leaving and wont come back till she can plant flowers again in the spring, and she will come back again when she takes the test over again, linking her personal journey to the cyclical patterns of nature. This connection emphasizes that endings are often followed by new beginnings. In conclusion that is why the author ends the story with this paragraph, to underscore the theme of seasonal change and personal renewal.

The reason the author of "Winter hibiscus" ends the story with the last paragraph is to give hope to the end, transforming the narrative's tone. It gives a certain lift of joy at the end of a moderatly depressing story, providing a sense of relief and forward momentum for the protagonist. It just goes to show that if you care enough you can keep moving foreward, using the hibiscus as a symbol of enduring spirit. And that the end of your world comes when you make it so, suggesting that resilience can redefine one's circumstances. That is why I think the author used such a powerful statement at the end, leaving a lasting impression of hope and determination with the reader.

The character has what seems to be a new found confidence and a new joy of the plant that reminds her of her home land comforting her and motovating her. This connection to her heritage provides her with the emotional strength to persevere. She says when those things come back she will try hard to complete the test, using the return of spring as a personal deadline for her own growth. She is setting a time to push herself, a strategy for turning failure into a future goal. As most people try to do, she finds a way to move forward with renewed purpose and hope.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows how sometimes you have to wait till the time is right for you to try again, just as the plant must wait for its proper season.
