For example, In the book it says ìMadagascar periwinkle, its tag announced, ìHow strang to see it in apat,î Back home it just grew wild jutting out from the cracks in brick walls or between roofs.î This shows that anything can be done when the time is right, suggesting that the character, like the resilient plant, will find her own moment to flourish again in a new environment.

Emotions, symbolism, and the realization of these elements are all reasons the author concluded the story that way. A reason the author ended the story that way is to leave you with mixed emotions. Emotions like sadness, hope, and wonder. The author makes the reader feel sad with the girl failing her test and missing home. The author also gives the feeling of hope that they one day will return home, and a sense of wondering because the conclusion leaves a lot to be answered. The author uses symbolism in the concluding sentences by giving the plant and the geese a sense of importance in the story, and the plant has to do with the home that she really misses, representing her roots and memories. In the final story the author leaves a lot of perceptions on several elements open for the reader to consider. Like the importance of the plant and why did they move from a place that they loved so much. That is why I think the author ended the story that way, to provoke thought and emotional reflection.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng is fond of beautiful flowers that once grew in her homeland, which hold deep sentimental value for her. Her favorite flower was the winter Hibiscus that had beautiful red petals on it soft as of velvet, a vivid reminder of the home she left behind. She also failed a test that she had taken, which deepened her feelings of displacement and struggle. So what the story is trying to say is that nothing can be as good as what's at home but sometimes you just need another chance at something, emphasizing the themes of resilience and the possibility of new beginnings despite initial setbacks.

I think he did because he wanted to show how he loved everything in life, finding beauty and value in the world around him. This deep appreciation is reflected in the narrative's focus on small, significant details and the emotional connections the characters form with their environment. Through this perspective, the story conveys a message of universal affection and the importance of cherishing even the simplest aspects of our existence, ultimately celebrating a profound and heartfelt love for life itself.

The reason why the author of the story ended it like that is because after all the hard time that plant went through, it will still be there at the end of the winter, representing endurance and resilience. The author said that the plant will take that test again; that test is surviving through the cold winter and blooming at the end of the winter. This cyclical challenge mirrors the protagonist's own struggles, suggesting that she, too, must endure difficult periods with the hope of emerging renewed, just as the plant prepares to bloom once more after the harsh season passes.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. One reason is that the author is trying to say that she is going to overcome the obstacle of the test no matter what. In the text it says “it can make through the cold months,” a sentiment which consumes her and supports the last paragraph. Also, she is in a new country and is starting a new beginning. In the text it says “Not like the same kind we had before.” This implies that it is different in this country and she will soon adjust to this new life. Finally it says, “this hibiscus is budding,” which means she will bloom just as the flower does, symbolizing her own growth and resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is by herself, and she is letting herself know that she is going to try the test she failed again. This decision comes as she is starting to get used to her new home, having now found something that reminds her of her life before she left. The discovery of the hibiscus plant provides her with a sense of familiarity and comfort, reinforcing her resolve to face the challenge again with renewed hope and a stronger connection to her new environment.

The author ends the story like this so readers can understand the theme. Which is, you can always start over after a mistake is made. For example, Saeng failed her driving test and then it took a toll on her, but she resolves to try again in the spring. I guess she figures that once she has renewed herself, she will do better. The budding hibiscus serves as a metaphor for this personal renewal, suggesting that after a period of hardship, new growth and second chances are possible, allowing her to bloom in her own time.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it all makes a little sense to end the story this way. Here is why I think it does. The paragraph is one of the main pieces to the story. “In the spring, when the snows melt and after return,” all she says is that when the snow is gone and the grass comes back, she will start planting again and she would be happy with it. “This hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” she went to put her plants up again and tests them to see how they overwinter so she can tend to them again. Saeng loved this plant so much that she can’t wait. But when it does bloom she is going to plant a lot. That is what the paragraph is saying; Saeng is going to wait so she can plant a hibiscus. However, since she came to the United States she loved the flower very much, and it represents a promise of a new beginning and the perseverance to try again.

The author chooses to conclude with this paragraph because to Saeng, spring is the best time to do things. This is the season when all the happy memories return along with the geese and the hibiscus flowers. It is a time of renewal and hope, symbolizing a fresh start after the cold, difficult winter months. This cyclical return of life and joy gives her the strength and optimism to face her challenges again, making this moment the perfect point to end her story of resilience and new beginnings.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the hibiscus is motivating her to test for her drivers test. In the spring, when the snows melt, the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding, then she will take that test again. The flower serves as a natural timer, its cycle of dormancy and rebirth mirroring her own need for a period of rest and preparation before she can summon the courage to face the challenge once more. Its eventual blooming will be the sign that she, too, is ready to blossom and succeed.

There are several reasons for her decision. First, in spring she will have had more time to adjust to her new life and become familiar with the roads. Also when the hibiscus starts budding she will feel comforted, as though it automatically brings back her childhood memories of resilience and beauty. It also is a tangible link to her past home in Vietnam, a piece of her heritage taking root in this new soil. When the hibiscus adjusts to its new life in ground soil, she will adjust and be ready to take the test again, having found her own footing. Its as if, when the plant is ready to start budding, she will also be ready to face her future.

The author concludes the story with that sentence as a vow made to the flower. It’s just stating that Saeng will come back and try again next year and see if it works out with the hibiscus. The promise is not just about the driving test, but a deeper commitment to her own growth and perseverance. By linking her personal goal to the plant's natural cycle, she finds a source of quiet strength and determination, ensuring she does not give up. This final vow encapsulates her resolve to try again when conditions are more favorable.

The author put the paragraph in to show that the character cares about the flowers and draws strength from them. Flowers only come out during spring and summer time and that's when you plant and study all that grows in a garden. The process of nurturing the hibiscus and witnessing its growth provides her with a sense of purpose and a metaphor for her own learning. So she can pass the test and be happy with the garden, finding success both on the road and in the soil of her new home. This connection to nature gives her the confidence to face her challenges.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” ends the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" for a couple of reasons. Most of all because the hibiscus blooming represents hope - the plant will survive through the winter months and will grow again and become strong, a testament to endurance. So, too, will Saeng, who will draw strength from the flower's example. Although Saeng is in a strange place where she doesn’t want to be, she is able to overcome adversity and hardship by aligning her spirit with nature's resilience. In the same way, the hibiscus can withstand the winter, proving that life persists even in harsh conditions. This is why the author ends the story the way she does, to give the final impression that Saeng still has hope for a brighter future.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng makes a vow to herself. “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This vow means that she will start fresh, make changes, and adapt to her new life. She does not want to disappoint her mother and she won't be broken down by her memories of the past. The author concluded the story like this to show in the future how her life will change and how she would learn to like where she is now, embracing the new beginning that the spring season symbolizes for her.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph that says, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because the author wants to convey that Saeng isn’t going to quit. She is determined to take and pass the test, showing her resilience. It also means that Saeng will wait for the right moment to take the test, a time when she is better prepared. She will wait till things get better and the situation that she is in improves, because it says, "The snow melt, the geese return, and hibiscus is budding," indicating a period of renewal and hope for her success.

The author concludes the story with this last paragraph because it shows that by spring she will be ready to retake her test. It shows that, like the geese who care and come back, she will have had time to study and prepare to pass her test. In the story the author includes this last paragraph to truly show her dedication to eventually grow to be comfortable in her new home and to pass her driver's test all in good time. Saeng wants to be comfortable with her new life but isn’t yet because of what she misses from her old one. But she knows that after this winter she can go back and try again, just like the geese do each year. This was a very effective way to end the story because it really communicated Saeng’s message of dedication and her longing to overcome her obstacles, both in her new home and with driving.

I think the author concludes like this because its almost like a new beginning for the protagonist. The ending of the story makes you think that Saeng is going to get on with her life and move forward. It makes me think that Saeng plans to start her life over in comparison with the hibiscus, finding inspiration in nature. Once the plant “starts over” by rebudding, she will start over once again with renewed hope. It also shows that she is determined to continue on with her life in her new country. She will not let her life be distraught by her move from Vietnam. She hopes that she will be able to start her life over again successfully. The ending is a “cliff hanger” to show that her story has not yet completely ended, leaving room for her future. It shows that there is still possibility that she can get on with her life and achieve her goals. It also shows she doesn’t let her failures control her, demonstrating her inner strength. She is a strong young woman and is determined to overcome this challenge and build a new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it's a very good ending paragraph that grabs your attention a little bit with its symbolic promise. Also it shows that the girl is determined to pass her test, so that makes you think this is a determined story about perseverance. The vow she makes provides a clear sense of her resolve and future intentions. This is why the author concluded the story with this paragraph, as it effectively encapsulates the story's theme of resilience and hope for a new beginning.

The author concludes the story this way to show that Saeng intends to try again, using the hibiscus as a powerful symbol of her renewed resolve. An example of her trying again is when she sees the plant and realizes what it symbolizes to her, recognizing its resilience as a quality she must embody. Another example is her saying that she wants to plant the hibiscus herself so that she holds the memories forever, actively choosing to cultivate hope rather than dwell on past sorrow. This decision to nurture the plant mirrors her decision to nurture her own spirit, which is why the author concludes the story in this manner, ending on a note of quiet determination and forward momentum.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she was trying to say since the hibiscus is planted we are going to see how it does with the winter, using its survival as a metaphor for Saeng's own journey. And when spring arrives and it's still standing she can go take the test, her personal success linked to the plant's endurance. I think the author was comparing the hibiscus to their life and obstacles they will go through, creating a parallel between natural and human struggle. So if the hibiscus is still standing then that means everything will be fine to where she can go back and take the test, its resilience promising her own.

The last paragraph of “Winter Hibiscus” describes determination and the growth of a person, using the changing seasons to frame Saeng's emotional journey. Saeng says that when “this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” directly connecting her personal goal to a natural, cyclical event. Just as the hibiscus blooms Saeng will bloom forth and strive through the winter to try and succeed in passing her test, demonstrating that growth often requires patience and endurance. Saeng concludes by saying this as a realization that she can’t be sad forever, acknowledging that she must move forward. She must be determined in order to pass the test, and the next season will be a sort of renewal, starting fresh and coming out beautiful as does a hibiscus in bloom.

The Author of “Winter Hibiscus”, Minfong Ho, concluded the story with the paragraph about how when the geese are there, and the hibiscus is blooming, Saeng will take her drivers test again, because she wanted to end on a hopeful and happy note. In the beginning of the story, Saeng, who had just moved from Vietnam to the United States, failed her drivers test, which compounded her feelings of displacement. She had found a plant they had back in Vietnam, but it made her sad, initially intensifying her homesickness. “I mean it’s not like the kind we had at — at—" she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again.” (Ho, @NUM1) So by ending by describing positive things for the future, Saeng could think about that, and get her mind off of everything else, focusing on renewal instead of loss.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a very good reason, as it encapsulates Saeng's shift from despair to hope. In a way she is just letting her initial failure go and will wait to take the test again, showing maturity and patience. I think that it is a good thing that she found the flower, as it serves as a crucial turning point for her character. That is because it let her connect with her mother and in a way make her feel better, strengthening her support system and her resolve. For example when it says " the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," it shows she has set a future goal inspired by nature's cycles, concluding her arc on a promise of perseverance.

The author concludes the story this way to show how the main character, Saeng, has changed from the beginning of the story to the end. It shows a small amount of newfound confidence Saeng now has, a quiet but significant shift in her perspective. This ending also shows how much of an effect the “Winter hibiscus” had on her, with its presence bringing back powerful memories of her old country. If Saeng wouldn’t have found the hibiscus, she would have never started to reminisce about her old home in such a vivid and emotional way. This reminiscing not only reminded her of her past, but it also helped her compare her new home to her old home, allowing her to see the connections between them. Through this reflection she realized that life in @LOCATION1 is not so bad, and that she still has a little bit of her old home with her everyday in these small, familiar comforts. This realization gave her just enough hope and confidence to want to try the driving test again, a concrete step toward her future. This ending effectively shows the change of heart Saeng feels for @LOCATION1 and her small but crucial gain of hope and confidence.

The author decides to conclude the story with that specific image because she wants the moral of the story to be burnt in your head, leaving a lasting impression on the reader. She believes that you will always have a chance to try again, and the flower restarts its cycle and it gets another chance to bud; that natural process symbolizes that you can start over and try again just like the girl is going to do on the test. She is doing the test again when the season starts over so she can attempt it with a renewed spirit. The flower and the flower budding will support her and give her the hope she needs to persevere, illustrating the story's central theme of renewal.

I believe that the author ends the story the way she did because it talk’s about both of the subjects, connecting the character's internal growth with an external symbol. The author is trying to say that when she takes her driving test next spring the hibiscus will give her confidence to pass her driving test, serving as a personal talisman. The author links the character's future success to the natural world, suggesting that the budding flower will provide the emotional strength and reassurance needed for her to succeed in her new environment.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author ends the story in a way that shows that she wants to start fresh and embrace a new beginning. I think this because when she is talking to her mom at the end of the story, she says “In the spring, when this hibiscus is budding, I will take the test again”. She is saying that she wants to start over and adapt to her new country, using the new season as a marker for her personal renewal. Also, I think this because she wants to wait until the seasons change to go take her test again, as she says “when the snow melts and the geese return.” She states this because she wants a completely new slate when she takes her test again, a clean start free from past failures. That is why I believe she wanted to conclude her story this way, to emphasize themes of patience and cyclical renewal.

I think the author concludes the story like that because its showing the time that will be passing between her failure and her next attempt. When it shows time passing, she’s grew up more and maybe she’ll be ready to take the test since now she knows how it is and what to expect. Also because the hibiscus will be budding, that will make her feel more comfortable and relaxed because it will all make her feel a more secure home feeling, a sense of belonging. “hibiscus is budding” this way the flower will be starting new and so will she, embarking on a parallel journey of growth and new beginnings in her life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that she needs to adapt to the new country. She wants to wait until the hibiscus is budding, a sign of new growth. The plant budding shows that it is adapting to a new environment just like Saeng, finding a way to thrive in unfamiliar soil. The story shows that Saeng is not yet used to the new country, as she cries when she sees the plants because they remind her so vividly of her old home. Yet, the plant also comforts her, offering a tangible link to her past. When she finally adapts to the new country, finding her own strength, then she will take the test again, ready to face the challenge with renewed hope.

The author concludes this story with “when they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because Saeng didn't pass her test and knew her mom would be mad, so that is why she sought out the flower for solace. If she wouldn't have failed her test, she probably wouldn't have gone to the greenhouse and found the hibiscus in the first place. This sequence of events highlights how her initial disappointment led her to a source of comfort and motivation. The flower becomes a symbol of her personal vow to try again, tying her resolve to the natural cycle of renewal and growth that the budding plant represents.

The author of the story "Winter Hibiscus" ends the story with Saeng saying a vow to herself because it shows how important the flower is to her. For example, the hibiscus flower gives her determination because it reminds her of home and the strength she had there. Saeng says “… and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The hibiscus flower gives her the confidence she had lost after failing her driver's test. It reminds her of her home in Vietnam before they moved to the new country, serving as a bridge between her past and her future. Therefore, the author concludes the story with that certain paragraph because it powerfully symbolizes the emotional importance of the flower and its role in restoring Saeng's spirit.

She feels very connected to this hibiscus plant because it reminds her of her homeland and the warmth she left behind. I think she is trying to say when the hibiscus plant shows its inner budding she will, too, revealing her own potential for growth. The plant has to try hard to produce flowers, and the sun has to come out to melt the snow, so that means when spring comes around she needs to emerge and melt all of her bad habits and do what she needs to do to pass the test. But she will do this while still not forgetting where she came from and all the memories left behind, carrying them with her as a source of strength. Her silent vow, “…vowed silently to herself…then I will take that test again,” is a promise of this personal transformation, linking her future success to the natural world's resilience.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author concludes the story with the last paragraph like that because when the season comes back around for budding she is going to be right back out there exploring her new surroundings with a fresh perspective. She’s going to want to learn more about the hibiscus and what they do, seeing them as a part of her new life. And she can’t wait to start taking care of them as they start to bud, nurturing them as she hopes to nurture her own chances for success. That’s why they ended the story with that paragraph, to leave the reader with a sense of hopeful anticipation for Saeng's future as she finds her place in the cycle of the seasons.

There are many reasons this paragraph is included. It shows the flower will emotionally encourage her when it is budding, because it will remind her of home and provide comfort. This is shown when she says “a blossom or two would have blown into the well,” which clearly reminds her of her homeland and her past. It also is to show she is adapting to her new home and becoming more comfortable in her new environment. For instance, when the geese flew by she said “she realized that many things that she thought of as strange before had become, almost familiar to her now.” This shows how she is adapting and is now beginning to enjoy her new life, finding familiarity where there was once only strangeness. This final paragraph is important because it shows how her life is changing and she is finding her place.

The author is saying that she will be ready soon enough, when the flowers begin to grow and the geese begin to come home; she will be ready for a new start. She needs the hope and renewal that spring represents to feel prepared. The changing seasons signal a time for personal growth and new attempts. Therefore, she associates her own readiness with these natural cycles, believing that with the new season comes new strength and a better chance for success in her endeavors.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she failed the driver's test and is reflecting on her experience. She is saying when it gets a little warmer outside and the plants grow in, maybe she will then take the test again and hopefully pass, using the spring as a metaphor for a fresh opportunity. I know that she failed the test because it said “As Saeng walks home after failing her driver's test,” which directly states the outcome. I guess that from the snow being on the ground, it may have caused her to make mistakes when taking the test, as the unfamiliar winter conditions were a challenge. In conclusion, that is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, to show her resolve to try again under better circumstances.

In “The Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with “in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to make a point about her need for renewal. She needs all of those things to happen for her to be sound enough to take the test again, as they symbolize the emotional and environmental stability she requires. The melting snow, the returning geese, and the budding flower each represent a facet of the change she is waiting for. This confluence of events will provide her with the confidence and peace of mind she currently lacks, wrapping up her journey toward readiness.

The author ended the story this way because the plant represents new beginnings, which is what Saeng needs after her disappointment. Seang failed her test and needed some comfort and a symbol of hope. She went to the greenhouse and spent her money on a hibiscus plant that reminded her of her home and her past. At the same time, the hibiscus plant reminded her that her new home is another new beginning and a chance to grow. The hibiscus plant gives Saeng better hopes that starting over can be a good thing and that the next time she takes the test, she'll pass, having found strength and perspective through this symbol of resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a couple of reasons. The primary reason why he does is because he wants to conclude by writing about geese, which are a significant symbol of seasonal change. Second, he like plants and the season’s that they bud, seeing in them a natural cycle of renewal. He vowed that he would take that test in the spring, linking his personal goal to this cycle of nature. He cant wait until the snow melts so that way he can take the test, viewing the coming season as a fresh start full of potential and new beginnings for his endeavors.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph is because she wants that same envioronment and everything she wanted before when she took the test. She longs for the familiar conditions and the sense of readiness she once possessed, hoping to recapture that moment. The conclusion reflects her desire to return to a point in time when her confidence was intact and her goals felt attainable, suggesting that the right circumstances are crucial for her to attempt the challenge again and finally achieve the success she seeks.

The author’s choice of words in the conclusion of the story, I believe sent of let the reade knew that the story continues beyond the final page. The language suggests an ongoing journey for the character, implying that life moves forward. But, I think that the test is that to remind her of home, serving as a powerful symbol that connects her present challenges to her past and her roots. This connection provides a deeper meaning to her struggle, indicating that the test is not just an obstacle but a link to her identity and memories.

The Author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself. in the spring, when the snow melt and the gees return and this Hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She concludes it with this because she begins the story with Saeng Failing Her Driver license test, creating a narrative frame that moves from failure to a promise of future effort. and also she was think that the Winter Hibiscus was good luck after it goes away and how she was familiar with the geese; she put these elements together and thats why she said when the geese comes back and the snow melts. The return of these natural signs represents hope and the right time for a second attempt, which is the core reason for her concluding vow.

I think Saeng concluded with this story because there is always time to make up for the past if the past allows you to, meaning that Saeng didn’t past the test but is not defined by that single failure. I feel she meant that “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” and to me this means that even though it is snowing outside there is always next spring to start growing back up. This also relates to Saeng; even though she failed the test there is always another change we can make up for that lost and retry and try to succeed at this one, emphasizing the themes of resilience and the cyclical nature of opportunity that life continually presents.

The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with this sentence when Saeng comes back and vowed silently to herself, "in spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The Winter Hibiscus symbolizes her fondness of the place she used to live before. It is not a real one, as she thinks, "I’m mean not the kind we had at—at"—she was still too shaky to say the words "at home." When the hibiscus buds, she will still be fond of her home, but she will have adapted better to her current environment. The geese returning to their home signifies that she, too, will find a place to call home in this new country one day. When she finds that sense of belonging, she will find herself ready to “take the test" or do things normally again. The author concluded the story with that sentence to show that Saeng will eventually grow into her new life, finding the strength to move forward while still honoring her past.

The author concluded the story in that manner because she was being positive about Saeng's future. Just as the geese are coming back, Saeng is positive that she can take the test again with a new sense of hope. She knows deep down that she will pass the test next time. In the story, she reflects that “Many things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This means that when she had just moved here, she thought that everything was strange because she had not seen anything like this before in her homeland. Now, as she continues living here, she would get used to it because she knows what will happen; nothing will become strange to her anymore since this is her home now, and she is learning to embrace it fully.

The reader thinks the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the girl is declaring she will try again and take that test. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng, the girl, took a test and failed it, which was a discouraging experience. And she found this flower that brought back memories from her past and decided she would take the test again, now that things are going to get better. Also, when the girl saw those geese flying over her, she knew they would be coming back after winter in the spring, and when they do, her flower will blossom, the one that brings back good memories from the past, and she will retake that test and pass. The cyclical return of the geese and the budding flower reinforce her renewed hope. Those are some examples of why I think the author concluded the story with that paragraph, to show her commitment to a fresh start.

The author concludes the story in that way because Saeng loves her homeland and loves nature and loves her mother deeply. She misses the greenness of her past home and cannot wait until spring comes, bringing with it a renewal of life and color. The promise of spring is a promise of personal renewal for her, so she will take the test of being out of place and overcome those feelings for herself. Her love for her family and her homeland is a source of strength, not a chain, allowing her to face her new challenges. That is why she concludes the story that way, to show that her affections empower her future actions and her adaptation to a new life.

The author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” concludes her story this way to demonstrate the girl's determination and to leave the reader anticipating more of her journey. I say this because obviously Saeng is determined to do well on her next attempt, showing her resilient character. However, leaving the story hanging at this point of decision builds excitement for more action and makes the reader wonder about her eventual success. This narrative choice creates a sense of hopeful expectation for Saeng's future, emphasizing that her story of adaptation and perseverance is ongoing and full of potential.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng is getting used to living in a new place. Towards the end of the text, Saeng says that many things she thought were strange before had become familiar to her. The winter hibiscus was comforting, and reminded Saeng of her home, providing a tangible link to her past. she says “In the spring when the snows melt” because she is beginning to get used to “the quiet repetition of season upon season” and the cyclical nature of her new environment. The geese, which form a distinctive V are becoming familiar to her, no longer just a strange sight but a part of her new normal. The last paragraph is an effective way to end the story because it shows that saeng is becoming accostumed to her new surroundings and is hopeful the future, finding solace in the familiar patterns of nature.

When they came back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. The author’s main purpose of these lines was to grab the readers attention by making a continuing paragraph that acts as a closing, showing she’s adapting to circumstances and finding a new resolve. Saeng values the uniqueness of plants, which connect her to her heritage, and she is also comforted by memories of her homeland, which give her the strength to face future challenges. This internal vow signifies a turning point where she channels her nostalgia into motivation for her new life.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to conclude that she will wait a little bit of time, until plants can be plentiful so if she fails again, she will have something to hold on to for comfort. For example, when Saeng failed the test she tried to overcome the feeling of failing, by buying something that reminds her of her country and bring back the memories to past to get through this difficult time. Another example is when Saeng “felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral,” she forgot about everything that was happening in her life, from moving to a new location to failing her test; this feeling concentrated her on feeling like home again, providing a temporary escape. In conclusion, the author's conclusion creates the belief that the way Saeng gets over her problems is by remembering memories like the plant, that reminded her of her home country, using them as an emotional anchor.

I believe that the author concludes the story this way to show that Saeng will be ready for the challenges of next year. She said now all the new things seemed weird to her when she first got here, but now they are second nature to her now, a part of her daily life. I think that the hibiscus is a symbol of hope and inspiration to her, representing resilience and beauty in a new climate. I think that she finally realizes that she is in her new country to stay and she cannot go back to Vietnam, which is a significant acceptance. So she has to accept that she is here now and this is her home, and I think she is on her way to doing that, finding her place and a sense of belonging.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she has faith for a new start, a fresh beginning with the coming spring. Saeng compares herself to the hibiscus, seeing a parallel in their cycles of dormancy and renewal. When the “hibiscus is budding,” she will retake the test. This shows that when the hibiscus restarts its life, so will she, embarking on a new phase of her own. Saeng feels that when the hibiscus is “strong enough to make it through the cold winter,” then she is strong enough to pass her driver’s test and live in a new country, drawing strength from nature's endurance. Winter and cold represent death and hardship, and spring represent a new life or beginning, a time for growth. Saeng thinks to herself, “in the spring… I will take the test again.” This is a new beginning for Saeng, a new hope that is tied to the natural world's promise of renewal.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author decided to end it with the sentence “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” because it shows that even though the main character Saeng failed once, she will be trying again too. The geese will be coming back to try out a new spring and the hibiscus will be budding new flowers, so it is like it is starting over again as well, and Saeng says that if both have made it once they tried again then she can as well, but this time she will succeed. Also, it shows the determination all living things have to succeed at their main purpose. The flower strives to re-bud. The geese strive at coming back again during the spring and the main character strives at passing the test. The author of “Winter Hibiscus,” Minfong Ho, put that quote as the last line of the story for inspiration, to inspire people to continue the path of life and if you fail a task, to try again. So the author gives you inspiration to help you continue to live your life with resilience and hope.

In the last paragraph of the story, Saeng vows to herself that she will take the driving test again in the spring. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the hope that nature brings to her. She describes peaceful things in nature, like the geese and the hibiscus, that she draws strength from because they remind her of her homeland and the familiar life she left behind. In this way, she’ll always have a little piece of her past with her, a comforting connection to where she came from. Throughout the story, Saeng relates to nature and pulls strength from it. Her mother has a garden, and she relates to it in that she has a different past, preferring natural foods like bitter melons over the processed options available in her new location. This final paragraph shows the hope that the beautiful nature from her homeland has brought to Saeng, helping her adapt to living in a new place by providing solace and a sense of continuity.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that she’ll hopefully be stronger in the future. By that I mean she’ll feel more comfortable in her new environment and she won't miss her home as much, having found a new source of strength. Also, she tried hard this year but failed the test, and she felt she had let her grandmother down because she didn't get her what she asked for and she spent her effort on something else. This failure contributes to her renewed determination. That is why I think the author added this paragraph to this story, to illustrate Saeng's growth and her resolve to improve her situation after a setback.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because it shows the main character, Saeng, adapting and trying her best with her new life style. For example, when she vowed to herself in the last paragraph saying, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This implies that she is putting more effort into what she does in her new environment and settings, using the cyclical renewal of nature as her motivation and timeline. In conclusion, the author concludes the story with that paragraph to show how someone is adapting to change, learning from past experiences, and moving forward with a positive and determined outlook on life.

The author includes this because he is using metaphors to explain how the author felt about Saeng’s personal life is reflected in the natural world. The budding hibiscus and the returning geese serve as symbolic representations of her own journey, her struggles, and her capacity for renewal and perseverance amidst change and challenge.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because it effectively shows Saeng's sympathy and her desire to mend the disappointment she caused. She wants to help her mom with the garden precisely because she feels she let her down. For instance, she feels genuinely bad about upsetting her mom, and while her mom is gardening, she offers, “Here, let me help, mother,” because her mom’s frail beauty touched her deeply. Earlier, when Saeng told her mom she failed the driving test, she even knew instinctively not to look at her directly because she could sense her mother's upset, as it says, “Saeng didn’t dare look her mother in the eye,” which clearly shows Saeng’s concern for her mother’s reaction. However, in the end, her mother was happy she got the plant, saying, “It’s a beautiful plant, I’m glad you got it,” which demonstrates the underlying closeness and understanding in their relationship. This is why Saeng’s sympathy and her subsequent desire to better herself are powerfully shown in the story’s conclusion.

The story “Winter Hibiscus” is about a young girl whose focus on gardening overshadows her schoolwork. The given conclusion explains that when spring arrives and the winter hibiscus is gone, she will then pass the school test she previously failed. Saeng only cares for the winter hibiscus in the present moment, for example, the line “I paid over nineteen dollars for it” explains that she used all her money on this specific plant rather than on any other necessities or food. Also, the quote “I failed the test” accompanied by Saeng crying shows that she failed it primarily because she was preoccupied with worrying about the hibiscus and its well-being. In conclusion, over the spring, when the winter hibiscus is gone and no longer a distraction, Saeng will be able to focus on school more diligently rather than on gardening. Maybe now, with her attention redirected, she will pass her test and can later return to her hobby of gardening with a clearer mind.

The author has a good reason for concluding the story in this manner. The main character of the story, Saeng, moves to the United States from Vietnam and subsequently fails her driver's test. Saeng has not yet adapted to life in the United States, and when she sees a familiar hibiscus plant, she buys it for the memories of Vietnam it evokes. The author is trying to show that since Saeng planted the hibiscus during the winter, its eventual blooming in the spring symbolizes that she will then be ready to try to pass her driver's test because she will have adapted to life in the United States. The theme of the story would be that if you are moving away from somewhere you grew up in, it is helpful to bring things that remind you of that place so you still have a little of that culture with you during the transition. Therefore, the author begins and ends with the same subject to reinforce this cyclical connection between memory and adaptation.

The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with a sentence about retaking the driver's test in the spring to express the themes of adapting to circumstances and a determination to succeed. The main character, Saeng, is a Vietnamese immigrant. Because America is not her homeland, there are still many aspects of life here she is not accustomed to, and the story shows her struggle to adapt. For instance, when she sees the flower “Madagascar periwinkle” she thinks “how strange to see it in a pot” because “Back home it just grows wild,” highlighting her disorientation. The last sentence of the story is symbolic when it says “and the geese return,” because the geese adapt to circumstances by flying south for the winter, just like Saeng is trying to do, and Saeng realizes their patterns are becoming familiar to her. The very last line says “I will take that test again.” This summarizes the determination Saeng has throughout the entire story. Not only is she determined to succeed in her driver’s test, but in other things as well. For example, when trying to plant the hibiscus Saeng observes that “the soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting her shovel into it.” Despite the difficulty, though, she “dug out a hole” and knows the plant is strong enough to move through the cold months, just like Saeng will be strong enough to overcome her own obstacles if she tries. The last sentence in the story is significant because it expresses these important themes and lends valuable insight into Saeng’s resilient character.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph to set the symbolic theme. In the story, the winter hibiscus represents very important things to Saeng – confidence, beauty, adaptation, and her memories of her old homeland. She had failed the driving test, which shook her confidence. Afterwards, she bought the hibiscus to comfort her homesickness. The hibiscus can be seen as a metaphor for Saeng herself; it is the same plant, but growing differently in a different area, just as she is still the same person but now in a new home. The significance of the last paragraph is mainly about the hibiscus budding. It represents a connection to Saeng's homeland; by the hibiscus blossoming, it can represent her enduring love for her homeland. When the author wrote “then I will take that test again” it is referring to the new confidence she will have later when the hibiscus blooms, completing another plant-to-person metaphor about growth and renewal.

The author, @PERSON1, concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with that paragraph to show Saeng starting over. In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, @CAPS1 to her life, is that she is starting fresh in a way. Although she @MONTH1 miss her old life, her grandmother, the well, and the fine toothed comb, she is making an effort and "take that test again." By relating the test she shows that she is not ready to give in to the "@CAPS2 of loss" and to her grief, choosing instead to embrace her new beginning with resilience and quiet determination.

The author ends the story with “when they back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” because she is concluding that the hibiscus comforts her and once the plant is well and alive, she will be comfortable to take the test. In reality, seeking comfort from a plant seems naive, but its not that she has comfort in the plant itself but that the hibiscus reminds her of her home, which she misses dearly. Once the plant is thriving, as was common in her tropical home, she believes that its presence will comfort her enough to pass the test, providing a tangible link to her past that strengthens her resolve. In conclusion, this is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, highlighting the symbolic power of the hibiscus.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph to show how as the plant will grow, so will Saeng. After failing the driver's test, Saeng goes to the greenhouse and finds the Hibiscus plant, which reminds her of her true home back in Vietnam where they had similar plants. The plant then makes her think about all the memories, and she is comforted by them even though she is sad. She uses this plant as a tool for comfort to help her think about where she is from and all the good memories to help raise her spirits higher. So to boost her confidence, she decides to plant it. “The ‘winter hibiscus’ was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it.” Then she sees geese flying in the sky, which is kind of a symbol of that day, something to remember it by, so the next year, “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” she will take the test again. These things bring back good memories which help to make her stronger and more determined to succeed.

I think Saeng needs to take the test over again because she needs to get her grade up. Saeng is wary about the snow, and in the spring she is thinking about the flower getting covered by it. Saeng's mother lets her help with the pepper and melons, and later lets her set the dinner, showing the small, supportive routines of her new life that provide a foundation for her to try again despite her initial setback and fears.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she wants us to know that Saeng is not giving up on her test. The author wants to inform the readers that she is not giving up; “then I will take that test again” clearly states she still has hope. The author wants to show Saeng's determination to continue on and persevere with her test, using the promise of the hibiscus's bloom as a symbol of her renewed effort. This is why the author concluded the story with that paragraph, emphasizing a future of possibility and resilience.

The author concludes this story with that paragraph because during winter everything in nature dies down and becomes dormant, waiting until spring where everything becomes lively again. In this context, Saeng would feel more motivated to do well on the test, seeing it as her own personal spring. Saeng is sort of like the plant, as she strives and worries through the difficult winter of her life and then blooms beautifully in the spring, achieving success. Also, I think the memories that the winter hibiscus plant brought her, of her past home and life, ultimately motivated her to stop staying in the past and to move on towards the future with renewed hope.

He wrote this because he is talking about the fundamental weather changes that occur with the turning of the seasons. The shift from one season to another brings about significant transformations in the environment, which is a central point of his discussion. This focus on cyclical change provides a deeper context for the narrative, illustrating how external conditions influence internal states. Therefore, the mention of weather is integral to understanding the broader themes he presents.

The author probably concludes the story with that paragraph because she is basically relating the plants to herself, meaning that as the plant blooms, she will too by taking the test and succeeding. Her reason could be because, reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. This process of gradual adaptation is mirrored in her actions. Basically, she did as the geese did by lifting her head, watching as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, and slowly facing into the distance, ready to move forward. This is why I believe the author put this to conclude the story, because she was comparing herself to the geese and does as they did, embracing a new direction.

The author describes the last quote because he wants her dream to be achieved. He describes how she realized that many of the things that she had thought were strange had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Saeng is from Vietnam, and her family has an American dream of a better life. So the author wants her family to adapt to their new life in America, letting go of the past and embracing their future. The conclusion serves to highlight this theme of adaptation and the hopeful pursuit of their aspirations in a new land.

She says this because right now it is winter, a season when many flowers cannot grow due to how cold it is. So she is saying that when spring is back, she will take the test again, which is akin to growing the flowers once more in a more favorable season. This parallel between the natural world and her personal challenges underscores her determination to try again when conditions improve. In conclusion, this is why the author states that conclusion at the end of the paragraph, to draw a clear connection between seasonal renewal and personal resolve.

The author ends the story with that paragraph to give you a sense of hope and determination for the future that dwells within Saeng at that time. Throughout the story, it seemed as though Saeng was giving into despair at the remembrance of her homeland; she wasn't doing so well in her new country, and she had realized it most profoundly when she had failed her driving test. But when she walked past the flower shop and saw all the plants that used to bloom so freely and beautifully in her homeland confined in those tiny pots and fighting to survive, it reminded her of herself here in @LOCATION1. As she began to plant her hibiscus, she again compared herself to it, drawing strength from its resilience, and that is why when her plant blooms so well in the spring, she will pass that test, symbolizing her own successful adaptation and growth.

The author concludes the story with this saying because he thought it would convey a message about hope and continuity, much like how the hibiscus is yet budding in the winter and how all of the geese will return home and stay there because they hate the cold season. This imagery serves to parallel the character's own situation, suggesting that just as nature endures harsh conditions and awaits a return to better times, so too does the protagonist hold on to the hope of returning to a more familiar and comforting place. The paragraph thus reinforces the theme of perseverance through difficult periods, implying that a change for the better is always on the horizon.

The author concludes the story using that paragraph for a few reasons. One reason is because of the significant change in Saeng’s attitude. In the beginning of the story, Saeng is upset and has no hope of adjusting to her new home, but by adding that paragraph at the end of the story, it shows that she has found hope, and she’s not going to give up. Another reason why this paragraph concludes the story is to show that life does go on even in the toughest situations. The fact that a new season will begin figuratively shows Saeng will not always feel this way, that she too will change and adapt over time. In this way, the author concludes the story with that paragraph for a few good and impactful reasons.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, I think, because since the girl failed her test, the bud reminds her of her grandmother's long grey hair, and that memory gives her comfort and a sense of good luck. This connection to her past and her family strengthens her resolve, so when the winter passes by and the springtime arrives, the buds start to come back out, symbolizing a new beginning. It is at that hopeful time, filled with the promise of renewal, that she will take her test again with greater confidence. That is why the author made this statement the last sentence of the story, to leave the reader with a sense of optimistic anticipation.

I am going to tell you why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. One reason the author does this is because it tells you that Saeng is confident in her ability to overcome her challenges. It also tells you she won't give up, no matter how difficult the circumstances may seem. And it shows that she is willing to take her ability to the next level, demonstrating her resilience and determination to succeed in her new environment. This final thought encapsulates her character development and reinforces the story's central message of perseverance, which is why the author concludes the story with the paragraph.

The author most likely intended to show the hopeful enlightenment of Saeng's complex dilemma. In the phrase, "when they come back" the author most likely refers to the hibiscus flowers that represent the fond memories of her homeland. The author illustrates Saeng's struggle adapting to her new life through a “test” of planting the buds just as she had done back home with her grandmother. This test represents the achievement of adaptation to her new life, symbolizing her personal growth and resilience. For that reason, the author concluded her story with the paragraph indicating Saeng will indeed take that test again, demonstrating her commitment to persevere and ultimately thrive in her new environment.

The author decided to conclude the story with this paragraph to show Saeng’s determination to adapt to her new life. In the third paragraph on the second page the author writes, “Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile… That at least, she could hold onto.” After failing her driver’s test Saeng was feeling foreign and alone, disconnected from her new surroundings. She desperately looked to the flower as a reminder of her homeland, Vietnam, seeking comfort in its familiar presence. The flower brought back comforting memories for her, so she bought one of the plants and returned home. After a discussion with her mother Saeng understands that she must cope with her new home, much like the flower must adapt to its new surroundings and learn to bloom in a different climate. By concluding the story with that stated sentence, the author is informing the reader that Saeng must “blossom” in her new home in order to do well. She still needs time for this, as the flower needs time to plant its roots into the ground, suggesting a period of nurturing and patience is required for her to fully settle in.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, most likely to show confidence that she would do everything over again if she had to. For example, the line "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" shows her resolve; so basically she's saying she's willing to take that step, that chance to try once more. The author ended the story with this sense of confidence and encouragement, leaving the reader with a powerful impression of Saeng's inner strength and her hopeful outlook for the future, a future where she is prepared to face her challenges anew.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” She does this to end on a note of hope, the hope of taking the test again and doing well. Also the author ends it this way because Saeng is believing in herself, so she made a vow to accomplish something specific. This personal promise will hopefully encourage her more and also motivate her to continue striving toward her goals, reinforcing her determination to succeed in her new life.

The author of this story concludes the story with a paragraph basically stating that the winter is coming and things are going to die off, then come back next spring. She's referring to the plant and its natural cycle of dormancy and rebirth. I think she is basically keeping track of the memories it left her and the thoughts that came to mind when she used her senses to connect with the flower, which provided her with a deep sense of comfort. Saeng is anxious to see how the flower buds next spring and what other new things she will experience, linking the flower's renewal to her own potential for new beginnings and personal discoveries in the coming year.

Well I think the author concludes the story like that because he is showing her attitude is better known now, as she is changing her perspective. She is going to put her mind to whatever she has to do, and she is going to take the test again with some pride and renewed determination. She will try again in the spring when the snow goes away, symbolizing a fresh start and a new beginning for her efforts. This ending highlights her personal growth and commitment to persevere despite previous setbacks, wrapping up her character arc on a positive and forward-looking note.

The author decides to end the story with the paragraph to show many things. First of all, the author uses the ending paragraph to show optimism. The whole story had been sad, but the ending shows some hope and a brighter future. In the beginning it says, “a sense of loss so deep…” and at the end it says, “I will take that test again.” This contrast shows how her attitude changes from cynical to hopeful and resilient. Another reason why the story is ended with that paragraph is to show how Saeng was accepting of her new environment. When the story says that the geese were “almost familiar to her now,” it demonstrates that even though Saeng is sad to leave her home, she is adapting quite well and finding a new sense of belonging. Therefore, the author ends the story with an inspiring paragraph to show change for the better and to emphasize the theme of personal adaptation and hope.

The author is concluding the story with that paragraph stating when spring and the warmer weather comes again, then she will take the test again. Meaning she will plant the flowers and get them to grow again, symbolizing her own regrowth and perseverance. Hoping she doesn’t fail at doing so, she draws strength from her cultural roots and memories. For example, the text mentions, "Mrs. Lambert liked it, this sharp bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue," which connects her to a comforting taste of home. This connection to her past gives her the courage to face the future and try once more, concluding the story with a sense of cyclical renewal and determined effort.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants to end it on a good note and send a good message that they are not going to quit simply because they failed the first time. The paragraph emphasizes the importance of resilience and the decision to try again. It shows that the character has learned from the experience and is choosing to move forward with hope rather than giving in to disappointment. This final thought leaves the reader with an uplifting feeling about the character's future prospects and inner strength, providing a satisfying and optimistic closure to the narrative journey.

I say the only reason why the author included that last paragraph was to show she was not going to give up easily. She was still going to take the test again, and she might get good luck from the hibiscus, which serves as a symbol of hope. Saeng was walking home one day from failing her driver’s test and she realizes that she recognizes a flower, so she went to a florist to see if she can buy it. When she does purchase it she goes home and gives it to her mom and they plant it together. So maybe it can bring back good memories from her home town or just good luck, I think, reinforcing her connection to her heritage and strengthening her resolve. This act of planting the flower represents putting down new roots and her determination to flourish in her new life, concluding her story with a powerful image of perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this passage because it is deeply symbolic. When the Geese come back in the spring, it will be like a new beginning, representing renewal and hope. When the Hibiscus is budding, it signifies the emergence of a new life from its dormant state. When all this happens, Saeng will have a new fresh start too, mirroring the natural cycles around her. Leaving the story to end like this is a cliff-hanger for some, creating a sense of anticipation. It makes you wanting more, and knowing she failed her test, you want to know if Saeng will pass it in the spring, which represents a fresh new start. Everything and everyone will have new starts when the beginning of the new season comes around; when the hibiscus blooms it will be like she has the new ability to overcome obstacles, forge new connections with her past, and find comfort during hard times. The Hibiscus powerfully symbolizes all this, tying her personal journey to the natural world.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because this is what the story was all about, focusing on Saeng's process of observation and learning. Saeng saw what happens in the winter, the dormancy and the challenges, and when it comes back around she trys to memorize it so that she can know what will happen and be better prepared. This act of memorization is her way of gaining control and understanding in her new environment, learning its patterns just as she learned the patterns of her old home. The ending thus emphasizes her determination to adapt and her growing familiarity with the cycles of her new life, showing that she is learning to navigate her world.

The author ends the story this way because by the time winter ends she will have adapted to her new society, just like the hibiscus adapts to the changing seasons. The hibiscus plant, which appears dormant during the cold months, holds the promise of blooming again with the return of spring. Similarly, Saeng is in a period of adjustment, and the coming spring symbolizes the point at which she will have grown more accustomed to her new life and surroundings. This parallel between the natural world and Saeng's personal journey provides a hopeful and resonant conclusion to her story of adaptation.

The young girl Saeng from the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, has moved from her home land of Vietnam to the United States, a difficult transition that leaves her feeling displaced. The young girl was hoping to get her drivers license but failed, an event that deepened her sense of isolation. The hibiscus she sees at the grocery store comforts her, strongly reminding her of Vietnam and the home she left behind. When she purchases it, her mother is initially concerned about the price but, upon seeing how home sick her daughter is, becomes understanding and supportive. After planting the Hibiscus in their new yard, She watches the geese flying overhead and understands that every year they change their habitat, migrating to survive and thrive. The geese inspire Saeng along with the Hibiscus, and she promises herself that "in the spring when the snow melts away, the geese return, and the Hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again," finding resolve in nature's cycles.

The author uses this paragraph because it works perfectly as an end, providing a sense of closure and new beginning. With this, Saeng tells her mother that once all the snow is gone she will take the test again, showing her renewed determination. If one reads between the lines, it says more than just this; it speaks to a deeper personal renewal. She really likes the hibiscus and when the hibiscus goes back to life in the spring, she will have new energy and inspiration to take the test again. From her experience with the hibiscus we can see that this plant really influenced her, because this plant reminds her so much of her old home and provides a tangible link to her past. Also we can see that everything and everybody should get a second chance, a theme central to the story. In her case it is the test she wants to take again, representing her second chance. Also, by the spring she will have lived a couple more months in the United States and she will have had more time to adjust herself to this new situation. At the moment she is just homesick, even if her home is the United States now, and she is still processing this change. So the hibiscus is good for her, it is something she can hold onto from her old home, a source of comfort and strength as she builds a new life.

The author, Minfong Ho, finishes the story like this to show the overcoming of obstacles. The story shows the many difficulties Saeng faces when leaving her old home and coming to her new one. In the day described, she fails a driver's test, doesn't eat lunch with her friend, and spends all her money on a plant from her old home, feeling a deep sense of displacement. Also, this paragraph shows how the hibiscus symbolizes her. The plant is not in its native home and faces many difficulties: the cold, its small pot, and even its general surroundings are harsh and unfamiliar. In every way, the plant is in the same circumstances as the main character, and the last paragraph is used to link them together, suggesting a shared resilience. This parallel reinforces the theme of enduring hardship in a new environment.

The reason why the author used this paragraph is because he was suggesting that the snow will go away in spring time, and that all the current hardships are temporary. Just as the winter landscape is bleak and unforgiving, Saeng's initial experiences in her new country are filled with failure and loneliness. However, the changing seasons promise a future thaw, a time for new growth and opportunity. The author uses this natural cycle to imply that Saeng's difficult period will also pass, giving way to a more hopeful chapter in her life. This connection to nature provides a sense of comfort and a reason for perseverance.

The last paragraph means only one thing: that one thing is to be like a hibiscus and to take the test again of life. She will come back in the spring just like the hibiscus will, ready to bloom once more after surviving the winter. So as you can see, the last paragraph had a very good meaning to it, emphasizing resilience and the capacity for renewal. It conveys a message of hope, showing that after a period of struggle, one can find the strength to begin anew. The character's resolve is mirrored in the plant's enduring life cycle.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph because this shows that Saeng is willing to change and she wants to do so by the time spring comes. By change, Saeng wants to feel comfortable in her new environment and be able to remember things from where she used to live without having to break down and cry from the painful memories. Also, the author uses the geese because they need to leave home every year and they deal with it, so Saeng can learn to deal with her migration as well. This observation provides her with a model of adaptation and survival, suggesting that such transitions, while difficult, are a natural part of life. The paragraph thus ends on a note of determined optimism for the future.

The reason why the author ends the story with that statement is because when you fail at something, you need time to dust yourself off and try again. When Saeng fails her driving test she is disappointed and feels a sense of defeat. After failing her test she went to a greenery where she saw flowers of her homeland, which stirred a deep nostalgia. There she bought the hibiscus, and it reminded her of how things were different back home and how things change when you go to a different place. Sometimes they aren't so pleasant at first, but you get used to them, just as she initially found the geese flying in a "V" formation to be strange, but now it is familiar to her. After failing her driving test, Saeng learns that even though things may change and present challenges, she needs to be able to try again and adapt to her new circumstances. This final realization underscores the story's central message of resilience and the importance of persevering through adversity.

She concluded the paragraph in that specific way to show that she is serious about her gardening and that she won’t garden until the geese come back, demonstrating her deep respect for the natural cycles and her commitment to not disrupting the wildlife. This firm decision underscores her principled stance on interacting with nature only when it is harmonious and non-invasive, thereby concluding her point with a clear and resolute statement of her values.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph they did because Saeng is a nature freak, which means she really likes nature and she would never ever hurt nature in her life. The author likely wanted to end off with a nice paragraph that reflects this core aspect of her character, emphasizing her profound connection to the natural world. Furthermore, the mention that she needs to take that test again introduces a parallel challenge in her human life, creating a balanced conclusion that touches on both her personal struggles and her unwavering environmental ethos.

The author concludes this story because it shows her determination and resilience. It clearly states that she will keep on attempting to make an adjustment to her life until she fully accepts her new home. The metaphor that as the buds grow so will she is powerful, indicating that her growth is more mental and emotional then physical. Her decision to take the test again signifies that she has faith in herself, believing she will mature and grow up to be a person who, while missing their home land, learns to accept and thrive in the new home that they live in. That is precisely why the author ended the narrative in this reflective and forward-looking manner.

She is saying here that she will start a new leaf when spring comes around; she is going to start anew and she is going to do better on her driving test. I think the author concluded with this paragraph because this shows that Saeng is not a quitter and she is going to try harder, embodying a spirit of perseverance. This final thought reinforces her character's resolve to face challenges head-on and improve herself, leaving the reader with a sense of hopeful anticipation for her future efforts and personal development.

The reserved items need to be checked keenly and with great attention to detail to ensure their condition and authenticity. This careful inspection is crucial for maintaining standards and verifying that all specifications are met according to the required protocols. A thorough examination will confirm their status and suitability for their intended purpose, thus concluding the verification process effectively.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the cold was brufield, or perhaps the author never wanted to be around while the cold was in session. At the time it was realy cold, a bitter and pervasive chill that seeped into everything. This final note on the weather serves to emphasize the harshness of the season, mirroring the internal struggles faced by the characters and providing a stark backdrop for the narrative's end.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. One being the fact that she wants to show sympathy for the hibiscus, highlighting its resilience. Another reason would be showing that Saeng wants to make her mother very proud of her, meaning that she doesn’t want her mom to think that she is going to give up after her failure. This also contributes to the reason that Saeng believes in herself and she truly thinks she can pass the test on her next attempt. Lastly I think that this last paragraph showed how Saeng wants people to know that even something as small and meaningless as a plant can help her overcome obstacles, and lead her to her dreams. The author chose this paragraph to end the story because of the main fact that how we know that Saeng will not stop believing in herself, no matter what challenges she faces.

The author of the story chooses to end the story with that sentence because the story is mainly about how Saeng failed her drivers test, but when she saw the hibiscus, it reminded her of home and made her feel better. In a preceding paragraph, Saeng says, “And that rich, sweet scent – that was familiar too," which talks about how nice the flowers were and how familiar they were because she recognized the scent from her past. Saeng was already upset about leaving her home, then coming to a new place and then failing her drivers test just made it worse, but then she saw the flower and it reminded her of her home, so she felt a little better and more determined. So when the author uses that quote, they end the story that way to show that she will have enough courage to try again when the flower blooms, symbolizing a new beginning.

The author concludes the story like that to show emphasis on Saeng's newfound resolve. Saeng vowed that so that it will teach her everything lives with hope and adaptation. She means that when everything returns and proves they can survive, she will too, drawing strength from nature's example. She will take that drivers test then, with renewed confidence. The author also wants to prove that people need to have faith in themselves, especially during difficult times. You just need to get used to their surroundings and find your own strength within them. This is why the author concluded that way, to leave the reader with a message of perseverance.

In stories, authors end them many different ways with many different effects. In the story, Winter Hibiscus, the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it has a “touching” effect on the reader and it basically sums up all the points talked about in the story. The first example is in the beginning of the conclusion, it says “Saeng vowed silently to herself”. In this unique quote, the author demonstrates imagery by giving you a mental picture of a silent, lonely girl kneeling down in the cold garden, whispering silently to herself, which creates a poignant moment.
