This quote and this part of the quote has a touching effect on the reader, evoking empathy. Another example of why the author concludes the story with this is because it sums up all the parts covered in the story. "When the geese return and the hibiscus is budding I will take that test again". This quote mentions the hibiscus which is mentioned a lot throughout, the geese in the end, and the failing of the test in the beginning, tying the narrative together. In conclusion, that’s why the author used that paragraph as the conclusion for such a touching story, providing a satisfying and resonant closure.

The author concludes in the story that Saeng failed a winter test, and because of her love of the hibiscus plant, the coming of spring will help her take the test again. The hibiscus, which appears to die in the cold, is a symbol of resilience, as it blooms once more with the warmer weather. This cycle of death and rebirth mirrors Saeng's own experience with failure and her subsequent hope for renewal. Her connection to the plant gives her the strength to face her challenges anew, believing that the new season will bring a fresh opportunity for her to succeed where she once did not.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wanted the reader to know that just because Saeng failed, it does not mean her life is over. The failure is presented not as an ending, but as a temporary setback from which she will recover. The narrative emphasizes that Saeng will recuperate and gather her resolve to attempt the same thing again the following year. This conclusion reinforces a message of perseverance, showing that resilience is defined by the willingness to try again after a disappointment, thus providing a hopeful and encouraging end to her story.

The author uses this paragraph to conclude the story to show she is going to give the test another try as well as embrace her new surroundings. For example, the story says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This statement indicates that she is gradually getting used to her new environment and is now willing to give it a genuine chance. It is as if she no longer finds it as foreign or unwelcoming as she first did when everything was different from her home. This growing familiarity fuels her determination to try again, integrating her past struggles with her present adaptability.

Maybe the author wrote that as the last sentence or paragraph because in the story the character did something and failed at it, so she wants to do it again. The failure is not depicted as a final outcome but rather as a moment that sparks a decision to persevere. This ending focuses on the character's internal resolve and her commitment to not giving up after a single setback. It highlights a universal theme of learning from failure and the importance of a second attempt, concluding the narrative on a note of quiet determination and forward-looking hope.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” ends this story with that closing paragraph because it wraps up all the themes seamlessly. It shows that Saeng has the determination to overcome obstacles, and it uses the plant as a metaphor, just like the rest of the story. The Hibiscus represents Saeng or the process of adjusting to change. The plant “dies” in the winter, and this is equivalent to Saeng not getting her driver's license, but the plant will come back, representing determination and adjustment. This is precisely why Saeng says she will go back and pass the test; because she has adjusted to her new life and is now determined to overcome this specific obstacle, mirroring the plant's cyclical and resilient nature.

After reading the quote "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test," from the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, I think the author is trying to say that after the winter and fall pass she will be up to the challenge to plant again and feel good about herself. The sight of the migrating geese, a symbol of seasonal change and return, seems to solidify her resolve. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive "V" was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance. Reflecting back I feel Saeng felt that the geese were secretly letting her know what she was doing was right, affirming her decision to try again when conditions were more favorable, just as nature renews itself.

He ends the story this way to show that she wants to and is willing to overcome the difficulty of leaving her homeland. In the story she goes to a greenhouse, a place filled with life, to test herself and her connection to her new environment. She finds a plant from her homeland, a hibiscus, and it reminds her of her grandmother and the life she left behind. She finds other plants and they remind her of her homeland and she cries, overwhelmed by the memories. I think she had a real connection with her grandmother, so these botanical reminders were deeply poignant. When they left their home country she probably cried for days; it's like she lost a part of her soul, and the greenhouse visit brought all those feelings back to the surface before allowing her to begin healing.

The author includes this paragraph into the story because the girl started giving up on herself and felt sad from moving to the United States and also from failing her driver's test, but lastly about the plant that she bought that wasn’t real, which felt like one more failure. Also because he wanted to show that her self esteem had gone up and that she was more confident and wasn’t gonna give up on herself. This shift is crucial, marking her transition from despair to a quiet determination to persevere despite the setbacks she has faced in her new life.

The author leaves the story with those words because it shows the reader a large metaphor in the story; although unfinished, it is self-explanatory that the metaphor compares Saeng and her test to the perennial nature of the winter hibiscus. They both have something in common, which is that they both come back; Saeng comes back to complete her test, while the winter hibiscus comes back, buds, and lives again with each new season. I can relate to this because I remember I entered a triathlon, and my goal was to place first; I placed second overall, then next year came, and I trained until the triathlon came again, and I placed first, so like the winter hibiscus, I came back and completed my goal, demonstrating the power of resilience and cyclical renewal.

The author includes that part in his story because it’s talking about nature and the beautiful things in nature. There’s the oak trees, tall green grass, the white picket fence, and in the story there are those same types of things that are seen in nature, which serve to create a vivid and tranquil setting. These natural elements provide a backdrop that contrasts with or reflects the internal state of the characters, grounding the narrative in a tangible, sensory world that enhances the overall theme of growth and belonging.

The author views the hibiscus plant as a new start, a symbol of her renewed determination. For example, when she says, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” she is connecting her own future to the plant's cycle. She failed the first time and got the plant; the next time, with the hibiscus as her emblem of hope, she’ll pass it. This parallel between the natural world and her personal resolve underscores the theme of new beginnings.

The author includes these paragraphs in the story to highlight the significance of the seasonal shift from winter to spring, when the snows melt and the geese return. The text describes the transition from a cold, dormant winter, where snow persists, to the arrival of spring, when the warmth of the sun causes the snow to gradually melt away. One reason for this focus is that the author is talking about how the changing weather mirrors internal changes, using the environment to reflect a shift in the character's own situation and mood.

She was upset with herself because she bought the hibiscus plant and not the seeds, feeling she had taken a shortcut. So she starts crying because she remembered how pretty their old one used to be and how this new plant felt like an inadequate replacement. Her declaration that when the snow melts and the flowers start to bloom is when she is going to take the test again links her personal goal to the natural cycle. The author ended the paragraph like that to show a new beginning next year, using the seasons to frame the character's resolve for a fresh start.

I believe that she included this because she wanted to show how important it was to her, emphasizing the depth of her commitment. For example, when she says in the spring she will take the test again, it is a promise to herself. I think that meant she will work harder and prepare more thoroughly to make sure she does everything right this time. So that she can say she follows through on things that are important to her, proving her own resilience and dedication. These are my thoughts on why she included this paragraph in the story, as it reveals her core motivation.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for a few key reasons. First, Saeng failed the test, and the paragraph addresses her response to that failure. Second, it takes time for a hibiscus to bud, which parallels the time and patience she will need to prepare for her next attempt. Finally, it sounds like a good ending because it is hopeful, and plus, she would not want to take the test in the snow, making the spring a more fitting time for a new beginning. This conclusion ties her personal journey to the natural world, providing a sense of closure and forward-looking optimism.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to let the readers know how Saeng feels about the hibiscus. I think the author concludes this because he is telling the reader that the hibiscus gives Saeng good luck and with this good luck she will pass the test. In the story it tells us how much Saeng adores the plant. For example, when she got to the hibiscus she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, a sensation that comforted her. That's why the author uses that paragraph at the end to indicate how Saeng values the hibiscus and how its presence makes her feel confident and hopeful for her next attempt.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to leave readers guessing and wondering what will be next. You can tell by the tone of the last paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author seems to leave a tone of suspense, creating a sense of anticipation for Saeng's future actions. This unresolved feeling makes the reader contemplate her determination and the challenges that still lie ahead, effectively drawing the narrative to a thoughtful close.

By ending the story in the way the author has in the short story “The Winter Hibiscus,” the author provides a sympathetic understanding for the reader of Saeng and her struggle to live in another country and her sadness of wishing to be back home. I think the author was attempting to end the story with a strong feeling for a strong note of Saeng's personality to draw the reader back into what they had just read. For example, by repeating the statement on the test saying “I will take that test again,” the author gives us that understanding that Saeng has not given up and lets the reader know she will stand and live strong, reinforcing her resilient character. This final impression emphasizes her inner strength and resolve to persevere despite her hardships.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because now she has something to work for. The author could have also put this conclusion here because she must wait that long till she can take it again; also, Saeng could wait to see the plant grow and get bigger and stronger, mirroring her own personal growth. These are reasons why I think the author chose to conclude with this paragraph, as it ties her future efforts to the natural cycle of the hibiscus, symbolizing hope and renewal. This connection provides a meaningful end to her current struggles and looks forward to a new beginning.

The author concludes the story here to show that Saeng would not give up. She simply set a time for her to try again. Saeng wants to make it in this world and wants to have a good life, so she tries new things and refuses to be defeated by her initial failure. This ending highlights her perseverance and her willingness to adapt and prepare for future challenges, demonstrating a resilient spirit that defines her character and brings the story to a fitting conclusion.

The story "Winter Hibiscus" is a good-day story about a foreign girl named Saeng trying to adapt to her new life in a cold climate. She likes tropical flowers, which remind her of her former home. The reason why the author chose to write the last paragraph like that is because it finishes the story right, providing a sense of hopeful resolution. That ending, when the old man goes away and the winter hibiscus flowers start to grow, suggests she will try to fit in and find her place when the spring arrives, symbolizing a new beginning.

I think the author used this paragraph for the ending because its meaning fails obviously; Saeng really likes the garden and it is something special to her, a deep connection to her past. Also, when all the snow finally melts away, she will take the driving test again and hopefully get her driver's license, marking a step forward in her new life. This conclusion ties her personal growth to the changing seasons, showing her determination to succeed.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it emphasizes the theme of new beginnings. What I mean by this is that the hibiscus represents new beginnings and personal resilience. She says, “When the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This will be a new start for her, a fresh attempt at overcoming challenges. The plant blooming makes her happy and fondly reminds her of her grandmother and her heritage. She is saying that by the time the spring comes around, she would be ready for a new obstacle, just as the hibiscus plant is ready to bloom.

I believe the author chooses to end the story with this paragraph because it symbolizes closure and acceptance. The plant represents her home and her past. But she realizes by the sight of the geese flying south that everyone has to leave home at some point, a natural part of life. She has now come to terms with what is happening around her, and she will try again for her driver's license soon. When the hibiscus buds again it will be symbolic to her, representing renewal, and that is precisely when she will be ready to try once again with renewed hope.

I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph because she is showing she is trying and that she wants another chance to succeed. She realized her mistakes and is ready to start over, learning from her experiences. Even though she failed by trying to grow her hibiscus in the winter, she is trying to start over when the spring comes in. For example, in the story, it stated the "winter hibiscus" was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it; overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and yet familiar to Saeng. This imagery connects her effort to the natural world, which is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she thinks it will bring her good luck in the test. When she goes back to take the test she will have the comfort of her home land and the hibiscus plant to encourage her to pass the driving test. When she takes the test again she will be more likely to pass due to the comfort of home, and she will be more used to the area, even though it is different from her homeland. In order for her to do well in the test she needs something to help her have a little bit more confidence in herself. Having things to remind her of home and the house that she lives at now, like the planted hibiscus, can help her a lot in being confident in herself and provide the emotional support she needs to succeed.

She said that she was going to take the test again because she wanted to show her mom that she can do it and pass it this time. This decision represents a shift in her focus, as she is now concentrating on her future efforts and proving her capability instead of worrying over her old home and the past that she left behind. Her motivation is now firmly rooted in a desire for personal achievement and making her mother proud.

I think that this shows hope because she had really missed her homeland and kind of found peace and serenity by being around the flowers; she says “That at least she could hold on to,” meaning the bud. I think that she was very upset because of missing home; she missed having her grandmother wash her hair and put a dok mallk into it. Since she really had nothing else but the flowers that reminded her of her homeland—the text said “where was the fine toothed comb, the hibiscus hedge, the well, her gentle grandmother”—she was missing all these things. So I think that by putting her in this position, it has brought her to a place where she not only misses the people from her homeland but the beautiful things as well, and how she always has a part of home with her because of the flower, which serves as a tangible connection to her memories and her identity.

In the last paragraph the reason why the author uses "when they come back, in the spring when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test" is because Saeng finally had found comfort. After moving from her homeland Vietnam to the United States, she felt homesick. For example, she comes across this flower that reminds her of the time she spent in her homeland. She remembers her grandmother's smell because of the plant. So when she finally got home to her mother, she showed the flower to her. They both planted the flower, and Saeng got a sense of relief. That's why she vowed that when winter was over and spring came she would take that test, because she had a sense of home in her that gave her encouragement and strength. It also shows that even when you are in a different area and you are new, there's always something that can make you remember the love and time spent where you came from, providing a foundation of comfort and confidence.

The author concludes the story like this because it shows that she is determined to pass the test. The seasonal imagery reinforces her resolve; it is also like if the birds can fly south for the winter and return in the spring, then she too can overcome her challenge and pass that test. This connection to the natural cycle of departure and return gives her a sense of hope and the belief that her own success is just as inevitable with patience and timing.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author does this for several reasons. Primarily, the author wants to show you that Saeng still has hope and that she believes she can make it right, demonstrating her resilient spirit. Also, it is to show Saeng will still try and adapt to her surrounding and make friends, embracing her new life. Saeng is also determined that she will pass the test next time she takes it, showing her commitment to overcoming her challenges. Last, it is emphasizing the central conflict and how Saeng ultimately overcame it through her perseverance and newfound resolve. This final vow solidifies her character growth and provides a satisfying conclusion to her journey.

I believe the author ended this story with this paragraph because life lives on. The statement, "When the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," proves that she's moving on with life and so will all the creatures in the world, following the natural cycle of the seasons. Also, even though she moved to a new country doesn’t mean she can’t still enjoy the things from her homeland, as shown when she admits, “but she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to the Big Mac.” That is precisely why the author put that last paragraph in, to show that life lives on and one can find continuity and comfort in familiar things while moving forward. The ending beautifully ties together the themes of renewal and cultural persistence.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she really isn't worried about when they take the test again; she is only concerned with the plants she picked out, which hold a deeper significance for her. Also, she knows that it will be a really long time before she takes the test again, so that gives her more time to study and get more prepared and focused for the next attempt. The author also ends this article with this paragraph because she wants to let the readers know that since she failed the first time, she will be back again to take it over and nothing will stop her from succeeding. This determination highlights her unwavering commitment to her goal, ensuring the reader is left with a sense of her resolve rather than her initial failure.

It shows not to give up, it ends almost the same way it began, and it shows that people should not stay too attached to the past; each are reasons why I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph. It shows that people should not give up because even though she failed her test then, she will try again later to pass it, demonstrating resilience. Also, the story ends the same way it begins by her taking the test or getting ready to, which is a good way of writing and provides a sense of narrative symmetry. One last thing is that it shows that people shouldn’t become too attached to the past because if they look at one thing that reminds them of it they might fall apart; that is why she takes the test, to see if she can look at the familiar flowers without falling apart and prove her emotional strength. This conclusion effectively reinforces the story's central themes of perseverance and moving forward.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to end on a happy yet motivating note, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism. In the story, Saeng says that she failed the test and was very disappointed with herself, which underscores the test's significance. The test must have been very important to her for her to be so disappointed, likely representing a major life goal. The author also probably ended with this paragraph to show that Saeng is devoted to passing this test, highlighting her persistent nature. Saeng seems like a sentimental yet reliable person, which makes her vow to try again feel genuine and earned. I believe that the test is to spend a minimal amount of money and she wants to earn respect from her mom, making her success deeply personal. That is why taking and passing the test seems so important to Saeng, and the author's ending perfectly captures this driving motivation and her hopeful spirit.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author concludes the story with the lines “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason that the author concludes the story with these lines is because she is re-establishing the symbolism of the plant. In the text it said that the plant buds in the spring, once it has time to grow and adapt to the new environment. Just as the plant needed that time, so did the main character Saeng. She just moved from Vietnam and failed her drivers test. Saeng is very unsure of her new culture. For example she likes bitter melon; it says, “But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself much preferred it to a Big Mac.” She appears to think she is misunderstood and that no one likes her, but just as the plant will adapt to this new life so will she, finding her own strength in time.

The author concludes the story by saying she will take the test again in the spring and until then vows silently because the spring reminded Saeng of home. In Vietnam there were many beautiful wild flowers. Saeng goes to the flower shop to get a piece of home. It said the flower's "leaves quivering in the wind." This shows that the plant was not the same because there were also no buds, indicating it was dormant. She had just failed her driving test before this and needed hope, so all waiting till spring when the hibiscus will bloom again will give Saeng a sense of home which will give her the hope and confidence to do good on the driving test. The connection to her homeland provides the comfort she needs to persevere.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng's whole world is tied to the plants, and since they are gone with the winter, there is no motivation for her in this new, cold environment. The dormant hibiscus represents her own current state of inactivity and discouragement after failing her test. However, the promise of its return in spring mirrors her own potential for renewal. She will find her motivation again when the natural world, and the plant that symbolizes her home, comes back to life, allowing her to try again.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author’s reasoning for saying this is because the presence of memories from Saeng’s homeland comforts her. So much so that she will pass her test with ease because she will not be as nervous. “It was like walking into another world,” said Saeng, when she entered the florist shop after failing her drivers test. It was almost as if she completely forgot about failing and was only thinking about the plants and flowers. The flowers take her to a happy peace and make her feel at home, like everything is going to be alright. This is why the author concludes with such a sentence, because it shows the reader how memories of her homeland will give her the calm and assurance needed to help her pass her drivers test.

The author may have concluded the story like that because of the title and the beginning of the story, which establish the hibiscus as a key symbol. Or he may have concluded the story like that because he wants to show a character's growth and determination. He may have concluded the story like that to show what will happen in the future for Saeng, linking her personal journey to the cycles of nature. It is a good conclusion because it provides a sense of hope and resolution, completing the narrative arc.

I really do not know why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. Possibly because she started to talk about the enduring nature of life and the resilience required to face new challenges, which mirrors the protagonist's own journey. The paragraph serves as a subtle reflection on the themes of continuity and personal growth that have been woven throughout the narrative, providing a final, quiet emphasis on the character's internal resolve without overtly stating it, thereby allowing the reader to fully absorb the story's emotional weight and underlying message of perseverance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's determination. Saeng has been through a lot and misses what it's like at home. She feels different and out of place but she is still strong. Life goes on, and this paragraph shows that Saeng will move with it. The paragraph says, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Spring will come, as nothing can stop time. The snow will melt because the weather changes. The geese will fly home and the hibiscus will bloom in spring. Saeng takes a positive look at things and decides to join them, aligning her own personal timeline with the natural, inevitable cycles of renewal. Sure she failed once but she is strong and willing to try again. If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again. Saeng will always have her memories of home but she is willing to change to her new surroundings, finding strength in her past while bravely facing her future. The concluding paragraph shows Saeng’s determination to succeed and survive in the new world, framing her resolve within the comforting certainty of the changing seasons.

The author concludes the story saying that because she wants to show us that Saeng is confident in herself and will not hesitate to take the test again. This final action of digging a hole is a physical manifestation of her newfound resolve, a deliberate step toward planting something new and hopeful. She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground, a simple yet powerful gesture that signifies her commitment to growth and putting down roots in her new environment, symbolizing her readiness to nurture her future despite past setbacks.

The author concludes with this paragraph to give a sense of hope and growth. The flower represents Saeng's homeland, and it makes her feel comforted, serving as a tangible link to her past. It connects her with her emotions and reminds her of the way things are, grounding her in a familiar symbol of beauty and resilience. The growth and flourishing of the hibiscus corresponds to the flourishing of Saeng herself, each new bud a promise of potential. When it blooms, she will have a true piece of home with her, and will be able to take the test again with renewed spirit. The story is about overcoming obstacles and adjusting to change. The visual, and nearly lyrical expression of the blooming hibiscus makes the reward and result of your struggles seem so much more beautiful and attainable, transforming the abstract concept of success into a vivid, natural event that the reader can easily envision and believe in.

The author concludes this story with hope in this sentence. The beginning was very negative with Saeng failing her driver's test and her mother yelling at her, creating a sense of despair and failure. But when this sentence comes the reader is filled with hope for the young girl Saeng, as the narrative tone shifts from one of defeat to one of quiet optimism. The author does this to show that Saeng will adjust and will persevere whereas before she was so upset, evident when she said, “I-I failed the test.” Then for Saeng to rebound from this event, to find a source of inner strength and a plan for the future, gave the reader hope and that's why the author did this, leaving us with a powerful impression of the character's resilience and the promise of a brighter tomorrow.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it reinforces the theme of a new beginning. Since Saeng failed the test, and in the winter the plant will die, the author draws a parallel to the natural cycle of life. In the spring the plant will bud again, symbolizing renewal, and she will retake the test. Its a new chance to start things over, mirroring the rebirth seen in nature each year.

Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, she would try again. Saeng didn't really like to talk very much and often preferred quiet reflection. Saeng liked to be by her self sometimes, finding comfort in her own company. When spring come it was a different story, as the world awakened around her. Saeng loved the spring and the warm sunshine. She would play outside all day every day, enjoying the fresh air. Saeng was just a nice girl who appreciated the simple joys of the season.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that the character will retry what she failed, demonstrating her resilience. In the story the character loves gardening, so the author uses this passion to symbolize hope. When her favourite plant comes back with the changing seasons, she will retry to pass her test, linking her personal growth to the natural world's cycle of death and rebirth.

The author concludes the story with that because as winter come every thing goes away and enters a period of rest. Like the trees lose the leaves, the geese fly south, and the flower die off, all signs of life recede. So this passage is saying in the spring time when every thing comes back to life, she will start the test again. it is like to start a new life back over, using the seasonal transformation as a metaphor for her own fresh start and renewed determination.

In the story called "The Winter Hibiscus" the author concludes with this paragraph: "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, than I will take that test again." The reason the author included this was because when things go underground or seem to end, everyone wants to wait until they come back up again. This is similar to failure; when you fail everything goes down, but if you wait awhile and persevere, everything will start to rise again, just like flowers and other natural things. So that is why the author put that at the end of the story, to tell people that it is ok to fail as long as you get up and try again until you reach your goal. The author, Minfong Ho, placed this there so that readers could understand this message of hope and resilience from the text.

The author concludes the story with that last paragraph to definitively set the final mood and tone. The author wanted to show that Saeng will not give up and she will continue to adapt to her new surroundings with quiet determination. It made the end of the story feel warm and it also inspired a sense of hopeful resilience. The end of the story encourages the reader to not give up as well when facing their own personal challenges. The last paragraph sets an example of how the reader can vow to improve as well, drawing strength from Saeng's resolve. The author knew that the last paragraph would stand as an inspiration and maybe help a reader going through something similar to the story, offering a message of perseverance.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because to her the plant seems to remind her of her homeland which calms her and when it is budding she feels stronger and more connected to her roots. In the story Saeng is kind of an outsider and when she sees the plant she sees a tangible part of her past back home, a comforting link to her previous life. In the story it says she gets shaky when she tries to say “at home,” revealing her emotional turmoil. When she says “and this hibiscus is budding,” I think it is really saying when she is ready to accept this country as her home because the flower is a familiar reminder of her homeland now thriving in a new place. At the end of the story it says how she is getting used to the geese flying in a “V” so she is getting more used to this country and its rhythms, and when she is ready she will take her test again with renewed hope.

The author includes the paragraph, "when they come back...then I will take that test again," to show that hibiscus is a symbol of time and the natural cycles of life. Saeng uses the hibiscus to measure the amount of time there will be until she takes her test again, using its bloom as a personal deadline. The hibiscus also symbolizes the power to get through struggling and to stay strong during difficult periods of adjustment. Saeng had trouble with her test, but the hibiscus is there to help push her through it emotionally to prepare her for the next test she will face. The hibiscus also helps Saeng's mother push through her hard time of seeing her daughter sad from not succeeding on the test, sharing in the symbolic comfort. The plant helps the mother try and stay positive and it also helps the mother by trying to do the right thing for her daughter to lift her spirits. In the story, the mother decides to plant the hibiscus in the garden to make her daughter happy, a nurturing act of love. The hibiscus shows strong symbolism and it helps Saeng and her mother stay strong throughout their struggles in a new land.

This final paragraph goes along with one of the main premises of the story, which is the theme of perseverance. To not quit and keep going in order to understand and be happy in this world is the central lesson Saeng learns. Saeng is taking this “test” to see if she's ready to change and adapt to her new environment, a test of her spirit and resilience. She failed this time, experiencing a setback in her journey of adaptation. But when all is right and the hibiscus is ready to bloom once more, she will try again to see if she's ready to let go of the old and be happy with the new, demonstrating her unwavering commitment to growth.

She said it because she didn’t do what she was supposed to, so she said she failed; her mother was mad for a second but then stopped, her anger quickly replaced by understanding. She said "I love it" and asked if she wanted something to eat, so they went inside, a simple act that showed familial support. But she took the task as a test of her own abilities and resolve, so she said next time I will do it right, vowing to learn from her mistake and succeed in the future.

I believe the author ended the story with the "test" because it is a big part of Saeng’s life and a significant part of her tradition. The driving test represents a rite of passage in her new country, a necessary step for independence and integration. This final focus on the test connects her past traditions with her present challenges, showing how she must navigate new customs while holding onto her heritage. The test is not just a single event but a symbol of the ongoing journey she must undertake, blending the old with the new in her life.

There are many reasons why the author concludes the story with that paragraph. First, that ending gives a lot of emotion which doesn't cause people to think the story wasn't interesting; instead, it provides a powerful, resonant feeling. Another reason is that it shows strength. Not physical strength, but mental strength and resilience. Saeng is stating that even though she failed the test the first time she will take it again, demonstrating her determination. Another reason the author may have used this paragraph to conclude the story is to show people to never quit. It shows how she failed and her mom was disappointed but she is not going to quit and take the driver’s test again, embodying a persistent spirit. Overall the author concludes the story with the paragraph because it gives off a great image to keep trying and never give up, leaving the reader with a lasting impression of hope.

The author most likely concludes the story with this sentence because it shows how dedicated the author and her child are to gardening, highlighting their shared bond. I am guessing that the young child’s favorite plant is the hibiscus, which holds special meaning for them. I think that the mother and her child’s favorite thing to do together would be gardening, a activity that strengthens their relationship. This is a nice way to end a story, providing a sense of warmth and continuity. It gives the reader kind of a look of question on their faces, prompting them to wonder. It leaves them suspicious of why the author did that, creating intrigue. But in my opinion I think it adds some curiosity to the story, making the ending more engaging and thought-provoking.

The final lines of the story, "Winter Hibiscus," are meant to provide a glimpse into the near future, to show a change in Saeng's attitude. Up until this point Saeng had been lamenting her old country, and not adjusting well to her new one. The Hibiscus inspires her, and lets her know that the new country has many of the same things as her old country, offering a sense of familiarity. In this last line, she comes to terms with her present situation and finds a new resolve. "When the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding," is a way of saying she’s going to let a little time pass, and by taking her driver’s test again, she will begin her new life with renewed hope and acceptance.

The author concluded the story with saying that Saeng will retake the driving test in the spring to prove a point about resilience. When walking home from her test, Saeng saw a familiar flower and chose to make a detour to a flower shop. There, she saw many flowers that reminded her of home, sparking memories and connections. She bought a hibiscus and went home, where her and her mother planted it, after Saeng realized the flower could make it through the winter, symbolizing endurance. She looked up to see many birds flying overhead and she realized that she has adapted to her life in this new location. The hibiscus has given her the will to survive and she knows she can adapt to life here, finding strength in its presence. The point the author wanted to get across was that the hibiscus gave courage and hope to retake her driver’s test and continue surviving, demonstrating how small connections can foster great personal strength.

The reason I think the author concludes this story with this last paragraph is because this is Saeng's true passion. And that Saeng is very dedicated and will do this every year. She really loves plants and she will wait to do it again, looking forward to the next spring. The last paragraph really showed a lot of dedication to her craft and her connection to nature. And she really values the spring and the Hibiscus, seeing it as a symbol of renewal and personal commitment. This cyclical return to her passion underscores her resilient and hopeful spirit.

The author concludes the story with this line to show that just like the hibiscus, adapting and struggling to survive and fit in in its non-native land, Saeng will too. She will not give up her fight to pass the test to become a part of her new country. This is supported through out the story when her mother comments on the hibiscus by the lake. She says, “It’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters” (Ho). Here the author shows the comparison between the hibiscus' struggle through hard times in a foreign land similarly felt in Saeng’s life. Both must be strong and fight through hard times where no one, “not even her classmates or friends, or Mrs. Lambert” (Ho), understood how alone and out of place she felt. So just as she vows to take the test again, she's promising herself she will fight through the hard times to grow strong, just as her winter hibiscus does each year, embodying a parallel journey of perseverance.

Primarily why she said that was she was saying with time comes change and cause. She was basically saying in a while when things change again she believes that her performance could change as well, improving with the passing seasons. I depicted this by the idea you can tell that she is beginning to get over missing her home in Vietnam and that is a memory; with time, change comes along. That is a simple aspect of logic that with time comes change. But I think as much I did properly interpret the aspect of what this is supposed to mean overall, capturing the essence of gradual transformation. But otherwise and finally I believed Saeng said this because time brings change, and she is learning to trust in that natural process for her own life.

The importance as to why the author ended this story like this was to show readers the importance of the plant to the main character. It seems that because the author is not in her native country that she doesn’t have a lot around in this new place that can comfort her or feel familiar. The author, through Saeng, being able to find a hibiscus in a place she thought she wouldn’t be able to, gives her strength to do anything that she can. It is possible that whatever the challenge may be that the author is trying to get through, the fact that she has some support from the plant gives her the achievement and confidence to complete her task. This connection to the hibiscus serves as a vital source of emotional sustenance and resilience in her new environment, making the ending profoundly significant.

The author concludes the story with this because the hibiscus and Saeng are very similar in their resilience. Also the narrator compares her to the geese returning, which symbolizes new beginnings and persistence. The geese returning represents her starting over at driver's school and doing it again, refusing to be defeated by failure. The hibiscus represents her staying strong in the winter and then, come spring, she builds up her strength and goes to take the test again. That is what the narrator chose to end the story that way, to highlight this powerful theme of cyclical renewal and enduring strength in the face of adversity.

The reason why the author concludes the story like this is for the character to have a fresh beginning. I mean to me I think that it means she is going to try again when spring comes, so her and her plant can have a fresh start together. The plant's new growth in the spring parallels her own resolve to begin anew, and I think that is a good and hopeful way to end the story, emphasizing renewal and second chances.

The author concludes the story with, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” for several distinct reasons. One reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the hibiscus flower will be adapting to the spring season just like Saeng should adapt to her new environment in the United States. Another reason is that, like the hibiscus budding, Saeng has began to grow older and much wiser of things, allowing her to go back in the spring and hopefully pass the driving test with newfound confidence. Lastly, in the text it says, “she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This shows Saeng is becoming familiar and at ease now of where she is living, just how the hibiscus flower adapts to its place with ease and gets used to the changing seasons, symbolizing her personal growth and acclimatization.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is saying that when she comes back she will take the test over again, which means that in a form the entire experience was a test of survival. When the story begins it is the beginning of the test, and at the end of the story the test concludes with their leaving, and she wants to come back to see what grew from her efforts. The author is also saying that you don’t know how good you have it until you face challenges and reflect upon them, highlighting a theme of appreciation and perspective gained through struggle.

Because the "Winter hibiscus" was in the ground now and Saeng tamped down the soil firmly around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and -Yes- familiar to Saeng now. This moment signifies a connection to her new home, as the planted hibiscus represents putting down roots and the geese's call symbolizes a comforting and recognized part of her changing world, completing her arc of settling in.

The author includes this paragraph in the story because it shows an impression on work ethic and how adaption to a new environment can be difficult. The phrase “not even the teacher looked at it" makes a dislike for the work apparent; for a student that is new, not receiving good feedback can damage their work ethic and that will issue them mentally also. Therefore the girl is not comfortable and not enthused to working on something that none would appreciate, leading to a feeling of discouragement and isolation in her efforts to adapt.

The author concludes with this because she is determined to pass the driving test that she had previously failed. For example, she writes, “she vowed silently to herself.” When you vow to do something it usually means that you are very determined to do something, and this internal promise signifies a deep commitment. Everything else that she says after that she really means it, reinforcing her unwavering resolve. Therefore, that is why the author concludes with this sentence, in order to show her devotion and steadfast commitment to her goal of ultimately succeeding.

The author of the story, *Winter Hibiscus*, concluded the story with that paragraph because the author wanted to show that Saeng is finally going to start getting used to her new home. She won’t spend so much time dreaming about her past, having confronted her memories and emotions directly. The line, “And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept,” represents a crucial emotional release. I believe that that's what she needed to get on with her life, allowing her to move forward from that point on.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to let us know when she’ll take it again, specifying that it will be when the seasons change. Saeng is probably embarrassed by her failure, which is why she wants to wait so long before attempting the test again. Earlier, Saeng took a long walk home and stopped at the flower shop, attempting to get her mind off failing the test. She brought a nice flower or plant for her mother, who was upset at first but then realized her daughter wasn't happy and changed her mood to one of understanding and support.

I believe that the author concluded the story with this because he is saying that she will keep trying and will not give up, demonstrating her persistent spirit. I say this because she just moved to America from Vietnam and is having a hard time adjusting to life in America, facing numerous challenges. I think the geese represent something that is always changing their surroundings, much like Saeng herself, and when they come she is going to fly again to get her license, symbolizing her readiness for a new attempt when the time is right.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because now she has something to work for, a clear goal that gives her purpose. The author could have also put this concludes the story with this paragraph because she must wait that long till she can take it again, implying a period of growth and waiting. Furthermore, Saeng could want to wait to see the plant grow and get bigger and stronger, mirroring her own personal development. These are the reasons why I think the author chose to conclude the story with this particular paragraph.

Saeng vowed silently that in the spring she will take the test again. It is a good ending to this story because the narrative had concluded on a note of resilience and hope. Spring is a beautiful time, a season of renewal for all plants, and this ending is fitting because spring is near, symbolizing Saeng's trying again. She is ready to take the test again at that time of year, and she thinks it’s a good ending because the ruler is strong, about machines, Saeng, and spring. It makes the future feel near. That is why it is a good ending; the plant continues to live, and so does her hope.

The author ends with this because of what the hibiscus means to Saeng. To her it is a potent symbol of strength and comfort, a reminder of her own capacity to endure. She knows that if the hibiscus can survive the snow and the cold weather of the winter, she knows that she will not fail either, drawing a direct parallel to her own struggles. To her, the hibiscus is a symbol of herself and if it survives the harsh season, she knows that she too can survive and thrive. She is also going to take the test again when the hibiscus are budding since their blooming reminds her of her homeland and comforts her, giving her courage. Then even if she fails she will still be happy since her favorite plant is budding, a small but significant victory. Finally I think the author ended this way because of what the plant means to Saeng; if it survives she knows that she too will survive, and life goes on, continuing its cycle.

I believe the author concluded the story with “When they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” because it shows the entire theme of the story. The theme of this story is adjusting to things in life and finding the strength to persevere. The conclusion demonstrates this when she says she will take the test again, showing her resolve. The hibiscus allowed her to get over the changes in life by providing a tangible link to her past. For example, “The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother's long grey hair," shows how the flower evokes powerful, comforting memories. The hibiscus encouraged her to accept her new life and keep trying to make it better, providing the solace she needed to move forward.

The author most likely concludes the story that way because that is the time that Saeng feels most comfortable and connected to her roots. Saeng and her mom moved from Vietnam, where the hibiscus plants are popular and familiar to Saeng, making them a cherished symbol of home. She ends the text in this manner because it reminds Saeng about Vietnam, and how she feels better and more secure during that time of year when the plant blooms. When she says “And beside it was yet another old friend,” she feels as if this plant is a true friend to her and it makes her feel more comfortable in her new environment. This connection to a familiar and comforting symbol from her past is why the author ended the story in the manner that she did, emphasizing solace and familiarity.

The author concludes the story with this saying because it will be a fresh start and it will be spring, a time that is beautiful and full of potential. The phrase is telling me that she wants another try, a new beginning. She wants a fresh start, and come spring when all of her pretty flowers are blooming and getting their chance to shine, she wants her own new chance to pass her test. This parallel between the natural world’s renewal and her personal resolve creates a hopeful and fitting conclusion to her story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because of her sadness and regret for what she did. The test she was telling about was how she was supposed to use the twenty dollars they had for a practical purpose, but instead she ended up buying a Big @CAPS1 that consumed most of the money. She only had a little left afterwards to buy a plant, which reminded her of home. This last paragraph expresses her resolution, saying that when she has the chance to do the “test” again, she will do what she is supposed to do and make the correct choice.

After reading “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I believe Ho ended the story with that paragraph to support her central idea of overcoming obstacles. First, after failing her driving test, Saeng was very upset and didn’t know if she would ever pass it, feeling defeated. But after unexpectedly seeing a hibiscus plant, it powerfully reminded her of her home in Vietnam, which inspired her and lifted her spirits. Second, when she bought the plant, her mother was initially a little angry because it was an expensive purchase they could scarcely afford. But, after seeing how the plant brought joy and comfort to Saeng, her mother softened and forgave her. Last, when Saeng was digging a hole to let the hibiscus grow, the act of nurturing the plant inspired Saeng to take the test again because she had already overcome the obstacles of bringing the plant home and letting it grow in a new environment. Therefore, I believe Ho ends “Winter Hibiscus” with that paragraph to go along with her idea of overcoming obstacles through resilience and hope.

The last paragraph of the story displays the theme of determination. The Hibiscus reminded her that her "home" was her old life, but she misses @CAPS1 and a sense of belonging in her new life. She gains determination through the powerful reminder of this connection. She soon realizes that she is home now, for things have become familiar and comforting to her, such as the V formation of the geese flying overhead. She loved her old home, but she realized it was time to move on and build a new life. The last paragraph does not only mean retaking a driving test; it more profoundly symbolizes the determination to fully embrace her new home and the life that lies ahead of her.

She declares, "I will take that test again." She has gained @CAPS1 confidence from the symbolic hibiscus and the falling snow. She will wait for the season to change, for when the snow melts and the hibiscus buds finally open. Then she will go again, kind of growing and transforming with the hibiscus, so in all she is @CAPS2 to have enough confidence and inner strength for the test. This parallel growth gives her the assurance she needs to face the challenge once more.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because they want people to know what happened in the story and to understand the character's resolution. Also, it is included because they want people to consider what it might mean or what it might say in relation to the story's broader themes. The sentence means that when spring comes and when the snow might melt, the plants will be out and budding, representing a new beginning. Similarly, by next class or next school year, the character will come out of his shell, be brave, and take the test all over again with renewed hope. That is what the sentence means in the context of the story and how it might be compared to both the natural world and personal growth in different, meaningful ways.

The final paragraph in "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho reads: "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently, to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This paragraph creates a direct comparison between her and the flowers, which shows that she is resilient like the flower is strong. She is determined to take the test again next year and pass it, drawing strength from the plant's endurance. She would also take the test because the hibiscus is comforting to her and reminds her of home, providing a sense of familiarity and hope in her new environment.

He ended the paragraph like that because he may want you to read on, or it could be that he is showing you the direct comparison between the flower and Saeng. The quote, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," is showing the flower can fight through the winter and come back, just as Saeng can. Saeng failed the test once and is now going back to retake the test, which shows that they both have the motivation and the integrity to come back stronger after a period of hardship. This parallel underscores their shared capacity for resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph: "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." I believe the author concluded the story like this because it shows that the hibiscus represented to Saeng a new beginning and a chance to restart what she had failed. When Saeng saw the hibiscus after failing her driving test, it gave her comfort in a time of disappointment, a connection to her past experiences, and the belief that she could overcome her obstacles. Therefore, when the narrator says, "when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," this implies a new beginning, so the hibiscus is representing Saeng's own potential for renewal. This is why I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph, to highlight this symbolic connection.

The last line is included in the story "Winter Hibiscus" because it showed the deep connection between Saeng and the flower. Even though Saeng failed the driving test the first time, she decides to take it again in the spring. The hibiscus flower, like Saeng, is out of place and will have to make it through the winter into the spring so it can bud again. This shows how, like the flower, Saeng will bud again in the spring by retaking the driving test, demonstrating new growth. Another reason is that Saeng and the flower are not used to the conditions in their new, colder climate. So they both have to weather the winter months they are not used to, a shared struggle. This shows again how the last line connects the girl and the flower together through their parallel journeys. In conclusion, the last line is used in the text to wrap up the story with a final, poignant connection between the flower and Saeng.

I think the author concludes the story with this statement because Saeng is determined to get used to the new country and surroundings. In the story, the author is showing Saeng's homesickness. She sees a plant that is known from where she comes from and buys it; her mother can’t believe it. She didn’t want to tell her mother exactly why she got it because she was too shaky to say "home" or start crying again. The last sentence is showing that Saeng is trying to adapt and find her footing, using the plant's survival as a model for her own. Her vow to retake the test in spring signifies her commitment to this process of adaptation and growth in her new life.

The author concludes with this paragraph because she wanted to close the story with a fitting conclusion that portrays the story's central themes. The author talked about the hibiscus in the story as a “comfort in time of distress,” a hobby or thing she likes doing with her spare time that connects her to a sense of peace and familiarity. In conclusion, the author concludes with that paragraph for the reasons stated in the organization, which emphasize how personal comforts help one cope with challenges and provide a sense of resolution to the narrative.

The author ends the story with the given paragraph to get across the emotional resolution for Saeng. It highlights the things important and familiar to Saeng that gave her comfort, and uses them to essentially say that she’ll take the test over again once she feels better. The winter hibiscus was a plant that Saeng remembered of life back home up to the story, so when she saw the plant, “a wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” Saeng was unable to comfort her emotions when she first saw the plant because she realized how much she missed her old life and the memories associated with it. The plant is mentioned in the final paragraph because when it blooms in the spring, the winter hibiscus will help fill the emotional void, and help Saeng to try to take the test again with renewed hope. She also mentions the geese for the same reason, but in a different way. Unlike the winter hibiscus, it took a while for the geese to become, “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” Saeng mentions this so that she can get used to the strange and unfamiliar parts of her life, and to come to grips with her failed test by finding solace in the natural cycles around her. Therefore by mentioning the things she does in the last paragraph, Saeng uses familiar objects, foreign and domestic, to illustrate her coming to grips with her failure and her path toward acceptance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it expresses the core meaning of the story, which is that life continues no matter what obstacles one faces. The hibiscus will return again in the spring, symbolizing this enduring cycle. The hibiscus is like a symbol to Saeng's life, representing resilience and adaptation. The plant normally doesn't survive in winter months, but this one did, just as Saeng and her mother have endured hardships. The mother says, "It's flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the winter months here..." This statement reinforces that Saeng and her mother are just like the plant. They are strong and their lives will continue even though they are in a new and challenging environment. The author chose to end the story with that paragraph because even though it says the hibiscus will come back every spring, the deeper meaning is that Saeng and her mother, like the hibiscus, will continue to live their lives with strength and perseverance.

The author chooses to end the story in a very deep, connected way. It is ended on a note of rebirth and second chances. When Saeng vows, “when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return, when the Hibiscus is blooming, I will take the test again," the author is connecting a sense of a new country with the themes of second chances and rebirth. Spring and snow melting could be connected to rebirth and new beginnings, while the geese returning could symbolize a second chance and the cyclical nature of opportunity. This is connected to Saeng's second chance at the test and her life in a new land. The author also shows that Saeng is getting used to the new country, which shows a sense of hope and gradual adaptation. It shows that there is some hope for her test and for her future, concluding the story on an optimistic and forward-looking note.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants us to get the moral of the story, which centers on perseverance and being tested by one's environment. I said this idea because in the story he talks about how orchids, lanno bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. It talks about how these flowers surrounded her to test her resilience and her ability to find strength and beauty amidst challenges. The paragraph serves to underscore the lesson of her CAPS1, illustrating how nature itself can be a trial that ultimately leads to personal growth and understanding.

I think the Author concludes this in the story because it is a key piece of information for understanding the character's motivations. It is dealing with her mom and the deep connection they share through their shared passion. She loves to work on the garden and dreams of becoming a gardener and having a real job, just like her mom, which shows her admiration and desire to follow in her mother's footsteps.

Saeng thinks that she has failed because she misses her grandmother intensely. The hibiscus plant that she buys reminds her of her grandmother’s scent, a powerful memory from her past. Saeng spent a significant amount of money on the hibiscus plant because she needed it to feel a little bit more at home in this new and unfamiliar place. Saeng feels she had very little time to leave her country, as if it happened in a blink, which made the separation from her grandmother even more painful. Her grandmother would want her to be strong and not cry at the thought of being away from her, so Saeng needs to think of the good memories and smile when she is reminded of her past. Saeng wants to pass the test of adapting to her new life, and she resolves that next time the hibiscus are budding she must not cry, but instead find strength.

The reason I think that the author included these details is because she wanted you to know what time of year it took place and what the weather was like during that specific season. It also tells you how long she is going to wait, like till the snow melts completely, and that is going to be a while. The mention of when the geese leave and return home establishes the cyclical nature of time and seasons, reinforcing the period of waiting. So this is why I think she tells you what the environment is like, to set the scene and convey the passage of time central to the narrative.

I think that this is about winter and the hibiscus plant, which stood tall and lush and bad surrounded their garden. Its lush green leaves were dotted with vermilion flowers, creating a vivid and striking image against the bleak season. She said when she got to the hibiscus she reached out and touched a petal gently, feeling its delicate texture and drawing a sense of comfort and connection from its enduring beauty.

The reason that the author had ended the story the way she did was to leave the reader on a poignant and reflective last thought. Also it symbolizes rebirth and a new beginning for the main character. When Saeng says, “... this hibiscus is budding ...”, she is also describing that they will start over when spring comes, mirroring her own personal renewal. And that leaves the reader with the last thought about Saeng, and how she has overcome the challenges of living in the new place, showing her resilience. Lastly, it ties up Saeng's feelings and experiences the whole time she had moved, “... I will take the test again”, which tells the reader she will continue to give her new home a shot and persevere. In conclusion, the reason for this quote being the last paragraph is to show that Saeng will continue to try to overcome her difficulties and build a new life.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she wants there to be hope for the future. Seeing the hibiscus budding in the spring is what Saeng is waiting for, as it gives her hope that she will be able to pass that test again. This is shown when she says, “… and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” During the winter, Saeng hopes she will improve, and when the hibiscus buds, she will know that it is time to try again. Saeng sees the spring as a new beginning, which means it is a time to overcome her obstacle. I think that obstacle or test might be to not cry when she thinks about her old life in Vietnam. When she accomplishes this, she is growing and moving forward, just like the hibiscus plant that endures the cold to bloom once more.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for one main reason: to emphasize a sense of hope and renewal for the protagonist, Saeng. The budding hibiscus serves as a natural symbol for this new beginning, representing the promise of a fresh start after a period of hardship. This hopeful ending allows Saeng to look forward to the future with optimism, suggesting that challenges can be overcome with time and patience. The paragraph thus provides a fitting and uplifting conclusion to her journey.

The author is showing that Saeng wants to keep on with her mother's gardening traditions. This desire to take over an elder's traditions and continue what her mother started represents a deep connection to her family and cultural heritage. By tending to the plants her mother nurtured, Saeng finds a way to honor her past while putting down roots in her new home. This act of gardening becomes a meaningful link between her old life and her new one, showing her commitment to preserving her mother's legacy and the values associated with it.

I believe that the author ended the story with this paragraph to show the persistence of the main character. I believe this because in the beginning of the story when she is walking home, she states that she failed the driver's test. In the last paragraph, she states that after winter is over she will take the test again when her hibiscus blooms. Her persistence allows her to push through life as if she was a plant trying to survive the winter. This comparison highlights her resilience and determination to keep trying despite setbacks, using the changing seasons as a metaphor for personal growth and the cyclical nature of opportunity.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because she wants to show that Saeng is determined to do it right next time. What it is saying is that she can try every year to get it right and to impress her mother, demonstrating her commitment and willingness to persevere. This cyclical promise of trying again with each new season underscores a theme of continuous effort and hope. In conclusion, that is what I have to say about the paragraph and its message of unwavering dedication.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author most likely ends the story with this quote because he wants to show that she thinks of the Hibiscus as more than just a flower; to Saeng it is also a memory. For Saeng the Winter Hibiscus is like story books, waiting to be read simply by smelling the flower, for it unlocks wonderful memories of precious time spent with her gentle grandmother from her first home. The author is trying to use the flower to show the reader how much a simple object can trigger a memory, a thought, and so on. The last sentence clearly states, with evidence from the story, that Saeng cares deeply about her past, and so to fit in with life today she must not forget who she was. By keeping the hibiscus in her garden she can have a beautiful and constant reminder of where she came from. Therefore, one is to believe this reasoning is the assumption as to why the author ended the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the paragraph selected.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. For example, it shows a sense of hope, when she says “this hibiscus is budding". That indicates a new beginning or starting over, a sign of life continuing. I think that is the idea the author is trying to get across. Obviously it was difficult for the character to adjust to her new country. For example, she was disappointed that the hibiscus wasn’t the same as the one in her homeland, which deepened her sense of displacement. Even though she's feeling nostalgic, this paragraph reassures the reader that the character is willing to give her new country another chance, finding a spark of optimism in the budding flower.

The author concludes the story with that particular paragraph for a number of reasons. The last paragraph states that “when they come back ... I will take the test again.” Already upset about failing her driving test, the main character is also upset missing her homeland. The buds of the flowers give her hope and, essentially, the strength to take the test over again. Also, when she was originally in the flower shop, after smelling and seeing the flowers, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her ... And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” It is obvious that to the main character these flowers mean so much to her; they take her back to her home country, which she was abruptly torn from and misses, they give her hope and they remind her of the things she loves, like her grandmother. In conclusion, the author chose to end the story with this paragraph because the hibiscus and what it represents is what means the most to the main character, symbolizing both her past and her future resilience.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show she loved the flowers. They meant a whole lot to her, serving as a powerful connection to her homeland. When she failed her driving test she was sad, feeling the weight of her struggles in a new country. The flower made her feel better, offering comfort and a sense of familiarity. Now that the snow is falling she waits until spring, for that is when they will come up, and she will have the faith and determination to take the test again, inspired by the flower's promise of renewal.

The author concluded the story with this sentence because he was letting everyone know that Saeng would return to the hibiscus and take care of it still, demonstrating her ongoing connection to it. The sentence confirms that she has not forgotten about the plant, which serves as a vital touchstone to her heritage and personal history. This act of tending to the hibiscus signifies her commitment to preserving her past while continuing to live in the present, ensuring the memory and its significance endure.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," by Minfong Ho, a teenager named Saeng moves from Vietnam to the United States. She later takes a driver's test, but does not succeed in passing. However, she does succeed in finding comfort from her memories of her homeland. The last paragraph states, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. These being that Saeng was very upset about failing her test and was reminded of her homeland and the many changes she's had to adapt to during this move. The hibiscus plant gives Saeng a hope to continue her journey even when things get very hard. The winter is this plant's time of trouble and sadness, as Saeng's time of trouble and sadness is failing this test and not being at her real home. The end of winter gives both the plant and Saeng a chance to start over and a renewed hope to begin again. Ultimately, Saeng will find it easier to get through hardships if she continues to find comfort from her past and the symbolic promise of the hibiscus.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to get the readers wondering about Saeng's future. It serves to show that she is not going to give up on what she wants to do. This final vow demonstrates her resilience and her determination to try again when the conditions are better, leaving the audience with a sense of hopeful anticipation for her next attempt.

The author Minfong Ho ends the story talking about the test Saeng failed and vowing to take it again because, like in the story, the test was symbolizing slightly moving on, just kind of starting her new life and not living in the old. But Saeng couldn't do that immediately. She bought the flower with all her money because it held important memories for her. But as the story goes on she kind of realizes she can have both, her old and new life. The author ends the story that way because Saeng really does want to try again. She wants to be able to please her mom, and herself; she wants to be able to move on and start her new life, finding a balance between her past and her future.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng realizes that she needs more time to prepare herself. Her failure makes her understand that if she takes a break and does what she needs to do to feel ready, then she will be able to pass the test. This final thought shows her growing self-awareness and her plan to approach the challenge again with better preparation and a renewed spirit.
