The author concludes the story this way because it allows for the possibility of expanding on this story, creating a sequel about Saeng’s future success. Also, by ending the story this way the author is showing the limits Saeng is facing and how she will stop at nothing until her test is complete. Saeng is having difficulties adapting to her new lifestyle because the plants and the previous luxuries that she had are no longer present. In the story, Saeng’s determination is shown when her mother finds out that she spent a significant amount of money to have a similar plant. The mother responds by saying their whole garden is worth less than that amount, highlighting the depth of Saeng's longing and her resolve to hold onto a piece of her homeland as she perseveres.

This sentence concludes the passage to show how when the hibiscus is budding and a new season starts, Saeng will be a new person and will be able to take the test. In this sentence, the cold snow, fleeing geese, and planted hibiscus can all represent Saeng and what she is going through. They are either cold, ready to leave, or restricted just like Saeng feels, mirroring her own sense of displacement and confinement. But, when a new season starts, the geese come back, and the hibiscus is no longer restricted in a pot, Saeng will also grow up and be able to take the test. This sentence is put at the end to show how much Saeng can now grow because she has the hibiscus, which is growing with her, symbolizing her resilience and the promise of a fresh start.

The author ends the story with the sentence provided because she was saying that when winter is over, there will be a time again to get back to the test with the plant she had planted. The conclusion ties the changing seasons to Saeng's personal journey, suggesting that the end of winter signifies the end of a difficult period for her. As the natural world renews itself, so too will Saeng find the strength and opportunity to try again, using the plant as a focal point for her renewed hope and determination to succeed.

The author has concluded the story with a paragraph about Saeng taking the test again another time. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because Saeng wanted to take the test again when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding. She feels ready when that time comes around, as these natural signs mark a period of new beginnings. Saeng is trying to say to herself that she needs more time to be ready for this test, and the cyclical nature of the seasons provides her with that necessary timeframe. When she gets more time to be ready for the test, she will take the test again, demonstrating her perseverance. I think that is why the author wrote the paragraph as a conclusion, to emphasize the theme of patience and personal growth aligned with nature's rhythms.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when the hibiscus started budding it will give her inspiration to try and pass the test again. In order to pass the test she wanted to feel like she was home, and to have memories of her home to encourage her to try again. The budding flower serves as a tangible connection to her past and a symbol of hope for her future in this new place. Therefore, this is the reason the author concludes the story with the last paragraph, highlighting how the hibiscus provides the emotional strength and sense of belonging she needs to face her challenges with renewed courage.

The author concludes the story with a paragraph about taking the test again to show that the narrator is upset about being in a new place but she will keep trying. The narrator gets upset when she knows the hibiscus is not like the ones from her old home. This upsets her because she probably misses things that she was used to before, and the different hibiscus underscores the unfamiliarity of her new environment. The author uses that paragraph to show the narrator is strong and won’t give up on making things the way they were but also showing that she'll try to adapt to her new home. The author does this to show that you should keep trying at something that you love. The narrator will keep trying when the geese fly back and the hibiscus is budding, using these natural milestones as personal deadlines for her efforts. So the author is saying try if you fail and set goals to never give up, framing resilience as a continuous process tied to the cycles of nature and life.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons, primarily to provide a final reflection on the protagonist's journey and to underscore the central themes of resilience and personal growth that have been developed throughout the narrative, offering a sense of closure to the reader.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he knows that he messed up on the test and he is saying when spring comes back around he will be ready to take the test again. I know it is spring because he said when the snow melts, which signifies the end of winter and the beginning of a new season, a time for renewal and a second chance to succeed where he previously fell short.

When she moved to America she saw all the beautiful flowers that were out in the spring. She saw a blossom that caught her attention; it was called hibiscus. She felt a connection with it, so strong that she went to the florist to see if they had it. Back where she came from they grew wild, jittering out from the cracks in cement walls. The blossom reminded her of her grandmother, its long gray hair freshly washed and shining in the sun, evoking a deep sense of nostalgia and belonging.

In the passage "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the quote “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, I will take the test again,” symbolizes her new journey in the new country she lives in. In the test Saeng is having a personal discrepancy, missing her homeland, and she states “I – failed the test.” This test meant more to her than just failing; it was a test of her ability to function in her new country and she failed. The “when they came back…” quote stated above can be analyzed deeply as the snow being her obstacles and the hibiscus being herself. When the obstacles melt away and she buds into a new, stronger person, she will take the test again, ready to face the challenges of her new life with renewed strength.

She will go back to where she started. It is a circle and she will be back the next year where she began, completing the cycle of her journey and returning to the familiar point of origin, which provides a sense of symmetry and finality to her story.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” because that flower budding would make her feel confident about everything. The reason I think this is because that flower reminds her of past time memories of her homeland, providing a sense of comfort and familiarity in her new environment. It’s basically like she has a little piece of home in her new home, a tangible connection to her past life. An example that represents this is, “Not like the kind we had before,” this is explaining the new hibiscus is similar, but not the same as the one from home, so this reminds her of home while acknowledging the differences in her new reality. This is the reason I believe the author ends the story the way they do, to emphasize the power of memory and symbolic objects in fostering resilience and hope for the future.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to show that Saeng is not just going to give up. She is going to overcome the problem she faced with her driver's test, demonstrating her inner strength and determination. This is a great way to end this story because the entire story is about overcoming problems and if Saeng just gave up it would ruin the story's central message of perseverance. But just like she was able to move away from her home land she will eventually pass the test, learning from her initial failure. The mother was also able to overcome some obstacles, setting a powerful example for her daughter. Such as moving away from her homeland and having to plant all new plants in a different climate and soil. She obviously misses the old plants, the familiar flora of her past. You can tell by the way she knew what her gift was immediately, recognizing the hibiscus with a deep, nostalgic familiarity. But she is able to deal with that just like Saeng will do on her test the next time, showing that resilience runs in the family.

Everything in the story is about to change with the turning of the seasons. The winter will change to spring, the snow will melt and vanish, the geese will return, the hibiscus will bud, Saeng will also change and mature as well, adapting to her new circumstances. Saeng is just like the hibiscus plant as the plant is out of place on the road, seemingly fragile and displaced, Saeng is out of place in the new country and she must adapt like the hibiscus plant must adapt to the new soil. The plant looks different in the United States than in Vietnam because it matured and grew in a new environment, changing its appearance but not its essential nature. That is what Saeng must do she must mature and grow in this new country, finding her own way to blossom. For example Saeng observed how different the plant looked in the shop window then in did in her home country, noting the variations in its leaves and form. She was observing herself and how different she appeared as well, feeling just as foreign and transformed. The reason for putting the paragraph at the very end was to show that she had matured already and putting it at the end to show that she had grown through the day's experiences. Putting it at the beginning would not give the same effect of earned wisdom. The hibiscus plant was able to sustain the harsh winters change, surviving the cold to bloom again. Saeng is able to do that as well and she made the silent vow to take that test again when she has matured just as the things around her have, aligning her personal growth with the natural world.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph shown for several reasons, each contributing to a satisfying resolution. First, the author needs to conclude the story without leaving any questions in the readers mind as to what happens next for Saeng. This is achieved by incorperating the geese, hibiscus and her drivers test into the last paragraph, tying these symbolic elements together. Next, this last paragraph adds a theme of perseverance to the story, reinforcing the idea that one must continue trying despite setbacks. The main character is driven to take the drivers test again through memories of Vietnam and the hope that the hibiscus plant inspires. Lastly, it adds to the character by saying that she will "take that test again", she is shown as being realistic and not overconfident, but patiently resolved. These are some of the ways that the last paragraph enhances the story, providing closure while emphasizing its core themes of memory and resilience.

The author's choice to conclude the story with this specific paragraph serves multiple important functions within the narrative's structure. It provides a sense of cyclical renewal by connecting Saeng's personal vow to the natural cycles of the seasons, suggesting that her opportunity for success will return just as spring follows winter. The imagery of the melting snow and the returning geese evokes a feeling of hope and new beginnings, which directly mirrors Saeng's internal resolve to attempt the test again. The hibiscus plant acts as a crucial symbolic bridge between her past life and her present circumstances, a living reminder that growth is possible even in unfamiliar ground. Her silent vow demonstrates a significant shift from the frustration she felt earlier to a more mature and patient determination. This final note leaves the reader with a powerful impression of Saeng's resilience and her capacity to draw strength from her heritage as she navigates the challenges of her new life.

The author chose to end the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng is starting to adjust to her new home and that she will not give up. You can tell that she still misses her homeland by her reaction to seeing the hibiscus plant, which evoked a powerful sense of nostalgia, but also that she is growing accustomed to her new home because of how she recognizes the geese and will make the decision of when to retake the driving test based on their migration patterns. This connection to the natural cycles demonstrates her increasing familiarity with her new environment and her resilient spirit, ensuring the story concludes on a note of quiet determination and hope for the future.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph because it shows that Saeng was not prepared for this test, largely because she was not accustomed to the place and its unfamiliar demands. However, after seeing the plants that reminded her of home, providing a comforting link to her past, and knowing that the spring time is when more will blossom, symbolizing a new beginning, she will be ready to take the test over. This final thought establishes a clear timeline for her renewed attempt and frames her failure not as an end, but as a temporary setback before a future success.

The reasoning for concluding this story this way is to state that the season of the flowers is over and is to be held off until the spring. This provides the author with a natural point where the narrative can pause and end the story, while also creating an opening to begin on a new one for when the flowers come back in the spring. The cyclical nature of the seasons mirrors the character's own period of waiting and preparation. In conclusion, this is why the author ends the story with this paragraph that they chose, as it offers a sense of closure while simultaneously promising future developments.

The author concludes the story with the vow, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". This is done to show that Saeng is going to take the test again and is not going to give up. This is shown by the decisive statement, "then I will take that test again". This shows that she has not given up and wants to try again, framing her resolve within the hopeful context of nature's renewal. The paragraph thus solidifies her determination as the central theme of the story's conclusion.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because of how it related to when Saeng failed her driving test. The failure was a significant disappointment, but she was determined to take it over when she feels she is ready. The paragraph stated "in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take this test again." This specific vow connects her personal goal to the natural world, indicating she has found a new rhythm and a concrete plan. It effectively communicates her unwavering resolve to persevere despite the initial setback, bringing the narrative to a close on a forward-looking and resilient note.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” which was written by Minfong Ho, I believe she put the hibiscus there because it keeps you asking questions about its significance. I think because her mom was so disappointed with her after failing the test, that maybe she can change things and make things better for the future. The flower acts as a catalyst for this new resolve, connecting her past to her present circumstances and motivating her to improve her situation, thereby answering the questions its presence raises.

The author ends the story by saying “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” She chooses to end like this to show the change of the mood throughout the story, moving from despair to hope. When she gets home her mother “noticed the tear stains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes,” which highlights Saeng's initial sadness and feeling of being out of place. Saeng felt sad and out of place in the beginning of the story but by the end she felt happy and optimistic, a transformation that is perfectly captured by her vow for the future. This concluding sentiment solidifies her emotional journey from sorrow to determined optimism.

I think the author concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with this paragraph for these reasons. The first reason is to show that the girl won't give up, demonstrating her resilience. She was crying in the store and just very depressed after her failure. But, she knows that she has to keep going, and it shows a sense of determination to try again. Another reason why I think the author made this the last paragraph is that it showed her getting used to her new environment, finding a sense of belonging. I think the author used what she remembers about her old country and what she now knows of the new country and puts them together, creating a bridge between her two worlds. That way she gets hope from both, forging a new identity. For example, in the article it says “many of the things she had thought of as strange before, had become… almost familiar to her now.” This shows that she is realizing that she is used to the arrangement right now, so she then gets hope from it. Also, I think the author did that so that it would add a positive and uplifting effect on the story, ending on a note of promise. That is why I think the author wrote that as the last paragraph, to emphasize Saeng's personal growth and newfound optimism.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show people that the story, or the people in the story, have a strong connection to nature, or that the author likes writing about natural elements. It highlights what is in nature, the change of seasons, or maybe this story is about nature at its best, using it as a metaphor for growth and renewal. The cyclical patterns in the natural world mirror the internal changes and new beginnings experienced by the main character, underscoring the story's central themes.

The author wrote that last paragraph to give hope to Saeng and the reader, offering a sense of closure and forward momentum. After seeing the hibiscus flower, Saeng is reminded of her old country and feels sad; the author writes, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” Saeng buys the flower and talks with her mum about it at home, which becomes a pivotal moment of shared memory. The flower reminds her of home but it also gives her inspiration and a symbol of resilience for her new life. That is why she says she will pass the test when the Hibiscus buds bloom, linking her personal success to a natural, hopeful event and concluding her emotional arc on a positive note.

The author concludes with this paragraph because it fits along with a lot of the story and sums it up well. In the story the hibiscus means a lot to Saeng. Durring the story she relates a lot of memories to the hibiscus, as it serves as a powerful symbol of her former life. It reminds her of her home and her past so it plays an important role in her new environment. When she is planting it itís winter and the hibiscus hasenít bloomed yet, mirroring her own current state of dormancy and struggle. So by saying that she will take the test again when it is budding is like saying she will take the test again when its budding again, aligning her personal growth with the plant's natural cycle. She is pretty much acting the same as the flower once again showing its importance to her journey. And thats why I think the author ended with that paragraph, to emphasize this deep connection.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because itís saying that she canít work in the garden in winter, but ìwhen the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding,ì are all signs of spring, representing a time of renewal and new beginnings. In the spring, she will take the test again; which implys that she will work in the garden and find a more suitable time for her efforts. The paragraph effectively ties her personal resolve to the cyclical patterns of nature, suggesting that her success is linked to this natural rebirth. This connection provides a sense of hope and timing for her future attempts, making the conclusion fitting and resonant.

The author concludes the story like this because the Author (Minfong Ho) is telling you what will happen in spring time. I think this because the text say's Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that the test again. This means that in spring the hibiscus will begin to bloom, signaling a period of growth and opportunity for Saeng as well. The author uses this parallel to show that Saeng's own potential will blossom with the flower, linking her personal vow to the natural world's cycle. This final thought leaves the reader with a clear and hopeful outlook for the character's future, completing the story's arc.

She thinks she will do better in the spring for some reason, perhaps because she will be in a better mood then and it will look more like her home place. The familiar sights and warmer weather of spring may evoke memories of her homeland, providing her with comfort and confidence that she currently lacks in the foreign winter landscape. This seasonal change could restore a sense of belonging and strength, making her feel more capable of facing the challenge again. Therefore, her decision to wait for spring is intrinsically linked to her environment mirroring the one she left behind, which she associates with success and happiness.

The author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph becauses it symbolizes Saengís decision to try again. Things in nature are repeatative, seasons change but eventually they appear again, geese migrate but they too return and the author used this as a comparsion to Saengís decision to try for her license again. Just like Saeng the winter hibiscus was out of its normal environment but was learning to adapt and that inspired Saeng to keep on trying even if she failed because the hibiscus was trying to survive the winter even though it was out of place. The paragraph reinforces the theme of resilience, showing that failure is not permanent but part of a larger cycle of effort and adaptation. By drawing this parallel, the ending provides a powerful and uplifting message about perseverance and finding inspiration in the natural world.

I think that the author concludes the story with that paragraph because no matter what she said or did, she had to get the flower because it reminds her of where she used to live and how it was there, so she started to cry. The test was not about buying the flower and not about crying; it was about accepting her new life. That in the spring she is going to grow her own flower, which represents a new beginning. That is what I think the test is truly about, a test of her resilience and her ability to start anew.

She will see if her plant will survive through the winter, just like the ones back at home used to do. And she hopes that things will be the same, that her new plant will thrive as a living memory of her past. This act of nurturing connects her to her old home while she builds a new one, providing a sense of continuity and hope for the future.

It is the start of a new life for her. She has a new school and a new plant to care for. It is like she has a deep connection to the plant, a bond where when it grows, she grows stronger and more confident herself. That is when she declared that when they come back, when the hibiscus is budding, she will be ready for that test, having found her own inner strength.

The author ends it with that because it shows that she won’t give up and that she will give her new country a real chance. She ends it with that to say that she will be strong like the flower and that she will stay no matter what the challenges are! That she will be there, in that very spot, to see it grow back and to witness her own growth alongside it. That's why I think she concluded the story with that powerful statement of perseverance.

Throughout this story we are given background information on a girl who desperately misses her true home. When we are first introduced to young Saeng she is in a florist’s shop simply looking at flowers; we soon learn that she is not only looking at flowers but looking at pieces of her home and past. She then purchases a hibiscus, which is a flower native to her home in Vietnam. After discovering that she has just failed a driving test, it becomes more apparent that buying the flower is a way to cope with her new situation and feel comforted by her past. The author is able to conclude the story with that statement because it speaks of moving forward without clinging too tightly to the past. In the spring, Saeng will have a new home and find strength in her past, using it as a foundation for her future. That is what I feel the final paragraph suggests about her journey of adaptation.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is determined to pass the test. She knows when it's spring and the hibiscus is budding, she will retake the test. I think she wants to retake the test because the hibiscus makes her think about her homeland, which gives her a sense of comfort and strength. It makes her feel more confident, reminding her of her roots and resilience. She thinks she can pass it next time, as the hibiscus makes her happy and overwhelmed with a renewed sense of hope. She wants to retake the test, and she’s sure she will do better next time because of this newfound inspiration.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that if that type of flower could bloom in different places and go through natural changes, then so can she. To me, the flower is a symbol to the author that encourages her to keep trying no matter the obstacles. No matter if you have to start all over and do it again, it’s just this time you will know and would have learned from the past mistakes, growing stronger from the experience. Just as a flower blooms one spring, it dies in the winter and then comes again in the spring, representing cycles of growth and renewal. That’s the same as Saeng failing that test that year; she can go back next time and take it again with the wisdom gained from her previous attempt.

I guess that she is saying that when winter is gone she will be prepared for that winter test again. I guess this because they were not prepared for the winter to come as they were planting, which left them vulnerable to the harsh season. As in the reading she says, "As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel." This detail shows they were caught off guard by the sudden change. That's the reason why I believed that they were not prepared for the winter, and this lack of preparation is a lesson she will apply to her next attempt.

The author concluded the story in this manner so that the audience would feel sympathy and understanding for the things that Saeng and her family were going through in this hard time. It makes the reader feel sympathy for Saeng because all she can think of to make herself feel better is her home town and how she got taken away, highlighting her profound sense of loss and displacement. This emotional connection helps the reader comprehend her inner struggles and the weight of her memories, fostering a deeper empathy for her character and her journey.

He concludes the story because he was given another chance to retake the test. This opportunity represents a new beginning and a hope for redemption after his initial failure. The conclusion emphasizes the theme of perseverance and the possibility of improving one's circumstances through determination and a second attempt. It leaves the reader with a sense of optimism for his future efforts and potential success.

The author concluded "Winter Hibiscus" with this paragraph to emphasize a new life and new chances for the main character. The future setting of the paragraph, spring, symbolizes rebirth and another start from the cold, hard winter. The author takes this to heart, including more events which enhance this symbolized meaning. The author has used a structured choice of words to carry her thoughts. For instance, to convey the theme of rebirth, the author uses phrases like "the geese return" and "take the test again," which add to the importance of a fresh beginning at home. Also, the literal action of the "hibiscus is budding" captures the essence of rebirth. In winter the plant is dormant and less colorful, but in the spring the plant shows rebirth through the vibrant color in its buds. The author finally conveys the theme of rebirth by ending with this paragraph, solidifying the message of hope and new beginnings.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, it tells of a girl who just moved to a new country and is having a hard time adapting to the new land and its people. But I think the author put that quote at the end to lead you to believe to never give up, that there is a new beginning and you will make it. I believe this because Saeng thinks to herself, “almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her.” This shows that she has finally found comfort and is confident, much like the geese that adapt to a new area and then will come back, and that the winter hibiscus never gives up and will keep living in the new weather conditions every season. This parallel between nature and Saeng’s personal journey reinforces the story’s central message of perseverance and adaptation.

She concludes her thoughts at the end of the paragraph; she says a whole thing which means she will look at it when the winter is done. She will be able to retake the test again in the spring. That is what she was writing about, focusing on the promise of a future opportunity. The mention of spring signifies a time for renewal and a second chance, which is the core idea she is trying to express. This final reflection ties her immediate feelings to the hopeful prospect of starting over when the seasons change.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that she is trying to adapt to her new surroundings. The hibiscus reminds her of her old life and it comforts her. So when she takes her test in the spring she will feel better and more comfortable while she is remembering her old life in a new place. In the story it says that she failed her test and then she bought a plant that reminded her of her old life. The plant brought back memories of her old life and that helped comfort her. The spring reminds her of her old life because the flowers in the garden are blooming, the geese return, and the snow has melted. Saeng feels like she could adapt to her new surroundings with the comfort of her memories of her old life, finding strength in the familiar as she faces the unfamiliar.

The author chose this paragraph because it fit right as a good conclusion; it showed, for example, the word "again." It means that you did something already and it's over but you miss it so you retry what you missed, but in the paragraph it's talking about nature and how they want to test it "again." This choice of word effectively encapsulates the theme of cycles and second chances present in the natural world, which mirrors the human experience of trying anew. The paragraph thus serves as a fitting end, connecting the character's personal resolve to the enduring patterns of the environment.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it still shows how determined Saeng is to take the test again and pass it this time. The paragraph highlights her resolve, connecting her personal goal to the natural cycle of renewal she observes. By ending the story with this paragraph, the author is creating suspense, a narrative choice that is probably intended for a potential sequel of another story, leaving the reader anticipating Saeng's next attempt and its outcome.

In the short story "Winter Hibiscus," a young girl from Vietnam moves to the United States and fails her driver's test. After she decides to spend money on a winter hibiscus to remind her of her homeland, the ending paragraph, where she states, "when the spring comes back, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again," shows her deep feeling towards nature. She feels a connection between the natural world and her own life, believing that when the geese are ready to return home and when the hibiscus is ready to bud, so will she be ready, and she will take the driver's test again with renewed hope.

She is talking about the flowers, and when she mentions the test, it seems she is reflecting on her own appearance and state of being. She examines the flowers and sees the snow fall all over again, drawing a parallel to her own experiences. It sounds like the author is someone who admires flowers a lot, or perhaps just this one hibiscus and how it buds, using it as a central symbol. Maybe she is just someone who likes to observe and derive meaning from natural changes, seeing them as metaphors for personal transformation and growth.

I believe the author adds this passage to the story to represent determination and resilience. While Saeng is not originally from America, she is determined and willing to try and adapt to her new culture. The winter was cold and harsh in many ways for her, representing her struggles and initial failure. However, the spring will bring forgiveness and relief from her hardships. She will try to pass the driving test again to further integrate herself into American society, while the blooming of the hibiscus will simultaneously bring her a comforting sense of connection to her original home, beautifully balancing her past and future.

The author probably concludes the story with that paragraph to show that Saeng has realized she needs to be confident, and to also end the story on a good, hopeful note. The author skillfully wraps elements familiar to Saeng, like the hibiscus, with things native to her new home, such as the geese and snow, into the last paragraph. At the beginning of the story, the girl seemed very upset and lost in this country, missing her home greatly, as shown when "a wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her." But after returning home and confessing her failure to her mother, she begins to feel better. Towards the end, after planting the hibiscus, she sees the geese and feels they are "almost familiar." The concluding paragraph effectively ties her past, represented by the hibiscus, her present, symbolized by the geese and the snow, and the central drama of failing the test into one cohesive and resonant image, signaling her acceptance and newfound determination.

She wanted to learn and do more things, her curiosity blooming alongside the greenery she so admired. She loved the way the plants looked at the store, their vibrant leaves and delicate petals captivating her attention. Her mother noticed this fascination and got the plant, went home, and they started planting it together in a small clay pot. The daughter loved the plant very much, watering it carefully and ensuring it received enough sunlight. And she said that next year she would grow a plant as wonderful as the one her mom was growing, her voice filled with determination and a newfound sense of purpose.

I think the author concludes this paragraph in this story to describe how grown up Saeng is now since it doesn't look like she lives with her mom anymore. The author probably wants to emphasize the reader of Saeng's independence, now that she has probably left home since she doesn't live with her mom anymore. The events described were just her past and will be memorable to Saeng, serving as a cherished memory from her youth that she can carry forward into her adult life.

The author uses that passage to end the story to show that Saeng will try to adapt. When Saeng smells the Hibiscus, “The familiar fragrance filled her lungs and Saeng could almost feel the light sounds of her grandmother’s long gray hair." This suggests that Saeng was looking for things that were familiar to her and reminded her of her homeland. The fact that Saeng paid over nineteen dollars for a plant also indicates how much she missed her homeland. "She had failed the test," suggests to the reader that she attempted to adapt to her new home but failed. This makes her sad and causes her to miss the way things used to be. At the end of the story she said that "I will take the test again." Seeing the familiar hibiscus and geese leave, knowing that they will return, gives Saeng hope. The final lines suggest to the reader that she will always remember her homeland, holding its memory close as she continues her journey.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng isn't going to give up. Despite the challenges and the sadness she feels, her resolve is clear and her spirit remains unbroken, ready to face the future with renewed strength.

With the hibiscus around, Saeng will have more courage and also have had more time to adapt in their new home. For Saeng, the hibiscus is like motivation and it also reminds her of her old homeland, connecting her past to her present. The reason I think the author chose to end the story with this particular comment is to show that Saeng had in the end found courage and is ready to accept her tasks in this foreign land, embracing her new life while honoring the old.

The story concludes with that particular paragraph because it tells you that there are changes in the weather and the seasons, just as much as there are changes in your own life. The narrative illustrates that you sometimes have to deal with changes in your life, much like the inevitable shift from one season to the next. The driver's test might be one such challenge to see if Saeng can understand herself and her own resilience. There are changes in the weather all the time; there are changes in the spring and the fall, showing that some obstacles are simply part of life's cycle that you just have to get over and move forward from, finding strength in renewal.

In the story "The Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the writer ends with a paragraph that effectively concludes the story. One of the reasons she concluded with the last paragraph the way she did is because it tells the reader that Saeng has not given up on her driver's test. The line, “... Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” provides a specific timeline for her resolve. This explanation offers more detail about when she will take the test again, not immediately but after another winter has passed, and it leaves the reader to think hopefully about how the rest of her story will go, implying a future of growth and perseverance.

I believe that the author concludes the story with the line, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” was a great way to end it. This is because I think that she sees how much the hibiscus can endure the winter, and she realizes that if the plant can take such hardship, then she can take just about anything, mainly the test. Also, when her mother said “You what?” and “Her mother stared at her incredulously,” it showed a moment of surprise that was not entirely negative. She might have also understood that if her mum could get over being mad, then she could overcome being upset about the test, drawing a parallel in their capacity for forgiveness and resilience.

The author writes this conclusion to the end of the story because he wants people to know that the seasons are changing and the flowers are going to be dying, as part of a natural cycle. He also wants you to know that when the season changes back to spring, the flower will try and fit again with the other flowers, symbolizing a return and a new beginning. That is what the author means when he talks about taking the test again; it is a metaphor for Saeng's own process of wilting and then blooming once more, finding her place again after a period of difficulty and dormancy in a new environment.

The hibiscus flower is viewed as a powerful symbol of hope and a cherished reminder of their homeland. When Saeng first sees it in the florist shop, she is immediately taken over by vivid memories of home and how all the flowers grew freely and abundantly there. I believe the author wants the new flower to represent an opportunity for Saeng and her mother to do the same in their new country, to put down roots and flourish. Planting the flower is a clear representation of adaptation, since they have moved to a new land and must learn to grow in different soil. Saeng seems to be using it as a direct motivation when she says “when this hibiscus is blooming, I will take the test again.” The final paragraph therefore provides a sense of closure and a strong feeling of hope, which is an excellent and uplifting note to end the story on.

the author concludes the story with this paragraph, because it tells that if you fail the first time their is always a second time just like the hibiscus I dies in the winter and it come back alive in the spring. This natural cycle of death and rebirth provides a powerful parallel to Saeng's own experience, showing that endings can lead to new beginnings and that failure is not permanent. The resilience of the plant mirrors the inner strength she is developing, promising a fresh start when the seasons change.

The author leaves us at the end of the story saying “when the snow melts and geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The author is said that because the girl Saeng failed the test but still found something that reminded her of her home, providing her with a sense of comfort and belonging. She was happy, but the plant were not exactly like the one from home, yet she found a new appreciation for it. But she got used to it. The flower may not be the same but it’s an American flower and she is getting used to being in America. When she goes back to take the test she will be ready and so will her plant, which will be full of life and symbolically representing her own renewed spirit and determination to succeed.

I think the author ends the story like this because of Saeng's respect for the plant, which she views with great significance. In the text she holds the plant in a very high value, having paid many coins for it, which underscores its importance to her. So I think it ends like this to symbolize that Saeng believes that the best time to take the test is when the hibiscus is growing, as its flourishing state will bring her the fortune and confidence she needs to pass.

The author includes that paragraph at the end of the story because it connects Saeng to the geese and plant with deep symbolism. For Saeng, the snow represents her troubles adjusting to America, creating a cold and difficult environment. The geese show her that she is, even now, adapting to her new homeland when the geese seem familiar, offering a sign of hope and continuity. The Laotian hibiscus was pretty but the new American hibiscus, which symbolizes her since she came to America, is adopted to be more resilient and withstand the snow which symbolizes her problems adapting to America. For Saeng, the hibiscus budding again represents her becoming stronger and overcoming her troubles, a sign of her personal growth. She wants to go take the test again when she is stronger, linking her fate to the plant's cycle. The author concluded the story with this paragraph to connect the Hibiscus budding with Saeng overcoming her obstacles and finding her place in a new land.

The author chose to conclude the story like that because she’s saying that it isn’t over and she’s going to take the test again with renewed hope. In the story Saeng says “I- I failed the test” so shes determined to go back when the flower blooms again to get things right, seeing the plant's rebirth as the perfect moment for her own second chance. This ending emphasizes her perseverance and refusal to be defined by a single setback, looking forward to a future attempt with optimism.

I think what the author is trying to say is that she will take her driving test again in the spring when the flowers are out because it will make her feel more relaxed. The flowers put the author in a relaxed state of mind where she can focus, as their vibrant colors and pleasant fragrance create a calming atmosphere. This sense of peace is crucial for her to perform her best, allowing her to approach the test with greater confidence and composure when the season changes.

Because she is saying when the flowers grow back she will be ready to take the test again. The return of the blossoms signals a new beginning and a time for renewal, which gives her the necessary courage and positive mindset to try once more. She associates this natural cycle with her own personal readiness, feeling that the blooming flowers mark the perfect moment for her to succeed.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author is concluding the story with this last sentence because it is showing everyone that the season is over for the growing of the plants but when it comes time for the flowers to start growing again she will be back to take care of the plants because it is her favorite and they are what she lives for now that she has to take care of them. Also the author probably put the conclusion of the story like that to get people interested in reading more of the story later on because you are getting left in a sense of suspense, because you don’t know if she really will go back to the plants or just forget about them. Another reason I think the author ended it that way is because it is still snowing she cares about the plants but she isn’t going to worry about them until it is the right time again. For example she says “when they come back then I will take the test again,” that’s showing she isn’t giving up on anything she loves and she will keep trying until she gets it, demonstrating her persistent and hopeful spirit.

In the story “The Winter Hibiscus", I think the author uses the last paragraph to show that although the memories of her old country would always be with her, she soon will adapt to her new one. Also from time to time she still will visit her old country, holding onto her heritage while building a new life. For example “when the snow melts and the geese return", The last sentences, “then I will take the test again", This sentence means that once she is adapted to this country or goes back to her old one she still will enjoy it there either way, finding happiness and success in both worlds as she moves forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is going to retake the test when all these things happen. Saeng shows that she is not going to give up, and that she is going to keep trying. The hibiscus is a lucky charm to her to keep during the test to strive her to pass the test, serving as a tangible reminder of her strength and roots. In addition, the author also concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's personal thoughts, and how she feels about this test. In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, is an indication that it is time to give the test another try. In conclusion, the paragraph is an indication that Saeng is never going to forget her determination or her connection to the hibiscus, which symbolizes her enduring hope and resilience.

The author concludes the story with the last paragraph, which serves as a powerful resolution for Saeng's internal journey. When they come back home, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take that test again. This quiet promise marks a turning point, showing her newfound resolve to face her challenges with the changing seasons, symbolizing hope and renewal for her future.

I guess she felt that it was a good way to unite everyone, bringing them together after a period of disagreement or distance. In "Winter Hibiscus", the author concludes with Saeng saying "I will take that test again," which powerfully signifies that Saeng will be ready as soon as the spring arrives and her hibiscus is all in bloom. When Saeng bought the hibiscus, she was sure that as soon as the winter passes with the coming of spring, she is sure that taking the driver's test again will be easier, helping her to overcome the fear and grieving times in a new place. This means that Saeng is able to overcome her fear of a new place, drawing strength from the resilient plant. Saeng is also sure that the comforting memories of her homeland will help her, too, serving as a foundation for her courage. In the end, it is revealed that Saeng has become strong and has high hopes to see her success be fulfilled in her new homeland, embracing her future with optimism.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows her determination and parallels her struggle with nature. I believe the author used that statement to end the story because by the end Saeng was ready to face her obstacles again, and it also shows that she was beginning to appreciate her new environment. The plant that Saeng purchased, which her mother stated was "strong enough to make it through the cold months here," was telling Saeng that if the plant can make it through the harsh conditions then just maybe she can make it through living in a new country. When Saeng realized that things had a repetition season upon season, she must have realized that she can do it too, and face the driving test again with renewed confidence and a sense of belonging. This cyclical nature of life gave her the courage to try once more, completing her character arc.

The author includes this last paragraph in the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” to show that the main character still has hopes and has not given up on her new lifestyle. During the story, the main character Saeng reminisces on her not so distant past memories of her native home in Vietnam when she recognizes a certain plant from her country. This is important in the story because Saeng is still unhappy about moving to @LOCATION2 and she begins to cry as she walks home, having bought the plant, to her mother. “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” Saeng’s mother understood how she was feeling, and she was not disappointed in her for failing her driving test either. Her mother made Saeng feel better by planting the familiar Hibiscus into the garden right away, an act of nurturing that mirrored the support Saeng needed. The last paragraph of the story gives hope to the reader that Saeng will not give up her strength to live a different life in @LOCATION2 that she is not used to. “When the snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” It is as if Saeng is vowing that in time, she will be happy with her new life, not just passing a driving test. The Winter Hibiscus stands as a symbol for Saeng to be strong in the new country while still remembering her old life in Vietnam, a delicate balance between past and future.

The author Minfong Ho concluded the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the Spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again" because when the plant begins to blossom she @MONTH1 feel more confident and comfortable. At times you can see how she's trying to adapt to new surroundings, testing her resilience against the unfamiliar. Since the hibiscus represents a comfort at times of disappointment, is the reason she went out and purchased the plant, seeking a tangible piece of her homeland. So when it Spring again and the hibiscus is fully bloomed that why she take the test again because she will feel more comfortable in and with her surroundings, having found a sense of belonging. The past experiences of our lives often influence things in our life, whether we consciously know it or not. In this story Saeng tries to go to the flower shop and pass the test of not buying the certain flower that reminds her of her home, when she fails, she confronts the depth of her nostalgia. She is trying to get over the fact that she is not “at home,” that things and people that use to be ground no longer are, and she must find her footing anew. I think that the author ends the story with the paragraph that he did, to show that you can always change and grow. She is trying to put things that make her uneasy further back in her mind, and with time, she can do that maybe even by next year, because it is always possible to do something if you really wants to do it, and the author is showing that Saeng really wants to pass her own mind test, so she can further adapt to change, and her mother will be proud of her for her perseverance and inner strength.

I think that she was that way to say, hey I didn’t over come something and I’ll be back next year to take the test again like the hibiscus budding when the snow melts and the geese return @CAPS1 year. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wanted the readers to know that Saeng was going to take the test over again. This simple statement carries a deeper significance, revealing her determination and refusal to be defeated by a single failure. It shows that she is committed to persevering in her new environment, using the promise of spring and the budding hibiscus as a source of motivation and a symbol of her own potential for growth. The conclusion therefore leaves the reader with a sense of forward momentum and optimism for Saeng's future, emphasizing that her journey of adaptation is ongoing and full of hope.

When Saeng said that she will go and take the test over next year, she means trying to plant the plants all over again, nurturing them from seed to flower as a personal trial of resilience. When Saeng says “Here, let me help, mother,” right then you know that Saeng does want to help with the plants after all, signaling her renewed commitment to growth and her family’s shared endeavors.

The author's choice of the last paragraph in the short story, “Winter Hibiscus,” shows the hope for the future that Saeng feels. The winter and cold represent how she feels out of place and upset at not receiving her driver’s license, a stark contrast to the warmth she associates with her past. In the spring she will have a piece of her homeland blooming and she will be warm again, finding solace in the familiar. She will feel ready to take her test again “when they came back,” a phrase that signifies the return of migratory geese and warmer seasons. This shows her process of adapting to and accepting her new life away from her home and her memories. The last paragraph proves that she was strong enough to move past her hardships and move on, embracing the future with newfound strength.

The speaker can conclude the story with that paragraph because the geese returning and the hibiscus budding will help her with her confidence, serving as tangible signs of renewal and continuity. She wants to feel like she can do this test, and these natural symbols provide the assurance she needs to believe in her own abilities once more, thus completing her emotional arc.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph "when they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese returned and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." She realizes she has another chance to pass the test, a future opportunity born from the cyclical promise of nature. When the spring blossoms again she will begin to garden, reconnecting with the earth, and when the spring returns she will be ready to face her challenge, having found her resolve in the rhythm of the seasons.

Saeng finds comfort in memories of her homeland. When she took that test, everything was unfamiliar to her, so she failed, but on her way back something familiar found her: native plants of her home. “There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single bloodred blossom,” “floating in the bucket.” Saeng needs familiar things to comfort herself, to anchor her in a new world. So when she sees the geese, and this symbolizes change and migration, a natural cycle she understands. “Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched” against the sky. Spring is a time for new beginnings, "when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding.” When the familiar object is at its best, she will be her best and be able to face anything, having drawn strength from her past. Winter is the “getting-ready” stage, a necessary period of waiting and preparation for the growth to come.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" ended the story with the paragraph, “when they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She did this because she bought the flower when she failed the test, so when the flower blooms she will take the test again, linking her personal resolve to the natural cycle of rebirth and growth that the plant represents. This connection between her promise and the hibiscus's seasonal change reinforces her determination to succeed.

I think the author tried to say when it comes to spring and the snow melts, then she will come back. This seasonal shift marks a period of renewal and hope for the future.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" uses this paragraph to conclude her story because it is a symbol of Saeng’s future. "Winter Hibiscus" is a symbol of Saeng for many reasons. For one, both Saeng and the plant are from Vietnam and both struggle to survive and thrive in the new world of the United States. Saeng promises herself that when the plant thrives in the spring, so shall she by retaking her driver’s test. This symbol of future is extremely important to the story's life and this is why Minfong Ho, the author of "Winter Hibiscus," chose to end with this vital symbol, emphasizing the parallel journeys of the character and the plant.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author most likely chose this as the last paragraph to help the reader understand the message. The message of this story is no matter what happens or what challenges you face, never give up and always keep trying. The author makes that the last paragraph to make the reader think and ponder upon what it means, leaving a lasting impression of resilience and hope.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph for one reason. That reason is because Saeng thinks she failed because she got a fake plant instead of a real one. She felt disappointed when she brought it home. For example, she said “I failed,” talking about the plant. She also compares where she is now to where she used to live, feeling a sense of displacement. For example, she said “it’s not like the one at home,” highlighting her longing for her past and the authenticity she misses. That’s why the author concludes with this paragraph, to underscore Saeng's initial disillusionment and her subsequent resolve to try again.

When they come back, Saeng vowed to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. This statement connects with the story because she likes being in the garden and you're not allowed to be in the garden when it snows, which makes the arrival of spring a significant time for her. Second of all she loves plants and things similar to plants etc, that’s why the author concluded the paragraph to the story due to the fact that when it hits spring Saeng is going to purchase plants and flowers, finding comfort and a sense of purpose in their care. Last of all Saeng she sees a familiar plant, later she goes to a florist shop to see if it can be purchased and Saeng gets highly upset when something goes wrong with them, revealing the deep emotional connection she has to these symbols of her past and her hopes for the future. This emotional journey underscores her determination to try again when the conditions are right, just as the plants return to life.

In the text, when the mother said “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matter.” This sentence shows that Saeng is just like the flowers, possessing an inner strength that may not be immediately visible. They’re strong to live through the winter, that shows they are very pretty and strong in the spring, having endured the harshest conditions. This emphasis that Saeng will be strong and more confident in the spring suggests a parallel cycle of growth and renewal. That’s why the author put it in at the end, to leave the reader with this resonant comparison. It’s also reflected to the flower, how they’re pretty and strong in spring, mirroring Saeng's own potential to bloom after a period of difficulty, thus concluding the theme of resilience.

In the short story, “Winter Hibiscus,” by Minfong Ho, the author includes a paragraph at the end, stating that the main character, Saeng, will take her driving test again. Ho includes this paragraph to show that Saeng is determined to adapt and persevere in her new environment. Saeng is new to the United States, her and her mother had moved here from Vietnam, which marks a significant transition in her life. Throughout the story she is reminiscing about her home life in Vietnam, thinking about her grandmother, and the flowers there, which highlights her sense of displacement. “Where was me...hibiscus hedge?.. Her gentle grandmother?” When at the flower shop, Saeng finds a hibiscus, a flower they also had in Vietnam, creating a tangible link to her homeland. She sees how it has adapted to survive in the winter here, learning a lesson in resilience. As she is planting the flower in her backyard, she makes a promise to herself to pass the driving test next spring, linking her personal growth to the natural world. She too, wants to become adapted to the new location and be able to live here without missing home too much, seeking a new sense of belonging. This vow she made is included in the last paragraph to emphasize her resolve. The author included it to show Saeng too, wants to adapt to her surrounding and pass the driving test, solidifying the story's message of hope and determination for the future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate the true meaning of the hibiscus and its profound significance to Saeng's journey. The hibiscus is symbolic to Saeng in several ways, but the most important is that it represents change and growth and the ability to overcome obstacles, serving as a metaphor for her own life. Upon seeing it, she is overcome with childhood memories and sentimentality, connecting her past to her present. However, she must adjust to her new home if she wants to grow as a person, recognizing that clinging only to the past will hinder her progress. She will survive here, just as the hibiscus will survive through the winter, drawing strength from this parallel. Also, Saeng vows that “in the spring” when “this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” directly tying her personal commitment to the plant's cycle. She is determined to succeed, and the hibiscus itself represents triumph over obstacles, embodying the possibility of beauty after hardship. It stands for survival and endurance through life’s disappointments and challenges, from failing a driver’s test to starting a new life in a strange and foreign country, making it a powerful, multifaceted symbol. The author’s choice to end the story with this paragraph exhibits Saeng’s ultimate understanding of her strength through the symbol of the hibiscus, providing a resonant and hopeful closure to her narrative.

I believe that the author concludes the paragraph like that because he/she wanted to show an important message to the audience about perseverance and hope. The message that the author was trying to get across was that even though she didn’t pass the test she was going to try again next year, demonstrating resilience in the face of setback. An example of this is an exact quote “in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” which frames her resolve within the hopeful context of nature's renewal. This is why I think the author concludes the story like that, to leave the reader with a sense of optimism and the understanding that failure is not permanent but a step toward future success.

The author includes the story with this paragraph because since Saeng failed her drivers test for the first time, the budding hibiscus represents a significant change in her life. This moment of failure coincides with a new beginning, symbolized by the flower. Also, Saeng use to have hibiscus flowers at her old home in Vietnam so when the flower buds it could show that she has a new home, creating a tangible link between her past and her present. The hibiscus thus serves as a marker of both transition and continuity for her.

The author finished the story with, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melts and the geese return and this hibiscus budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason for this conclusion is that it is important for Saeng to feel at home in her new environment. When the hibiscus buds it will remind her of home and this will comfort her, providing a sense of peace and belonging. When she feels at peace and at home she will do better on the test, as her confidence will be rooted in this newfound sense of place.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to show she is not giving up on her new home or forget her old one. She shows she isnít giving up when she brings home the flower to plant, a deliberate act of putting down roots. That also shows she will not forget her old home, as the hibiscus is a direct connection to it. Also when she says, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” That shows she is giving her new home another shot and isnít giving up. Another example is when it says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” Here she is accepting the changes and giving her new home another chance, demonstrating her resilience and adaptability. She is not giving up on it, but rather choosing to persevere.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph. She does because she is ready to do the same thing next year, indicating a cycle of hope and renewal. She like spending time with her mom, she likes plants, and she likes having fun with her mom, all of which are positive aspects of her new life that provide her with comfort. This are some reasons why she concludes with that paragraph, as it emphasizes the simple, enduring pleasures that help her cope with disappointment and look forward to the future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the hibiscus provides comfort. After Saeng failed her driving test and was new to the area, she was frustrated and was missing her real home in Vietnam. The hibiscus reminded her of her grandmother, serving as a powerful sensory link to her past. She writes “she closed her eyes and breathed in deeply as the fragrance filled her lungs” after Saeng smelled the flower it reminded her of “combing her grandmother’s long grey hair, freshly washed” it brought her comfort in a time of disappointment. Since she didn’t have her grandmother, the flower comforted her. Although she was disappointed the hibiscus was “exquisite” and as she said the Laotian word “dokor malik” meaning hibiscus she “savored the feel of the word on her tongue.” Ultimately, the joy and comfort is what the flower brings to Saeng, she will take the test again in the spring when “the snow melts and the hibiscus is budding, thus bringing joy, love, and comfort to the reader as they feel what Saeng feels, sharing in her moment of solace and renewed determination.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because it powerfully relates the idea of the hibiscus to Saeng and her situation in a new country. It shows that Saeng is using the hibiscus and its ability to adapt for personal inspiration. During the story, Saeng describes how she had always seen the hibiscus at home in her old country, a familiar and comforting sight. Her mom describes to her that the hibiscus she bought is a bit different from the one back home, but she explains that it’s because it is strong and was able to adapt to the cold winter environment of the United States. This is precisely what Saeng was able to use as inspiration for her own life. She might have failed her license test, but she used the hibiscus's actions to set a goal for herself. The plant will go through a cold and snowy winter, but it will grow and blossom again in the spring. Similarly, Saeng decided she would use that time to study and get ready, and she’ll be confident for the test when she retakes it. The paragraph that the author finishes on effectively shows the profound connection Saeng made with her situation and the plant’s situation, drawing strength from its resilience.

“If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again.” This quote is often used by many parents trying to encourage their children or by coaches to motivate their team. The quote can also directly apply to Saeng’s situation in the short story, “Winter Hibiscus.” Saeng fails her driver's test and, when walking home after the test, notices a hibiscus flower which vividly reminds her of her homeland. Sadness encompasses her and she purchases the plant to pacify her grief. She brings it home and is at first gently reprimanded by her mother but then thanked for buying it. While Saeng is planting the hibiscus, she hears the honk of Canada geese, a sound which had become familiar to her by then. The text says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, become familiar to her.” This quote clearly shows the gradual adaptation she had to face in coming to her new home. The author concludes the story with the paragraph to show that, like the hardy hibiscus flower, she too will adapt to the terrain and toils of her new environment. Ultimately, the hibiscus inspires her to push forward and try again for her license, just as the plant pushed forward through the harsh winter to bloom again.

The author ends the story this way because Saeng feels a deep sense of comfort with the hibiscus flower. The flower strongly reminds her of her homeland and of her grandmother. According to the story, “the familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmothers long gray hair.” From this, you can also tell she misses her homeland but always keeps it close to her heart wherever she goes. The text states that, “it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers.” She seems to be very close with nature and all of its desirable traits. When she failed the test she bought her “Malik” flower, as a source of comfort. They both decided to plant it in their garden and while doing so, Saeng received a huge boost of confidence to retake the test, feeling a renewed connection to her past and a hopeful outlook for her future.

She compares the paragraph to the story to compare it to her experiences at school. In this context, the test represents the challenge of making new friends and doing well on academic tests and in classes. The parallel is clear; just as she must persevere in her studies, she must also persevere socially. In the paragraph it said, “Then I will take that test again.” That statement of resolve is the key reason she is comparing that paragraph to school, showing her commitment to trying again until she succeeds in all her endeavors. This connection underscores the broader theme of persistence in the face of various life challenges.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize Saeng's determination to overcome the obstacles stemming from her past experiences. For example, the story starts out with Saeng taking a ‘test’, and while reliving her memories in the greenhouse, she started to breakdown, as shown by the line, “A wave of loss so deep and sharp it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her." She then buys the plant and takes it home to her mother, telling her that she 'failed'. The mother then becomes understanding and helps Saeng vow to retake the 'test'. Through this final paragraph, the narrator emphasizes Saeng’s renewed determination to overcome the troubles of her past and move forward with hope into the future, mirroring the resilience she sees in the winter hibiscus.

Because her school work was the whole reason as to why she was studying flowers in a green garden, focusing on their botanical structures for an important examination. And it is obvious she failed the test, a setback that has not discouraged her. So when spring starts to show she will retake the test because the flowers will bloom and she can do more study, observing them in their full, natural state to pass the test and not have to take it again. I get the feeling though she is also looking forward to the spring time coming back now an day so she can enjoy the flowers and the presents of growing and studying, finding a personal joy in the process that goes beyond mere academic requirement. This dual motivation enriches her resolve for the coming season.

I think that the author concluded the story with that particular paragraph because she wanted us to see that Saeng was not giving up. Saeng was originally from Vietnam but she moved to the United States, a transition that proved difficult. She missed being home so much because nothing was the same, a feeling captured in her quiet observation, ìItís not a real one,î Saeng mumbled. ëI mean, not like the kind we had at-at'. She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, the memory of her past life feeling both vivid and distant. But once Saeng finally realized that she was beginning to adapt to the life in the United States, noticing small, comforting signs of continuity, she decided that she was going to give the driveís test one more try. Her declaration, ìWhen they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," marks her commitment to persevere in her new environment.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because she seems to led comfortable when she saw the geese and plants the hibiscus in the winter and keeps it from dying, actions that symbolize her nurturing hope. In the story it said,"... their faint banks clear and -yes- familiar to Saeng now". I think this is explaining how she feels after seeing the geese fly over head because she uses to see that in Vietnam, and their presence offers a sense of connection to her homeland. Also, "when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is buddingî, she gains more confidence because she leds like sheís back in Vietnam, surrounded by elements that feel like home. All in all, that's why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, to underscore this moment of personal comfort and renewed self-assurance.

I think the reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to allow the reader to imagen what happens next once spring rolls around for Saeng, leaving her future open to positive possibilities. This allows the reader to use their imagenation to connect to the story and become more invested in the character's journey. Another reason why the author chose to conclude the story like that with that paragraph was to give hope to the reader that maybe she will pass the test next time, fostering a sense of optimism. It was also a way to end the story in a good note, emphasizing resilience and the promise of a new beginning rather than focusing on past failure. This hopeful ending resonates with the themes of growth and adaptation present throughout the narrative.

The auther ended the story with that preticular paragraph because like the geese she will be back to try again, using the migratory birds as a symbol of her own cyclical return and determination. Just in case she didnít get to finish JUST about everything she wanted to do and that the auther wanted the reader to know the determination and ambition of the character in the story, highlighting her inner strength. Also to show the readers that the characters characteristics couldnít be beat by one winter and that she is going to keep going at it untill she does what she has to do, demonstrating a resilience that defines her core identity. This final note solidifies the story's message about the power of perseverance in the face of adversity.

The author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” most likely concludes it with the paragraph of Saeng vowing to retake the test to show that even in difficult times and new situations a person can never give up and sink into despair and that there are always things to comfort someone. In the story, glimpses of Laos home are given in her memories and from them, the reader can understand what a difficult day Saeng is having. The author is describing these warm, comforting memories to help clash with the cold, bitter day the girl is having. “She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs.” Here, Saeng recalls a memory of her grandmother and it saddens her at the thought of her home and her loss. The author builds up Saeng’s despair and upset for the final paragraph. The author has this as the final paragraph because it shows hope. As Saeng says, “then I will take that test again,” you can feel her hope.
