Also, the author wants to express how there is still structure and stability in a changing world and that you can look to the simple things. Saeng says, “the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” and this shows how there are some reliable things that can give you security when you think you have none. The author uses this last paragraph to balance the feeling of despair in the story, to emphasize the need for hope and to show that there are always things that can give you hope and security.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author would like to finish the last sentence of the story with a powerful, hopeful resolution. Also at the end of the paragraph is when she is visualizing and putting her hope into the hibiscus. Therefore, her thoughts are appreciated and directed towards the plant, which serves as a symbol of her resilience. The author wanted to provide more evidence for this theme of renewal in the story. For example, when it said, “in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it includes the winter time for the plant as a period of waiting. Also, the spring the plant comes back, which parallels how the character Saeng will get her chance back, and revisit her determination. This cyclical nature of the plant reinforces her own promise to try again.

The author made it seem like the character did not like his new situation, but he actually loved flowers and he liked working in the city with the people. His mom is a seamstress, and he liked to see himself get together with his life so that people would come back because they liked the place he was making for himself. The flowers connected him to something beautiful and familiar, providing comfort and a reason to persevere despite the initial challenges he faced in his new environment. This underlying affection for his work and the community ultimately defined his experience and growth.

The author includes this at the end to show how much she cares about the plant and that its smell brought her back to her childhood. An example of her loving the plant is “that rich scent" from the text. Another example is “It felt smooth and cool” which describes her tactile connection to the hibiscus. An example of the connection to her childhood is that she had not even realized she had known the plant but had forgotten it over time. She comes back to this memory, and we could read about her reawakened connection. For these reasons, I think that is why the author adds that detail at the end, to highlight the plant's role in triggering a significant and comforting memory from her past.

I believe that the author left this as the last thing the reader will read, so it will be a lasting message. In the story this girl has now moved to this totally new environment and new culture. The only thing she knew of was a flower that grew wild where she lived. This little vow to herself was a message to not give up. Keep on going and if you open your mind to new things who knows what you can experience and learn. So this girl didn't just give up. Her plant was like a representation of a new beginning. When her plant starts over then so will she. Also it can be a representation of her life itself. I say a new beginning because in the text, it says the hibiscus will bud again in the spring, mirroring her own commitment to renewal and growth after a period of hardship. This final thought leaves the reader with a sense of optimism and the importance of perseverance.

I think the author wrote that because maybe that is how she feels; in the winter she could really show people who she is, but when spring comes she is like a flower that has been dead all winter and is now ready to bloom. The winter represents a time of inward reflection and hidden identity, while the spring symbolizes a period of renewal and outward expression. This seasonal change mirrors her internal journey from concealment to revelation, allowing her true self to emerge just as a flower blossoms after a long dormancy. The contrast between the seasons effectively illustrates her personal transformation and the eventual unveiling of her character.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph before they were talking about the “winter hibiscus” and the geese. So the author just simply writes another concluding paragraph that wraps the story up, and the reader walks away with a feel-good feeling. This final section ties together the central symbols of the narrative, providing a sense of closure and hopeful resolution. By echoing the earlier imagery, the ending reinforces the story's themes of patience and cyclical renewal. It leaves the audience with a comforting and optimistic impression, perfectly concluding the character's emotional arc.

In the story the Winter Hibiscus by Minfong Ho it explains the obstacles Saeng went through coming to a different country. In this story Saeng had just failed her driving test as she was reminded of her home through some tropical flowers. Moreover the author writes at the end of the story referring to geese “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus budding, then I will take the test again.” This part of the story is very important because it examines her growth and hope for change, just as the geese will come back and the hibiscus will change into a beautiful blossomed flower. Furthermore it explains to the reader that she will not give up and that she will change to the environment just as the plant lives has and the geese come back to the changed environment. That part of the story is very important for the reader, as it concludes Saeng's thoughts and hopes for the future while adapting to her new surroundings, showing her resilience and determination to succeed.

The author could have concluded the story with this paragraph for many reasons. I think the author wanted to give an interesting fact about what happens to hibiscus when it snows; for example, the author explains how the hibiscus grows and things that are needed for it to grow, like sunlight, water, soil, and picking up their waste. Maybe the author figured that explaining that when it snows the process begins all over again, drawing a parallel to the character's own cycle of setbacks and new beginnings. This botanical detail serves to underscore the theme of natural cycles and resilience. By connecting the flower's lifecycle to the narrative, the ending emphasizes renewal and the persistent hope for a fresh start.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng said she failed the test, and when spring comes back then she will take the test again. The last paragraph reads “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” She really does not tell us what test she is supposed to be taking, which adds a layer of ambiguity and allows the test to symbolize any challenge in her new life. This vagueness makes her vow more universally relatable, representing any personal struggle or goal. The promise to try again with the changing seasons highlights her enduring hope and commitment to overcoming future obstacles.

The reason why she said she will wait til spring to take the test again is to see if she is still like the bitter melon over the Big Mac. She needs time to adjust and to see if her preferences have truly changed, just as one's taste might develop over a season. This period of waiting will allow her to reflect and ensure she is ready, making the decision a thoughtful one rather than a rushed reaction to failure. The comparison highlights her internal conflict between her old life and the new one she is navigating. Ultimately, spring symbolizes a new beginning where her true preferences will become clear.

The author concludes the end of this story with this paragraph because it reinforces the idea of taking the test again. What she means by this is that she will have to do the same thing next year, demonstrating persistence. She will have to adapt to life just like the hibiscus did, showing resilience and growth in a new environment. She is also saying to do her best because everything in the world is achieved by living to your fullest potential, embracing every opportunity. So it serves as a good conclusion for the story, tying the character's personal journey to a universal lesson about effort and adaptation.

I think that the reason the author concludes the story like that is that it provides a satisfying and hopeful ending. It also lets you know that the story is complete, yet implies that the characters could make more progress in their lives. This type of ending suggests future possibilities without detailing them, leaving room for the reader's imagination. It wraps up the immediate narrative while hinting at ongoing journeys, which is a common technique to provide closure. Therefore, the conclusion effectively finishes the tale on a positive and forward-looking note.

What the author concludes is that in the spring time when the snow melts and the flowers come back, it brings the fresh risk and beauty of springtime at home. This seasonal change makes her feel relaxed and at peace with her surroundings. Also, springtime is a more pretty time because all the flowers are out, and the specific flower that reminds her of home brings her feelings of blessings and comfort. This connection to nature and memory provides her with a sense of belonging and serenity. Thus, the conclusion uses the imagery of spring to symbolize renewal and emotional solace.

Saeng vowed silently to herself that in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take that test again. Saeng is going to wait to take the test when she knows that she will pass it so she can get her license. She wants her license so she can drive anywhere she wants to go, gaining a new sense of freedom and independence. This way, she doesn't have to get her mom to take her everywhere; she can take herself anywhere she desires. But she has to wait till the snow is melted before she takes her test again, using the season as a marker for her personal readiness and new start.

The paragraph shows that Saeng has a lot of feelings for her plants, revealing a deep and personal connection to her garden. She enjoys plants immensely and she loves taking the time to spend with the plants, tending to them with care. She means in that last paragraph that she cant wait for winter to leave so her plants will be budding and that she can enjoy her plants, anticipating the renewal and beauty that spring will bring to her cherished garden.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it ties it all together, providing a final, cohesive thought. I think that the author uses it also to say that in the spring she will pass the test, connecting the seasonal change to her personal triumph. I really like the part when she says "in the spring, when the snows melt..." I like that because it explains what she wants and how she puts her mind to it, illustrating her determination and hope for the future in a vivid and meaningful way.

The author most likely uses this paragraph to show her setting a goal for the cycle to start over, emphasizing the theme of renewal. She uses geese as a symbol for spring, when she would start preparing for this “test” once again, linking nature's rhythms to her personal challenges. The hibiscus budding in this paragraph shows hope, because it is once again, a start of a cycle as well as an object of reminiscence in the story, representing past memories and future possibilities. In conclusion, this concluding paragraph uses several symbols and devices in order to convey hope, good memories, and fresh start, effectively wrapping up the narrative's central motifs.

She would grow some flowers and water the plants, nurturing them with dedication. The geese would come back to her pond, signaling the arrival of a new season and completing the scene of her peaceful, hopeful garden life.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. One reason being that the author wanted to really show the meaning of the flower, highlighting its symbolic importance. Another reason is to express the theme, tying the narrative together. For example at the end of that paragraph it says “then I will take that test again.”, its relating that small topic of the driving test to the larger topic of the flower, creating a powerful parallel. Which then relates it to the theme of adjusting and keep trying till you adjust, emphasizing perseverance. That last paragraph was quite vital to the theme and meaning of the story, serving as a crucial element for understanding the author's message about resilience and growth.

I believe the author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus,” written by Minfong Ho, with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” because she is trying to show how past memories can be transformed into hope and determination. After failing her driving test, Saeng finds the Hibiscus, and the memories of her homeland and her grandmother consume her with a powerful nostalgia. She buys the plant and puts it in the vegetable garden, a small act of reclaiming a piece of her past. After she is done planting, Saeng sees a flock of Canada geese fly overhead, a sight that connects her old life with the new. Using her memory of her old home and her family, applied to her new surroundings, Saeng vows to re-take the test, to try again with renewed spirit. The author ends the story “Winter Hibiscus” with that paragraph to show that Saeng will not give up, finding strength in her memories to face the future.

The author concludes with this story to show how Saeng is ready to accept her new life and find a sense of belonging in her new environment. Once the geese and the hibiscus are back, she feel like she's at home, as these natural elements serve as comforting reminders of her past. When she feels more at home is when she will be ready to take the test again, having found the inner peace needed to succeed. The text states “when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. Clearly the geese and hibiscus remind her of home, providing her with the emotional foundation she lacked. Once she feels at home, she will feel at ease and confident enough to face the challenge again. That is why the author concluded with this passage, to highlight Saeng’s emotional journey toward acceptance.

The author concluded with this paragraph because it effectively restated the main idea of the story, allowing the readers to fully understand what the story was about and the central message the author intended to convey. This final passage serves to crystallize the story's core theme of resilience and personal growth for the audience. By revisiting the key elements of Saeng's vow, the conclusion reinforces the narrative's purpose and leaves a lasting impression. That is why the author concluded the story with that paragraph, ensuring the main idea was clear and resonant for the reader.

The author explains that Saeng has failed the test, an event that leaves her feeling discouraged and out of place in her new country. While it is still winter and the hibiscus is still trying to grow its lovely petals back, Saeng sees the plant’s struggle as a parallel to her own. As she tells her mother “that she will not take the test again, until the hibiscus starts budding and spring is back,” she links her personal resolve to the natural world’s cycle. This connection shows that she needs a sign of renewal and life, represented by the flowering hibiscus, before she can muster the courage to try again. Her statement reveals a decision to wait for a symbol of hope and new beginnings before facing her challenge once more.

Yes, I do think that this concludes the story because after all of the events in the story and all that learning about gardening from her mother, she remembers what her mother had said about the hibiscus and its budding. This memory of her mother’s wisdom gives her a new perspective and a timeline for her own goals. And what she means by this ending sentence is that when the spring time comes, a season of growth and renewal, then she is going to take that test again. The test will determine whether or not she has learned enough about gardening from her mother over the past time, serving as a measure of both her practical knowledge and her personal development. This conclusion ties her academic effort to the cultural and emotional lessons she has absorbed.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is implied that her grandmother passed away during the migration of the geese, a significant seasonal event. Alternatively, that specific time might also coincide with the blooming period of certain flowers, creating a poignant connection between the natural cycle and the memory of her grandmother's passing. This timing serves as a subtle yet powerful anchor for the story's emotional resolution, linking the character's personal loss to the enduring rhythms of the natural world.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” included the last paragraph to convey to readers that she will be moving on, but still remembering her old country. Before finding the flower, the author terribly missed her old country, as shown when Saeng is too overwhelmed to even speak of it, leading her to burst into tears. She missed her home and was having trouble getting past it, unable to accept her new country as home yet. The hibiscus flower brought back vivid memories of her old country, making it even more difficult to move on initially. When one of the blossoms fell, Saeng picked it up and could almost feel her grandmother’s presence, a memory so potent it was almost tangible. The flower was too much of a memory, yet it finally gave her something from home that she could physically hold. Gently closing her palm around it, she held it tight; that, at least, she could hold onto. This tangible memento became the first step toward finally moving on. The narrative shows that Saeng now needed some time to get used to her new country, as she realized that many things she had once found strange had become almost familiar. She decided the period between fall and spring, a time of hibernation for the hibiscus, would be long enough to adjust to her new life. Just as the plant would eventually bloom again, she would be ready to accept her new country. By taking the test, Saeng will be moving on. The author included this last paragraph so that readers can infer that Saeng will take the final steps towards acceptance, using the winter hibiscus as a bridge to her past while stepping into her future.

The story includes this paragraph because at the very beginning, the girl failed her test and saw that her mother was upset about it. This initial failure creates a narrative problem that requires resolution. After they planted the plant together, the girl decided to take the test over again, knowing that her mother would approve of this effort and think the best of it. The paragraph is also necessary because the story started with her confessing the failure to her mother. If this follow-up were omitted, readers might be left wondering if the mother simply accepted the failure without any further action or encouragement. Furthermore, when a reader learns that the girl failed the test, they naturally want to know if she attempted it again and what motivated her to do so. This concluding action provides a satisfying answer to that narrative question and completes the character's arc of perseverance.

The author ended the story with an unconcluded ending, which is a deliberate narrative choice. This type of ending is written to keep readers interested and engaged, potentially making them want to read the author's other books to find more closure or continuation. With an ending of that sort, it also leaves room for improving upon the storyline and ample room for a sequel to be developed. It invites the audience to speculate on the characters' futures, thereby extending the life of the story beyond the final page and fostering a lasting connection with the reader.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is not going to give up until she successfully passes the task her mother gives her. Saeng fails the initial test because, though she buys a beautiful plant, it is far too expensive, prompting her mother to exclaim in dismay about the cost compared to vegetable seeds. Saeng becomes very upset and realizes that she has failed her mother in this specific endeavor. Despite this failure, Saeng still plants the winter hibiscus in the ground, tending to it with care. This action shows that even though she had failed the practical test, she was not going to give up on the hibiscus itself because it represented her homeland and was very special to her. Her perseverance in nurturing the plant signifies a deeper, more personal commitment that transcends the initial failure.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to provide a final, summarizing thought that encapsulates the central theme of the narrative. This concluding section serves to reinforce the main argument and leave the reader with a clear understanding of the author's primary intention, ensuring the text feels complete and well-rounded.

I think the author concluded the story with this paragraph because it shows that the character in the story is starting to adapt to her new country. In the beginning of the story the character Saeng is feeling homesick and has not adapted to her new country. She is on her way home from her driver’s test, which she just failed, and on the way she spots a hibiscus in a flower shop. The hibiscus is special to her because it reminds her of her home country of Vietnam. For Saeng the hibiscus represents comfort in time of disappointment, a connection to her past experiences, and the ability to overcome obstacles. Saeng has not adjusted to this change in her life and it has affected her badly. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because he wanted to show the reader that there will always be changes and obstacles in your life but there will always be something or someone that will help you overcome it. The author shows this by concluding the story with this paragraph and showing the reader that Saeng saw the hibiscus as her way of overcoming and when she is ready and she has adjusted she will take her driving test again, symbolizing her newfound resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he’s saying that once winter and spring are over and the hibiscus is budding, then Saeng will start over again and try again. The author is saying Saeng can’t wait till spring so she can plant her own little garden, which represents her hope and plans for the future. This forward-looking perspective, filled with anticipation for new beginnings, is why I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph, leaving the reader with a sense of optimistic closure.

This paragraph represents an action that Saeng is going to do over a time period of a year. She is going to build up and change in time for the retake of the test; it is like a rebirth in a way. The girl wants to be a whole new person for when the test comes up again. Her mom seems to be bothered by every action or choice of her daughter. The daughter suddenly realizes the action of the hibiscus and why it dies. She contemplates "the quiet repetition of season upon season." She relates the flower and geese to herself. Over the year the flower goes through phases, dying then experiencing rebirth. Saeng wants to get better once she goes through a phase like the flower, which opens up to be beautiful again, mirroring her own desired transformation.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is that when Saeng comes back from taking her driver's test, on the way home she saw a winter hibiscus that was so beautiful. Then she went to the store and bought that flower, and it cost a lot of money. When she got home and her mom was planting vegetables, her mom asked what it was. She told the truth and her mom, knowing that the flower cost a lot of money, got mad at the extravagance of her purchase. Saeng took a big decision that she was going to keep the flower even though her mom was mad, because she loved it, I guess, because it reminded her of Vietnam. The author put this paragraph, I think, to show that just as the geese return and the flowers grow, she will take the test again. When she bought it, no flowers had come out yet, so when they finally bloom, she will go again. This signifies that you must first plant the seed and wait for it to grow before you can succeed. In my opinion, that is a good ending and it is a good question too, as it beautifully ties the natural cycle to personal perseverance.

The author concludes the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself...," because it offers the reader a conclusive and hopeful resolution. That passage means that Saeng will try taking her driver's test again once she has more fully adjusted to her new life in a new country. Once she can find familiarity in her surroundings, such as recognizing the seasonal return of the geese, she will feel more at home. Throughout the story, her detachment from Vietnam makes her feel profoundly alone. The hibiscus plant is what first offers her a tangible sense of comfort, "It felt smooth and cool... just as she had known it would feel." The ending paragraph shows that Saeng will ultimately find more comfort and a sense of belonging in @LOCATION2 than just a plant and a couple of geese, integrating her past with her present.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when the snow does melt and the geese return, it will signal the time to plant and work in the garden. The narrative connects this natural cycle to Saeng's personal growth; with snow on the ground you cannot plant, but the geese's return marks the season to plant seeds and foster new beginnings. The test she plans to retake is to see if she can achieve a better outcome than last year, and the year before that, paralleling the annual renewal of the garden and her own persistent efforts to succeed in her new environment. This cyclical pattern underscores her determination and hope for the future.

The author concluded the story with that particular paragraph because it provides a fitting and resonant ending for the narrative's themes. The choice reflects a deliberate literary decision to leave the reader with a specific emotional tone and a sense of closure. The paragraph serves to crystallize the character's resolve and the story's central message, which is why the author ended it in that manner. This final thought effectively encapsulates Saeng's journey and her quiet determination moving forward.

The author concludes the story with “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to show how Saeng is adapting and making purposeful decisions in her new country, just as she did in her homeland. In Vietnam, Saeng used to brush her grandmother’s hair and help put it into a bun, placing a hibiscus in it as part of their tradition. Also, when she fetched water from the well, a hibiscus would sometimes come up with the bucket. Thus, the hibiscus was consistently seen as a comfort object from her past. Now, as she is in the states, she is trying to put this symbol to good use while also observing the new cycles around her. She notices that the geese come back in the spring and leave in the winter, and that plants begin to grow anew in the spring. By deciding to take the test again in the spring, she is symbolically aligning herself with this season of rebirth, ready to start anew just like the hibiscus that is going to bloom. The plant being potted in her garden and Saeng moving there both signify significant change, but also a remembrance of old traditions and the creation of a space for new ones to take root.

The author included that sentence in the story because it reflects Saeng's practical and emotional reasoning. She feels that waiting for spring will give her enough time to properly prepare and get the test right. Furthermore, her connection to the geese, creatures she likes and observes, provides a natural and comforting marker of time. This simple justification underscores her desire to attempt the test again only when she feels truly ready, linking her personal goal to a positive and familiar sign in her new environment.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show the final determination and inner strength Saeng has been given. It’s almost as though it’s taken this resilient plant to show her how to get back up and pass the test. The plant becomes a comporting item that reminds her of her homeland and her past. She returned with the plant to show her mother but found herself too shaky to even say the words “at home". This poignant moment shows how much she misses her original home. But through this experience, she is able to realize that this is her new home and everything, from the streets to the seasons, is becoming more familiar to her, allowing her to finally feel a sense of belonging.

She ends it with this sentence because its a sign of new life and hope. Just as the winter that killed the plants is ending life, the spring will inevitably come and start anew. This cyclical process is how Saeng feels because she left her country and all the memories left behind; she feels out of place and dormant like the winter hibiscus. But as the spring comes she’ll feel as an anew person, ready and able to take challenges as she said here: “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now". She describes that with a new season comes new changes and upon those changes she will go on to take the drivers test again with renewed confidence and strength.

The author ends with that paragraph for several important reasons. One is to show that even though she has failed this time, more opportunities will surely come later, just as the seasons turn. Also, it shows that even though bad times befall her now, good times are still to come, offering a message of resilience and hope. The paragraph connects her personal growth to the natural world, making her realization more profound. For these reasons, it was a powerful and efficient way to end the story, leaving the reader with a sense of optimistic closure.

The author uses symbolism to convey a different and deeper message. Saeng said, “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, and then I will take that test again." The author uses the hibiscus to symbolize how Saeng, like the hibiscus, needs time to grow and mature; that then she will be ready to take that test again. The plant's cycle mirrors her own journey of adaptation. The author uses this symbolize to convey more of the story's emotional depth and the theme of patient renewal, enriching the narrative without explicit statement.

She wrote that response to tell everyone that she will be ready and prepared by the time when spring comes, a season of renewal and new beginnings. Then, with the newfound strength symbolized by the changing season, she will take the test again and, with determination and learned resilience, she will pass. This conclusion provides a clear sense of her resolve and optimism for the future, showing that she has not given up but is instead planning for her eventual success, thus wrapping up her character's arc on a hopeful and forward-looking note.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng wants to start planting again. I know this because Saeng's life revolves around planting and the changing seasons. Saeng and her mother get most of their food from what they plant in their garden. So all throughout the year, they spend most of their time working in the garden, growing crops to sell and to save for their own use. They save their harvest for the winter and sell the surplus to get the equipment they need to continue what they do. The part she is talking about in the paragraph that says "when they come back" is talking about the geese returning. She loves watching the geese flying over her head and landing in the yard when she is outside on a beautiful day in the spring. When the snow melts she wants to get back into the soil on her hands and knees to start planting again. Once the hibiscus starts budding, everything else in her garden begins growing. Saeng's life truly revolves around the annual cycle of planting. The author put this paragraph in the story because this return to the garden is what Saeng wants to do more than anything else, marking a renewal of her spirit and her most essential work.

In the conclusion of "The Winter Hibiscus," Saeng notes how she will retake her driving test in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return. The spring is when these hopeful events occur, along with the annual budding of the winter hibiscus plant. Her family had moved from their warm homeland of Vietnam to a new, colder location, and she had bought a winter hibiscus plant to remind her of her childhood and her previous home. When it blooms, she feels it is the right time to retake her driving test because the flower's blossoming will bring her the hope and courage for a new beginning in her life, and as a citizen in her new country. This symbolic new start is tied directly to the natural cycle that the hibiscus represents for her.

In the short story "The Winter Hibiscus," a young girl named Saeng moves away from her home to a new country. This short story focuses on the girl's experience as she is trying to adapt to the new lifestyle and the many changes she encounters in her unfamiliar surroundings. She faces challenges with the language, the climate, and the culture, all of which are vastly different from what she knew before. The story details her struggle to find a sense of belonging and a connection to her past while navigating this new world, showing her journey of adjustment and the resilience required to build a new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants the reader to see that Saeng will not stop trying until she passes her driver's test, just like the geese won't stop flying until they are in the south for the winter. The author is trying to show the beauty of trying again and persevering through your obstacles to reach your goal. The comparison to the migrating geese highlights a natural, unstoppable determination. This parallel suggests that Saeng's resolve is as instinctive and powerful as the geese's journey, emphasizing that persistence in the face of difficulty is a noble and beautiful part of life's journey toward achieving one's aims.

In the story "The Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author leaves the story off with a powerful and resonant ending. The ending was, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will try the test again." Basically, the author concluded the story with that because it shows she's powerful in spirit, that she's willing to try and make herself stronger by facing her challenges, that she's willing to try again after a failure, and that she wants to help herself succeed. Text examples to prove this would be, “then I will take the driving test again," which shows her determination. Another is, "Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become familiar," showing her growing adaptation. Finally, "There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply," highlights the strength she sees in resilience. All those statements help backup why the author might leave such a powerful paragraph for last, to underscore the theme of inner strength and renewal.

The author of the story "Winter Hibiscus" concludes with the paragraph to show how often Saeng gets tested by her memories. Saeng has been "tested" earlier in the story when she was in a florist shop. There, memories come rushing back to her like a flood, and she tried to feel the same as she did long ago when her grandmother was there. She realized that things in her memories were long gone, so she wept. Saeng reported to her mother that she had failed the test, and bought the plant to try and comfort herself. Her mother was very understanding and accepted the situation. Saeng planted the hibiscus and at the end says that "In the spring when the snow melts, this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". Saeng knew that seeing the flower again would make her cry and bring her memories back, meaning she will be re-tested by the past, but she is now prepared to face it.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, a girl named Saeng failed her driver's test that day then vowed that she would retake it in the spring. She ends with this statement to say that it is a new season and a new beginning for her in her new life. This archetype, being the change from the harsh cold of winter to the nice warmth of springtime, shows that the troubles for her mother and Saeng would get better. As the hard, troubled winter is left behind, there is a calm, warm new beginning with spring. Saeng knows this transformation is symbolic of her own life and knows with this new hope that she is going to pass.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for various reasons. For example, the whole passage is talking about how the hibiscus flower provides Saeng with the ability to overcome obstacles and comfort her in a time of disappointment. This ending paragraph shows that “in the spring, when the hibiscus is budding,” and everything is beautiful again, then Saeng will take her test again. She knows that with the help of the hibiscus plant, which serves as a tangible link to her heritage and inner strength, she will pass the test. It shows that her hope and trust to pass the test comes from the symbolic hibiscus flower. The plant with “waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers” will provide her the strength, determination, courage, and will power to pass the test in the spring, serving as her personal talisman for success.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus”, the author ends with the statement, “…then I’ll take the test again.” This shows that Saeng is willing to try to adapt to this new place she lives in. That adaptation is what refers to when she says “test”. For example, in the story she said, “I-I failed the test,” when her mother asked her what was wrong, referring to her driver's test but also her struggle to belong. She spent so much money on that plant hoping to stay home in her mind and reconnect with her past. She just couldn’t handle the overwhelming feelings of displacement at that moment. She ends with the positive statement because it just sends the message that she now looks forward to a bright future in her new home, ready to try once more.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho the author concludes the story with that paragraph for many reasons. She puts in examples from the story that could help find these reasons. One reason is that we know she won't give up. In the story she says “Then I will take the test again.” It tells us that she will keep trying and is determined to do so, showing her resilience. Another reason is that she’s trying to tell us that there is a future for the hibiscus. This is shown when she says “…and this hibiscus is budding,” indicating that the hibiscus has a chance to change and get used to its new surroundings, just like the girl in the story will be doing. A last reason is that it tells us that she is and will be doing her best. When the text says she realized that many of the things that she had thought were strange were almost familiar to her now, it shows she is trying to get used to her surroundings and now realizes she can adapt. In the story there are many reasons to suspect why she ended with that paragraph, as she gives examples that illustrate Saeng's journey toward acceptance and hope.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story determined to pass the test after the winter is over and the flower is budding. This shows the connection between the plant and the narrator and the hardships of each. The winter represents an obstacle for the flower, but it will live through it to thrive in the spring. This gives the author confidence that she too can make it through her hardships to thrive. Another hardship that she and the hibiscus both face is being "root bound." The author misses her home of Vietnam very much, feeling confined by her new surroundings just as the plant is confined by its pot. However, both of them must and will adapt to their new environments, finding a way to grow and flourish despite their constraints. The hibiscus thus becomes a powerful symbol of resilience and the possibility of new beginnings.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that she misses her home and that affected her driving test. At her home country it was warm and she had all her family memories, a comforting contrast to her current life. In the new country it is cold and snowy, something she isn't used to, and this unfamiliarity distracts her and undermines her confidence. It states she will take the test again when all these things happen because it will feel like her home country and she will be more focused on the test and not what she misses. The changing seasons represent a personal timeline for her adaptation, where the return of warmth will signal her readiness to succeed. Her plan to retake the test is therefore tied to achieving a sense of belonging and comfort in her new home.

The author Minfong Ho concluded the story “Winter Hibiscus” with that certain paragraph to show that Saeng would not give up, that she was determined to pass the driving test and also in a way get used to her new home. It is kind of like a motivation, “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The motivation is the flower, bringing back good memories of people that made her happy and believed in her. Minfong also concluded the story the way she did to say, by next year Saeng will start fresh. To become happy with her new life and not dwell on her past. Saeng says, “.. in the spring...” it’s the beginning of a new year to start over, and rejoice. This was a really good way to end the story, because it sets a positive vibe. It’s letting the readers know that Saeng is a strong person, who can remember the past but move on to a new day and life. And I think the author is trying to point out that everyone should have the strength to do the same, using memories not as anchors but as foundations for future growth. The hopeful conclusion affirms the universal capacity for resilience and renewal.

She ended it with that paragraph because she wanted to prove even though she misses the “old country” she will adapt and survive. The paragraph serves as her declaration of resilience, acknowledging her deep connection to her past while firmly committing to her future. It shows her acceptance that life has changed, but also her belief in her own strength to meet its challenges. This final thought encapsulates her journey from longing to determination, illustrating that survival involves both remembering where you came from and bravely facing where you are. Her resolve to persevere in a new land is the story's ultimate message of hope.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it sounds hopeful. She wasn't adapting to her new home very well and that made her feel hopeless. Saeng failed her driving test which only made things worse for her, reinforcing her feelings of isolation and failure. To make things better, she bought a hibiscus that reminded her of her old home, a tangible link to her cherished memories. She found the plant to be very comforting and it helped her get past the tough times, serving as a symbol of enduring life. In the last paragraph, Saeng is looking forward to the spring so she can retake the test and hopefully pass it this time, linking her personal growth to the natural cycle of rebirth. I think the paragraph provides a feeling of hopefulness which is why the author concluded the story the way they did, leaving the reader with a sense of optimistic anticipation for Saeng's future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng will not give up and there is still hope. It is also to teach the reader to have hope and patience and the knowledge that things take time. Saeng failed the test of not giving into her sorrows and misery of missing her country, but she is learning to adapt. She says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This shows that she is adjusting to her new life. So by ending it with this and comparing to the geese, its showing that she is getting stronger and more resilient. She will take the test again because she wont give up, demonstrating her enduring spirit.

Clearly From rending the story Winter @CAPS1, the author @CAPS2 this phrase “when they come Back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test Again” in the story because the passage relates to the title of the story Winter @CAPS1. The mention of the winter season connects directly to the story's title, and the vow for spring represents a future hope that contrasts with the current hardship. This cyclical reference to the seasons reinforces the central theme of patience and renewal embedded within the narrative.

The reason the author concludes the story with that paragraph is because, even though Saeng didn’t do well on her last test, Saeng will go back and take it again so she can pass it. The author is showing Saeng’s determination to pass the test and do better next time. This final resolve highlights her character development, transforming a moment of failure into a promise for future success. Her decision to try again underscores the core message of perseverance in the face of adversity.

I think the author ends the story with that paragraph because it is linting the plant that stands for many positive things to the character that failed the test that the really wanted to pass. Both the character and the plant show perservirance and I think the author is trying to send a message to the reader to never give up on something you want to accomplish. The plant gives an emblem of perseverance because it survives through the harsh winter, waiting to bloom again. The main character isn’t giving up on the test she wants to pass, mirroring the plant's resilience. The author is giving a message not to give up, using the hibiscus as a powerful symbol of enduring hope.

At the end of the story the author says “when they come back in the spring, whe the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that again.” The author concludes this at the end because she felt like she didn’t do her best because she failed so when the spring comes again She is going to retry to do it and hopefully this time she will past. This vow ties her personal resolve to the natural cycle of renewal, suggesting that just as spring returns, so too will her opportunity to succeed. Her commitment to a future attempt provides an uplifting and hopeful conclusion to her story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to come back and do the smell test again when the snow melts and the geese return. This final thought shows her commitment to reconnecting with the natural world around her, using the changing seasons as a marker for her own personal renewal and another attempt to engage with her new environment through her senses.

The story is about a girl named Saeng. She is a teenager whose family just moved to the United States from Vietnam. After Saeng failed her driving test, she discovered a beautiful plant named Hibiscus on her walk home and immediately falls in love with it. Saeng's mother has a garden she is always planting things and using plants and veggies from her garden for dinner. The author concludes with a paragraph that says when the Hibiscus plants are budding in the spring, Saeng will take the test again. I think Saeng says this because she wants to see the beautiful plants when she passes the test, and she believes seeing the Hibiscus will help her pass the driving test by giving her confidence and a sense of beauty.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because she is giving herself hope for passing her test. The hibiscus will have started sprouting, and its growth will give her the strength to take the test again and hopefully pass it. This is all because the winter hibiscus reminded her of home, providing a comforting link to her past that empowers her to face future challenges in her new life.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph of "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because this paragraph can show that the hibiscus is the reason why Saeng wants to try the test again. If the hibiscus is budding after the snow melts and the geese return, then she can act like the hibiscus, be strong, and won’t give up on her test. The plant's resilience serves as a direct inspiration for her own determination to persevere.

The author concludes the story with this to show that Saeng won’t give up, illustrating that it is possible to adapt and try to love what is around you. Saeng struggled to get out “I-I failed the test” and couldn’t say “at home,” which shows her insecurity and loneliness in the new world around her. By saying she will try again in the spring, it gives the reader hope that she will adapt and love her surroundings. She goes through an experience today comparing her old life to the one she is living in now, noting they have some similarities, and her decision to try again in the spring means she has decided to give this new place a chance and embrace her new life.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she says, “Then I will take that test again,” showing her belief in the Flowers. She sees a parallel between her own journey and that of the Flowers, as they both adapt to their circumstances. They both demonstrate a powerful determination to thrive in difficult places. They both overcome significant obstacles, and this shared resilience gives her hope. Maybe she wants to see what lays ahead for her, just as the Flowers emerge in spring. Ultimately, she hopes she is right about the Flowers, and perhaps she simply likes the promise that spring represents.

I actually like the way the author concludes the story with this paragraph. It effectively summarizes the core themes of the story and sums them up into a few poignant words that leave a lasting impression. This conclusion makes you wonder what happened next to the characters, and if there is perhaps a sequel that continues their journey. This is a very good story that I personally can relate to in many ways, as it touches on universal experiences of growth and reflection. The ending perfectly captures the story's emotional resonance.

The reason why the author concludes with this type of scenario is simply because the author illustrates a character who has a pain to cross, or a challenging situation to overcome. In this particular story, you see a struggle, but if you get the message straight, you’ll open your eyes and see that its your time to shine. The conclusion serves as a call to action, suggesting you might as well grab that opportunity before you loose your chance. It emphasizes that you only get one day to prove you are worthy to the people who are watching, so you must seize the moment with conviction.

The author concludes with this sentence because he is showing the girl's renewed confidence in herself and her abilities. This final statement not only highlights her personal growth but also gives her a clear timeline, implying she has enough time to properly get ready for the next test she will face. Furthermore, she has found a symbolic guide for her readiness; she knows with certainty that she will be prepared when her flower starts to bud, linking her fate to a natural and hopeful process. This connection provides a satisfying and symbolic end to her arc.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph so he can potentially write another story building on the promise made silently by the character. The final line sets a future scene, and he will write the continuation of the story in the spring when they come back, leaving a clear opening for a sequel. This technique creates anticipation for the next chapter in the characters' lives, making the reader look forward to the narrative's return just as the characters return with the new season. It is a clever way to hint at future adventures while providing a sense of cyclical closure.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she was expressing a conditional hope, saying that if it is possible for these impossible things to happen then she should be able to take the test and pass it. She was comparing things together that she knew logically do not go together in her new, cold environment. For example she said that in spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this specific hibiscus is budding, then and only then would she take the test over. She meant that if the thing she likes the most, symbolized by the tropical flower, overcomes its climatic obstacle then she would do what hurted her the most over again. She doesnít know if she takes the test over she would pass, but she would keep trying over and over until she succeeds. In the story she doesnít know how to fit in this new world. All she knows is what she learned in her home country, which feels entirely different. All she have to do is try harder and she maybe will be able to pass his test, finding her own strength through this symbolic promise.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because when she told her mom she failed her test she was crying, but I think it was deeper than that simple failure. I think she missed home so much that she couldn't concentrate on studying or the test itself. The disappointment of the test became a safe outlet for her deeper, more profound sadness. She had to cry about something immediate because she didn't want to let her mom know the true depth of her homesickness, fearing it would be an additional burden. The tears for the test were real, but they masked a larger, more persistent ache for the home she left behind, which was the true root of her struggle.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. The author concludes the story with this vow because it shows Saeng finding a new resolve and a personal timeline for her courage. The scene continues as if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel. This image of her mother's quiet, persistent labor mirrors the determination Saeng is now forging within herself, connecting her future effort to the enduring, hardworking spirit of her family. The ending thus ties Saeng's personal promise to the ongoing cycle of work and seasons that defines her new life.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it is showing that the hibiscus inspires her and gives a comfort that no person could try and do. For example, after Saeng failed her drivers test, she was deeply disappointed and felt out of place. On her way home she saw a hibiscus and was drawn to it, leading her to a florist shop to try and buy it. Saeng took a peddle from the plant and held it tightly while she closed her eyes, seeking solace. The plant vividly reminded her of her real home in vietnam which she loved and missed dearly. The hibuscus became a powerful form of comfort for Saeng since she had just failed her drivers test, even though the plant was not the same species as the one at home. By the author ending the story with Saeng saying she will wait until the hibiscus starts budding to take the test again, it shows that the hibiscus helps her to overcome obstacles in life and it helps her to get through the hardships she faces by connecting her to a sense of hope and cultural memory.

What Saeng means at the end of the paragraph is that she will wait for a specific season, a time when those plants she remembers are in bloom, to take the test again. The test itself seems to be a beginning, a way to start to understand and appreciate her new environment, much like one learns to like a plot. She must learn to see the likeable features and characters about this new place, to find beauty in it as she did in her homeland. Also, she needs to learn the history and nature about these plants and this new land, weaving them into her own story. Her vow is a promise to herself to bridge the gap between her past and her present when the conditions feel right, using the natural world as her guide and calendar for this personal growth.

She is demanding to not take the test again if the winter hibiscus don't come back, for she was deeply upset that she had failed the test. She spent most of her day looking at the bare branches of the hibiscus, a constant reminder of her loss, but she was still upset that they were not the real ones back at home, the vibrant flowers of her memories. Her mother reassured her, saying they are strong enough to make it through the winter, a statement that planted a seed of hope. When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this very hibiscus is budding with new life, then I will take that test again, finding her own strength in its resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it symbolizes the enduring hope that things will get better. The author ends with this sentiment of hope because the flower symbolizes the girl's own journey, and the girl is saying that if the flower can survive the harsh year, so can she. This symbolizes a profound hope because the girl is realizing that it is going to take time and patience before she can fully adapt to her new country, but eventually she will succeed. This is particularly meaningful because the girl considers the day she had to be horrible, filled with failure and longing, and this final statement ends her difficult day on a good and promising note. The girl spends the entire day wishing that she were back in her own country, missing her grandmother and old friends intensely. But this paragraph marks the pivotal moment of the girl vowing a promise to herself that she will withstand the emotional winter until spring arrives, believing it will get better when she can take the test again. The entire story builds up to this turning point when Saeng realizes that she will make it through this struggle just like this flower will make it through the winter. Ultimately, Saeng realizes that it is going to take time for her to adapt to this new and strange country and the new lifestyle that she must adopt, but she now has the faith to begin.

The author concludes this story with this sentence because it powerfully shows hope for the future. This single sentence lets readers know that times are hard now, a period of winter and difficulty, but in time things will get better with the coming spring. Saeng might have failed this test, a significant setback, but she is not giving up hope on passing it eventually. She believes with conviction that she will pass that test in the spring, when the time is right and conditions are more favorable. Saeng might miss her home terribly, a deep and persistent ache, but she will not let that sorrow interfere with her future prospects and determination. That is precisely why the author concludes the story with the line, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” as it encapsulates her newfound resolve.

What the author is talking about is that the snow was melting and the spring is coming, a time of renewal. I guess what they mean is that flowers, trees and grass are going back to being beautiful, awakening from their winter sleep. Also he was letting us know that spring is here and that it is not winter anymore, a change in the season. That is likely why she starts to plant plants in the winter, preparing for the future. So in the spring they can grow out to be nice and beautiful for the spring season, fulfilling their purpose. That is what I think the author meant to convey about cycles of life and growth. Also that is the reason why he put that description in the paragraph, to illustrate this transition. He could have added more to the paragraph like describing how the plants and stuff was growing so beautiful, with more vivid imagery. He should have added more details to let us know more clearly what he was talking about in this paragraph, to strengthen the connection for the reader.

The author chose to end the story in this way because it effectively ties in different aspects and principles of the story into a single, powerful image. For example, this final sentence includes both the geese, representing migration and memory, and the hibiscus, representing her new home and the old, together in harmony and coexistence. It also states that "... Saeng vowed silently to herself... I will take that test again," which relates directly to the determination and resilience of the hibiscus flower, which struggles persistently through the cold winter to bloom again. A lot of wisdom can be gathered from the symbolic messages hidden within that final sentence, offering a lesson in perseverance. It implies that, though the past may be behind you, it is with you in your heart as you face new challenges and unfamiliar situations, and if you are determined and steadfast, those challenges can be conquered in time.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph they do because it shows Saeng's determination and her overcoming her obstacles of being new in a country. With all of the doubts Saeng had right after her test, it is very significant of her to come to the conclusion of retaking the test, as shown when she says, “Here, let me help you, mother,” she offered. With her mom comforting her and telling her it is okay, this gives Saeng the emotional boost she needs to help her mother and think to herself that she can’t let just one failure hold her back in life. With the support system Saeng has from her family, she will definitely be better prepared to pass the test the next time she attempts it.

In the story “The Winter Hibiscus,” the author Minfong Ho ends with the vow, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." She ended with this to show Saeng's determination to do good in her new country and to show that the memories of her grandmother help her to strive for the best in her new home. In the beginning of the story, Saeng is at a flower shop and she sees all the flowers of her home country growing in pots. At the sight of all these flowers, memories flood back to her, memories that bring her both joy and sadness. Then when she returns home, she tells her mother that she failed the test, and you can tell from her actions that she is disappointed, “I-I failed the test,” Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. After a while, she planted the hibiscus in the vegetable garden. The buying and planting of the flower shows that Saeng wants to remember her grandmother and her homeland. Thinking about her grandmother helps her to strive for better and helps her want to succeed in her new home. The memories of her grandmother make her sad but in a way also make her happy and provide her with strength.

The author concludes the story this way with a quote that says she will get another try at something. Many authors end stories in a different way because it makes the reader want to go on to a sequel or the next story, and it really adds a twist to the ending. Also, another reason an author would end like that is because they want you to use your imagination so you can picture what happens next. Using this technique is effective because you know what has already happened, and it makes the reader wonder if she fails or succeeds the next time around. This sense of open-ended possibility engages the reader more deeply with the character's future.

The author closes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is willing to try again. Even though it may not be right away, Saeng wants to try to see all of the flowers that remind her of home again without breaking down emotionally. She can tell that although her mother is understanding, Saeng feels she has let her down a little bit. “But how could you? You know how much we—what happened?” When her mother says this, Saeng feels that she has indeed let her mother down. But then, Mrs. Panouvong expresses that she is glad Saeng tried her best, after hearing that she had failed. Sensing her mother’s inkling of disappointment, Saeng’s resolve to try again is strengthened, showing her growing resilience.

Most likely the author concludes this story with that paragraph because the author wanted to show that Saeng was a very determined person. The author wanted to show readers that Saeng was a strong character because throughout the story she seemed very determined to pass the test for the first time. But when she failed, the author wanted to show that Saeng was not going to give up hope and that she was going to take the test again. This final resolve highlights her inner strength and her commitment to persevering despite the setback she faced.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph so you can get a clear view of what she is saying and also so you can understand it from her situation while she was growing up. For example, she said that her experiences were shaped by the specific environment and challenges she faced during her youth, which provides essential context for her final reflections. This allows the reader to fully grasp the emotional and situational background that informs her concluding thoughts, ensuring the message is received as intended from her unique perspective.

The author concludes the story with the sentence "when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because he is making a point about the immigrant experience. The point the author is making is that when immigrants came to America they were often told to forget where they were from and to assimilate completely. The word "test" in the story metaphorically means getting used to her new life in the United States and forgetting her homeland. Saeng says those words because she failed this test of assimilation and bought a hibiscus plant, something that powerfully reminded her of her homeland. In conclusion, the author is describing how immigrants were treated and told to forget who they were because they are in America now, a pressure that Saeng ultimately resists by clinging to her memories and heritage.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author was trying to say that Saeng was from somewhere different than where she is now, highlighting her sense of displacement. In the text it says “It was like walking into another world,” which illustrates that she is there thinking like nobody knows him except for him and him only, emphasizing her profound feelings of isolation and anonymity in this new and unfamiliar environment. This conveys the deep cultural and personal divide she experiences as an immigrant, making her former life feel distant and unknown to those around her in her new home.

The author concludes this story with that paragraph because it shows clear signs of hope and the comforting knowledge that spring will come again. This seasonal change represents a new beginning for the family and the reassurance that everything will be okay for them also. The paragraph suggests that the girl will makes friends also when spring comes, as the warmer weather and renewed environment will provide opportunities for connection and a brighter future, ultimately leaving the reader with a sense of optimistic closure.

In “Winter Hibiscus” Saeng took her driver’s test and failed it, but she wants to try and take it again in the spring. I think she ends the story by saying that because in the spring the hibiscus plant that she got and her and her mom planted will be growing and blooming, and the geese will be back, which makes her feel more at home. That way she will feel a sense of comfort and be able to take the test and pass, because the familiar sights and symbols will remind her of being home and give her the confidence she previously lacked. This connection to her heritage provides her with the inner strength needed to face the challenges of her new life.

In the end of the story they say that she will take the test over again, in the spring when the geese come back from the winter fly. What they are saying is that she will make a fresh start in the spring when the geese come back, so she would just be starting all over again fresh new start to a new year and a new time to study for the big test and time to regroup from the last test that she took and failed the test she will just get a new start and a new chance to do something over again. Her mom was in disbelief when she found out that she failed the test, her mom said to her that it will be ok and you can take it over again, in a new season, a time of renewal and growth. This promise of a second chance gave her the comfort and strength she needed to look forward. Her mother's supportive words helped to soften the initial shock and disappointment, allowing her to see a path forward with renewed determination and a clearer focus for the future, ensuring she would be better prepared next time.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she is thinking what it will be like when all of this happens. Saeng said; “when they come back, she vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This internal vow marks a pivotal moment of personal resolve, connecting her personal growth to the natural cycles she observes around her. The budding flower and the returning geese become symbols of her own potential for renewal and success. By aligning her goal with the turning of the seasons, she frames her future attempt not as a repetition of failure, but as a natural and hopeful new beginning that is destined to arrive with the spring.

The author of the story concludes the text with that paragraph to end on a good note and show hope for the future. First, throughout the story Saeng felt lonely and depressed because she missed her home in Vietnam. With all this depression Saeng saw the winter hibiscus that reminded her of her childhood memories. She felt a little hope for adapting to the new environment and new life. The flower represented the light and hope for the future. Next, it shows perserverance factor in the story Saeng fails her drivers test and came home feeling unacomplished. When she says she will retake the test in the spring when the hibiscus blooms it shows perserverance and never giving up. Lastly, the author ended the passage with that paragraph to end on a good note and show a positive outlook on life. No matter where you come from with love and perserverance you can overcome any obstacle. Whether it be your school, tests or home with a little hardwork and faith you can achieve your goals and build a fulfilling life in a new place. The conclusion thus serves as a powerful and uplifting message about resilience and the universal capacity for a fresh start.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show that she will do this once she has gotten use to the change of her new country. When she says, “When the geese return” their faint honks and flying overhead are familiar to her now season upon season. Also when the hibiscus is budding because this will remind her of her home in Vietnam seeing flower and hearing these geese will give her the confidence and encouragement to retake the drivers test. These familiar natural signs act as anchors, providing her with a sense of belonging and a connection between her past and her future. By waiting for these specific symbols of continuity and life, she is giving herself the time needed to fully settle in, ensuring that her next attempt is backed by a stronger, more adapted sense of self. This thoughtful timing reflects her strategic and hopeful approach to overcoming the challenges of her new life.

My detail on Saeng vowed silently to herself because she had difficuilty makeing new friends. She like to plant stuff around her because she feels like Plants are her friends, Saeng took the shovel and finished the planting for her mom that make Saeng feel so good about herself. This simple, solitary act of gardening provided a tangible sense of accomplishment and peace that social interactions had failed to offer. In the quiet company of plants, she found a reliable comfort and a way to express herself without words. Tending to the earth became her way of nurturing her own spirit, building the inner confidence she needed to face other challenges, like the vow she made to retake her test. This connection to nature was a fundamental source of her strength and personal satisfaction.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” decided to end the story with this paragraph because it signifies a new beginning for Saeng. After Saeng moves and fails the test, she feels disheartened. The winter hibiscus comforts her, evoking memories of where she used to live and providing a sense of continuity. It gives her hope for the future, as in the winter the plant would not be as vibrant as it would become in the spring. Spring is traditionally a time for new beginnings because in the winter everything seems to die, only to come back to life in the spring. Similarly, Saeng feels she would take the test again as her own new beginning. From my personal experience, I always do spring cleaning because I want to begin fresh, and the season is filled with fresh air that gives me inspiration to do good. This could be why Saeng wants to take the test in the spring time, associating it with renewal. Therefore, the author decided to end the story with that paragraph to show how Saeng wanted a new beginning and found the motivation to try again.

Authors sometimes conclude a story with a certain paragraph describing an action that will take place in the future to emphasize transformation. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes by saying, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” One reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to help show that things will change come spring. For example, in the story the girl says, “I-I failed the test.” By her stating this and then planning to retake the test in spring, it shows she believes she can change and improve so that this time she will pass. Also, the line, “The ‘winter hibiscus’ was in the ground now, and she tamped down the soil around it,” helps show that the hibiscus is being planted in its dormant state, but come spring it will have changed color and fully bloomed, mirroring Saeng's own potential for growth. In conclusion, authors end stories with a paragraph like this to illustrate the hopeful changes that could happen in the future, leaving the reader with a sense of anticipation.

The author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons, each tied to a specific symbol. The “budding hibiscus” symbolizes comfort for Saeng. When moving to a new country, she could not take all her friends and possessions with her, but she could bring her memories. The flower reminds her of home, which is comforting after the disappointment of failing her driver's test. In addition, the “geese returning” symbolizes a new beginning. After being away for so long, the geese returning ushers in spring, a time to start all over after a dreary winter, reflecting Saeng's own desire for a fresh start. Finally, the line, “then I will take that test again,” demonstrates that one should never give up. Even though it was hard for her to adapt to a new country, she made friends and tried new foods, like a Big Mac, showing her resilience. Therefore, Minfong Ho concludes the story with the paragraph to powerfully show the themes of comfort, new beginnings, and the importance of never giving up.

The reason why the author wanted to put that last paragraph in the story is because they want to keep the reader interested and thinking about the characters' futures. Another reason why the author included that part in the story is that it is letting the reader know that the plant, much like the main character, will never give up despite the harsh winter conditions. This parallel between the enduring plant and Saeng's own determination creates a lasting impression, suggesting that hope and perseverance continue beyond the final page. The ending thus serves to leave the reader with a sense of ongoing possibility and resilience.

The author concludes the story with the quote, “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show that she is encouraged by the memories of her homeland. For example, in the story it stated that she realized many things in her new environment were similar to things in her homeland. As the seasons went by, she discovered these comforting similarities, which helped her adjust. The spring time, in particular, reminded Saeng of her home, so when it comes she will feel motivated and emotionally prepared to take the test again.
