In conclusion, the author included the quote to show how she is encouraged by memories of her homeland, using the familiar signs of spring to fuel her resolve for the future.

The author concludes the story with the main character vowing to take the driver's test again to symbolize moving forward. This resolution is prompted by a pivotal moment where Saeng, upon stumbling to a florist shop, sees a flower that reminded her of her homeland, Vietnam. The sight of the hibiscus causes a profound reaction, as “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.” This encounter triggers a process of maturation, which is further shown when she assists her mother, saying, “Here, let me help, mother.” In relieving her mother in the task of planting the seed that she had bought, she began to mature emotionally. After reflecting on the memories of her past and coming to peace with them, she realizes there was nothing left stopping her from moving forward. Her vow, “when they come back I will take that test again,” is made as she sees geese migrating south for the winter in a V formation. This natural phenomenon inspires her to set a goal for herself, using that goal as a tool to help herself grow and move forward in the new country she is in. The main character’s vow in “Winter Hibiscus” thus powerfully symbolizes her decision to move forward.

It shows in this time of doubt that she will overcome the challenges she faces. In the story, the plant served as a crucial symbol, for it showed hope and in showing this, it ultimately gave her hope as well. All the memories that she recalled, particularly those of her past life, had made her sad at first, stirring a deep sense of nostalgia and loss. However, through her reflection, these same memories ultimately gave her hope for the future. This emotional journey from sorrow to optimism underscores her resilience and capacity for growth.

I think the author concludes the story with that statement simply because he is trying to send out some sort of message to people and get their attention regarding themes of perseverance and new beginnings. The author also could have concluded the story with that statement because maybe he just felt like he needed to do that to provide a sense of closure for the character's arc. It is possible he didn't have a particular reason for doing it beyond a stylistic choice to leave the ending open to interpretation. Ultimately, the conclusion stands as a final, resonant note in the narrative.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with the paragraph "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take the test again" because its sympathizing Saeng's ability to overcome her sorrow and give the test another chance. This is symbolised by when she says "when the geese return and the hibiscus," linking her personal resolve to natural cycles. After the failure of the test, she wasn't originally considering retaking it, but instead just wished she could return to her old home and not have to think about it. But much like the geese returning in the spring, she says she will retake the test. She is like the geese because they overcome and adapt to the cold harsh weather by flying elsewhere and returning when it's warm; like her, she must wait until she is more ready and confident to take the test the second time around. The Hibiscus budding is symbolizing her strength and determination to pass the test the second time she takes it, because just like her the hibiscus survives the cold weather months to bloom in the spring, so must she last through the emotional winter to pass in the spring. That is why the author concludes the story with the paragraph to show that she hasn't given up and will take the test again, assured that she will pass.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that the narrator wants to retake the test and is waiting for a better time, specifically the spring. It shows that she has perseverance and will not give up on passing this test, demonstrating a resilient spirit. She realizes that life comes and goes very quickly, much like the changing seasons she observes. And that she needs to appreciate it and seize the opportunities presented to her. This final thought completes her character development, affirming her commitment to her future.

The author concluded the last paragraph in the story "Winter Hibiscus" to say that the narrator "Saeng" isn't given up on her driving test. This final section highlights her resilient spirit, showing that while she faced disappointment, her resolve remains firm. The paragraph serves to underscore her commitment to trying again, emphasizing that failure is not the end of her efforts. It is a clear indication that Saeng's journey is one of perseverance, and she is prepared to face the challenge once more. This conclusion solidifies the idea that her determination is a central trait, ensuring the reader understands she has not been defeated by this setback.

At the end of the story, "Winter Hibiscus," the author's concluding paragraph shows many of the aspects of the story in a summary; Saeng is determined to go back to the driver's test and is open to a new beginning. The author used these concluding words in the paragraph to express the hope in Saeng of a better beginning and to show her determination to pass the driver's test. The author ties the objects in the story to represent this determination and new beginning. For example, the hibiscus is a reminder of her glorious home, spring is the time she picks because it is a new beginning, and the geese returning show the determination of her and her family to resolve to become new and better. These symbols collectively reinforce the theme of renewal and persistent effort, weaving together her past memories with her future aspirations in a cohesive and hopeful vision.

The author MinFong Ho concludes the story with this paragraph to evoke hope within the reader towards the characters in the story. One of the most important lessons anyone can learn in life is to never lose hope because things will get better so long as you try. Though Saeng was sad over failing her driving test and missed her homeland deeply, with ending the story and this paragraph, the principle that “never giving up is important” is presented and carried out hopefully through the character’s vow. This principle presents the idea that people can overcome hard times in their life no matter what circumstances they are presented with. In conclusion, hope is evoked within the reader because of the ending paragraph which contributes to the overall theme of the entire story; it is important to never give up and always have hope especially when life gets hard, thereby leaving a lasting and uplifting impression.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it provides a more satisfying and resonant ending, making the story sound more complete. If the author did not put that ending at the end of the story, it probably wouldn't be as interesting or be that good of a story. Also, the author wants to make the reader understand the story's conclusion and its beginning all at the same time. For example, if there were no good ending at the end of this story, nobody would want to read it at all, so it was a good thing for the author to put a stable ending paragraph at the end. It was a very good paragraph for the end of the story that seemed to match the narrative perfectly and allowed for a much clearer understanding of the entire piece, providing a fitting and conclusive finish.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he is trying to explain to us that this plant is going to bring good luck and symbolize a fresh start. The snow will melt, the geese will return, and the hibiscus plant will start budding. It's starting over fresh, a new beginning. Since she had failed her driving test, she will start over in the spring, using the seasonal change as a metaphor for her own personal renewal. The paragraph effectively ties the natural world's cycles to Saeng's internal resolve, suggesting that hope and new opportunities are perpetually available. In conclusion, this is why I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph, as it beautifully encapsulates the theme of cyclical renewal and enduring hope.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that in the spring, when the plant begins anew, Saeng will also start over. The story illustrates this meaning because Saeng was enduring a particularly difficult winter and was struggling to adjust to all the new things in her life. However, with the arrival of spring, she finds the capacity to begin again, just as the hibiscus will, symbolizing a parallel renewal of hope and spirit.

The author includes this concluding paragraph for several reasons integral to the narrative. One primary reason is that the story begins by detailing Saeng's failure of her driver's test and the subsequent depression she experiences. It then progresses to her encounter with the hibiscus, a flower that powerfully reminds her of her homeland and all the positive memories associated with it. This all connects directly to the final paragraph, which establishes that Saeng will not return to the testing center until the hibiscus, the source of her happiness and confidence, begins to bud. Thus, the paragraph serves to tie together every element of the story from its beginning to its end, creating a cohesive and resonant conclusion.

I think the author concludes the story in this manner because the return of the hibiscus signifies the moment the character feels she will be prepared to take that test again. This timing is crucial, as the budding flower represents a renewal of her inner strength and a regained sense of self-assurance, which she had lost after her initial failure. Her readiness is intrinsically linked to this natural cycle, suggesting that her personal growth and the plant's blooming are interconnected. Therefore, the conclusion effectively shows that she will attempt the test once more when she feels emotionally and spiritually restored.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasise the theme that changes in life are hard to adjust to. Saeng has moved to a new location and profoundly longs for her home. The flowers in the greenhouse vividly remind her of where she grew up and her grandmother, triggering a deep emotional response as described in the line, "A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her." Initially, Saeng cannot look at the flowers without crying, and she tells her mother that she did not pass the test. However, in the last paragraph, she vows to herself that by spring she will pass. The author is giving us insight into Saeng's resilient character through this resolution. We now know that even though it is difficult for Saeng to let go of what she knows and loves, she will ultimately find the strength to persevere and make a life in her new world.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph to show us that Saeng's days with nature are not yet over. The text implies that when spring comes back around, she will continue the routines that connect her to her past and her identity, which was growing her plants and taking care of them. This includes the intimate act of turning them into a goodnight dinner, a practice steeped in memory and tradition. The conclusion affirms her commitment to continue this cycle of care and connection for as long as she is able, sustaining her bond with her heritage and the natural world.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because the author is showing how she feels more comfortable with her old home. The winter hibiscus is related to her new home, but when winter is gone and new hibiscus bloom, they relate to her new home. The hibiscus from her old home, however, gives her a distinct sense of comfort and a tangible connection to her past. So when she feels that comfort again, drawing strength from the familiar, she will be brave and go take the test. The author ended the story with that paragraph because it shows that Saeng still does not like the change and would like to go back to her old home, finding her courage in memories rather than her new surroundings.

The author includes this paragraph because Saeng is starting anew in a new country, a place that is strange and unfamiliar to her. In this country she misses her homeland deeply, and the hibiscus reminds her of so, serving as a living memory. Saeng took a test and failed, and in the winter, flowers fail and fade, but they bloom again in the spring. When the hibiscus blooms once more, Saeng will similarly "bloom" and find the resolve to try the test again. Moving can be a hardship, especially when it is to a place very unfamiliar, and people find ways to make themselves promises and to remind them of their old home, using these symbols to navigate their new lives.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because this spring she had made a mistake, like buying the plants that were over a dollar and disappointing her mother. So she figures that when the spring comes again, she could get another opportunity to do her best and to get it right this time. The changing seasons represent a chance for renewal and correction. Also, so she will not be a disappointment to her mother again, she is determined to succeed and prove her capability when the next chance arrives.

The author ended the story with that paragraph because she said that the flower helps her with the moving and reminds her of her home town, providing a sense of stability. She believes that when the geese come back and the flower starts to bloom, she’ll know that she can pass that test. She is sad for failing the test, but it doesn’t matter how many times you fail; it sooner or later you will pass the test if you persist. She must feel comfortable and confident taking the test again when spring comes along, using the natural cycle as a promise of her own potential success.

I believe that the author concluded the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the paragraph that she did in order to imply that Saeng will not give up. By allowing the audience to know that Saeng was very sad about failing the test, but will take the test again, infers that Saeng is a determined and resilient person. It is my belief that the concluding paragraph was added to convey the feeling that Saeng was determined despite hardships, showing that her spirit remains unbroken and that she is prepared to face her challenges with renewed hope.

In the story, "Winter Hibiscus," by Mingfong Ho, the author concludes the story with, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," because the hibiscus represents hope and adapting to circumstances. Saeng is trying to adapt to the new changes in her life but nothing is working out for her. She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. The Hibiscus makes her life easier because it reminds her of her homeland, and it gives her hope. "Look how root-bound it is, poor thing," the root-bound state represents Saeng in her new country, unwilling to try anything and getting scared. But as soon as Saeng and her mother plant the hibiscus, Saeng realizes that by planting it, she is going to try to love her new life in America. In spring when the hibiscus and Saeng are ready to blossom, she will start trying to accept life and face her challenges with renewed determination.

Mingfong Ho closes the story with that paragraph because it shows how far Saeng has come and her determination to persevere. The narrator says, “She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.” This is when Saeng is recovering from crying, and even though she misses her homeland, she wants to adapt and succeed where she is now. The narrator also said, “she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again.” Being away from her homeland makes Saeng very emotional and filled with a sense of loss, yet the sight of the migrating geese and the promise of the seasons changing gives her the strength to look forward and commit to trying again, symbolizing her personal growth and resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because they feel that the plant will bring them luck or something. Saeng feels that the plant gives her some type of comfort, a tangible connection to her past and a symbol of potential for her future. It serves as a familiar presence in her unfamiliar new environment, providing a sense of stability and hope. This small piece of nature becomes a source of emotional support, helping her to cope with the challenges of her new life and reinforcing her quiet resolve to face the future, thus completing her emotional arc in the story.

I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph because in the story, the author says “through the quiet repetition of season upon season,” which means that seasons will come and seasons will go but she’ll always be there, ready to “take the test.” This cyclical nature of the seasons mirrors Saeng’s own journey of adaptation and recovery. It underscores the theme of perseverance, suggesting that time and patience will bring new opportunities for growth and success. Her vow is not just about a single test but about her ongoing commitment to her new life, emphasizing that her resolve will remain steady through the passing of time.

The author is probably trying to say that in the spring when the seasons change and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, he will take the test again. This final vow signifies a turning point for Saeng, where she aligns her personal growth with the natural world's renewal. The budding hibiscus acts as a metaphor for her own potential to bloom in her new environment. By linking her resolve to the specific, hopeful signs of spring, the author illustrates Saeng's decision to stop dwelling on past failures and instead embrace future possibilities, thus concluding her story on a note of optimistic determination.

The author concludes that failing the test is not the worst thing. She realizes that times change and you can always get another chance, which is explained in the last paragraph that once the hibiscus buds she will take the test again. This perspective shows her growth and understanding that setbacks are temporary. Her resolve is tied to the natural cycle, symbolizing renewal and hope for the future.

The author concludes the story with her saying in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again. This statement shows that she will not give up or give out like that. It is a promise to herself, a commitment to try once more when conditions are more favorable. Her determination is linked to the hopeful signs of spring, ensuring she will persevere.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it means so many things about her in just one little sentence. For example, "take that test again" shows she is willing to do it all over again; she loves it and wants to do it. Also, when she said "in spring; when the snows melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding," it signifies that when you come back, you do not forget about all the things she just listed. That is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, as it encapsulates her resilience and connection to the cycles of nature.

This story is about believing in yourself and never giving up; it was a story about perseverance. Saeng really believed she could pass her driver's test, and although she was disappointed with the result, she found a way to cope with her loss. The hibiscus flower means a lot to her because she can connect it to her homeland, and it is a thing of beauty, something she needed at such an ugly time for her. It's always hard to adapt to a new country in a short period of time. I know what it's like when one small thing goes wrong; you can snap and it will feel a lot worse than it actually is. You feel helpless and alone, just like the hibiscus growing next to the highway in the photo. Saeng vowed to take her driver’s test again when her hibiscus would bloom in the spring; I think the hibiscus really symbolizes Saeng as a person, representing her ability to bloom again despite adversity.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. Saeng was disappointed for failing her driving test, but she found comfort with nature after she went and bought a plant. Saeng must feel that when the geese leave and the hibiscus has not started to bud, she should not take the driver's test. She feels comforted by the return of the geese and the budding of the hibiscus, which implies nature comforts her. The author ended it like this because it shows Saeng is not disappointed about failing anymore. She knows she will have another chance next year when the geese return and the hibiscus starts to bud. With the comfort of nature, she feels she can pass the test next year, finding strength and reassurance in the natural world.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph or quote to give the readers something significant to think about at the end of the reading. For example, it lets the reader know that the person will continue to grow plants when the winter is done, suggesting a theme of renewal and persistent hope that lingers with the audience after the final page is turned.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it powerfully shows her determination. Saeng is having problems with both adjusting and adapting to the changes in her new life, and we see an example of this when Saeng comes home with her flower, “she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again.” We see that Saeng bought the flower because it made her feel security and comfort. It was something from home that felt familiar to her, and I believe that’s why the author included the story with this paragraph because next year she will have a renewed sense of security and familiarity when taking the test, as the hopeful experience she had will be happening again.

The author concludes with this paragraph to show that Saeng is not going to give up on her goals. She also concludes with this to tell people that they should never give up and that they should keep on trying, no matter the obstacles they face. Even if they have to take a brief break to study more or to rethink their original plan, the important thing is to persevere and maintain hope for future success.

When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself that in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take that test again. In the story, the author put the paragraph in his story to show what the girl was planning to do to improve on her grades, demonstrating her resolve to prepare better and face the challenge anew with the changing season.

He ends the paragraph with this because he is meaning to say he would rather take the test again when it is beautiful outside, associating the attempt with a more hopeful and pleasant time of year. In conclusion, this is why I think the author ends it with this sentence, to leave the reader with a sense of optimistic anticipation for the character's future endeavors.

At the end of the short story, "Winter Hibiscus," the writer Minfong Ho includes the somewhat inspirational concluding sentence, “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again.” I think this sentence was added in order to create a sense of hope for the future, which contrasts so greatly with the depressing nature of the story, thereby creating a more uplifting and happy ending. Throughout the essay, Saeng is depressed as she had to leave her homeland so hurriedly, losing her childhood and her beloved grandmother. “A blink, a chanced switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone,” as Saeng narrates in deeper detail, emphasizing the suddenness of her loss. Also contributing to the feelings of sorrow in the story is how much Saeng cries while remembering her tragic past, both in the greenhouse when recalling events involving her grandmother such as when she says, “Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s grey hair Saeng would help knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it," and later in the garden when she talks to her mother and plants the flower. After all this sorrow, by putting in a hopeful ending, the writer has successfully allowed a sense of hope for the future to emerge, providing a resolution to Saeng's emotional turmoil.

She says she is planning to take the test again in the spring because she knows if she failed the test again her mother would be disappointed in her, perhaps feeling that she is not trying hard enough or that they might never be close again. The mother thinks that she keeps failing the test because of her deep connection to her past experiences and her lingering affection for her old country, which affects her ability to focus on her new life. However, Saeng's decision to retake the test shows her growing ability to overcome these obstacles and her desire to succeed. Finally, I think she is comforted by the memories of her homeland, which give her the strength and resolve to face the challenge once more, bridging her past with her future efforts.

The author concludes the story with that quote for one main reason. That reason is that it shows that the girl has hope for a better outcome in the future. In a story, one of the best qualities a character can have is hope because it makes the reader more interested in their journey and helps provide a good morale for the overall narrative. Hope allows the character to look forward positively despite past difficulties, which is a powerful message for the audience. That is why the author concludes the story with that quote, as it leaves the reader with a sense of optimistic possibility and reinforces the story's uplifting theme.

The author of this story created the last paragraph so that it finishes the story with a great and meaningful ending. It emphasizes the important fact of never giving up and trying again and again, even after facing failure. The author has Saeng declare, “I will take the test again.” In the story, Saeng had previously said, “I failed the test,” but now her statement shows that she isn't giving up on her goals. This last paragraph makes a lot of sense and is needed to make this story feel complete and satisfying. So just as others don't give up in their own challenges, Saeng is doing the same and is determinedly retaking the test, demonstrating her resilience and commitment to improvement.

The author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” because he wants to express to the readers that she is willingly determined to do what she has to in order to accomplish what she has previously failed. Since she has failed the test the first time, she now wants to overcome her failure and succeed in it, showing her personal growth and resolve. The author wants her to look determined in the end to highlight her transformation from a state of sadness to one of active perseverance, providing a strong and inspirational finish to her character arc.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it serves to make the story longer and it gives it a good ending, but I have no idea on what that means. Therefore, the author should be the one to explain what it means, not me, as the reader's role is to interpret rather than to define the author's specific intent without further guidance. This leaves the responsibility for clarification squarely with the writer of the story.

The plant was important to Saeng because it was a direct connection from her home land. Saeng said that she would take her drivers test again when her plant bloomed, linking her personal goal to the plant's natural cycle. The plant was a reminder of her home and what she had come from, serving as a tangible piece of her past. The plant to Saeng was a form of confidence, providing her with emotional strength. Saeng went through hard times, and the plant was especially close to her because it was a living piece from her home land, offering comfort and a sense of identity in her new environment.

I believe the author ended the story with that paragraph to create a sense of wonder for the reader. I think this because if you put into context the word “test”, it could mean many different things within the narrative. For example, it could mean the test to overcome the profound sadness of her situation and find personal resilience. Also, it could mean the test to adjust fully to her new home when the spring finally arrives, symbolizing a new beginning. That is why I think the author intentionally tried to create a sense of wonder and open-ended interpretation with the final paragraph, leaving the reader to ponder its multiple meanings.

The story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, is about overcoming adversity and finding strength. She concludes the story by writing “when they come back [the geese] then I will take that test.” The main character, Saeng, had been having trouble at school and on her way home had seen an assortment of flowers that were indigenous to her homeland. “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense it was almost visceral.” The sight of those flowers, namely the hibiscus, reminded her of what she had lost and offered comfort in the face of the memory. The winter hibiscus could still survive and even thrive even though it was not in the land where it originally belonged. Her mother states “It’s flowers aren’t as pretty but it’s strong enough. That’s what matters.” Saeng, after hearing this, decides that she could be strong, too, and would try to do her best in school and in life. She would learn to adapt and persevere, just like the winter hibiscus that blooms despite the cold.

She said that because she was ultimately more interested in the flowers and what they symbolized to her than she was in a driving test. The flowers held a deeper, more personal significance connected to her heritage and inner life, making them a greater priority at that moment than a formal examination. Her focus was on the emotional and symbolic value the plants provided.

I believe that the author concludes with this paragraph because it shows the ending of one thing and the beginning of another. After she is upset and thinks about home, she realizes that something new is happening and she needs to accept it. The emotional turmoil gives way to a quiet resolve, a recognition of the cyclical nature of life. So therefore in the spring she is going to start new like the flower blossom, embracing the future with hope and a renewed spirit.

The author ends the story with this paragraph because he wants to get the point out that the character doesn't want to rush into things; she wants to do right and not take the quick way out. This final reflection emphasizes her commitment to a path of integrity and careful consideration. She understands that true success and adaptation require patience and a principled approach, rather than seeking immediate but shallow solutions.

It shows the importance of the Hibiscus to Saeng and her dedication to the flower. The hibiscus serves as a profound symbol of her heritage and personal identity, a living connection to her past. It is also stating that she will wait for next spring to admire the flower again, finding solace and purpose in this annual cycle of renewal and beauty. This patient waiting becomes an act of faith and continuity.

The author ends this story with this paragraph because she is explaining her thoughts and why she is taking that test. She is articulating her internal motivation and the significance of her decision. She is explaining that next year she will find out if it feels like home to her, framing the test not just as an assessment of skill but as a deeper exploration of belonging and her place in this new world.

When the author concluded the narrative with Saeng's vow to take the test again in the spring, it demonstrates her ability to overcome obstacles, finding comfort in a time of disappointment, and her connection to her past experiences. First, it demonstrates the ability to overcome obstacles because there are obstacles in everyone's lives, and you must learn to conquer them as they are unlimited. So the hibiscus flower represents the obstacles and the weather represents time, as the winter is stopping the flower from blooming. Secondly, it also represents finding comfort in a time of disappointment because when you are going through an obstacle, disappointment lingers. However, she knows that the hibiscus will be coming back, and she has the awareness that challenges will return but can be faced anew. Finally, it asserts her connection to her past experience because she is trapped in a world that she is not familiar with, which makes her feel alien. She captures the sense of being out of place; the hibiscus flower represents her because she is unique and different from the people in her new environment. She is trying to adapt her way of living and survive, just as she did in her home country, and the flower's resilience mirrors her own.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because this paragraph represents Saeng’s determination and the difficult situation she currently faces. She has just arrived in a new country and has not yet adjusted to her new life. She was deeply disappointed, a feeling captured by the phrase "a shaft of the war afternoon starlight," where the word "war" showed Saeng was very upset. After she encountered the flower, she was reminded of her old country and the homeland she missed dearly. This memory made her feel that life was full of hope once more. She understood she needed to adapt to her new circumstances, yet she was still too emotionally shaky to fully express her feelings at home, which is why she finally burst into tears, missing her homeland intensely. The "snows" symbolized the challenging situation she was enduring. However, she believed she could overcome these difficulties, as life was full of hope. The "spring" symbolized her hope for a new life; Saeng thought things would get better in the spring and that she would ultimately succeed. She possessed the determination to succeed, which is why the author uses that paragraph as the conclusion, as it powerfully symbolizes her enduring hope.

The author included this because she felt that since Saeng failed the test, perhaps she should be given a second chance, considering how hard she had tried before. When Saeng says, “Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it,” it upset her mother because she had used a significant amount of money for a single plant, a purchase driven by her desire to feel at home again, reminiscent of a plant she had in her old home. Eventually, her mother says, “It’s a beautiful plant,” to make Saeng feel better, as she feels remorse for how she initially acted towards her daughter. After all the struggles and emotional turmoil Saeng had to go through, including her failure and her longing for home, the author added the last passage into the story to underscore this moment of maternal understanding and Saeng's ongoing emotional journey.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that Saeng possesses a relentless spirit and will not quit until she passes that test; she will try and try again persistently. The author is referring back to the themes of the story, emphasizing Saeng's unwavering determination and resilience in the face of adversity, which defines her character until the very end.

The author's purpose for this conclusion is to show that every year, when the snow melts and the geese return, Saeng will have to again take care of the plant. This is clear because taking a test is a significant responsibility, and therefore, taking care of that plant is also a huge task, which refers to the ongoing challenge of taking the test again. This parallel is what the purpose of the concluding sentence meant, illustrating the cyclical nature of her struggles and her enduring duties.

Because planting flowers and working in the garden is her primary hobby, and without it, she finds she cannot think clearly or be creative. Therefore, waiting until the plants are back will make her happier, and she will also be able to do her work effectively once her creative outlet is restored.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons. One is because she is saying when everything gets back to normal, that is when she is going to take the test again. Second, because there would be nothing else to say if it is not back to the way she wanted it to be. For instance, if you were building a house and a blizzard came, you would stop; you said that you would not continue until there was nice weather again. This parallel illustrates the character's decision to pause her efforts until conditions are more favorable, emphasizing a state of patient waiting. The paragraph serves as a natural stopping point that reflects this internal resolution. In conclusion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph for many reasons, effectively capturing the character's mindset.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus," Minfong Ho, ended the story in this way to show the theme of starting over. Her mother adds to the theme of starting over by saying, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty but it’s strong enough to make it through the winter. That’s what matters.” Her words are a metaphor for the family starting their lives again in their new home, that this new place may not be as pretty, but it will survive, which is what matters. Her words soothe her daughter's worries about starting over, providing comfort and a new perspective. Also, the budding hibiscus could be considered a symbol of rebirth, since it is dying and growing with the seasons. The family is dying out as one type of family and being reborn as another. However, even though they “died” as their old family unit, that does not mean that they have lost their heritage, which is why the author ends by talking about a flower that is both of the old world and the new, just like Saeng, symbolizing a harmonious blend of her identities.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng will persevere through the winter and try to adapt to her new lifestyle. Moving to a new country and culture is extremely tough, and Saeng is sad, but she doesn’t give up on creating a new life in America. The concluding sentence, “in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test,” is one of determination and hope. The entire story Saeng was struggling with adapting to her new environment, and her memory of her homeland gave her a sense of security. The sentence wraps up her emotion and shows how strong she is; she could easily give up on her driving test, but she won’t. It is a happy ending for somewhat of a sad story. Furthering the sentence shows Saeng’s connection to her plant. This hibiscus will survive and so will Saeng; when the hibiscus blooms in the spring, so will Saeng. She will try as hard as she can to fit in and enjoy her new life. That plant will help her through it by reminding her of Vietnam as well as giving her a companion throughout the winter. The author would not have chosen a better conclusion for this story. The conclusion offers a new hope to persevere and succeed. As a result, the reader is left with a sense of pleasure and a good feeling towards the story. This conclusion shows how Saeng is adapting to changes and hopes to enjoy her new life in her new home.

The story was about a girl walking home after failing her driving test and breaking down about her “home” where she no longer lived. After she had broken down, bought the plant, and learned to actually accept the fact that she no longer lived in Vietnam and that she had failed her driving test, she realized that she just has to learn to like it. She also learned that her time will come and she will one day be driving. The reason why the author concluded the story with this paragraph is because this is the conclusion of the story; this is where one realizes the important things. It is the moment of clarity where the character's internal conflict finds resolution, and her acceptance of her new reality becomes complete. This final paragraph solidifies the story's central message about growth and acceptance, bringing the narrative to a satisfying and meaningful close.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story with a statement that Saeng vowed silently to herself. Saeng says she will take the test again, referring to the driver's test. Seeing the geese flying in a “V” and seeing the hibiscus gave Saeng a sense of remembrance to her homeland, as these elements are deeply connected to her past. Saeng misses her homeland profoundly. The author wanted it to seem to the reader as if Saeng is starting to feel at home again, finding familiar comforts in a new land. The hibiscus is just a symbol to Saeng telling her that it will be okay, and that it’s okay for her to miss Vietnam but also that it’s okay to have a new life. So Saeng, in the spring, will go take her driver's test again with a new attitude and will pass the test, embracing her future with renewed confidence and hope.

The author used that paragraph in order to create vivid imagery for the reader. The author wants you to get a clear and evocative image of the story's setting and mood. She also used that paragraph to express her own emotions, conveying a particular feeling through the descriptive language. This combination of imagery and emotion works together to draw the reader more deeply into the narrative experience, making the scene more tangible and the author's perspective more resonant. The paragraph thus serves a dual purpose, enriching the text both visually and emotionally for a more impactful reading.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph to tell you when Saeng was going to take the test again and also to foreshadow her reunion with the plant. This is a concluding paragraph that gives insight on what will happen in the future for the character, which is also why the author added this paragraph in the final position. It provides a sense of forward momentum and resolution, indicating Saeng's future plans and her continued connection to the symbolic hibiscus, thereby offering closure to the narrative while looking ahead.

The author ends the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to show a comparison between her current state and her hopeful future. Since the plant reminds her of home, when it buds she will be more confident and emotionally prepared to take the test. When she was looking at the petals of the flower it said, “Gently she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least she could hold on to.” This shows that she really missed her home, and she had nothing else to give her confidence in this new place. The flower is the piece of confidence she needs to feel at home and even pass her driver's test. Saeng felt out of place in her new environment, but the hibiscus gave her motivation and a tangible connection. It gave her a chance to connect with a part from her old home, in her new home. Saeng thinks, “And that rich sweet scent- that was familiar too”. This shows that this flower was of a sentimental importance that she needed. Therefore, the author ended with that paragraph to show a comparison and to underscore the importance of the flower to her process of adapting to a new life.

In “Winter Hibiscus,” Minfong Ho ends the story how she does to show a sign of hope and renewal. Saeng is going to start over when the world itself starts over, aligning her personal journey with the natural cycle. Spring is the time when animals come out of their winter holes, when trees blossom, and when the snow melts. It is a time of renewed life and energy. Saeng “vowed silently to herself to try again in the spring time.” Saeng purchases the hibiscus in remembrance of her homeland, but also to know when it is ready to come back out of its base so she can try again. The hibiscus signals this time by coming out of its buds and blooming. Ho ends her story in hope of a new beginning for her protagonist. Saeng vows, “Then I will take that test again.” In the word choice of “that test again” depicts her new and determined attitude. She wants to try again, to face her test with a refreshed spirit and the confidence drawn from nature's rebirth.

The paragraph is used to show how absent and disconnected she feels without them by her side. You see this when the author says “when they come back,” referring to the geese and the spring season. Also when she says “the geese return & this hibiscus is budding,” it highlights what is currently missing from her life. This shows how she feels without them and how she anticipates she will feel when they return, and how she will carry on where they left off last time as shown when she says, “Then I will take that test again.” Her personal resolve is directly tied to the return of these natural elements, emphasizing her dependence on these symbols of familiarity and home for her own sense of purpose and timing.

I think it was a good enough story by Minfong Ho. Throughout the story you feel somewhat happy, and somewhat sad, but always calm. You feel happy when they are talking about all the plants and when her mother accepts the plants she bought. At first, when you think the mom is going to yell at her for buying that after she failed her test, you feel bad for her but still maintain a calm mood. The story shows the girl doesn't want to give up, but just needs to take her time to recover and find her strength again, which contributes to the overall serene feeling.

I think the author concludes the story with the paragraph saying that she’s going to take the test again, to show us that this time she’s going to pass the test and she’s not going to feel the same way she felt when she didn’t pass. It tells us “in spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding" because that's when she is going to take the test. This timing connects her renewed effort to the hopeful season of renewal, emphasizing her determination to succeed where she previously failed and to move forward with a positive outlook.

Saeng vowed silently to herself and to her mother too. Saeng decided to tell her mother what she had done, that “she failed the test.” Probably her mom got upset with her, but then she talked to her again. Saeng’s mother asked her about the plant that she had with her. Saeng said that she bought the plant with her own money. She was sad because she failed the test, and when she bought the plant it probably made her feel better. I think the author probably concludes the story with this paragraph because it brings some kind of hope to her, and she probably will pass the test. When she said “then I will take that test again,” the plant seems to give her the courage and motivation to decide to take it again, symbolizing a new beginning.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wants to show the readers that Saeng will want to pass her driver's license test. The reason is so the reader sees how determined Saeng is after the winter. The first example is that in the story Saeng failed her driver's license test and was sad about it. The next example is that when she finds this flower, she knows she will do it again. This shows that the flower helps her feel better, indicating that she will try again. The first example shows that she was sad that she failed the test. At the conclusion, the author puts this statement in the story to show the reader that Saeng will pass the driver's license test later on, demonstrating her growing resilience.

In the story Winter Hibiscus by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with Saeng saying “when they come back in the spring. When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author chose to end the story this way to give it a positive ending. The rest of the story is sad because Saeng misses her home in Vietnam, as shown when she says, "It's — it's not a real one. I mean, it's not like the kind we had at — at — she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. Not like the ones we had before." The end sends the message that even though things are different than before, she won’t give up trying to make a good life in the United States and will not let this change affect her negatively, finding strength in her new surroundings.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he wants us to know that she will regain her confidence when the "hibiscus is budding" and take another slot at the driving test. He doesn't want to just leave us hanging with the girl watching the geese fly away into the distance, a moment of pure dejection. The girl felt very bad about failing the test which makes the reader feel sad, sharing in her profound disappointment. To cheer up the reader and provide a sense of hope, he ended the story in this way. Saeng is reminded of home and a cyclical sense of renewal when "the geese return and this hibiscus is budding," a natural promise of new beginnings. So, the author ends the story having Saeng have a sense of renewed confidence and the reader feeling happy and reassured about her future prospects.

The author concludes the story with that because she is determined to succeed in her new life. She misses her homeland and everything there: the vibrant gardens, her loving grandparents, and the familiar scents. For example, when she walked into the flowershop she smells the flowers like she used to back home, a powerful sensory connection to her past. She then smelled a flower that reminded her of her grandmothers "long gray hair, freshly washed," a poignant and intimate memory. But by saying that last sentence she said that when the hibiscus budded next winter she will take the test that she failed again, transforming her nostalgia into a firm resolution for the future.

The author concludes the story with "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again," because the girl is willing to try again and to not give up no matter what. The girl is upset because she doesnt have the real flower her mom had, feeling the artificiality of her new environment. "It's-it's not a real one," Saeng mumbled "I mean, not like the kind we had at- at." She was upset and afraid that her mother was going to be angry with her that she started to shake, overwhelmed by her failure. "I know," her mother said quietly, offering comfort. "I've seen this kind blooming along the lake," showing her daughter a path to acceptance. The author is just showing that the girl is going to try again next time, using the hibiscus as a symbol of her resilient spirit.

The author concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with that paragraph because he wants to get across to the reader that Saeng will not give up. Saeng and her family moved from Vietnam, and it has been hard for her to adjust to the many changes in her new country. Saeng really misses her homeland and the flowers that she sees in her memories of life there. She explains how the winter hibiscus is not the same as the one in Vietnam, highlighting her sense of displacement, so she plants this new type of flower and decides to wait till the spring to take the driving test. This shows that Saeng wants to plant her difficulties in the present and think of them again in the spring when the weather and atmosphere is nice, a more hopeful time. She is not giving up but she does not want to confront the difficulties till a later time, allowing herself a period of growth. That is why the author concluded with this paragraph, emphasizing a strategy of patience and perseverance.

I think he uses it because she wants to get another one next year to see what its like to care for something so much and get to look after it for a while, to nurture it and watch it grow. The narrator likely wants to show the character's desire for a second chance, not just with the object itself but with the entire experience of attachment and responsibility. That is why I think the narrator uses that phrase as his last one, to leave the reader with a sense of anticipation for the future.

The author concludes this story with the paragraph she did because it shows how Saeng is adapting with the change she is going through in her new home. The winter hibiscus helped her cope with failing her driving test, so Saeng figures it will give her luck when she takes it again. Also the hibiscus will survive, and while she works towards her goal it will develop more. Once the flower blooms, it will symbolize strength, helping Saeng overcome this obstacle. Her mother said the flower was not as pretty but will survive. She means that life here may not be as great as in Vietnam, but Saeng will stay strong and persevere, just like the resilient plant in her garden.

The purpose for the ending the author chose is to show how the hibiscus gives Saeng a good sense of comfort, compared to how she was at the beginning of the story. It was like she had very little confidence. And now she is forced to call this strange place home, and that emptied her desire to strive until she sees a very familiar face that brings back her memories of when she was the happiest. Having something around that was special to her around all the time can make her feel at home or like it used to be; she found her comfort in the hibiscus. So now that it rests in her garden to constantly grow through all the seasons, she will too, with that reminder of her old home and how good it felt, except now with new memories to build upon.

They go to the top and then over the hill, continuing their journey along the path that lies ahead. The ascent is challenging, but the view from the summit makes the effort worthwhile before they descend down the other side.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a couple of different reasons. The author wants to show with meaning that the budding of the hibiscus plant will be symbolic. Ho states, “Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.” This shows meaning because it is currently a point in time where Saeng has to overcome negative circumstances, and with the plant appearing dead it shows symbolically the meaning of the plant. At another point in the story, Saeng realizes that there is much more meaning to the seasons. Ho states, “Through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now,” she is realizing that come spring time when the plant will be healthy and budding, she will be able to succeed and become somehow like a new person, renewed by the same natural cycle.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because he or she feels like the audience should know what Saeng is feeling. This paragraph ending shows that Saeng will keep trying every spring to grow back her flowers, and this shows that Saeng has a lot of potential to make her vow to herself successful. Her determination is mirrored in the cyclical return of the seasons, promising new opportunities for growth and achievement.

This story is all about overcoming hardships and disappointments as well as accepting and adapting to the things life throws at people, so it is appropriate that the story is ended with a goal and a determined attitude. Throughout the entire reading, Saeng sought comfort in the things most familiar to her, such as the specific flowers from her past and the distinctive taste of bitter melon. She was hurting and disappointed, and those things were the only things that gave her a sense of peace and stability. It was those familiar things that save her the courage she needed to retake her driver’s test in the spring, so it seems fitting that she end the story with the mention of the hibiscus, a plant that connects her to her homeland. The end paragraph also shows that Saeng is adapting well to her new country. She says, “when they come back... in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return...” At first the sounds of geese were alien and strange to her, but now she has accepted their honking as a normal, expected sound. This implies that she is learning to accept and even anticipate the rhythms of her new country, which is the perfect way to end the story on a note of quiet hope and resilience.

The author concludes the story this way because in the winter time she won’t be able to see the hibiscus in bloom. She is used to going outside in the garden and seeing her beautiful plant, a living piece of her previous home. The winter represents a period of waiting and dormancy, both for the plant and for Saeng herself. In conclusion the author concludes the story that way, because in the winter time she won’t see her plant, highlighting a temporary separation that makes the promised return in spring all the more meaningful for her character’s journey.

In the story Saeng is trying to be ok with her new home, navigating the difficult space between her past and present. I think the author put that in the story to show that she has not given up despite her failures and deep sense of longing. She is going to keep trying to adjust to her new home, using the coming spring as a personal deadline for renewal. Saeng wants to adjust but she misses her old home too much, which creates an internal conflict that the changing seasons help to resolve. That is why she is waiting till spring to try again, allowing herself time to heal and gather strength for another attempt at her new life.

The author concludes the story with that line, to leave the reader guessing about Saeng's ultimate fate. The "she" means that she is determined to live up to her past, and get through it by facing her challenges with renewed hope. The paragraph leaves the reader to wonder if she got through it the following year, creating a sense of open-ended possibility. He describes the snow melting, and geese coming back as symbols of change which is exactly is what she hopes to achieve in her own life. The author was trying to show how she can change, and grow just like her plant, cyclically and with the promise of new beginnings after a period of hardship.

The author used the conclusion with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She writes that because when her flower starts budding she will be able to take the test cause she is like a flower, dormant in winter but ready to bloom again with the right conditions. The author uses this conclusion because when the flower is going to bud and the geese come back she will think that she is back home in spirit, finding the courage to move forward by connecting with these natural cycles. Thats why I think the author used the conclusion “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” as it perfectly encapsulates her resolve and the symbolic connection between her personal growth and the natural world.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the teenage girl Saeng fails her driver's test, and then, feeling dejected, runs into a winter hibiscus, an encounter which brings her in touch with her memories and heritage. The author concludes the story with Saeng's resolution to re-try the test when the geese return and the hibiscus buds, using these natural cycles to show a newfound comfort and familiarity with her surroundings. When the speaker says, “almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become,” this example shows that she had lost touch with the realness of nature and that this reconnection was precisely what was going to help her pass the test. The author sets an impatient mood for the reader because it took her until winter to discover this essential truth, and winter is when it feels too late, when the geese have left and the flower has closed. However, the conclusion implies that when spring comes, the natural world will be open to new opportunities, and so will she, armed with the familiarity now growing around her and within her.

I think she concluded with this statement because she doesn’t know for certain if she will pass, but she isn’t giving up on the test and will try to pass it again when her flower grows back, seeing it as a personal milestone. Right now she feels bad about her failure, and the plant, a symbol of resilience, helped to cheer her up and restore her hope. Therefore, when she sees the plant bloom again next year, she wants to take the test, using it as a source of courage. The plant is like a sign of good luck and a reminder of persistence. I think she concluded with this paragraph because it leaves you with the important idea not to give up when times are hard but to keep trying until you succeed.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a few specific reasons. One of the reasons is so the reader could imagine what the rest of the story would be like if it continued, creating a sense of future possibility. For example, when the author said, “then I will take that test again,” it invites the reader to envision Saeng’s second attempt and its potential outcome. Another reason is to give the reader one last, positive image to change their final thought of the story from one of failure to one of hopeful anticipation. For example, when the author described the scene “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” it provides a vivid, optimistic picture of renewal. Those were the key reasons why the author concludes the story with this particular paragraph.

The author concludes the story like this because the natural events signify a perfect time for a new beginning; when the snow is melting and the plant is budding and the geese come back, then she will take the test again. This is a way for her to really think about and solidify when she is going to do this again, using the predictable cycles of nature as a personal deadline and a source of motivation. The parallel structure emphasizes that when these signs of life return, so will she, with renewed determination, to take the test over again and face the challenge anew.

In the story, after her initial failure, Saeng vowed silently to herself, “When the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, she will take the test again.” This vow connects her personal goal to the rhythms of the natural world, giving her a clear and meaningful timeline. For some reason I think that is a fine idea, as it shows Saeng’s growth and her decision to move forward with patience and hope, using the familiar signs of spring as her guide.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” probably chose to end the story that way because then it’s ending with a sense of hope, providing a satisfying and uplifting closure for the reader. Also, it is showing how Saeng is adapting to her surroundings much like the winter hibiscus, drawing a direct parallel between her journey and the plant's resilience. In the second last paragraph, Saeng hears the honks of the geese and it is noted that their sound has become familiar to her through the course of the time, signifying her gradual acclimation. Saeng probably vowed to retake the test when the geese returned because the time would allow her to grow and adapt even more, using the natural cycle as a timeline for her own personal development. The hibiscus will be budding then, a sign that it overcame its obstacles and was successful in adopting, mirroring the growth Saeng herself hopes to achieve. If the hibiscus could adapt, Saeng could too, finding strength in this simple yet powerful comparison. She could look to the plant for inspiration, a constant and living reminder of the possibility of thriving in a new environment. This feeling of hope in Saeng and her future is left in the last paragraph, which is why the story ends there, leaving the reader with a lasting impression of her determined spirit.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because, just as seasons change, plants don’t most likely grow during winter time, emphasizing a period of dormancy and waiting. So you learn a lesson and take it as it is and await until the next time you learn basically the same lesson, when the right time comes, suggesting that growth and understanding are cyclical processes. The ending reflects the natural world's rhythm, where hardship is temporary and followed by renewal. This connection to nature's timeline provides a framework for understanding the character's patience, implying that just as winter ends, so too will her challenges. The conclusion thus reinforces the theme of perseverance through its alignment with the inevitable change of seasons.

I think that in the story “Winter Hibiscus” was a good story and also the author added the paragraph at the end because the main idea was like to work hard and that is why it mentions at the very end “I will take the test again,” highlighting a central theme of resilience. This statement shows that so you don’t fall and stay down you work hard and get back up and try again, which serves as a powerful lesson for the reader. The protagonist's decision to retake the test embodies the spirit of not giving up in the face of failure. It transforms a moment of defeat into one of determination, reinforcing the narrative's core message. The ending therefore effectively encapsulates the story's moral about the importance of persistent effort and a positive attitude.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph so he can tell the overall meaning of the story, providing a clear and focused resolution for the reader. Also, the author concludes this paragraph because it is probably a moral to the story and gives you pointers or clarifies some events in the story you didn’t know about, tying together the narrative's various threads. This final section serves to underscore the key lessons learned by the protagonist throughout her experiences. It acts as a final reflection, ensuring the central message about adaptation and hope is unmistakable. By doing so, the ending leaves the audience with a definitive understanding of the story's purpose and the character's emotional journey.

The story is somewhat sad, as the girl deeply misses her homeland and the life she once knew. She is also sad because she failed her driving test, which represents a significant setback in her efforts to adapt to her new country. The author, I think, ends the story with the girl saying she will take the test again, to show that even though she is sad about her country and failing she is not going to give up, demonstrating her inner strength. Failing a test, especially a driving test, stinks; you get very excited to get it but then you don’t, which makes her resolve all the more admirable. So the author is trying to show that despite the girls sadness she will not give up, emphasizing perseverance as a central virtue. The girl is going to keep trying until she finally passes, turning her initial disappointment into a motivating force. Also the author probably wanted to leave on a more positive note; you usually don’t want to leave a story sad with no solution, so she said she would try the test again to provide a sense of forward momentum. There were many reasons why the author ended the way she did but above are the more obvious, all of which contribute to a finale that balances melancholy with a powerful, uplifting determination.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the story ends with that phrase to show that Saeng has goals. First, she wants to adapt to this new land. This is because she says that when they come back in the spring, which means she won't give up and will try to adapt to her new life. This also says she has precision, she will continue to try to get her license because she says, "when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." She says that she will try again. Also, it exploits that she will get the courage to keep on trying and not give up, demonstrating her resilience and determination to succeed in her new environment.

Saeng was waiting for spring so that she could take the test again. I think she was worrying about it during spring because she went to watch the geese fly in a V shape and she went to see the plant grow, but the snow didn’t melt yet. She started talking to herself about it because she wanted to take the test during spring. She was concerned about if she could pass it again because she doesn’t like to take the test over and over again. When everybody gets to do different things after the test is over, she remains focused on her goal, showing her persistent nature.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the main character Saeng who moved to the United States from Vietnam with her family, just came home from failing her driver’s test. To Saeng, her failing the driver’s test shows that she is unable to adapt to her family's new lifestyle. Therefore she feels that she disappointed her mother and herself. On her way home she bought a flavor that her family also had back in Vietnam to try and comfort her mother. As her mother begins to plant the flower, a winter Hibiscus, she feels that her mother has forgiven her for failing the drivers test. Then she realized that she has adapted to her surroundings just like she believes her flower will and that motivates her to promise to take the drivers test again in the spring. By ending the story with Saeng’s promise, Minfong, the author, made sure that the last thing which is the most important thing for the reader to remember about the story is that Saeng didn’t give up. She promised herself that she will try again and adapt to her surroundings not like others around her have adapted. Her promise shows courage and perseverance, highlighting her personal growth and resolve.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she is not giving up and she will take the test again and the plant will grow again in the spring. This cyclical imagery of the plant's renewal mirrors Saeng's own commitment to try again, reinforcing the central theme of perseverance and hope for the future.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng is saying she is learning to adapt to this country. Earlier in the story she says that she failed the test, because she did not impress her mom. Saeng and her mom are used to life in Vietnam, and they are trying to adapt. Saeng thought that the hibiscus she got is just like the one she had at home. At the end she realizes if she just has faith everything will be fine and it will be just like home. She says in the spring because by then her hibiscus will be fully grown and she will take the test again to see if the hibiscus is like the one her mother thought she would get. Saeng is learning to adapt to her new country of the United States, finding comfort and strength in the familiar symbol of the hibiscus as she looks forward to her next attempt.

The author concludes with that paragraph because it powerfully expresses and continues the central theme of perseverance and adapting to change. The conclusion pointedly mentions the "test" again, a concept established earlier in the narrative. From the reading, one can conclude that this test the author refers to is Saeng’s emotional confrontation with memories of her old home without succumbing to the breakdown from loss. Saeng says earlier in the story that she "failed the test," having broken down in tears after looking at all the familiar plants that had been at home. By concluding with this paragraph which states she will take the test again, it clearly shows that Saeng is going to continue to try to adapt to her new home and feel at peace here, instead of feeling the tremendous loss of her old home. It ultimately shows the theme of perseverance because she is resolved to take the test again and try to overcome the overwhelming feeling of sorrow.

The girl is determined to win. She went and took a test for a flower, a task she did not pass, and she returned home feeling sad and emotional. She told her grandmother that these new flowers were not like the ones from her homeland, a place she could not even name because it caused too much pain. Her grandmother, offering comfort, simply agreed that they were not like the real ones, acknowledging the deep sense of displacement they both felt. This shared moment of recognition underscores the difficulty of their adjustment while highlighting the supportive bond between them.

In this story "The Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with the line, “When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” In the beginning of the story, she was less confident and she had indeed failed the test, overwhelmed by memories. But the discovery of the single, resilient hibiscus plant gave her a newfound sense of hope. Therefore, the next time she decides to take the test, she will be better prepared emotionally, strengthened by the symbol of life that persists even in a harsh new environment.

The author would conclude the essay in this manner because it effectively serves to tie all the dangling ideas together into a cohesive whole. For example, one person noted the significance of the final vow, stating, “she silently vowed to herself in the spring after the snow melts she would retake that test.” This concluding statement acts as a unifying thread, pulling together the various narrative strands about memory, loss, and the resolve to persevere. By ending on this note of quiet determination, the author provides a satisfying resolution that encapsulates the story's central conflict and the protagonist's forward-looking mindset.

I think the author ended the story with that sentence because it draws a powerful parallel to the natural cycle of seasons. Every winter, all or most plants die off or become dormant, and during the spring they must start all over in growing. This cyclical process of death and rebirth mirrors Saeng's own emotional journey, suggesting that her initial failure was not an ending but a necessary dormancy before a new beginning. Her vow to try again in the spring aligns her personal growth with the regenerative power of nature, implying that she, like the plants, will have another chance to bloom.

The author ends the story this way because they are trying to show that Saeng will be dedicated to the hibiscus gardening, and once she proves herself she will have passed the test. This dedication to nurturing the plant mirrors the perseverance she needs for her own challenges. It also shows that she wants her heritage to be a major part of her life by growing her nation's flower, thereby connecting her past to her future in a meaningful way.

The author ends the story with this quote because it shows how determined Saeng is to passing her driving test. For example, in the story, "Winter Hibiscus", Saeng, after she fails her driving test, says something to forget about failing, and she said, “Let’s plant, right now”. She said this because she was trying to forget about her failing, and focus on something positive, channeling her energy into a new beginning. In conclusion, this is why the author ends with this quote, and an example of how determined and focused Saeng is to passing her driving test.

The author concluded the story the way they did because it left hope. Saeng had been hurt and disappointed, but in the end she had shown hope. In the story, Saeng failed her driving test and she was very disappointed. In the end, it showed she was not going to quit in this new country. She was going to move on and make the best of what she has, demonstrating her resilience and capacity for renewal.

I think that the author concludes with this paragraph because she is determined to complete and pass the test. The first reason why is that she failed this year and wants to pass next year. Next, she is comparing the hibiscus to her passing and building on the test, seeing the plant's growth as a symbol of her own potential for success. That is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng is going to try to keep her next plant. The reason why she says she is going to take the test again is connected to the fact that she sold the plant to somebody, an act she now regrets. Saeng has seen the plant before as a child and that's why she was so attached to it, reminding her of her homeland. In conclusion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng will try and keep her next plant, learning from her past actions.

The author concludes the last paragraph to show that after a time period you can come back and try something again. Or maybe when the weather changes this can be different for Saeng. Perhaps she is relating herself to the plant, drawing a parallel that when it comes to spring the flower will be stronger and more resilient. She feels that she will pass the test the second time around when the geese come back and the hibiscus is budding, seeing it as a sign of renewal. And it also shows how she appreciates nature because if not, why would she wait until spring and when the snow is melting, a time of natural rebirth. The conclusion of the story is that she does like nature, because she talks about the hibiscus with such personal significance, finding strength in its seasonal cycle.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, a girl named Saeng is trying to adjust to her new life in America coming from Vietnam. She is sad and misses her home, especially after failing her driver's test. She walks by a store and recognizes a plant from her home, a hibiscus. She buys it and takes it home in a pot, a simple act that stirs deep emotions. She says thinking of home and all the great memories she shared with a plant like this back in Vietnam.
