Her mother then comes and shares the moment with her, providing comfort. Saeng feels better now, her spirit lifted. In the end sentence the author includes “saeng vowed silently to her herself, in the spring when the snows melt… and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.”(Ho, ??) The flower has given her the confidence to succeed and she wants to take the test again, linking her personal growth to the plant's cycle. This shows the connection she has with her home and the flowers, a tangible link to her past. She wants to overcome her sadness and plan onward not leaving her memories behind but her pain, moving forward with hope.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author chose to conclude the story the way she did to show the comfort the hibiscus provided that allowed Saeng to move on from her homesickness. The greenhouse provided a place for her to get her feelings out about her home sickness, “and in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept,” releasing her pent-up emotions. Then when she went home she was faced with the reality again of how she failed the test, a stark reminder of her struggles. I think when she failed the test it brought out feelings of how she thinks she is failing to adjust to her new home, seeing it as a larger symbol of her inability to fit in. But when the geese fly by the author brought the story to a conclusion to show how the experience has made Saeng grow and find resilience. “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, I will take the test again.” I think the author wanted to show that through the events in the story, she was able to overcome her feelings about a new home by connecting her personal journey to the natural world's cycles.

I think the author concluded the story with this statement because to me it sounds like it’s going to be a new start for her-self in the spring, a time of renewal. She talks about how when the hibiscus starts budding, the snow is gone and it's spring that when she’ll retake the test, linking her second chance to the season. To me it seems like when the hibiscus “comes back to life” it is having like a second chance and she deserves one also, drawing a direct parallel between herself and the plant. When it's bright out again and things start looking up again and things starts looking good she’ll feel good about taking the test over again, her optimism returning with the warmer weather. How she ended it to me was good, providing a sense of hope. You just have to read into it and try to understand what she is actually saying about timing and personal readiness. So practically she’s stating once everything “come back to life” then she’ll feel like she will pass it next time, feeling more prepared. Now she can be prepared, having found a new sense of determination and patience from nature's example.

There are many reasons why the author concludes the story with that paragraph. One reason is she likes the hibiscus flower; you can tell by when she again says “When she got to the hibiscus, She reached out and touch a petal gently,” showing a tender connection. Another reason is that they are pretty and provide her with a sense of beauty. You can tell by when she says “It was like walking into another world,” indicating how the plant transports her to a better mental space. Last reason is that she likes the presence of them, finding comfort in their existence. You can tell by when she says “Huge flat leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns, and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in seemingly random profusion,” describing the lush, life-filled environment that she finds so appealing. As you can see these are reasons why the author ended with that paragraph, emphasizing the flower's role in providing Saeng with solace and a positive focus.

The author of this story was smart to end it by saying she will take the test again in the spring, when every thing bloms. This girl, Saeng, just failed her driving test and she dose not want to take it right away, needing time to recover from the disappointment. The blomming of the hibiscus symbolizes her old life at her old home and it is also symbolizing a new start when it bloms. This will give her the confodence to pass her driving test and make he excited to get a new start on the year. "Spring is when the snows melt and geese return". This quote from this paragraph states that the snow will melt away and the geese will come back home, just like she wants to go home and fells contible, at home you are contible. The author ended this story of this girl, Saeng, with hope and drive to do what she wants to do. That is why it was smart to end the story like they ended it, leaving the reader with a sense of optimism for her future.

The hibcus, as the author has reveat to the audience, is a beautiful flower who in the story is the memories of a young girl who has fail the test knowing she was to depress for her failing the test. The flower helps as a symbol of encourage to the sad girl in her most tragrant event and shows how a little flower gives comfort to the girl, reminding her of her past and giving her strength. The girl Saeng vowed to demonstrate that when she overcomes the sad memories, she will succeed. She’ll be able to be capable to prove she will pass, after she feels ok about the situation she is experiment with her destroy life after have to come to a different country where you mast have a @PERCENT1 of capacity and it’s logical that the adaptation of the girl is not going to be right away. In othe words, the author message it’s to motivate the people who has problems in their lifes and that life it’s not give up. Instead you should keep working hard until you get it, learning from your failures. In conclusion working Hard and @CAPS1 give up it’s a part of our life and it’s up to our selves to overcome failing and move forward.

In the Story the @CAPS1 concluds the story with the sentance "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." I think he ends it this way because she has accepted that she failed or lost but is willing to try again to accomplish her goal and "take that test again". Also she is making a promise, or a vow to her self and to not give up on her goal, showing her determination to persevere despite the setback. This final vow provides a powerful and hopeful conclusion to her story.

The author concludes the story with he paragraph because they both go togather the away there both about things going and leaving the season changing. The ending connects the natural cycle of the seasons with Saeng's personal journey, like they don’t won’t to let go but they knew there be back soon. The promise of spring's return mirrors her own promise to try again, creating a unified theme of renewal. Thats why the author combided the story with the paragraph, to reinforce this connection between her internal resolve and the external world.

The author is expressing hope for the future in her concluding paragraph although just failing her drivers test and adjusting to a new atmoshere Saeng finds comfort in a Hibiscus. “it felt smooth an cool with a hint of velvet toward the center - just as she had known it would feel.” This expresses that the rememberence of “an old friend” was able to lift her spirits after a previous dissappoinment it was obvious Saeng was uncomfortable in her environment, which her mother noticed when she arrived at home. “she paused as she noticed the tear stains on her a daughter’s cheecks and her puffy eyes.” Her daughter was not adjusting to her new atmosphere and even though she had spent a lot of money on a single flower she understood. With all the negative attitude through out the story, once Saeng saw the geese and planted her “winter” hibiscus, she realized what was strange to her before had now become familiar. Saeng finally realizes with a memory of home, her goals can be accomplished and life can be stable somewhere other than home. She illustrates that from failure comes success, and this realization marks the beginning of her new start.

The author concluded the story in the paragraph, emphasizing that Saeng does not want to take the test under pressure. She vows to have the whole room to herself where it is quite when she is taking the test, ensuring a peaceful environment free from distractions that could disrupt her concentration and affect her performance.

She is saying that right now is not the right time to table the test. She is explaining that she is going to wait to come back until spring, when the flowers are blooming, to take the test. She is so eccentric about the exotic flowers, feeling they are essential for the right atmosphere. She can’t stand to do it now, when the time isn’t right, so she is resolved to wait until the perfect moment arrives for her to take the test.

Saeng has decided she will take the test in the spring when it is not so cold and the environment is more pleasant. She particularly likes it when the hibiscus is budding, as they smell so good. This good smell vividly reminds her of her native country, providing a sense of comfort. Furthermore, Saeng likes fried melon, which leaves a golden aftertaste on your tongue, and she would prefer it over a Big Mac any day.

There are many reasons why the author ends the story with this particular paragraph. It serves to encapsulate Saeng's resolution and her emotional journey, tying together the themes of memory and belonging. This concluding moment reinforces her decision to wait for a more favorable time, highlighting her personal growth and the symbolic importance of the spring season to her sense of self and confidence.

The author included that concluding paragraph because the hibiscus shows Saeng “comfort in her time of discomfort.” She would possibly feel more comfortable when the hibiscus is budding specifically because she misses her homeland and the flower strongly reminds her of it. She failed the test the first time largely because she was not comfortable with being in a new place. But when spring comes, she’ll be more confident and comfortable because the hibiscus is budding, providing the familiar solace she needs to succeed.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because earlier in the story, Saeng was talking about how she failed the test, which she was determined to retake. This declaration is tied to the natural cycles she observes, providing a timeframe for her renewed effort. So, Saeng declared that next year, when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, she shall take the test again, marking a specific moment of hope and new beginning that aligns with her personal resolve to succeed.

The reason why the author concludes this paragraph is to show Saeng that she will be waiting for them to grow back and she will try again for her test. The hibiscus means a lot to her, as it is a tangible connection to her heritage and her mother's expectations, and she will keep trying because she doesn't want her mother disappointed in her again. An example of where Saeng felt shame is when "her mother stared at her incredulously. But how could you?" This moment fuels Saeng's desire to not let down herself or her mother, leading to the moment where "Saeng vowed silently to herself," making a promise that she will pass and in doing so, show respect for nature as well as her elders.

In “Winter Hibiscus,” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with this paragraph: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The author concludes the story in this way because it is somewhat of a cliffhanger. In the story, Saeng is upset about failing her driving test and she has just moved from Vietnam to the United States, so she is a little homesick. She sees a familiar plant, a hibiscus, and purchases it because it cheers her up, reminding her of the plants in Vietnam. By ending the story like this, you know that Saeng hasn’t given up and that she is going to try and pass the driver's license test again. But what you don’t know is the end result of whether she passes or not, and so it is a cliffhanger. That is why the author ended the story in this way, leaving the outcome to the reader's imagination.

Saeng has been the victim of a tragic loss in her family and also a move to a totally different world. The paragraph is symbolic of turning over a new leaf and starting over. The “snows melting” and “hibiscus budding” are both symbolizing new life and the end of a difficult season. Saeng is going to have a new outlook on life and accept her situation to make the best of it, using this symbolism as her guide. Also, the author says “the winter hibiscus was in the ground now,” which compares to Saeng's new found outlook being planted firmly in her life. Like the flower, a seed of hope was planted into Saeng, and now she is ready to blossom and face her future with renewed strength.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” the author is very sentimental over the hibiscus plant because it reminds her so much of her home. The reason why the author concludes the story with that saying was because it gave her a goal and a specific time to aim for. She failed once at getting a job, but she seems to believe that the hibiscus is good luck, so she sets a goal on when to try for the job again, aligning her attempt with the plant's blooming. When she saw the plant, she remembered happy memories from her past, which provided the comfort needed to persevere. In conclusion, certain things can trigger your memories, but it's the good memories that make things in life something to wait and hope for, providing motivation for the future.

The author ends the story this way for a few reasons. First it shows that she is starting to like this new life, as she realizes that many of the things she had thought strange before had become almost familiar now. This is when she starts to see that her new life in the location is not so bad, a feeling connected to the geese and referred back to when she vows to take the test. Also it shows how the hibiscus she just planted is already important to her, symbolizing her growing attachment. The second thing it does is dream about future conclusions, leaving the story open. The reader does not know if she will pass the test next time but assumes that she will because of the determined way she vows it. That is why the author ends this story the way they did, to show how she feels in her new life and leave an opening for people to draw their own conclusions about her future.

I think that the author concludes the story with her failing the driving test, so they added that she was going to take it over again. The plant she discovered could be or would be good luck to her, and after the snow melts and the geese return, it would symbolize a fresh start for her. This new beginning is tied to the natural cycle of the seasons, and it would be a nice development for her character after she discovered the plant, offering a sense of hope and renewal for what comes next.

The author concludes the paragraph with this section because she wants to try again. The author is saying that the hibiscus she planted last season did not work, and she is trying again this season to grow a hibiscus plant. Her success in growing the plant is paralleled with her determination to pass the test; she will pass the test if she succeeds in the spring with her gardening efforts. That is why the author concludes with this paragraph, to emphasize the theme of perseverance and second chances in the face of previous setbacks.

He concludes that when it is spring he will take the test again. That will give her another chance to pass it, providing an opportunity for redemption. This will give her another chance to do what is right and to achieve the goal she had previously failed, ultimately allowing her to move forward with her life and find success where there was once only failure.

She is going to take the test again because she feels like she needs to, and she vows to do it when the snow melts and the geese come back. That means she wants to take the test in the Spring, associating this new attempt with a time of renewal and fresh beginnings, which reflects her inner resolve to succeed on her next try.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author includes the sentence, “When they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself, in spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think the remembrance of home will help her take the test. She uses the geese and the plant to remind her of home, and by having these familiar surroundings, it makes her feel more comfortable and gives her the strength to try again. The connection to her homeland provides a sense of stability and hope that fuels her determination for the future.

In the same way the hibiscus flower prevails in the winter, Saeng wants to be the same way. Saeng failed a test which makes her feel unsuccessful and disappointed. Saeng wants to prevail; she wants to stick it out, but the rough times she is going through make it very difficult for her. When Saeng says, “I – I failed the test,” this shows that Saeng feels disappointed that she did not expect that outcome because she is a fighter. So the author ends the passage with Saeng saying, “When they come back, in the spring, when snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to show how much of a fighter Saeng is because she is determined to strive and succeed under difficult conditions, just like the resilient flower.

The author puts this paragraph last because it shows that Saeng is looking to a new lease on life, a fresh start filled with hope. She now has something to take her through the year that is ahead of her; she can now wait until it is spring once again to see the hibiscus flower bloom and witness its beauty return, as well as many more blooms to come in the future. This cyclical promise of renewal gives her a goal and a positive focus, turning her disappointment into anticipation for a brighter time ahead.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I believe she concludes the story in this way to show that even though Saeng failed the test, she will try again someday, with that "someday" being symbolized by when the geese come back, a sign of a new beginning. Saeng is sad because she misses her homeland, and she sees plants that bring back memories, so she buys a winter hibiscus to ease and comfort her and remind her of home. This connection to her past through the plant gives her the resilience and hope needed to face her challenges and prepare for another attempt.

The author concludes this story with the paragraph because Saeng loves her garden and finds deep meaning in it. The author concludes it this way because the story is about her and her garden, and it eventually turns cold, leaving them with nothing to do until Spring. It suggests they have strong feelings for what they do, as it says "in spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding." Here, she wants to take the test to overcome her setback and prove she can take care of her garden and her life, using the garden's seasonal cycle as a metaphor for her own perseverance and growth.

At this time she vowed to retake a test because she understood that the flowers in the garden will always come and go with the seasons, but her grades for her school work would be there only one time, a singular opportunity she could not afford to miss. Instead of applying herself, however, she found she would rather tend to the garden then do her school work, a choice that reflected her conflicting priorities between fleeting natural beauty and lasting academic achievement. This internal struggle defined her resolve to finally focus on her studies with the same dedication she gave to her plants, understanding that while the garden would patiently wait, her education would not. She knew she had to channel her energy into her books, for the chance to pass the test would not bloom again like a perennial flower. Her commitment to her future was now the most important seed she needed to nurture.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph primarily because the sight of the winter hibiscus gave her a renewed sense of hope during a difficult time. This feeling was compounded by the fact that her mother was unexpectedly understanding about her failing the test, offering comfort instead of criticism. The combination of this familial support and the symbolic hope of the flower provided a powerful, uplifting resolution to her struggles. That is why the author chooses to conclude the story with this particular paragraph, as it encapsulates the moment her despair began to turn into determination. It is a fitting end that highlights the themes of resilience and comfort found in small, beautiful things.

The author concludes the story with a tone of optimism and hope for the future, which is clearly embodied in Saeng's silent vow. She finishes her story with the resolution that “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” By concluding the story in that specific way, it helps to fully demonstrate the profound hope the hibiscus plant brought to her after the disappointment of failing her driver's test. The hibiscus ultimately helped give Saeng one step closer to adapting to her new home, a sentiment echoed in the story: “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, were almost familiar to her now.” In this manner, the way the author ends the story provides genuine inspiration for a new beginning, aligning personal growth with the promise of a new season. The final lines serve as a powerful metaphor for her own budding resilience and integration into a new life.

In the story, "The Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, a young girl named Saeng tries to adjust to a new country, but she finds it is nearly impossible. She is particularly stressed about failing the driver’s test, and she painfully realizes that nothing in this new environment is the same as her old home. Except for one thing that she quickly and thankfully recognized: a specific plant called the “Winter Hibiscus.” This familiar sight immediately made her think of her old life in Laos, not Vietnam, and it helped her persevere through these hard times so she didn’t want to give up on anything. This is exactly why Minfong Ho ends the last paragraph by stating that Saeng will retry the driving test when the hibiscus is budding, symbolizing a new start. The flower gives her a comforting thought of home, providing the strength to try and try again no matter the obstacle. Also, the author ends the story like this to clearly state a universal theme for the reader. This particular theme is, “No matter how hard something might be, you can get through it, but you just have to find a way that benefits you most and gives you the courage to continue.” The story thus closes on a note of empowerment and self-discovery.

The author comes back to that paragraph because in the story Saeng is genuinely sorry she did not pass the test. Now Saeng wants to make up for her failure, and she vowed to herself with determination that she will pass that test the next time. For example, when I say to myself I am going to get something done, I do what it takes to get it done and I don't give up when things get rough, I persevere. This last sentiment is what the main idea of the story truly is: to make up for that test and pass it, to get done what needs to be done in order to succeed and move forward. The paragraph reinforces the core message of personal accountability and unwavering resolve in the face of setbacks, concluding the narrative with a clear sense of purpose.

The reason why this author includes this story with this paragraph is because it is still talking about Saeng and that is more like her, illustrating that she has a mind like a butterfly that was trapped but burst out with this openness. The conversation Saeng and her mom had reveals a shared understanding, and as a teenage girl, I find that me and Saeng we kind of relate to the same thing, navigating similar feelings of confinement and the desire for personal expression. This connection underscores a universal adolescent experience, making the story's message about emotional growth and identity particularly resonant and poignant for readers who have felt similarly constrained.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I think the ending paragraph is there to show that Saeng has not given up. She says, “When they come back…then I will take that test again.” She is talking about the hibiscus and the geese, the natural things that remind her of home and provide her with comfort. When these reminders of home return and give her strength, she will have the renewed power and determination to take the test. This shows that even though she has failed initially, she will not give up and she will try again, demonstrating her resilience. I think that is the central purpose of the paragraph, to show Saeng hasn't given up on her goals or herself.

The reason why the author concludes the story like that is because he is telling the reader that after the snow leaves, the author will begin to plant more plants with care and attention. The test he mentions is a personal one, to make sure his plants don’t die during the next winter, reflecting a cycle of preparation and learning from past experiences. This ending emphasizes a theme of perseverance and looking forward to future growth, both for the plants and for the narrator himself, suggesting a quiet optimism for the seasons to come.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author is stating that Saeng is happy when she is around the plant and she finds peace with it because it brings back cherished childhood memories. For example, “And that rich sweet scent, that was familiar to her.” She loved the way it made her feel comforted and connected to her past. When one of the leaves fell off and she breathed in its fragrance, it reminded her specifically of her grandmother and a sense of home. Minfong Ho might have experienced something like this in her own life, drawing from personal emotion. She might have wrote this because the story could relate to other people who moved from another country and have an object or a scent that powerfully brought back memories. Everytime that I touch or smell a particular sweater, for instance, it brings back memories of my own grandmother. I feel that she wrote this not only because of her personal experience but also because it could genuinely relate to others who share a similar sense of nostalgic connection.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to show how some people vowed silently because they don’t want to express themselves openly to others. Also, maybe because they are not very trusting of people, or even of themselves at that moment. One day I was like that; I didn’t want to talk to anybody and felt withdrawn. All I wanted to do is sit in my room and think deeply, think about my life and where I am going to go after I die. I would just sit in my room in the dark, wondering if I would come back in another body or if my soul would roam the earth endlessly. But then I started to think that I am just a kid, and I have a wonderful life ahead of me. I realized that when I get to the point where I need to think about those heavier things, then I would, but for now it was okay to be present. So I started talking to everybody again, re-engaging with the world around me and finding a better balance in my thoughts.

The author concludes this story by making this statement because the author wants you to feel like the character in the book is determined. The author is trying to put across a statement saying to get through a challenge and then try again. The character is not giving up, and she will get through the test even though it is hard, demonstrating her persistent spirit and resolve to succeed despite the difficulty she faces.

The author is talking about gardening and how she wants to get better at it in the spring. She probably thinks she is bad at gardening because her mom is really good at it, and she wants to be that skilled at gardening too. This creates a sense of aspiration and a personal goal for her to achieve, hoping to match her mother's ability when the new season arrives.

The reason for this is so you get the feeling that Saeng has about gardening. She is praying for spring to come so she can do it over again and improve. She likes to watch plants grow and become something that you can eat, which brings her a sense of accomplishment and joy. That is the way the author concluded the story with this paragraph, to highlight her hopeful and nurturing connection to the natural world.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to show determination and hope. The geese and the hibiscus symbolize Saeng’s determination, because they always come back no matter what. Saeng will be back to take the test, just like the geese will also be back. The hibiscus also symbolizes her because it has faced adversity also. It has been taken to new places and had new homes, much like Saeng, and has a harsh winter coming in the near future. However, it always finds a way to come back and bloom in the spring, which is what Saeng hopes to do by taking the driver’s test. The author included the last paragraph to show symbolism between Saeng, the geese, and the hibiscus, reinforcing their shared theme of resilience. That is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because he is basically trying to say that everything happens for a reason, and that reason might be understood through the seasons. She thinks that she would have done better on her test in the spring only for the simple fact that everything blooms in the spring. This connection suggests a natural cycle of renewal and opportunity, where setbacks are temporary and new beginnings are always possible.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that she can go through these obstacles even though she moved from her home land. The paragraph highlights her resilience in the face of challenges, emphasizing her personal growth in a new environment. Also it shows that she has more confidence, which is a key development from her earlier struggles. This newfound self-assurance is why the author concluded her story with that paragraph, as it signifies a positive and hopeful resolution for the character's journey.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to show what happens in her life and her decision to try again. But in the story it talks about the fallen blossom, noting "One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it." This careful action suggests they take care of their garden and try to make it live in the winter, symbolizing their nurturing spirit and hope. So thats what I think about the last paragraph; it connects her personal vow to the symbolic care for the hibiscus, showing her determination is linked to the cycles of nature and her own efforts.

The author concludes the story with this because that one paragraph basically sums the whole story up. The line "When the snow melts and the geese return" essentially goes back to the beginning of the story when Saeng started planting, creating a sense of cyclical renewal. This connection to the story's opening reinforces the themes of growth and new beginnings. This is why the author gave the story its concluding paragraph, as it effectively ties the narrative together and emphasizes the character's journey from start to finish.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a few reasons. First, the test is important to Saeng so that she can prove to herself that she is able to pass it, representing a significant personal goal. Ending with this paragraph also gives the reader some suspense as to whether Saeng will pass or even go to take the test again, leaving her future open to imagination. Lastly, this paragraph shows Saeng’s personality traits through her vow. It shows that she is persistent, determined, and strong willed, which are central qualities that define her character throughout the narrative.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," at the end the author writes, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, In the spring, when the snow melt and geese return and this hibiscus Is budding, then I will take the test again." The reason why the author included that is because she is trying to tell the readers to get right back up and do it again, conveying that if you fell once there is no harm in trying again. This vow, made for when it's spring and the birds return, shows her promise to take the driver's test after her initial failure. After failing the test, Saeng buys a flower at a florist that reminded her of Vietnam, and she takes it home and puts it in the garden, finding comfort in a memory from her past. When she told her mother that she failed, Saeng's mother was very understanding and told her maybe next time, providing supportive encouragement. In conclusion, the author writes the last paragraph as a moral to never give up and keep trying until you accomplish your goals in life, framing Saeng's resolution as a universal lesson in perseverance.

The author concludes the story that way so she can keep everyone wondering. I believe she ended that way to let us know that she will be back and when she comes back she will be ready for everything including that test. She left us wondering because when she does come back she is going to want us to read about what happened when she came back and what happened when she passed the test. She only made that vow to herself and told nobody else because if she did, she would have let them down if she failed. This private promise is what gives her the strength and determination to try again, ensuring that her motivation remains pure and personal. That is precisely why she concludes the story in that particular way, leaving her future open yet full of quiet resolve.

The author ends the story with this because she is saying she will be around next year to take the test again. She is saying how she wants to be around when the plants grow, to witness the renewal that spring brings. She mostly wants to see the hibiscus grow, a specific flower that holds deep meaning for her. Because she appreciates and likes nature so much, she finds a profound connection to life and her own future in its cycles, and she wants to be around again to see them grow and flourish as a symbol of her own potential for growth.

The author concludes the story with this final paragraph to show how sentimental and important the plant is to Saeng. She will take that test again when the winter is over because it's too cold for nice hibiscus to survive, mirroring her own struggle in a harsh new environment. You need a winter hibiscus, one that is resilient. The line, “Not like the kind we had before,” shows how important it is that she finds a hibiscus like the ones she had at home, a symbol of her past and her enduring identity. She shows disappointment in herself throughout the story until that last paragraph when she finally shows courage and strong will, deciding to persevere just as the hardy plant does.

When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. The author concluded this story in such a way that it makes the reader ask questions, much like in the modernists' interpretation of a story by making the reader ask questions instead of there being a clear moral to the story. For example, in many modernist stories, a main character might run away and all the reader gets is a slamming door, an open-ended conclusion. Much like in this story, there is a twist in that what test is the main character talking about? Is she going to try to make new friends? Is this like a resolution she is making to herself? This ambiguity also leaves the reader wanting more of the story so that they may go back and even read it again to uncover deeper meanings.

The “Winter Hibiscus” is a relatively sad, but hopeful story that uses lots of symbols. The author concluded the story with a confident ending that makes the reader feel satisfied. The two reasons he wrote this conclusion paragraph is to give the ending a hopeful tone and relate the objects she sees to the spring. “Winter Hibiscus” ends with a hopeful tone thanks to the confident vow Saeng silently makes to herself. She had a rough day, and the author wanted to make sure she had something to look forward to as a goal, which also reveals how strong of a person Saeng is internally. The author uses this conclusion paragraph to leave the reader with a hopeful and confident tone. The second reason the author concluded with that paragraph was to relate some of the objects she sees to the spring and its themes of renewal. The geese represent the new place she is living in, and the hibiscus represents her old home, linking these two symbols together so the reader can relate them to the coming spring. The way the author concluded the story was brilliantly done, representing a hopeful tone and symbols that relate to spring, ending confidently and leaving the reader satisfied with Saeng's quiet determination.

I think the author concludes with this paragraph because she wants to emphasize the importance of not giving up. For example, he wants to show us that we should never give up at anything, even if we fail initially. The paragraph serves as a final, powerful reminder of this core theme, reinforcing the idea that persistence is key. Therefore, that is why he ends the story like that, leaving the reader with a clear and motivating message.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph primarily because she wanted to get her point across effectively. Furthermore, she aimed to create a deeper understanding of the complexities within the passage for the reader. By crafting this final section, the author wanted the reader to feel her message as if they were there to witness the events firsthand, creating a more immersive and impactful experience. This final paragraph thus solidifies the story's emotional and thematic resonance.

The author concluded the story with the sentence because she wanted to show that since Saeng found the flower, she has gained new hope and a reason for passing the test. The flower gave her inspiration because it made her look back fondly on her home in Vietnam, as seen when she stuttered, “I mean, not like the kind we had at-at” and found she was still too shaky to say the words "at home." When Saeng brought the plant to her new home and planted it in the garden, it was like bringing a little piece of Vietnam home, which comforted her. The overall inspiration and the memories the flower held for Saeng made her feel better about her new home and gave her a reason to start fresh with her driving test, symbolizing a new beginning.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she is conveying a sense of cyclical renewal and patient hope. She is saying that when the flowers come back in the spring, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding after the winter, she will garden them again. This final image connects the character's personal resolve to the natural world's dependable rhythms, suggesting a quiet determination to begin anew when the conditions are right.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with the line, “when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” because it creates the mood that Saeng is accepting the changes in her life. Just as nature adapts to climate and location changes, Saeng seems to appreciate her new situation and is deciding to make it a positive instead of a negative. The author is showing that if you are having trouble, you should try again; this lesson is powerfully communicated through the main character, Saeng, and her newfound resolve. This ending beautifully ties her personal growth to the theme of perseverance.

I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph for a lot of different reasons. One reason why the author could have concluded the story with this paragraph is because she might try it again, showing her resilience and unwillingness to give up after a single failure. A second reason why the author could have concluded the story with this paragraph is because she probably wanted to try to make her mother proud, recognizing the importance of her mother's support and hopes for her. A third reason why the author could have concluded the story with this paragraph is because she probably really felt that she had disappointed herself and needed to prove her own capabilities. In conclusion, if you mess up on something, you should try again because maybe you will do a lot better the next time.

Minfong Ho concluded “Winter Hibiscus” with the lines “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to show that there is always hope for better things to come. Saeng had become sad because she remembered her home in Vietnam, a place filled with warmth and memories. She longed for her natural home and the familiarity of her past life. Her missed memories agonizingly hurt Saeng because she was now far away and in a different world, feeling isolated and out of place. However, the author started to reveal hints that Saeng would accept her new home and find some childhood memories there too, creating a bridge between her past and present. “Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and –yes– familiar to Saeng now.” Already, Saeng was growing familiar with her surrounding area, noticing small details that were becoming part of her new life. Her hibiscus would keep her Laotian culture, tradition, and memories alive, as the geese would help her feel happy and accustomed to her new environment. As one kept her heritage and “Southeast Asian” culture alive through memories, she would continue a successful life and pass her test, finding a way to thrive. That is why Minfong Ho ended “Winter Hibiscus” with the particular paragraph.

The author concludes the story in "Winter Hibiscus" in a way that is kind of funny or weird, like a quiet promise to oneself. The concluding sentence is ‘when they come back Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.’ I know one thing is that part of the title is in the concluding sentence, so it is basically concluding the whole story by tying back to its central symbol. It also provides a resolution for the characters, showing Saeng's internal decision and renewed determination for the future, which brings the narrative to a satisfying close.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that the narrator is ready to face her challenge again. The narrator tried the test once and failed, which was a difficult and discouraging experience for her. She bought herself a flower to cheer herself up, seeking a small comfort after her disappointment. Her mother talked to her and then she felt better, gaining perspective and encouragement from that conversation. She felt newly determined to pass the driving test, just like the flower was determined to survive the harsh conditions and bloom again when the seasons changed.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it symbolizes the change in Saeng as well as other things related to growth and cycles. The snow always melts when the seasons change, making way for new life. The geese always come back when the seasons change, following their natural migration pattern. The hibiscus will bud when the seasons change, ready to bloom once more. Saeng will try again when the seasons change, aligning her personal resolve with the natural world. But she’ll be a different person also, having grown from her experiences and reflections. Knowing that everything will change but stay the same on the inside, Saeng decides she will too, embracing transformation while holding onto her core self. She has more of an appreciation for Laos now after seeing the hibiscus and remembering her past, which has deepened her connection to her heritage and given her strength.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author shows that Saeng will take the test again and that she will be ready and she will pass the test. This readiness is tied to the hopeful season of spring, a time of renewal. Also, the author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that it ends the story knowing that she will take the test over again, so she knows she has faith to take the test again and make her mother proud that she passed. This final vow provides a sense of closure and forward-looking optimism. This is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the spring it’s warmer and more fun, a season that brings new energy and hope, plus she will have time to study her stuff in winter for the spring time. This period of preparation during the cold months allows her to build her confidence. Also because, like she says in the story, it goes along with the conclusion at the end that she finally understood what was going on, so she connected it to the way the geese are returning, which symbolizes her own cycle of trying again.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it is what she solemnly promised herself. This internal vow represents a pivotal moment of personal commitment and resolve for Saeng. It marks a firm decision to face her challenge again with newfound determination. This promise to herself is the core reason the narrative ends on this note, highlighting her personal growth and inner strength.

In “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author’s purpose in concluding the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” was to show how the hibiscus and the other plants in the store symbolized Saeng. When Saeng enters the store, she becomes overwhelmed by how many things she had forgotten about living in Vietnam. “Plants that she had not even realized she had known but forgotten grew her back into her childhood world.” This is when Saeng associates herself and her childhood with these plants, reconnecting with her past. When she sees another plant she knows in a pot, she thinks to herself, “How strange to see it in a pot; back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in the brick walls or between tiled roofs.” This symbolizes her, because out of her home, she seems to feel strange and caged, too, while at home in Vietnam she was much more free-spirited. The hibiscus plant, when Saeng takes it home, is described by her mother as strong enough to make it through the cold months. Saeng identifies herself with this description, and so decided that when the hibiscus is done dealing with the bad stuff, she will have, also, and will have budded and grown just like her plant, finding her own strength. Then, she will be ready to achieve her goal.

The author concluded the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Saeng believes that if the hibiscus can survive through hard times and adapt to changes, and survive she can also. She sees the plant as a model of resilience. Saeng concludes that even though she has moved to the United States and it is different she is strong enough to survive and eventually thrive. Failing her drivers test doesn't mean that she is incapable of anything, but that she is capable of trying again with a fresh start like the hibiscus, which buds anew with the spring.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author wants to show Saeng hasnít given up. Easly in the story Saeng goes to the green house and starts to cry, overwhelmed by her failure and the unfamiliar surroundings. When she gets home she says to her mother, ìI-I failed the test.î Despite the disappointment of this, Saeng wanted to go back and try again, demonstrating her resilient spirit. That is why the author ended with that paragraph, to emphasize her determination to persevere and not be defeated by a single setback.

The last paragraph was added in order to represent the determinedness and adapting to new things in Saeng and her family. In the beginning, Saeng held bitterness at failing the test, feeling defeated by her new environment. But after she remembers her homeland through the flower she accepts it, recognizing the possibility of growth. Just as the flower will bud, she will be a new person and thus pass the test, symbolizing her personal evolution. An example of her being determined to deal with it is that she does make friends, and, though the food she offered was rejected she didnít give in, showing her persistent effort to connect. The moment of breakdown was as she got the flower, a catalyst for her emotional release and subsequent acceptance. After she got home it was over with and again she accepts the change, ready to move forward with renewed strength.

The author includes the last paragraph because Saeng is not going to give up and she will try again, showing her resilient character. I think Saeng bought the flower because she had them at her home land and it will help her by providing a comforting link to her past. For example, Saeng started to cry because she miss her homeland, and the familiar flower triggered a wave of nostalgia and sadness for what was left behind. This emotional connection to the plant ultimately fuels her resolve to adapt and succeed in her new life, just as the hibiscus endures the winter.

I think that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he thinks when the flowers come back they would be batter, symbolizing a future renewal. I think that he thinks that it would be a better test next time, as the changing seasons promise new opportunities for growth and success. The imagery of the budding hibiscus directly parallels Saeng's own potential to bloom after a period of hardship, suggesting that her next attempt will be met with a more favorable outcome. This hopeful ending reinforces the idea that perseverance leads to improvement.

The author concludes ìWinter Hibiscusî with the paragraph because it continues the theme of adjusting to changes in life. In the story, Saeng has come to the United States from Vietnam and it is quite a change, requiring significant adaptation. Also changed are the plants, which must survive in a different climate. The hibiscus reminds Saeng of Vietnam, but it is different, a symbol of altered yet enduring life. The mother in the story says, ìIts flowers arenít as pretty, but itís strong enough to make it through the cold winter months here, this winter hibiscus.î The hibiscus also relates to the theme because it is able to adjust to changes, just as Saeng must. The final paragraph talks about snow melting, geese returning and the hibiscus budding, which are all changes the author uses to connect to the theme of cyclical renewal. This adds more understanding to the storyís message about resilience. Additionally, the tone of the last paragraph is hopeful, which gives the reader a positive feeling about Saeng's future. The tone adds to the theme of the story, concluding with a sense of peaceful acceptance and the promise of new beginnings.

The story is about her failing the driving test. Disappointed but not defeated, she says she will try next year when the geese come back, finding a rhythm of hope in the natural cycle. This simple statement connects her personal setback to a larger, more patient timeline, suggesting that her opportunity, like the seasons, will return in its own time.

I think he means that seasons change and that winter will come again, presenting a recurring challenge. I think that is the test, a cyclical trial of endurance and adaptation that all living things must face. This interpretation frames the struggle not as a single event, but as a fundamental part of existence, where resilience is built through repeated effort against the inevitable return of hardship.

I think that the author concludes the story with the given paragraph to show that she is similar to the hibiscus and geese. First, the geese and hibiscus both have a goal, which is to survive the winters. Geese fly south for the winter to stay warm, just as Saeng moved to a different environment where she must adapt. Also, Saeng must experience winter along with the hibiscus. The hibiscus needs to be strong to overcome winter; from this, it shows Saeng is like her hibiscus because she needs to be strong to overcome the test. If her hibiscus can overcome its test, winter, then she can survive to conquer her own, drawing strength from nature's example of perseverance.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” includes “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because it shows that she can adapt to change and still can think about her old country too. An example of how she can keep her old country alive in her life is “But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac.” This shows that she can still eat the foods she ate back at her old home and try new things at her new home, blending the familiar with the foreign. In conclusion the excerpt shows that the author can put both cultures together and be happy, finding a balance that honors her past while embracing her present.

There could be many reasons why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, each offering a different layer of meaning. There could be many different interpretations of this paragraph that could have importance to the story. I think that the author includes this to say that when the spring comes, she will have many more reasons and a renewed spirit to take the driving test. You can break this paragraph down to mean many different things. I interpreted it to mean that when the spring comes back, she will have a new beginning. The snow melting away represents all the hardship she faced in the previous year fading. The geese returning and the hibiscus budding means that they are also coming back to start the new year, symbolizing rebirth. It is included at the end to show how Saeng is trying to forget about how she failed the test, using this time now to prepare mentally. She thinks that once she forgets all of the bad things she went through the previous year, she can move forward. She had to move on and be able to pass the driving test the next time around, learning from her experience. The author concluded the story with the paragraph to show how Saeng plans to solve her problems with patience and hope. The way you interpret the paragraph gives you different ideas about what it is trying to say, but I think that it is showing a new beginning that she will have to go through the next year, a fresh start aligned with the renewal of nature.

I think the author concludes the story with the phrase, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to signify her determination. The statement shows that she will be ready for them the next time they come back, using the cyclical renewal of nature as a metaphor for her own personal resolve and the promise of a second chance. This connection between the natural world and her internal vow strengthens the message of hope and persistence, illustrating that she is not defeated but is instead preparing for a future attempt with renewed spirit and commitment.

The author ended the story “Winter Hibiscus” with Saeng vowing to retake the test to powerfully show the central themes of the narrative. One theme of the story is to never give up, which is mirrored in the winter hibiscus that must last through the long, harsh winter but ultimately does survive. Its resilience directly inspires Saeng to keep trying despite her own setbacks. Another theme is to overcome your obstacles, as the flower faces many dangers like the cold and snow but still manages to blossom beautifully. Similarly, Saeng wants to overcome her own obstacles and pass the test that challenged her. Therefore, the ending of the story effectively displays these themes by linking the character's resolve to the symbolic strength of the hibiscus, creating a cohesive and meaningful conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this particular part because it made the story stand out a little and provided a poignant resolution. For example, when Saeng said that she meant when the plants came back, it tied her personal journey to the natural cycle of rebirth. It also gave the ending a little something to hold on to, a specific and hopeful image for the future, rather than simply stopping or continuing to talk about the geese in a way that might get the reader off topic. Lastly, she also meant when the geese came back, which completes the seasonal imagery she uses to mark the time for her renewed effort. This focus ensures the ending is both memorable and tightly connected to the story's central symbolism.

I think the author finished the story with that phrase because the girl sees this plant as a symbol of strength and faith, so she will take the test next year when it comes back. She truly likes the plant, viewing it as a resilient and hopeful presence in her life, and she hopes it will bring her the luck and fortitude she needs to succeed in her future attempt. The hibiscus serves as a tangible reminder that beauty and success can emerge after a period of hardship, reinforcing her decision to try again with a more positive and determined outlook.

I think the author ended the story with that phrase to show that she won't give up; no matter how hard it is, she keeps trying. The girl says in the story, “I failed the test,” which acknowledges her initial defeat, and then at the end she declares she will take that test again, proving she is not willing to accept failure forever. I also think the author ended the story with that paragraph to make you wonder if she will ever pass the test, leaving a sense of hopeful anticipation about her future and the outcome of her perseverance. This creates an engaging and thoughtful conclusion for the reader.

I think the author writes this because whatever test she has to take she wasn’t ready for before, but now whenever the geese return and the hibiscus returns, she will be ready to take the test. Perhaps she was not prepared mentally or emotionally for the challenge it presented. The return of the geese and the budding of the hibiscus seem to signal a time of renewal and personal readiness. So in conclusion, I think when she says the geese and the hibiscus return, she will take the test, and maybe she wasn't physically and mentally prepared for it the first time, but the changing seasons give her a new sense of confidence.

Authors chose their closing paragraphs carefully. The author chose to end their story with this paragraph because all of the imagery the narrator includes in the last paragraph represents something special in the character's eyes. There are specific reasons the author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph. The author's choice of the ending paragraph is very important for conveying the story's final message. The character says “this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The hibiscus that she mentions represents the ability to overcome obstacles and to grow again after a setback. In the story, it is talking about the girl overcoming the failed test and finding the courage to retake it. That is precisely why the author concludes with that powerful image. The author also writes, “when the snow melts and the geese return.” This, to the character, represents new beginnings and second chances. That imagery gives the character the sense that next time around, with a new season, she will pass the test. The author adds that paragraph in the end to symbolize new beginnings, fresh chances, and the ability to overcome obstacles. Authors choose their last paragraph for specific reasons, and this author did as well, using it to symbolize these important themes of hope and resilience.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because of a saying that reflects the character's inner state. When it is cold and silent, she is left alone with her thoughts, perhaps feeling isolated. But when the snow melts and spring is here, it signifies a change in her mood and activity. She is said to talk and do lots of fun things, coming out of her shell. The paragraph contrasts her winter solitude with her springtime engagement, showing how the external season mirrors her internal transformation and readiness to embrace life again.

I believe the author concluded the story with that paragraph because the geese that flew down south in a beautiful V formation fly down every season, marking a reliable cycle of nature. So she tells herself, almost as a personal promise, that she will take the test again when the geese return and the hibiscus plant is budding. For example, she thinks to herself, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” In that moment, looking up at the geese, she is almost reminded of an experience she went through somewhat similar, connecting her past struggles to the present promise of a new beginning. This connection to the natural cycles reinforces her determination to try again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph, "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" to emphasize that you can overcome a defeat or failure by waiting until the "season" comes again for you to re-endure. Basically, the hibiscus, a plant, meant much to the narrator and her mother; it was dying and they dug up a hole to help it to grow, so when it grows again that proves that it will be living better. So when Saeng relates the test to the hibiscus, it will be her having the opportunity to pass the test. The story ends with this paragraph symbolizing a new beginning about to take place. This actually means a situation that will come again that will help you to get what is needed out of it that you missed the first time. The story and the paragraph emphasize what life is about, a continuous cycle of budding and renewal.

She can’t wait till the flowers start to come back when the snow melts so it isn’t very cold out so they grow and she is going to take her test that she has failed when the geese and flowers come back. She looks forward to the warmer days of spring, a time of renewal and second chances. The bleak winter landscape will be replaced by vibrant life, and with it, her own opportunity to try again. The return of the geese and the blooming flowers will signal the perfect moment for her to face her challenge once more, filled with the hope that the new season brings.

The author concludes with this paragraph to show that Saeng, like the geese and the hibiscus, will return again and have hope. Saeng is a little depressed in the story because she is in a new country, and just failed her driving test. The hibiscus plant in the florist shop brings back painful emotional memories for her, but at the same time, it is very comforting. Later in the story, she plants the hibiscus outside in the garden with her mother. As her mother goes inside, Saeng watches the geese fly overhead. “Almost reluctantly, (Saeng) realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her. Like the geese.” Saeng knew the geese would return in the spring, just like she would to her driving test. The hibiscus would be in bloom again too to provide her with hope. This is what the final paragraph in the story “The Winter Hibiscus” means, illustrating her journey from sorrow to resilience.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng’s everlasting determination. This idea of her determination to succeed can be connected to the plant she brings home. The plant she knew grew wild where she used to live, but she found it potted in the United States which is limiting its growth, just like Saeng’s new country seems unordinary, and she feels out of place. The potted hibiscus represents her own contained life in a foreign land, yet its very survival hints at a potential for future flourishing. Just as the plant endures, so too does Saeng’s spirit, promising that her determination will eventually allow her to overcome the limitations she currently faces and find her own way to grow.

The author concludes the story with Saeng telling herself she’ll take the test again because it draws together the overall theme and major actions of the story. The theme of the story is that you can get used to a new environment by finding beauty in it and similarities to your old home. Saeng says that “many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now like the geese.” And when she’s in the greenhouse the plants draw her back into memories of Vietnam and her grandmother. Saeng was having a hard time adjusting to new things after moving to a new country, but she was determined to overcome the difficulties just like she had overcome the differences between the new environment and Vietnam. I think the author concluded the story by talking about the geese and the hibiscus and retaking the test because it demonstrates all the ways that Saeng is adjusting to her new life and shows her and the reader that she can overcome new things. She vows to herself that she can do it, and foreshadows her future success and adaptation to an American lifestyle, solidifying the story’s message of perseverance and hope.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph that she did because it was the end and the start of a new beginning. The author uses the seasons in her story. The winter is the current season and spring is on its way. Although Saeng failed her test in the winter when most things die, she is looking forward to spring to start again on her test. The geese will return and the hibiscus will bud to show spring is here with new life. Saeng will also have new life in her test to pass it this time and drive. The spring season will come and new life will be provided to all, marking a cyclical promise of renewal that Saeng now fully embraces for her own future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph effectively summarizes the essence of the narrative in a condensed and concise manner, capturing the main events and emotional core without needing to recount every detail, thus serving as a fitting and reflective closure.  This paragraph is a good way to end the story because it relates directly to the driving test, which is a central event in the narrative. The narrator says she will try again in the spring, which provides a sense of hope and forward momentum, tying the story's conclusion back to its central challenge and the character's resolve.  I believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it encapsulates the story's fundamental theme. It explains what happened in the end, framing the entire narrative as analogous to the growth and living of a flower, where the preceding events depicted the struggles and development leading to this final, blossoming realization.  In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes with a paragraph that seems intentionally incomplete, mirroring the ongoing nature of Saeng's journey. The girl Saeng vows to retake her driver's test in the spring. As she holds the plant, she feels cold and helpless, much like the hibiscus itself, a connection highlighted when the leaves are described as "quivering in the wind." Her mother's reassurance, saying "I'm glad you got it," and her observation that the plant is "root-bound, poor thing," signifies Saeng's own clinging attachment to her homeland. The mother's confidence that the plant will now survive suggests that Saeng, too, will become stronger by spring, which is precisely why the author chooses to end the story at this point of poised potential.  The author concludes the story by illustrating the girl's deep connection to the plant and the additional symbolism of the geese. The "Winter Hibiscus" represents her enduring link to her homeland. She resolves to retake her driving test when her plant buds and shows its bravery, a commitment she intends to mirror personally. The geese flying south further reflect her personal journey, as she plans to take the test when the geese return from their migration, symbolizing her own return and readiness after a period of growth and transition.

The author wrote the ending paragraph the way she did for many reasons. The main reason for this is because she wanted to end the story on a lighter note, providing a sense of hopeful resolution. All throughout the story there was a depressing, nostalgic tone that made the reader yearn for the past. The author wanted to put an emphasis on being strong even though you might not enjoy where you are at in the present moment. Also the author wanted to show the strength of the main character, Saeng. Even though she has just failed a test in a new, strange world she still wishes to continue pushing forward, demonstrating her resilience. This adds more dimension to the character and makes her less static and more dynamic, showing her capacity for growth. This is a very good story to read if you are homesick and need something to push you forward, as it champions the human spirit's ability to persevere.

The author concludes with that statement because it shows she needs time to heal and to grow accustomed to her new surroundings. She needs time to adjust to her new home like the hibiscus needs time to get some roots in the new soil she is on. When she is at the orchard she sees the hibiscus and has memories of her old home, making her cry but yet feel good at the same time, a bittersweet mixture of pain and comfort. This moment captures the complex emotional transition of adapting to a new life while still holding onto the past, illustrating that such adjustments are a gradual process.

I believe the author concludes that passage in the story to show the theme of patience and the importance of waiting for a better time. Saeng was to wait for spring, believing that maybe it will feel like her home town again when the seasons change. She likes the spring better than the winter, as it represents renewal and life. She likes the birds, the geese that return in spring, a familiar sight that contrasts with their departure in winter. That way I believe the author concludes that passage to highlight the cyclical nature of life and the hope that comes with new beginnings, suggesting that time can bring comfort and familiarity.

“When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author has left her home and moved to another country, a difficult and disorienting experience. She is now in an unfamiliar place where everything that now surrounds her is new and mostly unknown, creating a sense of isolation. By ending the story with this quote, it suggests that the author still has hope of adapting to her new home and finding her place within it. When she left her home, she did not just leave a building behind; she left her home, people she loved, and an endless list of memories, a profound sense of loss. At times she might have felt out of place because she was no longer in her comfort zone, struggling with her new identity. She is now “out of the box,” and in a whole new world, forced to navigate unfamiliar social and cultural landscapes. When she saw the hibiscus, the exotic plant took her back to her memories and to the love of her old home, triggering a powerful wave of nostalgia. Then she came back to reality and broke apart with sadness and “failed her test,” overwhelmed by the emotional weight of her displacement. The ending sentence shows that the author is willing to try to survive in this new place and that she is still determined to pass her own test of adapting, turning her momentary failure into a promise for future success.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" to mean that she will take the test and hoped she would pass so she could make her mother happy and support her family. She chose spring because spring is the rebirth of nature, a time of new beginnings and fresh starts. Saeng would like to retake the test with a clear and clean mind, unburdened by the initial shock and sadness of her new environment. I think that the reason why the author chose to put the paragraph in the end of the story is to leave the reader with a powerful message of hope and resilience, showing that Saeng has not given up on her future or her responsibilities.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for several significant reasons. Throughout the story, Saeng struggles with her past and the difficulty of overcoming it. The paragraph helps bring a sense of closure to the story and her emotional journey. When Saeng returns home with the hibiscus, she tells her mother she couldn’t help it and was unable to overcome her past. Saeng said, “I-I failed the test.” When she says “the test,” she means the ability to cope with the profound loss of her grandmother and her homeland, and to ultimately overcome that grief. In the concluding paragraph, however, Saeng declares she will retake the test. She said, “When the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This statement signifies a resolve to try again when she feels stronger. In conclusion, the author uses the concluding paragraph to bring closure to the story and the emotional obstacles Saeng faces, while also offering a note of future hope.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she wants to end the story with a sense of hope and renewal. For example, since Saeng has moved to the United States, she feels a deep sense of homesicknes. To make it worse, she failed the driver’s test, which compounded her feelings of failure and displacement. The narrator states, “She found she was still to shaky to say the words at home, lest the burst into tears again.” This quote helps illustrate the emotional state of the homesick girl, showing how raw her feelings are. She concludes with this paragraph to show that when spring comes, symbolizing a new beginning, she’ll start out fresh and re-live her life in her new home with a more positive outlook.

The author concluded this story with the paragraph because Saeng is explaining to the readers that she will take the test again when the time is right. She is acknowledging that she is not ready now, but she has not given up entirely. When things seem to be getting better, such as with the changing of the seasons, she will find the strength to retake the test. This final thought provides a forward-looking perspective, indicating her intention to persevere. That is why the author used that paragraph to conclude her story, as it encapsulates Saeng's delayed but determined resolve.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" written by Minfong Ho, the narrator goes to a greenhouse that has many flowers, but one in particular catches her eye: a 'winter' Hibiscus plant. This plant vividly reminds her of her homeland and everything that used to take place there. This plant also reminds her of her grandmother's long, silky gray hair and how she used to watch her dry it in the sun; then she would help her knot it up into a bun with a bud of this plant in it. The author ends the story with this paragraph because it counters her earlier, defeated statement when she says "I-I failed the test." The end of this passage, which says "..., then I will take the test again," provides a contrasting and hopeful resolution to her initial admission of failure.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the girl Saeng failed the drivers test. "I-I failed the test," said Saeng. She had bought a hibiscus because the flower reminded her of some of the memories from home and the hibiscus she had at her house. At the end, she says that she will retake the test when the geese come back, the snow has melted, and the hibiscus is budding. She does this, I think, because she needs time to just think things through, to remember back home and perhaps to make a hibiscus garden. The hibiscus in this story is just like Saeng. They both experienced a setback; Saeng failed the test and the hibiscus was constricted to a pot. But they both are going to change the bad thing into an opportunity for growth and renewal when the conditions are right.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the paragraph in that way to convey the determination and new found motivation Saeng found by buying the familiar plant. Although she failed her test, finding a plant that reminded her of her home and her grandmother instilled motivation in her to try the test again, she wanted to make her new home in a new country work out for the better, no matter what. “She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky ...” the author included details about the geese to represent moving on. The geese will go, and come back, just like Saeng.
