She failed the test the first time, but getting the plant and seeing the birds motivated her to try again. “Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become ...familiar to her.” The geese were one of the things mentioned that has become very familiar to her, in her new home. Concluding the story with a bit about the geese conveys to the reader that she is slowly but surely learning how to adapt to her strange new home. Finding the plant helped her, because it was already familiar to her. “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral. ‘Hibiscus,’ Saeng said.” After failing her driver’s test, walking into the florist’s shop and finding that plant comforted her. It made this new place feel closer to home than it did at first. The geese had become familiar over time, and finding the plant was simply comforting. Concluding the story that way showed the reader that she was adapting and learning to deal with a tough situation in a comforting way, ultimately finding the strength to persevere.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho the author concludes the story with "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". The author concluded the story with that specific vow because she is saying that when the year starts off anew and starts over, that she will too. She's saying that when the geese come back, the snow melts, and the Hibiscus starts to bud that they all start over and start a new beginning. So when she goes to take the test it will be a new year and a fresh start for her, aligning her personal renewal with the natural cycle of the seasons.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" ended her story with words regarding the natural cycle because Saeng had failed her driving test. Saeng cried when noticing her past through the flower, which evoked powerful memories of her homeland. As well as buying the *dok malik* seeds, this shows that the story ended the way it did, because next season represents a chance for new beginnings, mirroring Saeng's own resolve to try again when circumstances change.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is determined. She says that she is going to take the test again which shows that she is determined and will not be defeated by a single setback. Even though Saeng failed her driver's test she is not going to give up. This final thought solidifies the theme of resilience, demonstrating her commitment to succeeding in her new environment despite initial failures.

The author used that sentence because the snow is melting and the geese are coming back, signaling a shift in the seasons. The flowers were budding up and that is why I think the author used that sentence, to connect Saeng's personal growth to the renewal happening in nature. This parallel emphasizes hope and the promise of a new start, which is central to the story's conclusion. Scribed by the student.

I believe that this was a good ending to the story. When Saeng says "When they come back" she is talking about the flowers, referring to when they come back alive. The phrase "In the spring" shows the specific time when the flower will come back. Furthermore, "When the snows melt and the geese return" she is saying that after winter, when the snow melts, and when the geese return in the spring, this will be the time. "And this Hibiscus is budding" She is indicating when the flowers bloom again in the spring. "Then I will take the test again," she is declaring that after all this happens she will retake the test in the spring. This shows that Saeng will be watching all these things happening and counting down until spring arrives again, so she can retake the test. She is ready for spring to be here, so that she can study and pass the test, and work at the flower shop. This will be her goal for the winter, until spring finally comes, giving her a clear purpose and a reason to look forward to the new season.

The author concluded the story with that ending because in the spring when everything blossoms, the world is full of life and new beginnings. And she wouldn't be focused while there is snow, as the winter represents a dormant and difficult period for her. So when the hibiscus is budding, that is the signal, and that's when she will be able to take her test again, feeling renewed. I think he wrote that because it means something to her, connecting her personal growth and determination to the natural cycle of rebirth and renewal that spring embodies.

This conclusion of the story provides a sense of hope for the future. The girl is upset that she failed the test but still has hope for what will happen next. In the story the narrator says, "She lifted her head." This quote is showing that she is not going to quit and give up, but that she will try until she succeeds, demonstrating her resilience. The conclusion of the story leaves readers to wonder if she will try harder and pass the test for the second time. When she says, "when the snow melts and the geese return," this shows us that she is like the geese because they're both going back for a hard-fought journey, a return that requires effort and perseverance. Also, when she says, "and this hibiscus budding" she is saying when everything comes to life and is at its highest peak she will take the test because she will have the most confidence, feeling at her strongest. The author concludes the story to show that there is hope for the future and that she is not going to give up. Although she is upset about failing the test she will certainly be ready to pass it in the spring, having used the winter to prepare and grow stronger.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for a couple of reasons. Primarily, it serves to resolve Saeng's emotional journey, transitioning her from initial disappointment to a state of determined anticipation. It ties her personal goal of retaking the test to the natural world, using the changing seasons as a metaphor for her own cycle of failure and hoped-for success. This connection emphasizes themes of renewal and perseverance, leaving the reader with a final, impactful image of hope and forward-looking resolve that defines her character's arc.

Saeng is aware that it will be a long time before she will worry about school work again, as the winter season stretches ahead. That is why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, to emphasize this period of waiting and the shift in her immediate focus. The ending captures her acceptance of the timeline set by nature, indicating that her efforts will be postponed until the conditions are right, which is the central reason for the story's final thoughts being presented in this manner.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because he wants to emphasize that the girl is not completely dissatisfied with leaving her home. He ended with that because he wanted to show that there is hope for her to learn to love her new home, suggesting a future where she finds comfort and belonging in her unfamiliar surroundings. This final note provides a sense of optimistic closure, indicating her emotional journey is moving toward acceptance.

The author ends the story with this sentence because Saeng needs a break before she takes the test again. Saeng is comparing two indifferent things: flowers and taking a test. That is significant because the comparison highlights her need for a period of rest and reflection. The author chooses this ending to underscore the importance of this pause, allowing Saeng to gather her strength for the next attempt.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to show that the girl is going to be like the hibiscus. The next time it blooms, the girl will be ready for the test and will take it again and will pass. The author wants to show that the girl will not give up and will try again to make sure she succeeds. The author involves the hibiscus to show that the girl and the flower will bloom at the same time, symbolizing her impending success and personal growth. This parallel creates a powerful image of resilience and hope for the future.

Well, I think the author concludes the story with that sentence because maybe Saeng likes the spring and can concentrate better with her favorite flower that she thinks relates to her life. The connection to the season and the flower provides her with a sense of peace and inspiration. This final thought ties her personal feelings to the natural world, suggesting that this association gives her the mental clarity she needs.

The author ends the story like that to show the theme of working hard. Some other examples of working hard are the "winter hibiscus," which survives and blooms despite the cold. Another example is her vow to pass the test, demonstrating her determination and perseverance. The author uses these elements to reinforce the central message that persistent effort leads to achievement, which is why the story concludes on this particular note.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph that they did because it mirrors the opening, creating a cohesive narrative structure. To introduce the story, the author tells about Saeng failing her driver's test and then seeing a familiar plant that she wants to buy. The middle of the story details her struggles and difficulty adapting to her new home. So to conclude the story, the author states that Saeng will take her driver's test again once the flowers start budding and the geese come out. The flower and the geese remind her of her homeland, and this connection reveals that thinking of home, and the comforting objects associated with it, helps her overcome obstacles and find the strength to persevere.

Authors use many techniques to improve their stories and engage their readers. Without these techniques, a story might seem bland, average, or unattractive. Author Minfong Ho conveys the fact that Saeng will try to take the test again. Instead of simply stating the fact that she will retake the test, he has her make a promise on the geese that she will. The author ended the story in this manner to show how strongly she felt about the test and to emphasize her renewed determination through this symbolic vow.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it connects the hibiscus back to the trials and triumphs of Saeng. Just as Saeng cannot give up and must go back to retake the test, the winter hibiscus must make it through the hard, rough winter and come back strong. The hibiscus are a symbol of hope, and Saeng thinks of them as her hope. Throughout the story, the hibiscus are comforting to Saeng because they remind her of home. The author includes this because many people can relate to this and find hope in things. For Saeng, knowing that each year the hibiscus will come back in those difficult conditions reassures her that she will be okay there as well, reinforcing her own resilience.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph to show a new beginning and a sense of renewal. The geese are coming back to restart their life there, the hibiscus will be blooming, and she will re-take the test. At the beginning, Saeng was depressed about having to leave her old country and her grandmother. The text describes, "A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her." She remembered how some of these plants grew wild in bushes or between cracks in the sidewalk. Saeng saying what she did in the last paragraph shows that she found comfort and confidence in the hibiscus. Memories of the past showed her the way forward, and now she is going to retake her driver's test with a newfound sense of purpose.

I think the author concludes this story with this ending paragraph because the narrative is all about how she feels comforted by the plants and she wants to wait until the weather breaks and the geese come back to take her test. I think she wants to wait that way she will be more comfortable with her surroundings, feeling a deeper connection to her new environment. This waiting period allows her to clear her mind, draw strength from these natural symbols, and ultimately do her best on the test when the time is right.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows Saeng wants to take the test again, but she wants to take the test again when everything else good and happy returns like the plant and the geese, signaling a time of renewal. This is true because Saeng says "When they (geese) come back… and this hibiscus is budding I will take the test." This shows her maturity and happiness, as she has found a new sense of hope. She wants to do something hard and maybe even not fun when everything else returns and is happy, aligning her personal challenge with the natural cycle. Just as when she came, she was sad, but when the geese and plant comes back she wants to help them through this and make them happy too, sharing in the collective joy. This way they all can be happy at the same time, concluding her journey from sorrow to optimistic anticipation.

The short story “Winter Hibiscus” as written by author Minfong Ho, ends with main character Saeng, promising herself that in the spring when the geese return and the winter hibiscus begins to bud, that she would re-take her failed drivers test, marking a pivotal moment of resolve. Mingfong Ho, writes this story, with heavy imagery and symbolism, the hibiscus found in the floral shop, represents a connection for Saeng to her homeland, a tangible link to her past, and the bittermellon, which is loved by Saeng, but unbearable to people in @LOCATION1, represents Saeng’s hard time connecting to people in @LOCATION1, highlighting her cultural isolation. And for Saeng, the budding hibiscus, and returning geese, are representative of a new opportunity to pass her drivers test, and better adapt to life in @LOCATION1, symbolizing her readiness to embrace a new beginning in her new home.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she wanted to show that Saeng doesn’t give up and that nature gives @CAPS1 strength, reinforcing these central themes. The conclusion shows that Saeng doesn’t give up by saying that she is going to take the test again, even though she failed it earlier that day, demonstrating her resilience. Also, it shows that nature gives Saeng strength by saying that Saeng will take the test again when the geese return, when hibiscus buds and when the snow melts in spring; nature gives her strength because it reminds her of where they used to live and her grandmother, providing comfort and motivation. In conclusion, the author concluded the story with that paragraph to show that Saeng is not a quitter, and that nature gives her strength and confidence, wrapping up her character development on a hopeful and determined note.

The character, Saeng, experiences both internal and external conflicts, struggling with her new environment. Saeng had failed her driver’s test and stilled missed Vietnam, feeling disconnected and disappointed. The ending of the story was an excellent choice of conclusion for the story, as it provides a symbolic resolution. The flock of @CAPS1 geese represented her changes, mirroring her own journey of adaptation. She used to feel awkward and out of places, a stranger in a new land where many things were new to her. Saeng realized that life isn't so bad for her, finding a sense of belonging. The planting of the “winter hibiscus” represented her change as well, a physical act of putting down roots. It showed how she will start new and continue happily, as Saeng will “plant a new seed” for her future. The ending was well chosen for the story because it foreshadows Saeng’s future growth and acceptance. The story is inspiring and the ending greatly contributes to the effect, leaving the reader with a sense of optimistic closure.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show how Saeng relates the hibiscus overcoming of problems to her own overcoming of problems, drawing a direct parallel for the reader. Saeng is comparing the hibiscus to herself, seeing her own struggle reflected in the plant's resilience. If the hibiscus can adapt to its surroundings, then so can she, finding strength in this simple truth. And if the hibiscus makes it through the winter, then she too can make it; and she will re-take the test that she failed before, turning her initial failure into a future goal. Also, before this she says that things that were once strange to her now seemed familiar, like the geese, indicating her growing acclimatization. She then see’s them overhead flying in a V, a formation of unity and purpose. They are also adapting to their surroundings by flying to a warmer place, and Saeng too can adapt, concluding that she, like the natural world, is capable of change and survival.

The author concludes the story with that sentence because she is excited for spring to come back so she can plant more things and watch them bloom, and come alive. This final thought reflects a sense of joyful anticipation for the future, a feeling of renewal and growth that mirrors the natural cycle of the seasons. The author looks forward to the process of nurturing new life, from planting the seeds to witnessing the vibrant colors and vitality of the flowers. This ending encapsulates a hopeful and forward-looking perspective, emphasizing the continuous and rewarding cycle of gardening that brings her happiness and a connection to the living world around her.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows Saeng will not give up. Saeng failed her driver's test and as she was walking home she found a hibiscus. It reminded her of her old home. Saeng goes to the greenhouse or flower shop and buys one. When she returns she plants the hibiscus. The hibiscus is keeping her from giving up. When it starts budding, Saeng will take the test again. This act of planting and nurturing the flower represents her own resilience and determination to grow and thrive in her new environment. The budding hibiscus becomes a symbol of her personal hope and a promise to herself that she will try again, linking her success to the plant's eventual flowering.

The author chose that paragraph to put at the end because that is when everything will be perfect to redo her mistake. Saeng said crying "I-I failed the test!" which means she failed at what she thought she was good at. "Here let me help mother," getting up and taking the shovel away from her mother. Saeng is trying to get better at gardening so when she does redo her mistake she will do better. As the reader can see Saeng wants to pass the test, so she can believe she is a great gardener like her mother. This conclusion shows her commitment to learning from her failure and improving her skills, drawing strength from her mother's example. Her determination to master gardening is directly tied to her desire for self-validation and eventual success on her next attempt.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it makes people want to read the next story to see how she does on the test. In the story she failed the test, but now that she has changed she wants to retake the test because she knows she can do better now than before. This ending creates a sense of anticipation and curiosity about Saeng's future efforts and personal growth. The reader is left with a compelling question about whether her newfound confidence and perspective will lead to a different outcome, effectively setting the stage for a potential continuation of her journey.

The author concludes with this paragraph because everything that is in it is in the story somewhere, so it really intertwines together. She learns to adapt to her new homeland as does the plant. This final section weaves together the key themes of resilience and adaptation that have been developed throughout the narrative. The parallel between the character's journey and the plant's struggle to thrive in new soil is clearly drawn, reinforcing the central message of the story. The conclusion effectively echoes the core idea that both living things can find a way to flourish in a new environment, bringing the story's central metaphor to a satisfying close.

I would say that the author concluded this story with that particular paragraph because they wanted to be very consistent with the narrative's themes. They wanted the reader to have a very good example and a clear understanding of the text's central message. In brief words, the ending serves to reinforce the lessons learned and the character's resolve, providing a coherent and satisfying closure to the story.

The reason why they include the story with the paragraph is because they talk about the same thing, reinforcing a unified theme. Then they probably included the story with the paragraph might have been to show the good relationship between the mother and daughter and how they can do things together, supporting one another. Then in the story they talk about going to Canada together, which illustrates their shared journey and the bond that helps them face new challenges, solidifying the paragraph's purpose.

The author decides to conclude the story with this paragraph to show the strength and confidence Saeng has regained. By saying she would try to pass the test again in the spring is showing she is confident and is looking for a new beginning to come then, a season of growth. Also he concludes it this way because after she failed the test she didn’t have much self-confidence, feeling defeated. And once she spoke to her mother and knew she was understanding, Saeng knew she had to try again and persevere until she passed the test, completing her character arc.

I think when she takes the test over it is going to be in the spring and she is going to try and pass it, using the time to prepare. But she did not want to cry in front of her mother, wanting to appear strong and determined. I think she is going to make it up to her and pass the test, proving her resilience and commitment to her family's hopes, which brings the narrative to a hopeful and resolved conclusion.

The author concludes this story with that paragraph to show the readers she was knocked down but she is going to get back up again and take the test again, demonstrating resilience. This is also a very good way to end the story because it shows she is very determined to pass that test and won’t give up and will do anything to pass it, leaving the audience with a powerful message about perseverance and the human spirit's capacity to overcome adversity.

The reason the author concludes the story with that paragraph is because he is showing that she will not give up and she will do it when she is ready to. The reason I say this is because she is doing the test when she wants to, when she feels comfortable, rather than being forced by external pressures. This deliberate choice underscores her personal agency and growing self-assurance. Those are the reasons I believe that the author ended the story with that paragraph, as it perfectly encapsulates her resolve and the story's message of patient determination.

I believe the author concludes the story like this to show an example of perseverance. Saeng states, “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now." This statement represents adjusting to change, a slow and steady process of becoming accustomed to a new life. Soon she will adjust fully to her new home, it just takes time. If she keeps persevering, she will make it. In the last paragraph Saeng says, “when the snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Just as the seasons bring things back, she will come back, tying her personal renewal to the natural cycle. I believe this last paragraph was put in to show everyone should persevere because things just take time and patience is a vital part of success.

This statement shows what the author concludes about the story. It shows the theme of the story really. It is that if you fail, then you should try again. This is what the statement is saying; she failed her tasks so in the spring once the hibiscus blooms again, she will attempt to complete her task. The statement also concludes how you should never give up. Saeng had failed the test. She said, "I-I failed the test". This shows how sad and depressed she was because the tone the statement was said in was a sadder, more depressed tone. Even though sad and depressed, Saeng knows that next year she will attempt to complete the test, demonstrating her underlying resilience. Overall, the sentence shows what the author concludes and thinks about the story “Winter Hibiscus,” emphasizing the importance of persistence after failure.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” for several reasons. First, Saeng decides that she is determined to pass her driving test just like the hibiscus, which survives the harsh winter. Saeng’s mother says that it is “strong enough to make it through,” and Saeng decides to be strong like the hibiscus and make it through and pass the test. Next, the reason the geese are mentioned in the final paragraph is to tie in the fact that she is getting used to her new environment because the geese “sound familiar.” As much as she misses her old home, she is adapting. Finally, one can conclude that because she mentions the plant, which symbolizes her homeland and the geese, which symbolizes her new home, that as much as she misses her old home, she’s starting to get used to her new country and she recognizes that she is part of it. She knows that letting her past get in the way of her will not help her pass the test and, like the plant and the geese, she will return again, stronger and more prepared.

The author concluded this paragraph in this story because I think that he is trying to tell the reader a message. The author is trying to say that if a plant can make it through the cold winter then she can pass her driver’s test. The hibiscus serves as a symbol of resilience and hope, showing that endurance through difficult times leads to new growth and opportunity. That is why I think the author included that paragraph, to draw a clear parallel between nature's strength and the inner strength required to overcome personal challenges.

I think the author ended the story like that because she enjoys to see the geese and she loves the spring and wants to take the test and pass. She is studying for it in the meantime, focusing on her goal of overcoming her recent failure. The arrival of spring and the sight of the geese seem to give her a renewed sense of hope and determination for the future, which is why the author chose to conclude on this optimistic note.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because the author feels that Saeng will pass the test if she has the hibiscus with her, she thinks that because the hibiscus has something unique about it. The flower serves as a powerful symbol of resilience and her past life. And it also gives her a memory of where she used to live before she had moved, providing her with comfort and strength. Saeng had seemed out of place and she did not know what to do, but the hibiscus helps to ground her and restore her confidence for the challenges ahead.

The author is very creative. He concludes the story saying how the hibiscus is blooming and that she will take the test again. She believes that she will do better when the snow is gone and the environment is more familiar. The author ended the story with that because Saeng was very upset after failing a test but with the comfort of the hibiscus she’ll be able to do better next time. He also concludes the story with that paragraph because the climax was when she failed her test and somehow the author had to conclude what was going to happen to Saeng with the test, providing a resolution that looks forward to her second attempt.

He concludes the story like that because the test was the main thing that he was talking about throughout the narrative. It represents a significant challenge for the character, and its outcome is central to the story's message. Therefore, the ending naturally returns to this pivotal event, tying the narrative together and emphasizing its importance for the character's journey and development.

In the end of "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the narrator describes her desire to take and this time pass the driver's test she failed earlier in the day, she "vowed silently to herself" that she would succeed at something she had failed at in the past. This is an important concluding message, because it shows that the author will overcome obstacles in her future. Most of the story is about the sadness that the narrator experiences because of longing for her homeland; Saeng misses her grandmother and the plants of Vietnam, and she even buys a hibiscus plant to remind her of her homeland. She is also not enjoying her new life, because she has already experienced failure at her new home. However, the end of the story provides a contrast to this, for Saeng vows to succeed in the future, showing a shift from despair to a determined and hopeful resolve.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph they did because it shows how much the main character has grown and what she has learned. She has learned that if a delicate flower like the hibiscus can make it through rough times, she can too. The parallel between nature’s fight for survival is like Saeng’s own struggle in a new place. She discovers that you will adapt to your surroundings over time, and then after that time it will feel just like home. The adaption principle is shown throughout this story, and whether demonstrated by nature or a child’s life, it is there. Therefore the author would agree that the conclusion of the story illustrates the biological and physical growth of Saeng as she finds her place.

In the story, “Winter Hibiscus”, Saeng is new to the United States. She is missing home when she sees a hibiscus in a flower shop, a flower that reminds her of Vietnam. After she takes the flower home and plants it in her backyard, she decides the next time she’ll take the driver's test is when the hibiscus is budding in the spring. The author concludes the story this way because it directly relates Saeng’s journey to the flower’s cycle. Saeng feels out of place in her new country because the hibiscus is a tangible connection to her old home, so the ending symbolizes that if the flower can make it through the cold winter, she can too. She will take her driver's test as a sign of surviving and overcoming her own obstacles. In this story it has an overall theme that everything will get better with time. Saeng will adapt to the differences of her new environment, the hibiscus will bloom; and Saeng will pass her driver's test, marking a new beginning.

They ended it because the girl is not going to give up on her goal. She is going to keep trying at this test and won't stop at it either, demonstrating her newfound resolve. And she will be a little brighter in her outlook because of this persistence. She will also pass this test through her continued effort. And this way she won't disappoint her mother, who has been supportive of her. And she will be able to get this test off of her shoulders, finally achieving a sense of relief and accomplishment for herself and her family.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph in order to help the reader visualize a new beginning for the girl. It describes a time to re-take the test and have the fresh new flowers to look upon, and to watch the geese return. The geese are symbolic to her and the quest she had taken, migrating to her new home. The combination of the melting snow and the budding flowers lets the reader know of the bright, fresh, unclaimed future that is to come for the girl. The author uses the paragraph at the end in order to explain more of what is to come, to enhance the illustrations and capture the attentive audience. It is used to show a resilient spirit in the girl, a spirit that allows us to see that she is like the flower; she is having trouble rooting and grasping on to the new lifestyle but there is always going to be a fresh time to continue on and try again.

I think the author puts that paragraph in the story because it may function as a good luck charm or it could be a family tradition, so it is very important that it is included in the story. Also, it could be trying to tell us something significant about her character, like she only takes tests in the spring when the hibiscus starts budding, linking her personal challenges to a natural cycle of renewal and hope. This connection adds a layer of meaning to her actions and the story's conclusion.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with that special paragraph in order to mirror Saeng’s grief for wanting to be home but also to show that she is learning to overcome obstacles. Saeng wishes that she was in her homeland, and keeps up referring to it because she wants it back. “I mean, it’s not like the one we had at-at-,” Saeng continues to stumble because she does not wish to mention home because it brought her to tears. In addition, where she mentions the “test,” it makes her buy a fake plant. “It’s - it’s not a real one”. She refuses to buy a real one because it reminds her of the driving test and how sad she already is. The test refers to both the plant and the driver’s test. Saeng also ends with this vow because the flower represents hope to her, "... and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test". The emotional test of both of the situations she is in will allow her to be stronger. This vow at the end of the story shows her willingness to be strong and come through in the end, finding resilience through a simple, budding flower.

In the story the author concludes that after she has done her test and there is nothing left to see, she will grow more. This suggests a period of waiting and dormancy, where outward progress is not visible. Just as a plant rests in winter before a new growth season, Saeng’s failure is not an end but a temporary pause. The author implies that internal growth is happening even when no immediate results can be observed, and this quiet period of development is necessary before she can bloom again in the future.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because the girl did not pass the driving test, an event that symbolizes her struggles to adapt. And she adds all of the details of nature in there because Saeng takes time to care about nature, finding in it a sense of peace and continuity that her new life lacks. That is what it is mainly about in the story: the contrast between her personal failure and the enduring, cyclical beauty of the natural world, which offers her a different kind of solace and a perspective that helps her cope with her disappointment and find a path forward.

I am guessing the author adds this paragraph to tell the reader that when all of the beauty returns, she will try to get used to new things again. The budding hibiscus and the returning geese signal the end of a difficult winter, both in the environment and in Saeng's life. This natural rebirth parallels her own need for personal renewal, suggesting that with the changing season comes a renewed capacity for hope and adaptation, giving her the courage to face the challenges of her new world once more.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with that paragraph because it gives a sense of starting over and a new beginning for Saeng. The hibiscus is a reminder of her home country and it keeps her going and strong, and she compares herself to the geese saying that things she thought were strange became familiar through a quiet repetition from season to season. In the winter the hibiscus doesn’t bloom and Saeng fails her driver’s test. That paragraph tells that in the spring when the Hibiscus thrives and the geese return it will be a fresh start for them and Saeng as well, symbolizing that her period of hardship is temporary and that resilience, like the seasons, will lead to a new chapter.

The author most likely ends the story with Saeng vowing to take the test again because he wants to show Saeng’s determination. For example, when she tells her mother that she failed the test, her mother knew that it was hard for Saeng. Since it was a silent moment, her mother realized that yelling at her about the plant wasn’t a good idea. Saeng is kind of comparing herself to the plant. She might have thought, if this plant can make it through the winter and still keep growing, then she can make it through the test. Therefore, that is most likely why the author ended the story the way he did, emphasizing her resilient spirit.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it shows that Saeng has found new hope and determination. The author clearly loves and admires the hibiscus; for example, “But it’s strong enough to make it through winter,” says her mother. Saeng wants to be able to deal with hardships just as strongly as the hibiscus can. She is filled with new resolution when she says to herself, “Then I will take the test again.” This final statement solidifies her commitment to persevere, mirroring the plant's own strength.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the whole narrative was leading to this moment of resolution. The story would have been pointless and incomplete without this concluding thought, as it provides the necessary closure to Saeng's emotional journey and reinforces the central theme of perseverance that has been developed throughout.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show that Saeng is going to adapt to the conditions of her new life. The hibiscus is a plant that thrives in warm, tropical climates. However, it does not survive in the cold; only the winter hibiscus, which can survive in both climates, can. The hibiscus symbolizes Saeng. She lived in Vietnam and loved it with all the pretty flowers and being with her grandmother. However, now that she is living in the United States, she is finding it hard to adapt. Now that she has this hibiscus flower, which adapts to the cold weather magnificently, she feels she can adjust to her new life. When she sees the geese return for another spring and summer, she resolves to take the driving test again because they are giving her area another chance, just as she is giving herself another chance. This symbolism is why the author ends the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the paragraph describes how the snow melts and the greenery returns, symbolizing a kind of rebirth. This similizes her renewed motivation to take the test again. This imagery really shows how close she is to nature and the profound effect that her exposure to it has had on her perspective and resolve over the years, culminating in this moment of personal renewal.

I think that the author concluded the story with this paragraph because this whole story was sweet and left a beautiful picture in your head with like about every sentence. The narrative built a gentle and hopeful mood, so why not end it in a paragraph like, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Now tell that wasn’t beautiful; it perfectly matches the story's tender and uplifting tone, providing a fitting and resonant closure.

The author put the last sentence the way it did because it signifies a hopeful anticipation for the future. It means that by the next spring, they want to see how they will react differently to the same challenges. They now know what the experience is like, but they have also learned how to better react to the changing season. This final thought encapsulates the character's growth and newfound understanding, bringing the story to a thoughtful and complete end.

He uses this line at the end of the story because it shows she has another chance to pass the test, emphasizing the theme of renewal. They use the plant as a symbol because a plant will always come back and bud again, representing persistent hope. This was also a good way to end the story because it shows how in the present, plants can be a sign of inspiration and would teach you to look up to something. And maybe this is how she communicates with her mother through the plants, using them as a silent, shared language of comfort and resilience, which concludes the narrative on a deeply meaningful note.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," they end with that paragraph because it represents that she is getting used to the new country and its rhythms. She is also conveying the message that you need to adapt to new surroundings and circumstances, which is a central theme of her journey. That’s why I think they ended with that paragraph; it serves as a final, quiet affirmation of her acceptance and the beginning of her integration, providing a sense of closure to her struggle.

The flowers on this bush are very comforting to Saeng, serving as a tangible link to her past. In the story, she explains that they remind her of her home in Vietnam, providing a sense of familiarity. The budding of the plant and the arrival of spring represent new life and new opportunities. Saeng thinks that spring could also have a new beginning for her, a fresh start. That in spring, she will do better and pass the test, fortified by hope. But, if she falls again, the flowers will have bloomed to comfort her, ensuring that she is never without solace, which beautifully concludes her emotional arc.

The author concludes with that because she kind of relates herself to the flowers, seeing a parallel in their shared journey of growth and adaptation. She has grown to her environment like a flower, learning to thrive in a new soil. Also she had failed her test, so just like when a flower dies and then comes back, she is going to come back and try the test again, drawing strength from this natural cycle of renewal and resilience.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because she failed the test so over the winter they don’t get hibiscus but over the spring when they get again the hibiscus she will try to take the test again so she can pass it. The cyclical return of the flowers mirrors her own opportunity for a fresh start, reinforcing her determination to succeed on her next attempt and not be defined by a single failure.

The author concludes this as the last paragraph because of two main reasons. One of them is the flower is almost like her in the beginning, the flower wasn't bloomed. But when the snow melts and the flower blooms she is like the flower and is going to try again to bloom out in passing the test. Another reason is because it reminds her of back home and her mother understands why she paid so much for it so they want to take care of it, nurturing it as a symbol of their shared past and future hopes.

Minfong Ho, the author of “Winter Hibiscus,” concluded the story with Saeng vowing to herself that she will retake and pass her driver's test in the spring when the geese fly back and plants rebud. The author concluded the story with this paragraph to signify Saeng’s willingness to start over. After failing a test, Saeng visits a green house and misses her old home, Vietnam. She buys a hibiscus and plants it when she comes home after noting the geese flying south for the winter. The plant signifies her memories. When she first sees it, it’s blossomed. In the spring it will rebud and form another blossom while growing bigger. This parallels Saeng getting over her sadness and homesickness and rebuilding better memories while growing stronger when she gets the chance. The birds flying overhead are headed south for the winter for shelter from the cold. In spring they will return to start over, raise goslings, rebuild their home, and start over from last spring. Saeng is planning to start over, and pass it so she can drive and feel more accepted in her new community. Minfong Ho chose to end the story with this paragraph to signify the character’s starting over and rebuilding good memories, thus completing her emotional arc.

The last paragraph in, “Winter Hibiscus,” was added because the author wants to show that she feels bad because she did not pass the test. She feels disappointed because her mom is disappointed in her and knows she can pass it. While she stares at the Hibiscus and then the geese flying in the air, she thinks that she does have a chance in passing the test. Now that she is determined to take the test, she is going to take it at the same time in the next year and she believes she is going to pass it, finding inspiration and resolve in the natural world around her to overcome her initial setback.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because that is how the girl feels, capturing her emotional state and outlook. She feels that in the spring she can do better than what she did, seeing the new season as a chance for renewal and a fresh start. This final thought solidifies her hopeful perspective for the future, providing a sense of closure to her journey.

It means that she wants to do it all over again, to return to a familiar and safe situation. This process is the girl's comfort zone, a place where she finds solace and reassurance. So that is what she does when she is upset, retreating to this mental state to cope with her disappointment. That is what the story and the phrase ultimately signify, illustrating a personal mechanism for dealing with adversity.

The author concluded "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" to tell the reader never to give up and to keep trying, emphasizing the importance of perseverance. It also tells us that family is always there because you can't do it on your own, highlighting the support system around her. The final line, "It's a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi", she finally said, serves to connect her personal resolve to the beauty and cyclical promise of nature, reinforcing the story's hopeful message.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author is trying to show the reader that she realized she cares about nature and loves it deeply. This is evident because she is waiting for the spring, and as soon as the spring comes she will take the test again, linking her personal resolve to the natural world. So in my opinion the author wants to show the readers that the character in the story cares a lot about nature's beauty, finding in it a source of inspiration and strength for her future endeavors.

The author concludes the story with the sentence saying “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because the hibiscus is not just a good luck charm; when it’s not there things aren't right but when it comes back things turn out for the better, symbolizing a return to favorable conditions. Also, the author concludes this because the good luck charm the hibiscus gave her more confidence, and when one says something with real confidence, one will succeed. Lastly, this lets the reader know that she believes in something that gives her hope and that belief will make her do well, providing a complete and uplifting end to her narrative.

The author concludes the story that way because one central theme is to overcome obstacles. The hibiscus represents Saeng’s perseverence, and the last paragraph offers closure to the conflict that was introduced earlier in the narrative. The description of the hibiscus as being “strong enough to make it through the cold months here… that is what matters,” makes a direct connection between the plant and the author’s own perseverence because of the symbolism. The last paragraph adds that symbolism while providing closure because she says she’ll wait until spring to take the test again, showing her renewed determination to succeed.

Saeng is trying to say that when the time comes again, she will be ready to take the test. The author concludes the story with this statement because it leaves the reader wondering about what will happen the next time she takes the test. The author also does this to show that you should never quit; if the flower can survive the winter, then she will be able to survive that test. Furthermore, the author is saying that when the seasons change, things change for people as well. She was going to give up because she failed the test, but she saw that plant surviving through the harsh weather, and that sight gave her more confidence. She also cherished the plant because she wants to see it budding, as she and her mother spent quality time together due to this plant she had discovered.

Saeng is talking about her school work and the garden, and she always connects the two of them in the same thoughtful way. She knows that she has to study diligently while the garden grows, and she feels a pull to water the flowers and tend to them. She is saying that when the spring comes, she won't be there for the garden in the same way because she will have to take the test, indicating a shift in her priorities and responsibilities as the seasons turn.

The author ended the story that way to show that Saeng won’t give up and is determined to complete her task. The author wants the reader to understand that Saeng feels very sad and wants to overcome her feelings of being homesick. Saeng is very much like the hibiscus plant; she’s described as being both frail and beautiful in her new environment. Saeng says she will do her test again when the hibiscus is budding, almost like she’s growing and developing her own strength along with the plant, showing their parallel journeys.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph because it shows that everything and everyone can make it through a tough time. This paragraph acts as a final positive message to readers, reinforcing the theme of resilience. The text says, “when they come back... I will take that test again”. This quote shows that Saeng can see herself as one of the returning geese or the budding hibiscus plants, part of a natural cycle of return and renewal. She knows that her “winter” is her failed test and that when she is ready, she’ll be able to take the test again and be successful. The budding of the hibiscus specifically represents the time when she’ll be prepared to take the test. Though she is having a tough time now, she'll be able to get through it and make another attempt. This paragraph is placed at the end because it brings together the entire purpose of the hibiscus in the narrative. Without saying this, the readers might have believed that the role of the hibiscus was only to serve as a connection to Saeng’s past. In conclusion, this positive paragraph was included to show readers that everyone can bounce back from a bad situation.

One it could mean she can only take the test in the spring, as that is the next available testing season. But also because her surroundings during that period relaxed her, offering a more peaceful state of mind. When she was disappointed and upset about her driving failing grade, the calm of spring provided the mental space she needed to recover and prepare to try again, seeing it as a natural time for new beginnings.

The author concludes the story with this line because she really cared for the hibiscus, seeing it as a profound symbol of hope. She said this because she was comparing her test to the hibiscus and its cycles of growth. When the hibiscus will be budding she will take the test again, linking her own success to the plant's natural rebirth. Hibiscus is everything for her; it is her good luck charm and a tangible connection to her aspirations. And with the hibiscus budding she can make her new life, feeling a renewed sense of purpose. Without the hibiscus plant she was lost, repeating “I failed the test” and “I bought it,” Saeng answered, reading her mother’s next question. She was so depressed with her test failing that is why she bought the hibiscus to positively influence her life. She decided when it will be spring with the hibiscus budding she will start her new life by giving the test again and proving to herself how important the hibiscus truly is to her journey.

The author is concluding that anything can happen in the story, as demonstrated by the unexpected turn of events. Saeng planted a winter hibiscus and her mother was getting mad at her for the impulsive purchase. Saeng’s mother was mad because she spent money on the whole plant instead of planting a cutting from a seed, which would have been a lot cheaper. When her mother was mad and in disbelief, Saeng started crying, overwhelmed by her failure and her mother's reaction, and the mother, seeing her daughter's genuine distress, forgave her for her actions. This sudden shift from anger to forgiveness shows that anything can happen, revealing the underlying compassion within their relationship.

The author most likely concludes the story with that paragraph because they are trying to show the reader that even though you fail at something, you can’t be stubborn and give up entirely. So Saeng failed her drivers test but in the spring when the hibiscus plant starts to bud she will go back and take the test again with a fresh perspective. By the plant budding she thinks of that as a sign that she will pass the test, using it as a symbol of growth and a second chance to succeed where she initially did not.

The Author concludes the story with Saeng saying a vow silently to herself to show the reader that she will grow like the hibiscus plant and take the test again, this time determined to pass it with renewed strength. The plant gives Saeng hope because it reminds her of the homeland that she loved so much, serving as a bridge between her past and her future. When the hibiscus starts budding and gaining beautiful flowers, Saeng will “bud” too and gain her license, completing her own cycle of personal growth and achievement.

I think that the passage is trying to say the sum because in the passage it says “in the spring when the snows melt and only the sun does that and the gees return hunting season and the hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again”. The passage clearly marks the start of this new beginning in the spring, so it has to be the sun in the spring time that initiates this cycle of renewal. The melting snow and the returning geese are all part of this seasonal shift, signaling a time for Saeng to try again. This focus on the spring sun underscores the natural and inevitable passage of time that she is learning to align herself with for her own personal growth and acceptance.

The author used the paragraph telling about how Saeng would test in the spring at the end of the story because the words used and the way it is read can tell the reader that Saeng is at peace and accepts the fact that she lives in the U.S. When Saeng says, “and this hibiscus plant is budding," she is thinking about how the plant reminds her of her native country, yet it grows in her new home. Also when she says, "Then I will take this test again" she is promising herself that she will take the test when she feels at home in her new country, using the plant as a bridge between her past and future. Saeng also is in a way telling herself that she should accept the fact that she has moved and that she can still be reminded of her native country with the new hibiscus plant and many other things, finding comfort in these small, familiar connections. This final reflection solidifies her journey toward acceptance and integration.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph for a very good reason. The author could write a sequel to this one, as the ending naturally invites further exploration of Saeng's journey. She could want the people to keep coming back for more, or wants people to know when things start up again so will Saeng. Ending the story with that paragraph is a very good thing to do because it emphasizes cyclical renewal. The author wants you to know when the plant and geese restart their lives Saeng will do the same; she will not give up but instead re-take the test. The author could be planning to write a sequel to this short story, as it leaves you thinking so then the sequel will be about the start of Saeng’s new life and what she plans to do to keep her vow. When everything starts to come alive in the spring so will Saeng, mirroring the natural world's rebirth. The author may love having people wonder about what's coming next, ensuring the readers go home and wonder what the author will do next with Saeng, thus keeping people in suspense and waiting for an answer that may never come, leaving the future beautifully open to interpretation.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize the willingness of Saeng to overcome the obstacles and adapt to her new life. The hibiscus discussed in the ending quote describes Saeng’s new hope and determination to succeed in the United States. For example in the text it states, "… its fine petals splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral." When Saeng had found a plant that seemed to tie together her past in Vietnam and her future in America, she was overwhelmed with a sense of connection. The hibiscus represents new hope in a seemingly impossible situation, a tangible link to her heritage. When the hibiscus has blossomed, her world will be open and a new life will be waiting to begin, symbolizing her own potential for growth. With this thought realized at the end of the story, the reader understands that Saeng has found new stability and will eventually succeed because she has found a source of strength. In addition, in the text it says, “it felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center just as she had known it would feel.” Saeng’s past memories could be reached when this hibiscus was in her new environment and that served as immense inspiration to her, grounding her in her new reality. The author ended the story with Saeng’s new recollection and hope to prove that she had indeed found something helpful and stable in a new world, a foundation upon which to build her future.

The author concluded the story, “Winter Hibiscus,” with the paragraph she chose because she wanted to portray to her reader that even though Saeng was experiencing a hardship leaving her old home behind, she could still find a good life with new beginning here. In the final paragraph the winter snows represent hard times in the past, while the spring represents a more optimistic future, and a new beginning filled with potential. Although Saeng was grieving at the loss of her past, she could still find happiness here by recognizing the parallels between her old life and her new one. In the story she once knew hibiscus in her old home, and she finds hibiscus where she is now and it is a semblance and reminder of her old home, providing a crucial sense of continuity. Also, the story says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quite repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This quote leads into the final paragraph and shows her acceptance that she can appreciate and happily live in this new home, as familiarity slowly replaces strangeness. The final paragraph says, “.. when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again.” When things familiar to her and things that remind her of her old home come back, Saeng will have the strength to try to accomplish good things for this new life in a new home again, demonstrating her resilient spirit and determination to thrive.

The author concludes the story with that statement because it shows that you can always start clean and you should never give up when you really want something. The narrator really wanted to pass the test, so she worked hard, but she failed it. She knows, like the plant, spring will offer a new beginning in life, and you can always change something you don't like about yourself. I strongly agree with this statement because if you didn’t have a second chance, most people would all be losers, because everyone makes mistakes in their life and everyone has the opportunity to fix them. This belief in renewal and the chance to try again is a powerful message, which is why I believe the author concludes with this statement at the end of the story.

The story ends with that paragraph because Saeng believes next spring, when her new hibiscus is born, she will have good luck to pass her driving test. It is a good way to end the story because the hibiscus was not involved in her life before she took the driver's test. Now she believes that on her next driving test she will have the connection to her past experiences, the ability to overcome obstacles, and comfort in a time of disappointment. The flower becomes a symbol of hope and resilience, which Saeng thinks can help her pass the test and move forward with her life.

The author could have had many reasons to conclude the story with this paragraph. One reason may be to explain how she has changed in the story. Toward the beginning of the story, the author sounds discouraged and upset that she failed her test. In her final paragraph, it shows she overcame her fear. Also, the geese move like she did. Saeng and her family have moved to the United States, but the geese feel odd moving too, yet they come back every year. Along with the flower, Saeng is unique in her new life and must learn to adapt as the geese and flower do. She knows that the flower will bud and the geese will return in the spring, and that is what she must do. She won’t give up but try again later on in the year. This shows how she is adapting and changing to work with her new surroundings, finding strength in the cycles of nature.

In “The Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the passage with this paragraph to demonstrate Saeng’s determination to not only pass her driving test, but to accommodate to her new home. The author says “vowed” to express positive connotation in the paragraph, showing her strong resolve. The author writes, “almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become… familiar.” The author says this to show that she is adapting to her new lifestyle, yet he uses the last paragraph to say that she needs a little more time, waiting for the symbolic spring to fully embrace her new beginning and succeed in her goal.

In the story “The Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng made a promise to herself that she would never fail the test again. Saeng wanted to remember her past and homeland, which is why she bought the flowers. At the end of the story she vows, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” She says this because she wants to move on now and try to get used to her new home, using the natural rebirth of spring as a timeline for her own personal renewal and second attempt.

The author had the story end with the paragraph because all the ideas are brought together and to show that Saeng is ready for whats ahead. When they put in the flower they are concluding the flowers importance and how it relates to how the girl feels being happy or sad, serving as a final symbolic act. Yet when she says that she vowed... and shed take the test again she saying that she is ready for whats ahead but will be open minded to whats new so that she can see were sheís gone from. This demonstrates her newfound resilience and acceptance of her journey. Therefore the author ends with that paragraph to leave mystry for what happend and to conclude the character's emotional arc, tying together the themes of memory and moving forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because its winter now and the flowers are gone, but during that time when she was planting she grew more mature. For instance, like it says in the text things she used to think were strange are now becoming firmiliar and shes getting the hang of things in her new environment. This period of adjustment and learning has prepared her, because shes learning more about it and will be ready for the test next spring. The ending thus reflects a quiet confidence and the cyclical nature of growth and opportunity.

The author uses this as an ending paragraph in the story because the next year at the same time she will take the test of life over again. This decision signifies her determination and willingness to face her challenges once more, showing that she has not given up. It provides a sense of cyclical continuity to her journey, suggesting that growth is an ongoing process. The ending reinforces the theme of perseverance and the promise of a future attempt, leaving the reader with a feeling of hopeful anticipation for what is to come.

The ending of a story helps determine the meaning of the story. It is the final closure and will most likely be remembered by the reader, shaping their overall interpretation. In the end of the story Winter Hibiscus the author ends it with a paragraph of encouragement. The conclusion encourages you to keep trying, because it states that next year when the flower blooms Saeng will re-take the test. This shows encouragement because has the drive to try again and to pass, embodying a spirit of resilience. The author ends with the feeling of encouragement because it leaves the reader inspired by Saeng's resolve. Her conclusion is strong and also seems to recap the stories meaning because all along Saeng keeps getting disapointed about the flower, her mother, and homeland encourage her to move on and try again. The ending used was meaningful and showed what the author was truly trying to convey about the power of hope and continuous effort.

In the story ìWinter Hibiscusî by Minfong Ho, the main character is troubled because they moved away from home and the culture, customs and even food are different. Therefore, the main character has difficulty adapting to her new environment, feeling a profound sense of displacement and loss. The author concludes the ending statement to show that she will not stop trying to achieve her goal, highlighting her persistent spirit. She wants to take the test again change to see if over time things have changed, indicating a belief in her own capacity for growth and adaptation. The story is very emotional and expresses a great deal of sorrow that is overcome in the end through this final, determined resolution.

The author concluded the story with that specific paragraph about geese to show that Saeng is going to try to overcome her obstacles. She was deeply disappointed in failing the test, so she took comfort in memories of her homeland. She bought a hibiscus that she saw frequently in her homeland, and that flower represented comfort and affection. But it also symbolized her ability to come over obstacles, and while she was planting her hibiscus and saw the geese flying above, she knew she had to try again, finding inspiration in their determined flight.

The author says this because she will try to start her own garden. Her other garden didn't turn out too well, as the plants failed to thrive in the new environment. In the book it says she needed her mom's help to even get the garden started, showing her initial dependence. This new attempt represents her growing desire for self-reliance and a personal connection to her new home.

The author concludes the paragraph when Saeng realizes she can miss her old home, but she needs to adapt to the new place that she is in. Saeng misses the old memories of her homeland, as shown by the line, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” But, she begins to realize that not everything has changed; some things are still familiar, like the geese. “Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, the faint honks clear and –yes– familiar to Saeng now.” When Saeng realizes that not everything has changed, she gained the strength to continue her new life in her new country, understanding that familiarity can be found anywhere.

The reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because it was a good way to end the story off with a sense of hope and renewal. At the end, they were talking about how Saeng would come back when the snow melted and then she will take the test again. This final thought leaves the reader with a clear sense of her determination and the cyclical, hopeful nature of life, promising a fresh start in the spring.

The author concludes the story this way to show that Saeng still has hope to succeed and adapt in this new country. She previously had a lot of home sickness, missing her grandmother and keepsakes from her childhood. The height of her homesickness is seen when Saeng comes back to her house and is explaining to her mother the nature of the hibiscus. “She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again.” Saeng is uncomfortable living in her new home and wishes to go back to Vietnam. But by the end, Saeng’s attitude changes from despair to hope. Even though she has failed her driver’s test, Saeng is determined and hopeful to do at least something in this new country by saying "...then I will take the test again.” Saeng has changed a good deal within this story, and that change in attitude is seen with the excerpt on geese in the last paragraph, which solidifies her resolve.

I think he put this in here because he is trying to convey a cyclical sense of time and renewal. I think he’s trying to say when the snow melts just forget bout the first time, letting go of past failures. And when the geese return it your second chance, a new opportunity to begin again. Then the hibiscus budding is you get passed what you were trying to do, symbolizing the successful overcoming of a previous obstacle through natural growth and persistence. This progression mirrors the seasons and offers a hopeful perspective on personal endeavors. The paragraph thus uses nature's timeline to frame a message of resilience and continuous effort.

This author concludes the story with this paragraph because they both were talking about the cold or the weather and the seasons, so it stated when snows melt as it talks about weather or the climate. The paragraph directly connects to the earlier conversation, using the seasonal change as a central motif. It ties the character's personal resolution to the natural world discussed previously, creating a cohesive ending. By referencing the melting snow and the returning geese, the conclusion reinforces the themes of change and cyclical patterns that were introduced. This final note effectively links the character's internal state to the external environment, providing a unified close to the narrative.

The author concludes the story like this because it shows how the main character has been affected by the events or happenings in the story, leading to a significant change in her outlook. In the beginning of the story we learn that the main character has failed her driver’s test, which is a major disappointment. Also in the story she had spent a large amount of money just for one plant, in which her mother is shocked about, highlighting her deep emotional investment. The reader at that point would expect for her to be very sad and depressed given these setbacks. But because of her grandmother and her homeland she instead surprises the reader by looking on the bright side of things and saying that when the flower blooms again she will take the test again, demonstrating her newfound resilience. This shows the connection between the main character and the plant, where the plant's cycle of dormancy and blooming reflects her own journey. Giving the plant a humanlike existence reinforces this symbolic bond and underscores the story's theme of growth and perseverance.

I believe that the author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph to illustrate the overall message of the story, which centers on hope and resilience. That paragraph sums up the message of determination and overcoming obstacles, providing a clear and powerful resolution. Saeng is coming from another country and is facing challenges not only in the garden, but in her life as well, which include cultural adjustment and personal setbacks. She had to learn how to adjust to her new surroundings and never give up on what she wanted to accomplish, demonstrating her strong will. So, by saying "in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," she truly shows her determination and how she's not afraid to overcome obstacles that will face her, using the promise of spring as her motivation. This final statement perfectly encapsulates her character arc and the story's central theme of persistent hope.

The author of this story concludes the story this way because instead of absorbing all the pain she can look into the future with optimism. Also by looking into the future she can forget about the past and try better in the future, focusing on new possibilities. The conclusion shows a conscious decision to move forward rather than dwell on previous disappointments. This forward-looking perspective is key to the character's development and the story's uplifting end. It emphasizes the importance of resilience and the ability to start anew after a setback, providing a satisfying and hopeful closure.

The author concludes the story with this piece because she describes how "a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear." This imagery suggests that even though the geese flew over with their heads held high, Saeng's was not. Her vow, "Next year when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," signifies her determination to not keep her head down. She will learn to be grateful for her new home, and with time, she will grow stronger. When she looks at her hibiscus, she will have fond memories of her past but will no longer be overwhelmed by sadness, finding instead a source of strength and hope for the future.

There are two reasons why the author concluded the story with this particular paragraph. The first reason is that Saeng had silently picked up a Winter Hibiscus, an act symbolizing her resolve to pass the driving test that she had previously failed. The second and final reason is that she wants to try her driving test again, with the goal of passing so she can gain the independence that comes with being able to drive. These two reasons, while central to understanding Saeng's motivation, were initially confusing to figure out from the author's concluding sentence, but they ultimately reveal her character's persistence.

I think that the reason the author concludes with this paragraph in the story is to show the longing Saeng felt for the geese. The sight and sound of the migrating geese evoke a deep sense of yearning within her, connecting her to a feeling of freedom and natural cycles that she finds herself separated from. This moment of observation highlights her inner emotional state and her place within her new environment, emphasizing a poignant sense of distance and aspiration.

There are many possibilities as to why the author ended her story, "Winter Hibiscus," in the way that she did. The line, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here…” is what Saeng’s mother says of the flowers Saeng bought unexpectedly. The ending almost repeats this sentiment of resilience. When Saeng makes her vow, she is implicitly telling herself that she too is strong enough to make it through the winter and beyond. Also in the story, the author states that Saeng “realized many of the things that she had thought of as strange had become…almost familiar to her now.” Through this statement, the author shows that Saeng, of course, still misses her country deeply, but she will eventually adjust to her new home and prevail. When Saeng vows to retake her test in the spring, it is obvious that subconsciously, she is affirming that she can get through these hardships, and all she needs is time to adapt and grow stronger.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," when Saeng says that she will take the test again in the spring, it is so she can walk home and see the hibiscus flower that she found. The story mentions that in her past childhood she had seen the same flower in her country, creating a powerful link to her memories. The next time she takes the driving test, she is determined to pass. It shows that she was disappointed initially because the story says she paid over nineteen dollars for the test, a significant sum. Her mother was astonished and yelled at her for a second, but Saeng began crying and her mother calmed down to show sympathy for her. Now, having found the hibiscus, she has the renewed determination and inner strength to take the test again with a more hopeful spirit.

Minfong Ho, the author of the story "Winter Hibiscus," ended her story with Saeng thinking about the spring because she wanted to make Saeng's future appear more hopeful. The character Saeng seemed depressed and was always reminiscent of her past life in Vietnam. When she sees the Hibiscus and Jasmine flowers, she "brokedown and wept," and she vividly remembers her grandmother gently fixing her hair when she smells the fragrant Jasmine. To make matters worse for Saeng, she also failed her driving test, which is something that most teens find as a big disappointment and a significant setback. By this point in the story, I felt profoundly sorry for Saeng and I wondered if things would ever get better for her because she was so far away from everything she knew and loved, left with just some fading memories and a single winter hibiscus, which was unlike the vibrant kind she had back at her home in Vietnam. Then, in the last line, Saeng suddenly becomes hopeful for her future, looking forward to the time "when the geese return and this hibiscus is budding," signaling a new beginning and the end of her emotional winter.

The concluding paragraph to the story “Winter Hibiscus” gives a powerful sense of hope for the future. The girl, Saeng, has just failed her driving test and is feeling deeply depressed about this failure and her displacement. Through a series of event’s, including her encounter with the resilient winter hibiscus, her depression gradually leaves her and she begins to feel a renewed sense of hope. Her thought, “Then I will take that test again,” serves as the final sentence and powerfully shows Saeng’s newfound determination.
