She was initially upset about leaving her homeland and she was upset about failing her test, but thanks to the symbolic flower, she ultimately got her confidence and fighting spirit back. Whenever someone is upset it is easy to give up entirely. Until this final paragraph, the tone in the story is consistently depressing and heavy. When the author put in this conclusion, it was like seeing a light at the end of a dark tunnel, a welcome relief. The author is effectively saying that even when things are hard and seem impossible, something small and beautiful will be there to lift your spirits. There is always a positive in a negative situation, you just have to look for it and be open to finding it.

In guessing that it means that when winter or spring or whatever season it is, it's harder to grow that particular garden. The winter hibiscus itself might be a challenge to cultivate, requiring special care. Also, maybe it's a challenge of some sort for the character to make the garden grow successfully by that specific time of year, representing a personal goal. So I would assume that's what its talking about with its seasonal reference, using the garden's struggle as a metaphor for the character's own difficulties. The story uses the natural world to reflect the internal challenges faced by the individual.

The author includes that sentence at the end of the story because throughout the narrative it was consistently showing Saeng's inner courage. Her emotional journey from despair to resolve explains her getting better and finally showing the courage that she possesses. The concluding line demonstrates that she is going to go back and try to pass that test, not letting the initial failure get her down permanently. This final act of deciding to try again perfectly encapsulates the theme of perseverance that the author has been building, proving that her spirit, though tested, remains unbroken.

To me, I would have to say that the reason why the author concluded his story with this paragraph would be for a few different reasons. To explain, it could mean a new beginning or starting over after a period of difficulty. For example, when the geese fly away and then come back, that means that the seasons are changing and a cycle is completing. So with that being said, the seasons changing or starting over could represent her chance to take the test again and start over, and she will get another opportunity to succeed. The return of the geese symbolizes this cyclical renewal, offering a clear metaphor for second chances and the promise of a fresh start in her new life.
I think they think it will bring them luck, perhaps as a small charm or a personal ritual that provides them with a sense of comfort and confidence in their daily endeavors.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph because it shows you can overcome something if you have the will power. Saeng failed the first test, which was a difficult and discouraging experience for her. She bought a plant that reminds her of home, seeking a familiar comfort. She planted the plant despite the cold, hard ground, demonstrating her determination. She realized the once strange things were now part of her everyday life, signifying her gradual adaptation. She decided to retake the test. Saeng realized that even though you fail once you have to keep trying if it is what you believe in. She also realized that she will never forget her home but she still can move on and build a new life. Finally Saeng realized that good things can overcome bad. After she failed the test she bought the flower, which became a symbol of her new beginning. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because it summarizes the story perfectly and leaves the reader with its central message of resilience.

The author includes the excerpt at the end for a meaningful reason to Saeng. the hibiscus symbolizes everything, her home, her past, and her comfort, acting as a powerful emotional anchor. Saeng feels that if the flower can bloom, so can she, which is a source of great personal inspiration. Which will enable her to get used to her new home and retake the test with renewed spirit. It also resembles hope, because if the plant can make it through the winter and bloom in the spring, so can she overcome her own hardships. The author used this to connect the feelings of Saeng with the realities of the flower's ability to bloom, creating a poignant and symbolic parallel.

The author concludes that statement because the geese move south in the winter and come back in the spring, and Saeng has failed the test in the winter but she will retake it while the season of spring comes, mirroring this natural cycle. As Saeng fails her driving test and she sees the familiar plant, it means she will come back to take the test, just as the geese return. The geese have left but will come back when the season is changing, representing a promise of return. So both the geese and Saeng have a reason to come back north or retake the test, driven by instinct and personal resolve. The author adds the statement in the end because the geese's actions are just like Saeng's, illustrating a shared theme of perseverance and cyclical renewal.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph to show how Saeng was not going to give up on her new life. Throughout the story she had been feeling down and overwhelmed by her circumstances. From when she failed the test and she misses Vietnam, she experienced a deep sense of loss and displacement. So many things throughout where she and her mother lives reminds her of Vietnam, constantly triggering memories. “She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair....” This made her very emotional, to see how many things reminded her of Vietnam and the life she left behind. The author ended like this to show how the experience of all this affected her, ultimately strengthening her resolve to persevere and find her place.

The author chooses to end the story like this to inspire a sense of determination. Saeng purchased the plant to remind her of her homeland and cheer her up, serving as a tangible connection to her past. Once the plant has bloomed, she feels a parallel sense of hope, believing that she would as well blossom and be ready for the test. This symbolic connection between her personal growth and the plant's flowering reinforces her resolve to persevere in her new environment.

The author concluded the passage with a very powerful statement. “When the geese come back… in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again.” This statement shows renewal and persistence. I think she added this because after realizing the plant can come back time and time again, even after the harsh weather, she knew she could do it too. She vowed to herself that when the day comes again she will be ready to renew herself and get back on track. It conveys persistence also. The plant doesn’t die each season. It’s hardy and comes back. If the girl can be persistent and come back next year to retake the test, she will be considered persistent. I think the girl wants to be just like the flower. She sees it as being indomitable, renewing and beautiful, a symbol of resilience. No matter where the plant is being grown, it will always keep those traits, and she aspires to do the same in her own life.

The reason for the author concluding the following is because she wants it to be known to the readers that Saeng is not going to just give up because she fails it the first time. That she is going to achieve so that her mother can be proud of her and to show herself she is trying to make an effort. It states that Saeng will retake the test again in the spring when the snow has done melted and geese return and this hibiscus is budding. Not only was the hibiscus an important part to the story, it was a very important part to her life; it helped her move on and see how things change, for over time it will change and develop and adapt to the changes around it. Yes it was a disappointment to her mother but she sort of understood why she brought the plant home. It might have comforted her in a way, providing a sense of familiarity. There was many different things probably going on where she was; she missed the test, it wasn’t home. She has to adjust and adapt to the situation that she is in, just as the hibiscus must adapt to its new soil.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng failed the test and next time that time of year comes back around she will have another chance to pass the test. I say that because in the text it states that she paid a significant amount for the hibiscus, noting that all of the vegetable seeds in the garden didn’t even cost that much. This high cost underscores the plant's deep value to her, representing an investment in hope. That is why I say she concluded with that paragraph, to emphasize Saeng's commitment to trying again, mirroring the plant's cycle of return.

Next year around the winter time when she has to plant things again she is going to be ready and this time she is going to do it much better. She has learned from her previous experiences and understands the rhythm of the seasons now. Her determination is strengthened by the knowledge that growth often requires patience and multiple attempts, just as a garden does not flourish overnight. She will approach the coming challenge with renewed vigor and a clearer purpose.

The author included this because she was showing that it was winter and the flower was going to bloom and the geese were flying here because it is cold. The winter setting establishes a contrast between the harsh season and the resilient life within it. Also the author said that because the story title is called the “Winter Hibiscus” which obviously blooms in the winter so that is why I think the author said what she did, directly connecting the title to the narrative's central symbol.

The author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with a sentence stating that when Saeng’s Hibiscus’ first bud appears in the spring she will be back to take her driver's test. The author might have decided to conclude the story like that because what if the plant died, would she go back and take the test? This creates an element of uncertainty for the reader. The author was probably just wanting the reader to think hard about it and consider the connection between Saeng's personal growth and the plant's survival. In conclusion, the author of the story “Winter Hibiscus” might have concluded his story to make it somewhat suspenseful and thought-provoking.

The story ends with that line because Saeng draws strength from the hibiscus, so next time she will not fail the test. In the time that it takes for the hibiscus to grow she will be growing also as a person and so will be ready for the test. The story says, “Plants that she had even realized she had known but forgotten drew her back into her childhood world” (Ho). Saeng had a good childhood where she got love and support. By seeing all of those plants again especially the hibiscus she can draw strength from the memories she has. The memories the hibiscus bring back are also very sad. The story says, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her” (Ho). Experiencing all of that sadness again will only make her stronger by allowing her to process her past. Along with just the sight of the hibiscus other things will make her ready for the test also. The story says, “It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet towards the center – just as she had known it would feel” (Ho). The feel of the hibiscus will remind Saeng of distant memories, like helping her grandmother with her hair. All of these things will only make Saeng stronger so that the next time she takes the test she will not fail, having integrated her past with her present.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the spring when the snow is gone she will take the test again. The spring season symbolizes a new beginning and a time for renewal, contrasting with the winter of her initial failure. This connection between the natural cycle and her personal resolve reinforces the story's theme of hope and perseverance, suggesting that she will try again under better conditions.

In the quote above it is telling that Saeng is glad to be back and has found a sense of belonging. Saeng also states that she would be ready to do it again if she had to, demonstrating her newfound resilience and determination. This shows that her experiences have strengthened her, and she is now prepared to face challenges with a more confident and persistent attitude, ready to embrace her future.

I think the author concluded the story like that is because it was cold outside, which mirrors Saeng's internal feelings of discomfort and alienation. I also think that the author is trying to say is that when she wrote this letter it was cold outside and she wouldn’t take the test until it was warm again because of the cold, using the harsh weather as a symbol for her current struggles. “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this is when the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test over again.” This connection between the seasonal change and her personal resolve shows that she associates warmth and renewal with a new beginning for herself.

There are many reasons the author says “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author said this because the girl left everything just to come to this country and she can not fail, making this vow a testament to her resilience. The girl said “That at last, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? the hibiscus hedge?” She also said this because the hedge was all she had from her old home besides her mother and when the “hibiscus is budding” means its starting a new life and is starting to grow leaves, paralleling the girl's own journey as she is starting to grow and move on with her life in this new place.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because if the author tries it again it might work out a lot better now they know what they are doing, having learned from past experience. Also if they try it again then if it makes enough they can sell it and make money so they will keep doing it for years to come, establishing a cycle of practice and potential success that provides a hopeful outlook for the future.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with a resolution of Saeng in order to show how Saeng will not give up and how she is determined to overcome her challenges. The reference to the spring blossoms shows how Saeng will fight to survive through the hardships, which are represented by winter, using the changing seasons as a metaphor for her personal growth. Just like the hibiscus that struggles to adapt to a new home, Saeng is struggling to adapt to a new country, and the final paragraph provides a resolution to the internal conflict of Saeng throughout the story by suggesting that Saeng will succeed in taking the test when conditions are more favorable. In conclusion, the final paragraph in the story “Winter Hibiscus” provides a resolution to the conflict in the story, and shows the reader Saeng’s determination to persevere and eventually thrive.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because It show what Saeng will be doing and If she will go to school, clarifying her future intentions. Saeng didn't want to go school because she will wait for the snow to melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, and prefers gardening to school, as the garden reminds her about her homeland. For instance, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the winter hibiscus into it, an act that connects her to her past. The thing that made her think about her homeland was the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan, and the pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, sensory memories that deeply affected her. Another example is she went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground, that show she care about the garden and finds solace in nurturing life, which ultimately influences her decision to wait for spring.

The author concludes her story with the quote, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” because the author is showing that nature and the plant are valuable to her. Saeng, who says the quote, believes that the hibiscus will help her pass the test. Earlier on in the story it shows that when she gets in trouble, she rubs the plant leaves in her hands to help her overcome the problem, drawing strength from its resilience. The author is making the idea clear and portraying the concept that the plant helps Saeng with obstacles, serving as a tangible link to her inner resolve and the promise of a new beginning.

In the end of the story the girl Saeng vows to herself that she will take the driver's test next year. One reason she may have vowed to herself to do that is to prove that she can pass the test and overcome her initial failure. Also the flower, after she bought it and planted it, and after she remembered all the good times she had in Vietnam, it gave her the confidence to go out and get what she wanted. This newfound confidence, sparked by the memory of her homeland, fuels her determination to try again and succeed in her new life.

The author includes this in the paragraph to simply be sarcastic for you to know that it is almost impossible for Saeng to take the test afresh. I say this because she was being very sarcastic, meaning she’s not going to take the test. For example, if someone were to tell me to take a test and I said whenever a specific, unlikely event occurs, then I’ll take the test. That would be very sarcastic, meaning that it won't happen and I’m not taking the test, instead of just saying no. The author included that just to let you know that the chances of her taking the test is very low, using the distant promise of spring to underscore her current despair and reluctance.

The author includes this paragraph in order to show an end to the story and to show that Saeng has not given up. He wanted to show how the plant and the geese represented the continuation of Saeng’s life in the United States. The geese will come back and the Hibiscus will bud and flower, and Saeng will retake and hopefully pass her driving test. This paragraph is not just a closing but a new beginning of life for the geese, a Winter Hibiscus, and Saeng, symbolizing a cyclical renewal of hope and perseverance for all of them.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show Saeng's strength and encouragement. When she’s willing and able she will take the test again with more confidence. Saeng says this to herself to help her get through until she can drive. She’s saying by next spring she’ll take her test. By next spring she’ll be able to drive. By next spring she’ll be used to her new home. This paragraph tells that it takes time to do things; you don’t always get it right away, so you must keep trying until you eventually succeed.

In my opinion the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was feeling down about not passing her driving test, but when she saw those flowers she realized that when she came to America she had begun to forget all about her home town. The sight of the resilient plant reminded her of a different pace of life. So she decided to get back in touch with a nature side and hold off taking her test until the spring instead of rushing things, allowing herself time to heal and grow more confident in her new environment before trying again. This decision marks a quiet turning point for her character.

I believe that the author concludes the story with that particular paragraph to show that she still has hope of finding home and being happy. The hibiscus plant in her mind is a powerful symbol of home and happy memories with her grandmother, representing the beauty and comfort she left behind. So when the plant buds, she will feel like she is at home again and is happy, and that is precisely when she will feel ready to take the driving test. Also, that paragraph shows that she is slowly getting accustomed to the new home and lifestyle, as seen when “A flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks dear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now, like these geese.” Through these examples I believe that the narrator put that last paragraph there, to show Saeng's gradual assimilation into her new lifestyle, and her ultimate acceptance of her situation, finding a new sense of belonging.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng did not give up on the test. For example, she firmly says, “I will take the test again.” It shows that she possesses the determination to take the test and pass it, viewing her initial failure as a temporary setback. Saeng is going to wait until spring comes and when the snow melts to take the test, using the interim to prepare herself mentally. In the beginning in the box above, it talks about her taking the test and the disappointment that followed. Then it ends with her resolve to go and take the test again, creating a narrative arc that emphasizes her perseverance and resilience in the face of challenge.

At the end of "Winter Hibiscus," the author, Minfong Ho, concludes the story through stating, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The author ends the story in such a way in order to reveal the hope that lies in Saeng's future. After failing her driver's test, Saeng returns home filled with disappointment and sadness. This last paragraph, however, shows that soon enough Saeng's luck will change as she aligns her personal growth with the renewal of nature. The reader is left with a strong hint that Saeng will retake her test and pass. Also, this ending paragraph reflects upon Saeng's determined personality to overcome the many obstacles she is facing. This paragraph proves she will not give up even after she was forced to live in the United States instead of her home. Her success in fitting in with her new life is shown through the quote, "Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become... almost familiar." Truly Saeng is a determined character who is learning to thrive in her new circumstances.

The reason the author concludes this story with the paragraph is to provide a sense of closure and forward momentum. The story is all about the girl missing her home country and struggling with feelings of alienation. This paragraph implies that the girl will have adapted to her new country by the next spring, using the changing seasons as a metaphor for her internal growth. The story and the paragraph show the girl's inner strength to overcome profound hardship and loss. This quiet demonstration of resilience and the promise of a new beginning is why the author ended the story with this particular paragraph.

The author is letting the reader know that the girl plans to do the same thing again next year when the snow is all gone, when the geese come back, and when it is warm enough for the hibiscus flower to bud and bloom again. The author may also be concluding the sentence to show that this is the life the little girl chose, and she will keep up with her new gardening endeavors until the next spring arrives, embracing the cyclical nature of her chosen path.

Saeng concluded the story with that paragraph because it shows what she has just been through and feels she could go through it again. If she fails the driving test again, then she will use the plants to overcome her problems, drawing strength from their resilience. She did not actually pass the test this time, but the unique plants show that she is stronger than she thinks. She now believes in her own strength and feels comfortable with the plants that bring back memories of her childhood, finding solace in their familiar presence.

She shows that she loves her grandmother deeply and she loves the activities they shared, like gardening and other similar traditions. Her mother also cares about her, but she is really strict with her, creating a complex dynamic within their family relationships that shapes the girl's experiences and feelings.

The author concluded the story in such a way that the reader’s eyes are opened to a profound truth. It shows the reader that despite what may happen, how bad things seem, and how hopeless you feel, there is always a way to make it better. Saeng failed her test, was in a new land, and had lost her grandmother, but she still planned to try again. Like the waves on the shore that persistently return to wash away the sand, Saeng is willing to try again and again, as should we all in the face of our own challenges.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because that particular season is over and a new season is starting, symbolizing a natural transition. This cyclical change reflects the character's own journey, suggesting an end that is also a hopeful beginning, and thus the narrative finds its fitting closure.

The author concludes the story with "when they comes back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt & the geese reture and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again". This quote underscores that once the flower buds, she will take the test over again because Saeng will have found the courage and the will to do it, knowing she will pass it. The flower represents something deeply personal to her, a symbol that gives her motivation and determination. Everyone has something that motivates them in life to keep them going, and for Saeng, it is her plant. The author provides direction and an idea of where the story is heading by connecting her personal growth to the natural cycle, suggesting that when the flower buds, a new beginning for her is also on the horizon.

Saeng is not only just disappointed from failing her driver's test, she is also upset and missing her home of Vietnam. Walking home, she spots a little piece of Vietnam right there in the United States, a familiar sight that stirs her heart. She buys the beautiful winter hibiscus, or saebba, to remind her of her past and the life she left behind. The end of this story powerfully combines the two different countries, cultures, and almost worlds her life is split between. When she says, “when they come back”, she is referring to the geese, which to her symbolize her new life in America and how she has slowly become accustomed to it. The hibiscus is also a profound symbol of her life, representing her life and past in Vietnam. It brings back a flood of memories, and buying that plant was like getting a little piece of home. When the “hibiscus is budding” then she will attempt the test again, signifying that when this little piece of home gets stronger and grows, then she will try again. When she is more stable and grounded in the American culture, yet still maintains a firm grasp of her own identity, then she will truly be ready to succeed.

I believe that the Author ended the story with this paragraph because I think it is showing that Saeng isn’t a quitter. Her vow to retake the test reveals her resilient character. Saeng can’t wait until the Hibiscus comes back, as its blooming will signal the right time for her to act. When the Hibiscus comes back she’ll retake the test with renewed confidence and show her mother that she can do it, proving her determination to overcome the setback. This ending solidifies the theme of perseverance that runs throughout the narrative.

The reason why the author concluded the story with this paragraph is because when Saeng saw the geese, she knew that when spring comes back around she would be ready to seek out different flowers, reconnecting with her past. Also, she thinks back to when she was in her homeland, where she could see the flowers grow up from the ground, a memory that brings her comfort. Although now that she is in the city, she hopes and thinks the flowers will blossom like the ones back home, a place she misses a lot. Lastly, she describes the flowers as her friends, a testament to their deep personal significance. She also remembers the “Madagascar periwinkle” growing wild out from the cracks in brick walls or tiled roofs, a resilient image from her childhood. Basically, the author indicates that she is ready to look for other plants that she remembers from her homeland, using them as anchors in her new life. This search represents her ongoing journey of adaptation and memory.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with this paragraph to depict a significant development in the character of Saeng. At the beginning of the story, Saeng is dejected about failing her driver’s test, feeling defeated. However, this ending paragraph portrays the hopeful change that Saeng undergoes, moving from despair to determination. In the text, Saeng proves to not adapt well to the change from Vietnam to America initially, struggling with the transition. She finds solace and a connection to her past in a native flower of Vietnam, a winter hibiscus. By mentioning the winter hibiscus in the concluding paragraph (“…and this hibiscus is budding…”), the author depicts Saeng’s change of attitude and her growing acceptance toward America. Saeng now feels that, like the hibiscus returning after winter is over, she will be able to return and pass the driver’s test with newfound strength. Also, the concluding paragraph depicts Saeng’s new adaptation towards the creatures of America. Prior to her immersion in the new environment, Saeng had little exposure to Canada geese. In the concluding statement, Saeng’s mentioning of the creatures displays her adaptation to America (“…when the snow melts and the geese return…”). This shows Saeng’s development and adaptation to her new surroundings, recognizing the rhythms of her new home. At first, Saeng proved to have a hard time leaving her native Vietnam behind and embracing American culture. However, this concluding paragraph summarizes the noticeable and positive change that Saeng goes through, finding a way to blend her past with her present. In this way, the author includes this paragraph to note the complete development in character that Saeng undergoes, ending her journey on a note of promise.

They conclude the story with that because the winter is over and spring is here and it will be beautiful again. The harshness of the cold season has passed, giving way to a time of renewal and growth. This cyclical change in nature mirrors the emotional shift for the characters, suggesting that after a period of difficulty, a more hopeful and pleasant time is beginning. The beauty of the spring season symbolizes this positive turn, providing a fitting end to their story.

The author concludes the story with, “when they com back, saeng  vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding. Then I will take that test again.” This shows her determination to try once more. For example, the author says, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many things that she had thought of as strange before had become , through the quiet repetition of season upon season almost familiar to her now.” That tells me that she feels that over same time , she will become more familiar with driving and then she will take the test again. The passage of time and continued exposure will increase her comfort and skill. Then she will pass it, achieving the goal that once seemed so difficult.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” decided to conclude the story in that way because she wanted to tie in the theme of new beginnings. Saeng is new to the country and has had a rough time fitting in. She misses everything about her old home, from her grandmother to the old plants there. Saeng fails her driving test, so she feels that all is lost. But the hibiscus plant helped her realize she has another chance. The hibiscus can survive the winter and bloom in the spring and that is what Saeng realizes she must do. The last paragraph said “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Spring is the time for new beginnings: the geese return from the south, the flowers start to bloom, and Saeng can retake the driving test. In the last paragraph, Saeng realizes she wants a new beginning as well to be brought in the spring. This connection between the natural world and her personal resolve strengthens the story's message. In conclusion, the last paragraph ties the theme of new beginnings into the story. It shows Saeng's new realization and how the hibiscus inspired it.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that Saeng really wants to pass the test. You knows this when it says “And in the warm moist shelter of the green house, saeng broke down and wept.” This passage shows that she didn’t want to fail and that the failure affected her deeply. When Saeng got home she had the white bud in the pot and her mother seen that she was crying. Then her mother was going to put the plant in the ground, then saeng to the shovel and did it he self. This act of planting the hibiscus herself is a turning point, representing her taking control of her own situation. Having her realize she can take it again provides a sense of hope and agency for the future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. First, when the hibiscus buds in the spring that means that the plant is about to bloom, signaling a new phase of life. That also means that Saeng will be ready in the spring to take the test again, having used the winter to prepare herself. Also the last paragraph is at the end because if the plant can make it, then the girl can pass her drivers test and be happy both ways. The parallel between the resilient plant and Saeng's own potential for success creates a powerful and optimistic closing image for the reader.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author is saying it's going to be a great year or some change is going to happen. The character feels that they could have done better than what they did and is therefore going to take that test again. This decision highlights a resolve to improve and a belief in future success, framing the ending as one of hope and determination rather than finality.

The author concludes with this paragraph to emphasize the new beginning that Saeng is looking for. She was so disappointed when she failed her driver's test, and the hibiscus was the thing to make her happy. She needed a new beginning to start over in a new country, and the flower, the snow, the geese, and the test all symbolize new beginnings and challenges to overcome. The geese and snow represent a change in season, the budding hibiscus represents new life, and the passing of the test represents a milestone in Saeng's life. Ending the story with this paragraph makes the reader expect something new and exciting to happen to Saeng, effectively tying all the symbolic elements together into a cohesive message of hope.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to explain to the reader that she isn't done gardening, that she’ll go back when it blooms once again. This shows that she is not finished with this important part of her life; she’d rather garden than go to school, indicating where her true passions and priorities lie. This is what the author concludes about the story with the last paragraph, using the cyclical nature of the garden to suggest a personal commitment that extends beyond the story's end.

The author concludes this story with the few words “then I will take that test again” because she wanted us to know that she is not going to give up on something she failed once. She is going to keep going until she succeeds with passing “the test.” This final statement serves as a powerful declaration of persistence, turning a moment of failure into a stepping stone for future attempts and ultimate achievement.

The author concludes the last paragraph of the story because she already knew that she should not be afraid of trying a new life or new environment. For example, in the story, the mother says, “Its flowers aren't pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months. Here, this winter hibiscus.” It shows that the mother wants Saeng to learn that she should be strong even in times of difficulty. Another example is when the narrator says, “she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season…” It shows that Saeng realized that the new place that she's living in right now is almost the same as their old home. In conclusion, the last paragraph tells that Saeng should face the new reality of the world, learning to be strong and to follow the natural flow of life as it unfolds around her.

The author concluded this story for an internal adjustment, focusing on Saeng's emotional state. Saeng's memories and inner feelings are expressed through the one at the hibiscus, which serves as a focal point for her reflections. The spring is a season where everything is fresh and new, representing renewal. As signaled by spring, Saeng's hope would be restored and thriving, just as the budding hibiscus blooms. She will have the ability to try at the test again with more strength and inspiration, ready to face her challenges anew.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with Saeng, the main character, vowing to attempt the driving test in the spring when the hibiscus is blooming. This is a way of showing the reader that even after this story ends, Saeng will not give up on her goals. The author adds the thought of the hibiscus in bloom because the hibiscus is a symbol of strength and resilience for Saeng. The hibiscus flower is common in her home country, and the hibiscus she bought reminds her of everything she left behind when she came to the United States from Vietnam. Saeng is trying to accept her new life style and uses the hibiscus as a tool to help her through the tougher times, drawing comfort from its presence. After Saeng buys the flower she vows to retake the failed drivers test after spring comes, seeing it as a new beginning. Spring is a symbol of fresh start and rebirth. Saeng also feels that if the hibiscus can make it through the winter in this new country, so can she, finding strength in its survival. The conclusion for this story uses a lot of imagery that suggest that Saeng will be strong and continue to live in her new home, building a future there.

The reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is because Saeng fails the test and makes her learned to appreciate nature a little better. This experience teaches her an important lesson about resilience and finding solace in the natural world around her. The failure becomes a turning point, leading her to a deeper understanding and a renewed sense of purpose as she moves forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng will return to the flowers again in the spring, finding in them a source of hope and continuity. This cyclical return to nature signifies her enduring connection to life and growth, promising a future where she will try again with renewed spirit and determination.

The author states that idea because if you cannot do it once, you should do it again. First, if you take a test and cannot pass it the first time, you should try again and you will likely be able to pass with persistence. For example, in the story Saeng could not pass a test so they could have let her take it again to see if she can pass it on a subsequent attempt. Second, she could ask for help or use a book and study to improve her chances. For example, it will help you pass a lot easier if you study hard enough and prepare thoroughly. That is what I think the statement means, emphasizing the value of perseverance and dedicated effort.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph because its how each year will begin and end, creating a natural and reassuring sense of continuity. This cyclical pattern mirrors the protagonist's own journey, suggesting that endings are always followed by new beginnings. The paragraph reinforces the idea that life moves in predictable, comforting cycles, just as the seasons reliably turn. It provides a sense of closure by looking forward to the future, ensuring the story does not end on a static note but with the promise of renewal. This final thought leaves the reader with a feeling of hope and the understanding that time moves forward in a steady, repeating rhythm.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph, because the author wants to express to the reader that Saeng has been comforted by the hibiscus and is willing to give the test another try. She is now more open minded about the situation. In the beginning of the story, Saeng was upset and annoyed about failing her driver’s test. For example, “the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. I-I failed the test,” Saeng said to her mother. Obviously she was upset and disappointed in herself. The author didn’t want to end the story with a sad, unsatisfying ending. Saeng changes her attitude about the test by the end of the story. For example, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” I believe that this attitude was because of the memories of her mother country that soothes her and also her mother, whose quiet support helped her find inner peace. The hibiscus plant serves as a tangible link to her past, providing the strength she needs to face her future challenges. In conclusion the author ended the story with that to teach the reader a lesson to let change occur and time does heal, emphasizing resilience and the power of comforting memories.

The author of the story “Winter Hibiscus" concludes the story with the motivational paragraph because he/she wants to show the reader that Saeng is determined to adapt to her new life and home and overcome common obstacles like a driver's test. Saeng had a hard time coping with her problem so she bought a hibiscus because it reminded her of home, providing a sense of familiarity and comfort in a foreign land. I think that the line “and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." from the last paragraph is a symbol for growing up and overcoming obstacles, representing her personal growth and newfound resolve. The conclusion for the story is a nice ending because it shows Saeng’s transformation from despair to hopeful determination, leaving the reader with a positive and uplifting feeling about her future prospects.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph, because when the snow melts and the geese return, she going to have higher confidence in taking and passing the test. After she failed the test later on in the story the geese had flew away, symbolizing the departure of her initial confidence and hope. So when the geese return the geese will remind her of what had just now happened, but also of the cyclical nature of life and the chance for a new start. When the snow melts and spring comes the hibiscus flower will bloom once again, mirroring her own reawakening determination and inner strength. This natural cycle gives her a specific, hopeful timeframe to prepare herself mentally for the challenge ahead, turning a moment of failure into a promise for the future.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” in the spring come back the new hopes, comfort, and belief. As she said in the story “in the spring when the snows melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” She feels when the hibiscus comes back it brings new hopes to her life to take that test for. Here the hibiscus means hope. Second of all when she said “the geese return and this hibiscus is budding” she means that is comfort for her; it is stronger than hope and more so if her mom helps her believe in herself because it is not easy to do it without her mom's comfort. Lastly she said “Canada geese flew by, their faint honks dear and yes familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly she realized that many of the thing that she had thought of as strange before had became, through the quiet repetitions of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” She means that as the season is coming and the hibiscus grows she will regain the belief and the strength that she needs to have to take the test. The hibiscus means a lot to her; it means new hopes, comfort, and belief, all of which combine to give her the courage to try again.

Coming back from failing her driving test, Saeng is comforted by finding the hibiscus flower. It brings back cherished memories about Saeng's homeland, because it is very similar to the vibrant flowers that grew by her old home. The author concluded the story by saying "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to compare Saeng to the hibiscus. Like Saeng, the hibiscus must try to adapt to new surroundings and endure a difficult period before it can bloom again. The author shows that Saeng recognizes this deep connection and is inspired by it. In Saeng's mind, if the resilient hibiscus can survive being moved to a new and colder climate, then so can she, finding the strength to try once more.

The story of “Winter Hibiscus” is a prolonged metaphor for both connections to a comforting past as well as expectance and the future. Saeng misses her homeland but she must learn to adapt to her new circumstances, and pass her drivers test to succeed in this new life. The story is nicely concluded with Saeng's promise to herself that come spring, she will take the test again. The hibiscus flower itself generates this promise as it gives her some closure and alleviates some home-sickness by serving as a tangible link to her past. Saeng’s promise indicates that she is coming to terms with her situation and is ready to face the future. When she sees the Canada geese flying, she has somewhat of an epiphany about the seasons and the natural cycles of change. “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become.. - Almost familiar to her now.” I feel that was a landmark realization for Saeng and the conclusion illustrates that by showing she allows herself to change and grow.

In “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, Saeng has a deep emotional connection to the memories and flashbacks that the Hibiscus brings back to her. At one point in the story, she cries out of mourning for her grandmother because the hibiscus plants bring back a wave of powerful memories from her old life. Later on in the story, she takes the plant home to her mother. At first her mother is upset by the purchase but then she becomes understanding of her daughter’s actions and feelings, recognizing the plant's significance. Saeng is upset that she didn’t pass her test and her mother understands that disappointment. I think the author ends the story this way because she wants the reader to see that because the hibiscus is so important to Saeng and reminds her of her past and her grandmother's strength, she will have a reason and motivation to continue and reach her goal of passing her driving test.

Since it is getting close to winter the geese are going south and the natural world is preparing for a period of dormancy. The plants are losing their leaves, and the landscape is becoming barren. Saeng says that she will take the test again, but she ties this resolution to the return of spring. It seems that when the geese return and the hibiscus buds it will give her hope and confidence, signaling a new beginning. Especially the hibiscus because it reminds her of her homeland and her grandmother; when she first saw it and held the leaf it brought a tear to her eye, overwhelmed by the memory. And when it comes back next year it will rejuvenate her spirit and provide the courage she needs to persevere.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she thinks that it will explain what happened to Saeng very well, capturing her internal transformation and newfound resolve. The final vow Saeng makes to herself perfectly encapsulates her journey from disappointment to determination, using the natural symbolism of the changing seasons and the resilient hibiscus to illustrate her personal growth. This conclusion effectively ties together the story's central themes of adaptation, memory, and hope, providing a satisfying and meaningful end to Saeng's emotional arc.

The author concludes her story with that last paragraph because it shows the deep relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus, and how much just seeing it feels meaningful to her. It also shows that the hibiscus motivates her because it reminds her of her home land that she loves so much and that its like have a physical memory of her homeland, providing her with a tangible connection to her past and a source of inner strength.

The author is relating to that when the geese are ready, they will come back, and when the flower is ready it will begin to bud and grow. When she is ready she will take the test, is what is being said. She is explaining that she needs time just as the geese and flowers do as well, emphasizing a natural process of growth and preparation. So you can compare Saeng to both the geese and hibiscus, because they too need time in a way for when they are ready to do what they do. In a way Saeng has molded as one with both objects, finding her own rhythm within the cycles of nature.

I think the Author ends this as the concluding sentence because it symbolizes how the girl perceives things. The girl means when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding it means that it is going to be warm again, and this means when it is warm again it brings her spirit up because it reminds her of her homeland. I think by her being reminded of her homeland would help her take the test easier because she will be more happy, and this positive feeling I think will help her do better on the test. For example, the author said in the story that the flower bring her comfort, and I think being comfortable is the best way to succeed and pass the test. In conclusion I think the author ends the story like that because he wanted the readers to understand a connection with the girl and her homeland, and how the flower comforts her, ultimately highlighting the power of emotional solace.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it sounds like an interesting ending paragraph that has something significant to do with the story's themes. It serves to encapsulate the emotional journey of the character, providing a final reflection that resonates with the narrative's core about memory and belonging, thereby giving the story a sense of thoughtful closure.

I think the author concludes the story with that saying because it shows that she is adapting to the new place. It also shows that she isn't going to give up, demonstrating her resilience. Just like the geese don't give up flying back and forth every winter and spring, she too will persist through her own challenges and seasons of change, finding her way in a new environment.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng decides to retake her failed driver’s test in the spring. She does so because she is comforted by the moderate weather of the season, which stands in stark contrast to the harsh winter. The gentle warmth and the budding life around her remind her of her old home, a place to which Saeng remains very closely attached. This connection to her past through the familiar feeling of spring gives her the courage to try again. It reminds me of all the places I’ve been and how I still vividly remember my favorite one. Like Saeng, I often buy objects that remind me of my old home, seeking that same comfort. Saeng’s deep commitment to her old home and her way of coping actually makes me feel less different and alone when I find myself missing my own old home, showing a shared human experience.

The author concludes the story with that particular paragraph because it powerfully encapsulates Saeng's resolve to start over and do better the second time around. Having just failed her driver's test, she is determined not to disappoint herself again. This final vow represents a turning point from her initial failure to a state of hopeful determination. The paragraph serves as a fitting end because it highlights her internal promise and newfound motivation. Therefore, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to leave the reader with a sense of Saeng's personal commitment and her decision to face the challenge anew.

I think that the author concludes the story like this because it effectively shows a new beginning for Saeng. When the spring comes, everything in nature comes back to life; plants grow back, animals are seen again, and the sun shines bright. This cyclical renewal is a metaphor for her own life, as it can be seen the same for her. She could try again because the season gives her another chance, mirroring the rebirth occurring around her. Another reason he ended the story like this is because Saeng clearly loves nature, as shown by her connection to the hibiscus. Perhaps when nature is back around her in full bloom, it will give her the necessary hope and confidence to finally pass her test, completing this theme of a fresh start.

The last paragraph of the story was: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I think the author concluded the story with that paragraph to show that she is adapting to her new life and that she is starting to accept the change. I think that because throughout the story she is upset and not really liking the change, as evidenced when the text says, “And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” This last paragraph, in contrast, seems optimistic, talking about the flower blooming and the geese returning, which seems like she is finally starting to accept the change and look forward. In my opinion, the author added that paragraph to finish the story to show that Saeng is starting to accept the change and be optimistic about her future.

After failing her driver's test, Saeng told her mother the disappointing news. Feeling she needed to make up for it in some way, she offered to help out in the garden, perhaps seeking a familiar and comforting task. Her mother ushered her inside and, without further discussion, started to make dinner, providing a quiet and supportive presence. This simple domestic moment underscores the understanding and non-judgmental support within their relationship, allowing Saeng to process her failure in a safe space before eventually finding her own resolve to try again.

The author concludes that, when the geese come back she will take the test because she believes she will be more ready for the test then it will be easier in the spring. This will give her more time to learn and study and hopefully her head will be more focused instead of thinking about her home, which makes it easier to complete the driver's test in spring. She feels bad, like she let her mother down for failing it, and the line “I just stared at the hibiscus,” tells that she felt too ashamed to even look at her mother. So next spring she wants to make her mom happy and pass because she will be ready and more confident, having put her homesickness behind her.

The reason the author chose this paragraph is because the paragraph means that when the snow melts and all the geese returned, the flowers would bloom again. That one flower she had to study for her tests on represents a new beginning and a fresh chance to succeed, connecting the natural cycle of the seasons to her own personal goals and academic efforts.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph she did to tell people never to give up. She tells people never to give up through this method because she realizes at the end, she will be prepared and capable. In the story the line “.. Slowly fading into the distance.” could mean she realizes what happens; happens and you should never stop doing or going for a goal you want. One more reason she might have used this is, that even though you are down you have friends and family to pick you up from it. The line “.. Through the quiet repetition of season upon season.” basically said that she just needed to get into a routine and she will be able to do it, finding strength and consistency in the predictable patterns of life.

The author concludes the story with this sentence because she wanted to make a comparison between flowers and the test. To finish with this shows she will try season after season just like geese come back every year. Since she tries to make a connection, it shows she hasn’t given up and she will keep trying year after year. Also, it says that this girl is determined and she won’t stop trying till she gets it right. Next, this last paragraph can tell you about the whole story and its themes of perseverance. Lastly, I think it gives a feeling for the whole story, leaving the reader with a sense of hope and ongoing effort.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph so the reader has something to think about. When the author concludes with something like that he/she wants the reader to make their own ending or prediction, engaging them with the narrative beyond the final page. And sometimes it means a sequel is possible, inviting further contemplation of the characters and their future journeys, which makes the story's impact last longer.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it makes the story a happy ending, showing how she doesn’t give up and is taking the test again. Her determination is fueled by a desire not to disappoint her mom; she wants to make her happy and is therefore giving the test a second chance, demonstrating her resilience and commitment to overcoming the challenge she faces.

She ends it with that statement to show that she is ready to relive spring in the new country now that she is comforted by the hibiscus. The test is adapting to the new country and she failed it, she believes, because she had to be comforted by her native plants. However, she believes that she will pass the test next year because every repetition of the season allows her to become more adapted to the new culture. When she says “when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again,” all those natural signs tell her it’s a new year, which makes it easier to accept what is happening and find the strength to try once more.

She realized that things come and go but also change, that during certain times of the year the world around her changed and she had no control over it. She also had to deal with living in a new country, which was hard for Saeng. She had to eat new foods, hear new sounds, and see things that she never had seen before. Failing her driver's test was particularly hard for her. Not knowing the language and what was going on around her was tough on her, as the world around her wasn't something she was used to. She knew she had to change herself and work harder to get what she wanted, accepting the necessity of her own personal growth.

The author ended the story with that paragraph to let the readers know that she did not give up. In the story, it seemed like she had thoughts of giving up, but her memories of her homeland comforted her during those moments when she thought she was going to surrender. The last paragraph of the story confirmed that she wasn't giving up, solidifying the theme of perseverance and providing a definitive and hopeful resolution to her internal struggle.

I think the author concludes this story like this because the flower was beautiful and gave her good luck, because the first time around she didn't know they were there. This newfound awareness of the flower's presence provides her with a sense of comfort and a symbolic token of hope, suggesting that with this knowledge, her next attempt will be met with greater fortune and a more positive outcome.

To me it seems like whoever was saying that must have been going through a lot of things and that they were feeling like they were being tested or something. Perhaps somebody she really loved had left her, because it says "when they come back," so I am thinking somebody must have left or something. The reason I said that the person must have felt as if they were being tested is because it directly states, "I will take the test again." This feeling of being repeatedly challenged by circumstances is central to understanding the speaker's emotional state, suggesting a cycle of hardship and resilience that defines their current experience.

The author concludes the story with this because it shows that she is still uncomfortable in her new environment. A clear example is when she broke down in the flower shop, overwhelmed by memories that were not quite the same as being home. This shows that even though certain things can remind her of home, the feeling is not identical and the place itself is different. You have to get used to and become accustomed to a new place, which is a difficult and ongoing process. This also shows that she thinks with more time to get used to her new home, she will eventually be able to pass the test and find her footing, concluding the thought on a note of cautious optimism.

The author uses this conclusion for a specific reason. The reason the author employs this cliff-hanger of a conclusion is to keep the reader interested and wanting more from the narrative. By having the character say, "I will take that test again," the author makes the reader question if Saeng will pass the test next time and the reader will naturally wonder what exactly "the test" entails, creating a lingering sense of curiosity about the character's future and the symbolic meaning of the challenge she faces.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because she probably doesn't want the snow to melt so that the geese wouldn't return and disrupt the fragile peace of the moment. Also, I think it aims to inform the reader about what Saeng was thinking internally, providing a final glimpse into her contemplative state of mind as she reflects on her surroundings and her own feelings, thereby offering a quiet and introspective end to her story.

There was a specific reason as to why the author concluded the story with that quote. The author wanted to show how the plant gave Saeng a new sense of determination and hope for her own situation. Saeng was previously upset and was even tearing the plant apart in her frustration. But it seemed that she realized how the plant was able to bud against the odds and survive its harsh conditions. So she now was determined to battle the odds as well, internalizing the plant's resilience, and retake the test she had previously failed, thus ending her arc with a renewed commitment to persevere.
